heading: Resignation of Board members
HeadNote.description:
Resignation of Board members - Acceptance and consideration of - Appropriate authority and procedure, stated along with interpretation of S.67(4) of Goa Co-operative Societies Act.

	Section 67(4) Goa Co-operative Societies Act deals with several eventualities. Firstly, it provides that the members of the Board may resign by addressing their resignations to the Chairman. Secondly, it provides that the Chairman may resign by addressing his resignation to the Chief Executive Officer. Thirdly, there is a requirement for placement of the resignations in the meeting of the Board for consideration and acceptance. Fourthly, Section 67(4) provides that where resignation of an office bearer is accepted, the election of the new office bearer shall be done in accordance with the provision of the bye-laws of the society. Fifthly, it is provided that in the event the resignation is from majority of the members of the Board, including the Chairman or otherwise, such resignations shall be handed over to the Chief Executive Officer, who shall forward the same to the Registrar. Sixthly and finally, it is provided that the Registrar, after receiving the resignations from the majority of the members of the Board, shall assess the situation and decide the course of action in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

	There is really nothing in the provision which suggests that the resignations tendered by members require no acceptance for taking effect and only resignations tendered by the office bearers require acceptance for them to be effective. The provision only makes a distinction between the members, which will include all office bearers (except Chairman) on one hand and the Chairman on the other, for the purposes of specifying the authority, to whom the resignations may be addressed and nothing further. The members of the Board, which will include the office bearers (except Chairman) may address their resignations to the Chairman. Since the Chairman cannot be address his resignation to himself, a provision is made to enable the Chairman to address his resignation to the Chief Executive Officer. However, upon harmonious construction of the provisions, it does appear that the resignations, whether of members including office bearers (except Chairman) or of the Chairman, are required to be placed in the meeting of the Board 'for consideration and acceptance.' Thus, the expression 'for consideration and acceptance' applies to both the resignations of members including office bearers (except Chairman) and resignation of the Chairman.

	Section 67(4), in its first and second part, merely provides for the authorities to whom the resignations are required to be addressed. However, the said provisions cannot be interpreted to mean that the authorities to whom the resignations are to be addressed, are authorities, who have been vested with the powers to accept the resignations. For example, the Chairman may resign by addressing his resignation to the Chief Executive Officer. However, the Chief Executive Officer is not the authority vested with the power to accept the resignation of the Chairman. The resignation has to be placed in the meeting of the Board for consideration and acceptance. By the same logic, therefore, it cannot be said that because the members, which will include, office bearers (except Chairman) may address their resignation to the Chairman, the Chairman is the authority vested with the power to accept such resignations or that there is no acceptance of such resignations even contemplated by the provisions in Section 67(4) of the said Act.

	Section 67(4) of the said Act makes a distinction between the resignations submitted by minority of the members of the Board and majority of the members of the Board, including the Chairman or otherwise. This is evident from the fifth and sixth part of Section 67(4) of the said Act. In the event the resignation is from majority of the members of the Board, including the Chairman or otherwise, such resignations have to be handed over to the Chief Executive Officer, who shall forward the same to the Registrar. The Registrar, upon receiving the resignations from the majority of the members of the Board, shall assess the situation and shall decide the course of action in accordance with the provisions of the Act. This portion of Section 67(4) makes no distinction between the resignations of office bearers on one hand and resignations of members on the other. Both the sets of resignations have been treated on the same plane. This portion, thus, does not make any distinction between resignations of members on one hand and the resignation of the Chairman on the other. Even these two sets of resignations have been treated on the same plane in fifth and sixth part of Section 67(4).

	The distinction is broadly between the resignations from minority of the members of the Board and majority of the members of the Board. In the later eventuality, the resignations, whether addressed to the Chairman or to the Chief Executive Officer, have to be "handed over" to the Chief Executive Officer, who shall forward the same to the Registrar. Thereafter, it is for the Registrar to assess the situation and to decide the course of action in accordance with the provisions of the Act. The purpose of treating the resignations from majority of the members of the Board separately is quite obvious. In such a situation, the Registrar will have to take a call and decide the course of action in accordance with the provisions of the Act. Several options as contemplated under the Act, are available to the Registrar. The Legislature deemed it appropriate to leave the matter to the Registrar where the very governance of the society may be at stake on account of resignations from the majority of the members of the Board. 				 [Para 31,33,37,39,40]

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: No confidence motion against Chairman of Society - Challenge - On ground that majority members who voted out petitioner on 2/9/2016, have already tendered their resignations on 19/5/2016, therefore ceased to be members and cannot vote - Whereas, on 19/5/2016 special meeting was called to consider no confidence motion against petitioner - But same could not be proceeded due to erroneous interpretation of a decision of Apex Court that such motion could not be moved within a period of 2 years of Chairman assuming office - Respondent Board members protested against the same and purported their resignations to petitioner - However, same withdrawn on 26/5/2016 - Petitioner despite being bound by provisions of S.67(4) to hand over their resignations to Chief Executive Officer, did not take any action till 31/5/2016 when the resignations were already withdrawn - In such circumstances, resolution by which no confidence motion was passed, cannot be set aside - Petition dismissed. 		(Paras 6, 7, 44)

heading: Election dispute
HeadNote.description: Election dispute - Delay of 9 days in approaching Tribunal - No application made for condonation of delay - Explanation given that respondent was pursuing remedy before writ court, diligently and bonafidely - Writ Court granted liberty to respondent to file suit before appropriate Tribunal within one week - Respondent instituted proceedings within said time limit - Thus, sufficient cause shown for delay - Jurisdiction of Co-operative Tribunal depends upon sufficient cause and not upon condonation application - Hence, in absence of condonation application, it cannot be said that Tribunal lacks jurisdiction to condone delay. 2010 ALL SCR 961 Disting. 2007(3) Bom.CR 496, (1996) 6 SCC 199 Ref. to. 	(Paras 16, 17, 19)

heading: Locus
HeadNote.description: Order of Registrar u/S.67A of Goa Co-operative Societies Act - Challenge by existing Director in writ petition - Locus - By impugned order, two Directors suo motu appointed by Registrar on vacant seats in Board of Directors of a Bank - Grievance of petitioner is that wrong persons were appointed - Petitioner himself is on Board of Directors and directly interested in functioning of Bank - He will have to participate in daily affairs of Bank with such newly appointed persons - Petitioner has locus. 		(Para 15)

heading: Appointment of Directors
Not unguided
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Directors - Powers of Registrar u/S.67A of Goa Co-operative Societies Act - Not unguided - There are various inbuilt safeguards - Registrar cannot appoint any person of his choice from membership of society - He has to publish a notice inviting objections and consider same - Only as exception, when immediate action is required, such notice can be dispensed with - Even for such dispensation, cogent reasons must exist.

	The power conferred on the Registrar under Section 67A is not for gaining control of the co-operatives, but to take such steps as may be necessary in the larger interest of the co-operatives and the members. Upon examination of Section 67A of the Act, it cannot be said that it confers unchecked and unguided arbitrary power on the Registrar. The scheme of Section 67A shows that there are various inbuilt safeguards on the exercise of the power, so that it does not result into an arbitrary exercise. Section 67A(1) opens with the words "where the Registrar is satisfied". The satisfaction of the Registrar has to be well informed, rational, transparent and fair. If the Registrar is satisfied that the new Board cannot be constituted he may suo motu or on an application appoint any member or members. However, the Registrar, cannot straight away proceed to appoint any person of his choice from the membership of the society. He has to publish a notice inviting objections and suggestions to the proposed order and consider all the objections and suggestions. This helps him to arrive at an informed decision. In the process, the Registrar also gives an opportunity to all the members of the Society to be part of the decision making. This is the most crucial aspect of the power under Section 67A. This safety valve ensures that the exercise is transparent, prudent and in interest of the cooperatives. The Legislature has however visualized a contingency where there is a need for speed in taking immediate corrective measures. There could be situations where it is not reasonably practicable to publish such a notice and the second proviso permits dispensation of notice. However, dispensing with notice has to be an exception, not a rule. The requirement of issuance of notice before issuance of an order is a crucial component of the scheme of Section 67A. Merely because the Legislature has provided for a rare eventuality, where safeguard can be departed from, does not mean that the safeguard can be dispensed with at will. Cogent reasons must exist for doing so.	 [Para 29]

	Thus, there are safeguards in Section 67A of the Act of 2001 to ensure that it does not empower the Registrar with unguided, arbitrary or draconic powers. It is mandatory to call for objections and suggestions in respect of the proposed order, except where there is an immediate action required or that it is not reasonably practicable to issue such a notice. Keeping in mind the principles of democratic governance of the co-operatives, the proviso relating to dispensation of notice will have to be strictly construed. The grounds mentioned in the second proviso must genuinely exist and cannot be a mere ipsi dixit of the authority or that the grounds are artificially created. The order under section 67A must be a speaking order, so that there is transparency and good governance in the exercise of powers by the Registrar.

1983 ALLMR ONLINE 240, (1992) Mh.L.J. 1118 Ref.to.	 [Para 31]

heading: Justification
HeadNote.description: Suo motu appointment of Directors - Without notice inviting objections - Justification - As per bye-laws of Bank, 11 members required to constitute Board of Directors - First justification given in impugned order was, failure of Bank to elect 2 Directors - However, there is a bye-law as per which half of strength of Board will suffice to form quorum - Even in absence of 2, functioning of Bank could continue - Second reason was non-receipt of any application from members - Just because no application made, it does not mean there was lack of interest - Other reasons were adjournment of related writ petition and time restraint to fill up vacancies - Even this factor does not constitute grave urgency - No direction from Court to dispense with any procedure u/S.67A - Not a case that functioning of Bank had come to a standstill - Impugned order is bereft of any application of mind - Even otherwise, persons so appointed were disqualified u/S.60 - Impugned order set aside - Directions issued for free and fair election for said two posts. 1984 ALLMR ONLINE 368 (S.C.) Disting. 		(Paras 36, 37, 38, 39, 41, 48, 52, 54, 55)

heading: Suo motu appointment by Registrar
HeadNote.description: Suo motu appointment by Registrar - From members disqualified to be Directors u/S.60 of Goa Co-operative Societies Act - Contention raised that u/S.67A, Registrar has power to appoint "any person" - However, disqualified persons u/S.60 include defaulters, persons running same business etc. - Appointment of such persons would be detrimental to interest of Society - Besides, Legislature has knowingly placed S.67A by Amendment after S.60 - When it meant any member, it can only be a member who has passed stage of S.60 - Registrar has no power to appoint disqualified persons. 1986 ALLMR ONLINE 43 Ref. to.			(Paras 43, 44, 45, 46)

heading: Public Authority
Scope of definition
HeadNote.description: Public Authority - Scope of definition - Information sought from petitioner/Co-operative Societies - Petitioners receiving no financial assistance from Govt. - Though it had obtained Govt. lease to carry on its business, said lease cannot be construed as Govt. control or funding - Petitioners not falling within purview of "Public Authority" - However, its financial information being accessible to Registrar and available in public domain in terms of Co-operative Societies Act, such information can be supplied by Registrar. 2011(5) ALL MR 69, 2014(1) ALL MR 451 (S.C.), AIR 2012 Ker 124 Ref. to. 			(Paras 15, 16, 29)

heading: Election
Rejection of nomination
Writ Petition against
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Election - Rejection of nomination - Writ Petition against - Maintainability - Statutory remedy available u/S.83 of Goa Co-operative Societies Act to challenge the election and all related aspects - Therefore, writ petition held not maintainable - Interim relief however granted that no further action shall be taken by respondents on basis of subject notification under R.74 of the Rules 2003 - Petitioners granted liberty to invoke appropriate remedy before Tribunal. 	(Paras 3, 6, 8, 9)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.227 - Election - Rejection of nomination paper - Returning Officer, rejected nomination paper of respondent in summary manner, without making any inquiry what so ever and relying entirely on objections raised - And without recording any reasons - Setting aside of, by Tribunal - No perversity either in factual findings or in reasoning - Cannot be interfered with under Art.227 of Constitution.			(Paras 25, 28)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description: Election - To Board of Directors of Goa State Co-operative Milk Producers Union - Rejection of nomination by Returning Officer - On ground of non-compliance with by-law which requires authorization by society to be accompanied by declaration that no other member is representing society on Board - However, said by-law is applicable only in case of by-elections and not general election - Even otherwise, such requirement is not of substantial character - In terms of Rule 69(4), nomination cannot be rejected if defect is not of substantial character - Order of Returning Officer was based on mere technicality - Tribunal justified in setting it aside. AIR 1984 SC 192 Ref. to. 	(Paras 33, 34, 35, 36, 38, 39)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa College of Pharmacy Group 'A' Gazetted Post Recruitment Rules (1988)
heading: Method of promotion
HeadNote.description:
Method of promotion - Promotion should be viewed in the circumstances when vacancy arose and not at the time of making selection.

Constitution of India, Arts.310 and 311.

Case of promotion - Principles to be applied.

In examining the right of a candidate for promotion, the most important point to be considered is whether on the date on which the vacancy arose, he was eligible for promotion. Thus, where on the date when the vacancy of the post of Lecturer arose, the petitioner Demonstrator did not have five years experience, as laid down by the Rules, he was not eligible for promotion. Principles laid down for direct recruitment cannot be made applicable in the case of promotion. 1993 Supp (3) SCC 611 Disting.  [Para 2]

heading: Rejection of plaint
Legality
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Bar of S.50 of Goa Command Area Development Act - Legality - Suit filed against illegal tender process, alleging several irregularities in auction - Held, merely relying on bar, without examining pleading in plaint as to whether ground that action complained is nullity, being taken in bad faith or fraud, is improper - Impugned order is quashed - Application u/O.7 R.11 is restored back.	(Paras 13, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu (Extension of Indian Easements) Act (1978)
heading: Easementary right
HeadNote.description:
Easementary right - Art 2309 of Portuguese Civil Code does not stand repealed by extension Act. 

(X-Ref) Portuguese Civil Code Art.2309. (Para 10)

heading: Mining concessions
HeadNote.description:
Mining concessions - Application filed in 1962 prior to application of Mines and Minerals Act, to Goa - Notices issued and some other proceeding taken - Held, on facts no vested right accrued which was saved under S.4.

The Petitioners father sought mining concessions in the year 1962. The claim of concessions was transferred in the name of the petitioner. The Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act came to be applied to State of Goa on 1-10-1963. Right upto the time that Goa came to be liberated forming the Union Territory alongwith Daman and Diu, on or about 19th December, 1961, it was under Portuguese rule. On and from that date till 5th March, 1962, there remained what is known as interregnum, during which the Portuguese laws were not applying at all. Afterwards, some of the laws did govern the rights of the parties in the Territory and possibly, the laws relating to mines and decrees passed by the Portuguese Government from time-to-time were holding the field till Mines and Mineral Act came to be applied on and from 1st October, 1963. The Application for mining concession was made on 2-2-1962. all the fees came to be paid on 1-2-1963 prior to application of Mines and Minerals Act was applicable to State of Goa. The application was filed during interregnum what followed was nothing else but different stages at which the State authorities as well as the petitioner were required to do something under the Mining Laws.

Held, that the petitioner had no accrued right for mining concession saved by S.4(2) of the Regulation.  [Para 14,19,20]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Injunction against tenant
Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Injunction against tenant - Restraint on starting a new business - Sustainability - Premises let out to be used for paint business - Tenant changed the user to a toy shop - No specific mandate in lease deed that premises cannot be used for any other business - It only reflects that tenant would use premises for commercial use and not for residential use - Any user for commercial purpose not specifically prohibited, would require to be allowed - Unless there was an express negative covenant, a change in business by tenant cannot grant the landlord a right to injunction - Impugned injunction, set aside.		(Paras 10, 14, 15, 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Administration of Evacuee Property (Amendment) Act (1989)
heading: Declaration as tenant
Application for
Evacuee property
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Administration of Evacuee Property Act (1964), S.32 - Declaration as tenant - Application for - Evacuee property - S.56 of Act of 1964 originally exempted certain categories of lands from claiming tenancies including evacuee property - As per S.3 of Act of 1989 provisions of Tenancy Act of 1964 were made applicable only to agricultural land and tenancies created by Custodian of evacuee property - Applicant not claiming tenancy on basis of relationship existing with custodian - Further, applicant did not file any documentary evidence to prove that he was in possession of land to claim tenancy - Application seeking declaration as tenant, liable to be dismissed. (Paras 7, 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Administration of Evacuee Property Rules (1965)
heading: Restoration application
Deciding of
HeadNote.description: Restoration of evacuee property - Restoration application - Deciding of - Held, when the Act and Rules framed thereunder specify the procedure to apply and the manner and authority to decide the restoration application, it must be decided in that manner and by that authority alone.	(Para 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Administration of Evacuee Property Rules (1965)
heading: Restoration application
Hearing of
HeadNote.description: Restoration application - Hearing of - Government performs a quasi-judicial function while deciding application for restoration - Government or authorised person shall issue notice to the party or parties named in application, on receipt of the application so that the parties named therein may appear and defend their case. Natural Justice - Right of being heard. AIR 1952 SC 16 and AIR 1978 SC 851 - Referred to.	(Para 23)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy (Special Rights and Privileges of Tenants) Rules (1967)
heading: Validity of R.6
HeadNote.description:
Validity of R.6 - Rule not invalid on ground that it permits transfer of agricultural land to non-agriculturist.

In view of Ss.2 and 3 of Goa Land use (Regulation) Act, 1991 though Mamlatdar may sanction under Section 18K of the Tenancy Act a sale transaction for sale of agricultural land deemed to have been purchased by a tiller under Section 18A of the Tenancy Act to a non-agriculturist, such land shall not be used or allowed to be used for any non-agricultural purpose. In view of this specific statutory restriction, the agricultural land will continue to remain agricultural land for all practical purposes. Therefore, there is no substance in the Petitioner's case that the deemed purchaser of the agricultural land under Section 18A of the Tenancy Act will frustrate the object of Tenancy Act.  [Para 27]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy (Special Rights and Privileges of Tenants) Rules (1967)
heading: Appointment of Mamlatdars
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Mamlatdars - Mamlatdars were appointed from 27.1.1965 and were performing their functions as Mamlatdar though they were empowered to perform their duties only from 22.10.1996 - Held, notification dt.22.10.1996 was issued only by way of abundant caution and in such a case de facto doctrine would also apply. (Paras 35, 37)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Proof of possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession and permanent injunction - Proof of possession - Plaintiff claimed to be in possession of suit property on basis of lease - Rent receipts and auction certificates show that suit property has been given in auction to plaintiff from 1965-67 - Thereafter, no auction was held - No evidence to show that plaintiff had surrendered possession or that owner recovered possession - Owner of suit property did not deny status of plaintiff as tenant - Even in survey record, name of plaintiff mentioned in tenant's column - Plaintiff had established lease was not only for 1965-67 but continued thereafter - Decree of possession granted. (Paras 10, 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Dispute about possession of Land
HeadNote.description: Dispute about possession of Land - Suit filed for declaration of possession and permanent injunction - Application also filed for temporary injunction - Plea also of plaintiff that he had become deemed tenant under Tenancy Act - Injunction rejected after giving reasons - Discretion exercised by lower court in rejecting injunction, did not call for any interference  in appeal - Suit for injunction was also misconceived since plaintiff was seeking protection of his possession and his remedy was to approach Mamlatdar under S. 8A of Act. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Issue of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Goa, Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975), S.32 - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Issue of tenancy - Civil Court has no jurisdiction to decide the issue - Jurisdiction to decide the same has been exclusively given to Mamlatdar.

Held, whether the defendants were in fact in possession of the suit property or whether the defendants cultivated the land personally and as such were in possession of the same or whether the land was used for agricultural purposes were all matters which were required to be decided by the Mamlatdar, the same being incidents or attributes of the tenancy claimed by the defendants and could not have been decided by the Civil Court.  2002(2) Goa L.T. 15 and 1998(1) Goa L.T. 429 - Referred to. [Para 39]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Reference to Mamlatdar
Maintainability of
Reference is permissible
HeadNote.description: Reference to Mamlatdar - Maintainability of - Reference for determining whether land, part of which was used for extracting salt was agricultural land and whether respondent was tenant thereof - Reference is permissible - Held, it is only Mamlatdar who has jurisdiction under S.7 of the Act to decide the said issue which would entail giving a negative declaration also that respondent is not tenant or the lands are not agricultural lands. 2009(3) ALL MR 486 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Coconut grove
Tenancy
Termination
HeadNote.description:
Coconut grove - Tenancy - Termination - Suit against tenant by landlord for recovery of possession, mesne profits filed in civil Court - Tenant claiming dismissal of suit on ground that his tenancy was not and could not be terminated and he became deemed purchaser under S.18A - Fifth amendment Act of 1976 enacted during pendency of suit - Civil Court could not dismiss the suit and was bound to refer the issue of tenancy to Mamlatdar in view of bar under S.58(2) against civil Court.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.9. (Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar
Relief under S.8A
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar - Relief under S.8A - Can be granted only in favour of tenant and against Landlord - Relief claimed by tenant against person also claiming to be tenant - Mamlatdar cannot adjudicate matter - Proper forum is Civil Court.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.9. (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Proof of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Application for permanent injunction - Proof of tenancy - Applicant tenant need not produce lease deed as it is not necessary to have written lease.	(Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Suit filed by party claiming to be tenant
HeadNote.description:
Suit filed by party claiming to be tenant - Relief of temporary injunction claimed against defendant landlord from interfering with possession - Civil court has no jurisdiction to entertain application - Court commits error in granting injunction - Status of plaintiff as tenant disputed and matter pending before competent authority - Question of presuming plaintiff to be deemed purchaser in terms of S.18A of Act does not arise.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.9. (Para 5)

headline: Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964), S. 14 – Joint tenancy – Denial of claim – Validity – Petitioner claiming that he is joint tenant of suit property with respondent no. 1 as he has inherited tenancy rights after death of his father who is original tenant – Plea of respondent no. 1 that he is exclusive tenant of suit property as perpetual lease deed was executed in his name by landlord – Sub-Divisional Officer or Administrative Tribunal have not considered contention of petitioner that in absence of tenancy of original tenant having been surrendered or terminated in accordance with law no exclusive tenancy in favour of respondent no. 1 could be created – Held, denial of claim, improper.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Joint tenancy
Denial of claim
Validity
HeadNote.description: Joint tenancy - Denial of claim - Validity - Petitioner claiming that he is joint tenant of suit property with respondent no. 1 as he has inherited tenancy rights after death of his father who is original tenant - Plea of respondent no. 1 that he is exclusive tenant of suit property as perpetual lease deed was executed in his name by landlord - Sub-Divisional Officer or Administrative Tribunal have not considered contention of petitioner that in absence of tenancy of original tenant having been surrendered or terminated in accordance with law no exclusive tenancy in favour of respondent no. 1 could be created - Denial of claim of joint tenancy without considering above contention of petitioner, improper - Matter remanded to Administrative Tribunal for fresh decision. (Paras 29, 30)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Suit for recovery of possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Defendants claiming to be tenants of suit land - Suit filed in respect of bagayat lands not covered by Act at relevant time - Fifth Amendment to Act coming into force subsequently to cover bagayat lands - Held, trial court should refer issue relating to tenancy and nature of land to Mamlatdar for decision. 1993(3) SCC 123, AIR 1979 SC 653 and AIR 1954 BOM. 100 Rel. on. (Paras 9,11,12,13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Jurisdiction of District Judge
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of District Judge - To entertain appeals and revisions against order of Mamlatdar - As per S.9(2) of Amendment Act of 2017, all appeals and revisions pending before District Judge are to be transferred to Collector on commencement of Amendment Act - District Judge by virtue of Amendment Act ceased to have jurisdiction to entertain appeal - Order passed by District Judge in appeal on day on which Amendment Act came into force, is without jurisdiction - Order liable to be set aside - Appeal is to be transferred to Deputy Collector in view of amended provisions. 	(Paras 2, 3)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Inventory proceeding
HeadNote.description: Inventory proceeding - Application filed for exclusion of paddy fields in proceedings - Proceedings finalised after rejecting application - Rejection of application is illegal - Inventory proceedings have to be reopened and the same is restricted to tenancy rights in paddy fields. (Para 5,6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Acquisition Notices by Government of Goa for two plots of land challenged
HeadNote.description: Acquisition Notices by Government of Goa for two plots of land challenged - One plot of land vested in government - Other plot of land within 200 meters of protected monument - All necessary permissions obtained from Central Government in regard to second plot of land - Petition challenging acquisition notices rejected.	(Paras 9, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Judgment or decree obtained by fraud
HeadNote.description: Judgment or decree obtained by fraud - Can be treated as a nullity and can be questioned even in collateral proceedings - Declaration given by Mamlatdar - Ex-parte order by Mamlatdar - Opponents in that case who were not served, should approach the Mamlatdar and get the said order set aside - The ex parte order need not necessarily be an order which is a nullity - As long as the defendant had not challenged the said declaration either before the Mamlatdar or other Revenue Authorities or for that matter before a civil court on the ground that it was a nullity, it is impermissible for the Additional District Judge to examine the extract of the proceedings and without any evidence being led, to come to the conclusion that the said declaration was obtained by jugglery - The said declaration as long as it was not set aside in competent proceedings, is binding on a Civil Court. (1994)1 SCC 1 and AIR 1954 Bom 239 - Referred to.	(Paras 6 & 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Jurisdiction of civil court to decide issue of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of civil court to decide issue of tenancy - In respect of a residential building, civil court has jurisdiction to decide the issue of tenancy, if the issue arises in the suit - However, under the Tenancy Act of 1964, the jurisdiction to decide whether a person is a tenant or not vests exclusively in the mamlatdar, which is not the position under the rent control act.
W.P. No. 477 of 2010; 2009(3) ALL MR 486 (S.C.) : 2009 ALL SCR 388 - Ref. to.(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Deletion of name from survey records
HeadNote.description:
Deletion of name from survey records - Mamlatdar whether empowered to perform duties of Agricultural Lands Tribunal - Impugned order passed by Mamlatdar who had no jurisdiction at the relevant time to perform the duties provided in the Tenancy Act as there was no such appointment by Govt. - Having regard to the subsequent notification of the year 1996 impugned orders passed by the authorities below quashed and set aside - Contention of the parties however kept open with regard to validity of said notification - Matter remanded to Mamlatdar to proceed in accordance with law and ensure that Mamlatdar so appointed deals with the case.

In the present case, it is not in dispute that the impugned order deleting petitioner's father's name from survey records was passed by the Mamlatdar who had no jurisdiction at the relevant time to perform the duties provided in the Tenancy Act of 1964 as there was no such appointment by the Government. Having regard to the subsequent notification of the year 1996 and keeping the contention of the parties open with regard to the validity thereof. In the interest of justice court quashed and set aside the impugned orders passed by the authorities below and remanded the matter to the Mamlatdar to proceed in accordance with law and ensure that Mamlatdar so appointed deals with the case. The merits of the dispute between the parties have not been gone into as the Mamlatdar had no jurisdiction to pass the impugned order at the relevant time as the predicates of the said Tenancy Act of 1964 have not been complied with. All contentions on merits of both the parties are left open.
2002 (6) Supreme 43, 2006(2) ALL MR 126 (S.C.), 2009 ALL SCR 1415, 1990 (supp) SCC 777, 1990 (2) SCC 271, 1981 (3) SCC 133, 2012(3) ALL MR 1 Ref. to. 					        [Para 11,12,15,16,17]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Agricultural lands
Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar
HeadNote.description: Agricultural lands - Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar - Held, Mamlatdar has exclusive jurisdiction to decide the question as to whether a particular land is an agricultural land. 2001(1) ALL MR 548 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	(Paras 5 to 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar - He cannot grant negative declaration that opposite party is not tenant - Matter has to be decided by Civil Court.

The Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to grant a negative declaration that the opponent is not a tenant under the Act.  The matter can be adjudicated by Civil Court.  [Para 17,18]

The definitions of "landlord", "lease", "Tenancy" and "Tenant" indicate that apart from a person holding lease on land, the definition of "tenant" includes a person who is deemed to be a tenant under this Act. This is material as under Section 4 of the Act, even if the land was not held on lease, if a person was lawfully cultivating the land on or after 1st July, 1962, and before the commencement of this Act, that is 8th February, 1965, such a person is also deemed to be a tenant. Similarly, the Section provides that if there were sub-tenants between the said dates, the said sub-tenants become deemed tenants excluding the tenants.  [Para 9]

Considering the scheme of the Goa Tenancy Act, the Bombay Tenancy Act and the language in use, the construction given to the Bombay Tenancy Act by the Full Bench cannot be adopted insofar as the Tenancy Act is concerned. It is true that they are cognate legislations, but as the Apex Court has observed, merely because they are cognate legislations it must not necessarily result in construing the language based on the said cognate legislation.  [Para 17]

(Paras 40, 41, 46, 49, 50)

heading: Declaration as tenant

(Paras 40, 42, 48)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Question of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Question of tenancy - Jurisdiction of Mamlatdar to decide - He can grant a negative declaration to the effect that a particular person is/was not a tenant when such a question is referred to him for his decision.

When the wordings in the section are clear to the effect that the Mamlatdar has to decide about the tenancy of a concerned person, the expression "If any question arises whether any person is or was a tenant....." can not have a meaning that the mamlatdar is not authorized to issue a negative declaration that the person is not a tenant. This expression, is clear that when there is a dispute or doubt over the tenancy of a person, then the Mamlatdar shall decide such question after conducting a due enquiry to establish the same. Therefore, if the conclusion of the Mamlatdar, on enquiry, is that a particular person is not a tenant, he is bound to declare such a person that he is not a tenant. The expression "is or was tenant" in Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act which would include the positive declaration as well as the negative declaration. If the observations made by the Division Bench of the High Court are accepted, it would then mean that if a person approaches the Mamlatdar to declare him as a tenant or on the application of a landlord for a decision on the tenancy of his occupant, the Mamlatdar ultimately reaches to a conclusion that the concerned person whose tenancy has to be decided is not a tenant, he has to refrain from taking any decision and decline to exercise his jurisdiction. Such a situation would be unacceptable, untenable and a sheer waste of time of the Mamlatdar to conduct a detailed enquiry under Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act on the application filed before it. This, cannot be the intention of the Legislature to create such an ambiguous position, which would result in a lengthy procedure, that might ultimately yield no result.   [Para 5]

It is true that under Section 4(1) of the Goa Tenancy Act, the Mamlatdar is conferred with jurisdiction to declare the category of person mentioned therein is or was not a tenant in respect of the disputed property. But if we read Section 7 and the objects and reasons of the Act and considering the fact that for a limited purpose the Mamlatdar is conferred with such power to declare the negative declaration in respect of the certain category of persons under Section 4(1) of the Goa Tenancy Act, it cannot be said that while deciding the question under Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act, the jurisdiction of the Mamlatdar to declare that the concerned person is or was not a tenant is ousted. Accordingly, we are of the view that the High Court was not justified in holding that a Mamlatdar is not conferred under Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act to deal with and decide whether the concerned person is a tenant or not a tenant in respect of the disputed property.  				 [Para 12]

Again it is needed to be mentioned that the jurisdiction under Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act is not confined to cases where the relationship of the landlord and tenant is admitted. In fact, it is only where the said relationship is alleged by one party and denied by the other that the question falls to be considered and the decision of the question is left exclusively to be determined by the Mamlatdar under the provision of the Act. It is likely that a trespasser would thereby be able to prolong litigation between him and the owner of the property by frivolously raising a plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant; but, on the other hand, a landlord may also frivolously allege that a tenant is a trespasser. The only forum that can deal with this plea is the Mamlatdar. If he rejects the plea, then only the dispute between the owner and the trespasser would be triable by the ordinary Civil Court; but otherwise, the Mamlatdar alone would decide the dispute in so far as it falls within the purview of the Act. The jurisdiction of the Mamlatdar is not confined to cases where the question is whether a person is or was a tenant in respect of the disputed property.   [Para 13]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description: Scope of - Is different from each other - S.4 is to operate from a limited period of one year from date of enforcement of Act - S.7 is operative for all time.	(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Bar of jurisdiction of Civil Court
HeadNote.description:
Bar of jurisdiction of Civil Court - Suit for injunction by tenant against person claiming to be tenant of same landlord - Jurisdiction of Civil Court to entertain suit is not barred.

Considering the tone and tenor of the entire Chapter II and on a close scrutiny of the various sections contained therein it can be seen that the relief provided under S. 8-A in favour of the tenant can be granted by the Mamlatdar only against the landlord and not against any other person. The reliefs provided under S.8-A are akin to the reliefs under S.38 of the Specific Relief Act. S. 8-A(1) can be invoked by a tenant whose possession is threatened by a landlord by approaching the Mamlatdar for an order safeguarding his right to possession. Therefore the reliefs provided under the Act in favour of the tenant can be granted only against the landlord by the Mamlatdar and not against any other person other than the landlord, except those persons who step into the shoes of the landlord. As per S.58(2) what has been excluded from the jurisdiction of the Civil Court is the matter which has to be settled, decided or dealt with by the Mamlatdar under this Act. Matter to be dealt with under S.8A as is a matter arising between landlord and tenant. The reliefs provided under S.8-A can be exercised only against the landlord and not against any other person including those persons who set up rival tenancies. It follows that a suit for injunction by a tenant against a person claiming rival tenancy is not barred by S.58(2) r.w. S.8A.  [Para 10,11]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Tenant
Who is
HeadNote.description: Tenant - Who is - Definition of tenant is very wide - S.4 does not contemplate execution of any formal document of any lease or payment of any amount as a rent.	(Para 28)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Question of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Question of tenancy - Jurisdiction to decide question - An exclusive jurisdiction to decide the question as to whether any person is or was a tenant or was a deemed tenant under the tenancy Act is conferred on the Mamlatdar - Held, the exclusive jurisdiction to decide whether any land is used for agricultural purposes also vests in the Mamlatdar - Jurisdiction of Civil Court has been completely ousted. 2009 ALL SCR 388 : 2009(3) ALL MR 486 (S.C.) - Rel. on.			(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Communidades
HeadNote.description: Communidades - By a legal fiction, a communidade becomes a "person" for the purposes of the Tenancy Act and is on par with any other landlord.			(Para 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - There cannot be a termination of tenancy or surrender of tenancy except in accordance with Ss.9, 10, 11 of Tenancy Act - No tenant of any land shall be terminated or evicted save as provided under Tenancy Act.

The legal position which emerges from the provisions of the Tenancy Act can be summarised as under :

(a)	Exclusive jurisdiction is conferred on the Mamlatdar to decide the issue whether a person is a tenant under the Tenancy Act or not. Exclusive jurisdiction to decide whether any land is used for agricultural purpose is also conferred on the Mamlatdar.

(b)	The jurisdiction of the Civil Court and other authorities is expressly ousted to decide the issue of tenancy, which is required to be decided under Section 7 of the Tenancy Act.

(c)	The definition of tenant is very wide and any person lawfully cultivating any land belonging to another person on or after 1st July, 1962 but before the commencement of the Tenancy Act shall be deemed to be a tenant provided other conditions in Section 4 are satisfied. Therefore, any person lawfully cultivating the land of another person becomes a tenant irrespective of the fact whether there was any lease executed in favour of such a person.

(d)	There cannot be a termination of tenancy or surrender of tenancy except in accordance with Sections 9, 10 and 11 of the Tenancy Act. No tenant of any land shall be terminated or evicted save as provided under Tenancy Act.

(e)	In case of failure of the tenant to purchase the land in accordance with Section 18-A read with Section 18-C, the land does not revert to the landlord and it has to be resumed by the State for allotment to various persons named in sub-section 2 of Section 18-K.

(f)	Section 55 of the Tenancy Act declares lands owned by a Communidade to be owned by a single person and not by the individual members and to that extent Code of Communidade stands amended.

(g)	No exception has been carved out under the provisions of the Tenancy Act in respect of the lands held by a Communidade and Section 55 of the Tenancy Act makes it clear that a Communidade is on par with any other individual landlord of the agricultural land.  [Para 19]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Surrender of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Surrender of tenancy - There cannot be a surrender after the vesting under S.18-A of the Act.

The Tenancy Act prohibits surrender of Tenancy in this manner. In fact there cannot be a surrender after the vesting under section 18-A of the Tenancy Act. The Tenancy Act prohibits a tenant purchaser from transferring the land vested in him without prior permission of the Mamlatdar. Thus, on the face of it, the compromise was illegal and even in exercise of administrative powers of sanctioning compromise, the Administrative Tribunal ought not to have sanctioned such compromise which is completely in breach of provisions of the Tenancy Act. The Administrative Tribunal cannot permit compromise which is per se contrary to law. The Tenancy Act has been brought on the statute book as a part of agrarian reforms. Therefore, under the Tenancy Act, there is no provision permitting a deemed purchaser to surrender his rights. The tenancy of an ordinary tenant can be determined only in accordance with the provisions of the Tenancy Act. All these protections are made a part of the Tenancy Act with a view to ensure that tenants are not either tempted or forced to give up their rights under the Tenancy Act. Any compromise or agreement recorded by any Court or tribunal by which a tenant or a tenant who is a deemed purchaser surrenders or gives up his right, title or interest is without jurisdiction. And non-est.  [Para 25]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Surrender of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Surrender of tenancy - Can be permitted only by the Mamlatdar in accordance with S.10 of the Act and the jurisdiction of the Civil Court, completely ousted.	(Para 27)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description: Scope of - Is different from each other - S.4 is to operate from a limited period of one year from date of enforcement of Act - S.7 is operative for all time.	(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Mundkarship or tenancy
HeadNote.description: Mundkarship or tenancy - When an issue of mundkarship or tenancy is raised in a suit, it is required to be decided by the Mamlatdar in terms of S.32(2) of the Act of 1975 and S.58 of the Act of 1964.	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Section applies when landlord intends to sell land cultivated by a tenant to a third party - It does not apply if he sells land to tenant himself.	(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Issue of tenancy
Framing of
HeadNote.description: Issue of tenancy - Framing of - For framing issue requisite particulars of such tenancy is required to be given - Such particulars are found missing in written statement - Also no application to frame additional issue about tenancy is filed - Issue about tenancy cannot be framed. (Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Claim of tenancy
Jurisdiction to decide
HeadNote.description: Claim of tenancy - Jurisdiction to decide - Is expressly barred in civil court. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Permission to transfer
Scope
HeadNote.description: Permission to transfer - Scope - Permission to transfer can be granted only when land is to be used for agricultural purposes - Such permission can be granted only to ascertained transferee - Mamlatdar must satisfy himself that parties are bonafide and capable of carrying on agricultural operations - Moreover transfer can only be to categories of persons set out in S.18J. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Validity of R.6
HeadNote.description:
Validity of R.6 - Rule not invalid on ground that it permits transfer of agricultural land to non-agriculturist.

In view of Ss.2 and 3 of Goa Land use (Regulation) Act, 1991 though Mamlatdar may sanction under Section 18K of the Tenancy Act a sale transaction for sale of agricultural land deemed to have been purchased by a tiller under Section 18A of the Tenancy Act to a non-agriculturist, such land shall not be used or allowed to be used for any non-agricultural purpose. In view of this specific statutory restriction, the agricultural land will continue to remain agricultural land for all practical purposes. Therefore, there is no substance in the Petitioner's case that the deemed purchaser of the agricultural land under Section 18A of the Tenancy Act will frustrate the object of Tenancy Act.  [Para 27]

heading: Appointment of Mamlatdars
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Mamlatdars - Mamlatdars were appointed from 27.1.1965 and were performing their functions as Mamlatdar though they were empowered to perform their duties only from 22.10.1996 - Held, notification dt.22.10.1996 was issued only by way of abundant caution and in such a case de facto doctrine would also apply. (Paras 35, 37)

heading: Market value

heading: Reference
Dispute of apportionment
Followed.	(Paras 11, 12)
HeadNote.description: Reference - Dispute of apportionment - Appellant producing evidence of tenancy - Reference court has no jurisdiction to consider evidence regarding tenancy while deciding issue of apportionment - Matter liable to be remanded for de novo consideration with directions to refer issue of tenancy to Mamlatdar. Unreported decision of Division Bench of High Court of Bombay At Goa in F.A. No.17/2002 and F.A. No.30/2003, dt.3-5-2005 - Followed.	(Paras 11, 12)

HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing appeal against order passed in mutation proceedings - Delay of 3 years, 11 months and 7 days in filing appeal - Delay occurred as petitioner had no knowledge of order passed by Mamlatdar, because he was not made party to proceedings - Order was obtained behind back of petitioner - Sufficient cause made out by petitioner for delay - Delay condoned. heading: Market Value
Determination

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964)
heading: Compensation
Enhancement
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Enhancement - Appellant granted compensation of Rs.17/- per sq. m. as against adjoining landholder to whom compensation of Rs.78/- per sq. m. was granted - Ground that land which is subject to tenancy, fetches lesser price - Legality - Held, said principle applies only when land is acquired subject to tenancy - In instant case rights of landlord as well as rights of tenant have been acquired - Compensation rate will be no lesser than what was awarded to neighbour - Total amount  will be apportioned 50-50 between landlord and tenant. 

(1996) 3 SCC 594 Disting.  (Paras 10, 11)
