heading: Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Review application in execution proceeding - Rejection of - Validity - Application filed raising plea of tenancy - Review application rejected without considering the plea of tenancy - Rejection of review application, not proper. 			(Paras 14, 21, 31)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction - Suit for injunction and eviction - Relationship between  parties found to be that of lessor & lessee - Matter to be decided by Authorities under Rent Control Act - Jurisdiction of Civil Court, ousted. (Para 33)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Execution proceeding
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Execution proceeding - Eviction of lessee holding possession of demised premises - Bar u/s.21 of Rent Control Act - Applicability - Said lessee occupying suit premises even after expiry of lease - He therefore became statutory tenant - Hence having protection u/s.21 of Rent Control Act - Eviction of said lessee barred by provision of S.21 of Rent Control Act. 

1998(3) ALL MR 213 (S.C.) Ref. to.	(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description:
Rejection of plaint - Ground that suit for declaration appears to be barred by law from statement in plaint - Suit by daughter of tenant - Decree of eviction was already passed - That time daughter of tenant was not party to eviction proceedings - Whether or not married daughter has right in tenanted premises is question to be dealt by Court during trial in civil suit - There is no bar by any law taking away right of daughter, who subsequently gets married - Suit cannot be dismissed as barred by law.
1992(2) Bom.C.R. 666, 2001(3) ALL MR 509 (S.C), 2002 (10) SCC 501, 2011 (6) SCC 385, 2004(2) Goa L.R. 488 Ref.to.(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Tenant
Definition of
HeadNote.description: Tenant - Definition of - Sons who had not been living with tenant as member of his family upto date of his death - Would not be included in definition of “tenant” - Not necessary to bring them on record after death of tenant - Landlord, would be entitled to order of eviction straight away against LRs. of deceased, statutory tenant. (Paras 14, 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Powers of Appellate Board
HeadNote.description: Powers of Appellate Board - District Judge acting and exercising powers as Appellate Board - Does not act as "Personal Designata" - R.9(3) of Goa Rules 1969 providing that Appellate Board shall follow procedure under CPC - It would include power under O.47 CPC for review of its own judgment and order - Plea on basis of second proviso to S.47 of Act that finality having been attached to orders passed in, appeal or revision, the power of review stands excluded by necessary implication - Not tenable. AIR 1973 Ker. 214 Disting. (Paras 27, 30)

headline:
Goa, Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968), Ss.41, 32(4) – Goa, Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969), R.9(3) – Powers of Appellate Board – District Judge acting and exercising powers as Appellate Board – Does not act as "Personal Designata"
R.9(3) of Goa Rules 1969 providing that Appellate Board shall follow procedure under CPC – It would include power under O.47 CPC for review of its own judgment and order - Finality of orders and exclusion of power of review, on basis of second proviso to S.47 of Act, held not tenable

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Tenancy
HeadNote.description: Tenancy - Tenancy is a relationship between a landlord and a tenant and that relationship is in respect of a subject-matter - If the tenanted premises are destroyed due to natural causes or due to acts of negligence attributable to the tenant, the relationship between the plaintiff as tenant and the defendants as landlords would certainly come to an end and the tenant would not be entitled to insist that the landlord re-erects the said premises and gives to the tenant for his occupation - However, the situation would be different where a landlord pulls down a building governed by the Rent Act. AIR 1996 Bom 389 and (2003)5 SCC 150 - Referred to.	(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction cases
HeadNote.description:
Eviction cases - Bar of jurisdiction of civil court under the Act - Administrator of Goa extending provisions of Act to belt of 2 kms. around limits of city of Panji - It does not matter if such belt would cover some part of other taluka - Village of  Panha de France is within 2 kms. of Panji - Jurisdiction of civil court to consider cases is barred. 

Civil P.C. (1908), S.9. (Para 4)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Change in user
HeadNote.description:
Change in user - Premises let out for vocational training subsequently being used as hostel amounts to the change of user under the clause.

The lease, as pecified in the lease agreement was granted for the purpose of conducting classes pertaining to the Goa Group Vocational Training Centre. On the face of the lease agreement, therefore it is difficult to say that any other user was also permitted by the landlord while conducting the classes by the petitioner. The use having been specifically stated in the lease agreement and considering the entire evidence on record the fact finding authority having arrived at a finding that there is absolutely no nexus between the holding of the classes and allowing the trainees to use the same for lodging therein even during the training period by no stretch of imagination it can be said that the hostel facility is part and parcel of the purpose of training classes. AIR 1993 SC 2646 Relied on.	  [Para 7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Denial of title of land-lord - Mere claiming of right as mundkar under Mundkar Act in respect of the house - Does not amount to denial of title of land-lord within the meaning of S.21 r/w. S.22(1)(g) of the Rent Act.

Merely because a person has claimed the right to reside in a mundkarilal house, it cannot be said that he has denied the title of the bhatkar.  In fact he accepts the title but claims protection of the Mundkar Act.  Precisely in this case petitioners only claimed the statutory protection under the Mundkar Act and it was an error to read as denial of title of the landlord.  In fact they accepted the title and claimed protection.  Section 15 of the Mundkar Act gives right to a mundkar to purchase the mundkarial house and to a limited extent land below the house.  This is on payment to the landlord.  Thus there is recognition of title by the mundkar of the landlord.  Position can be visulised under various statutes giving protection to weaker community persons.  The question involved in such proceedings is very limited as in the present case whether petitioners can get protection of Mundkar Act.  If it is held that they get protection then legal consequences follow.  But claiming of such protection cannot amount to denial of title.	  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Failure to pay enhanced rent - Landlord enhancing rent unilaterally - Failure of tenant to pay the enhanced rent - Not a ground for eviction.

In the instant case relying on Clauses 3 and 4 of Article 80, it is submitted by Mr. M.B.da Costa, the learned Advocate appearing for the Respondents that the Plaintiffs had given a notice to the Defendants regarding increase of rent and as the Defendants had neither vacated the suit house nor had they paid the new rent, the Plaintiffs were entitled to a Decree of eviction.  Clauses 2 to 4 of Article 80 provide or cater to a situation which may arise after the increase in the rent under Clause 1 of Article 80.  Clause 1 of Article 80 provides increase in the rent either by mutual consent or by valuation under Article 107.  Clause 1 does not contemplate any unilateral increase in the rent.  It is not averred in the plaint that the increase in the rent demanded by the Plaintiffs was as a result of either mutual consent or valuation under Article 107.  That being the case, the very foundation of the Plaintiffs case is weakened.  On the basis of the prayer which was made in the plaint, the Plaintiffs could not have succeeded in getting an eviction Decree on the ground that the Defendants had failed to pay the enhanced rent and, therefore, the Plaintiffs were entitled to a Decree of eviction.  Thus, in respect of the substantial question of law that failure to pay enhanced rent, if the rent was enhanced unilaterally by the Plaintiffs, would not be a ground available for evicting the tenant.					 [Para 15]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Eviction proceedings - Duty of tenant to pay rent regularly during pendency of proceedings - Withdrawal by landlord of amount deposited by tenant - Does not operate as estoppel against landlord to seek stopping of proceedings and order immediate eviction of tenant.

The provisions of section 32(1) read with Rule 7 of the said Rules provides that the tenant shall continue to deposit the rent regularly during the eviction proceedings in the Court. Any amount so deposited on account of statutory liability of a tenant which the landlord is legally otherwise entitled to recover on account of his or her premises being in occupation of the tenant, if withdrawn by the landlord that cannot in any way amount to estoppel against the landlord and against his right to invoke the provisions of law which entitles the landlord to seek intervention of the Rent Controller to stop the eviction proceedings and order immediate eviction of the tenant on account of default on the part of the tenant in depositing the rent.  [Para 5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of arrears of rent
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant on ground of arrears of rent - Order directing tenant to deposit amount within specified time - Amount deposited by tenant falling short of some amount by mistake - Tribunal accepting bona fide mistake and extending time for payment of deficient amount - Order is within jurisdiction of Tribunal.	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Suit for eviction
Right of co-owner
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Bonafide requirement of landlord - Right of co-owner - Co-owner can sue for eviction alone without other co-owners joining him - Only exception would be an oblique motive for obtaining the tenanted premises upon some extraneous purpose. 1989(1) Goa Law Times 161 and AIR 1989 SC 758 - Rel. on.			(Paras 14, 18, 19, 30)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction application
Amendment to
HeadNote.description: Eviction application - Amendment to - Law has not conferred any powers either on Rent Controller or on Administrative Tribunal to deal with issue of amendment - Law is thus, silent regarding procedure to amend eviction application before Rent Controller - Held, Administrative Tribunal, clearly erred in holding that Controller could exercise inherent powers available to Civil Courts in allowing amendment applications. (2002)2 SCC 256 - Ref. to. (Paras 14, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Ground of change of user - Premises let out to a Bank for use as 'office' - Bank shifting its business to another place and using premises let out for godown for storing books of accounts - It later on started using them also for pigmy bank accounts and collecting electric bills but was unable to show Reserve Bank permission for such activity - Held use of premises as "godown" amounted to change of user.

Letting out the premises for commercial purpose can have different colors and hues depending upon the purpose for which it is let out. For example a non-residential premises can be let out for commercial purpose for running a shop, office, restaurant, hotel, cinema and godown for storing of the goods etc. If it is specified in the lease deed that the premises be used for a particular commercial purpose then the change of use of the premises falling in another category of purpose would amount to change of user of the building falling within the four corners of S.22(2)(b)(ii) of the Act and the landlord would be entitled to seek eviction of the tenant for having changed the use of the suit premises for a purpose otherthan for which it was let out. When the use of the building is identified in the lease deed as an 'office,' it would be taken that the parties had used the expression 'office' in the sense in which the 'office' is understood in common parlance or as indicated by its dictionary meaning. The building was taken on rent for use as an 'office' in which the appellant started transacting its banking activities and continued to do so till it shifted its banking activities in the new building. The suit premises ceased to be occupied as an office and were being used as a godown, which was a different purpose than the one identified in the lease deed. The story put forth by the Bank that it had restored its banking activities in the suit premises by carrying on pigmy bank accounts and taking of electrical bills has rightly been discarded. Even if it is so assumed for the sake of argument, even then the appellant has failed to show that it had a valid permission for carrying on its banking activities at the suit premises. Appellant had already shifted its branch office for the banking activities and it has failed to show that it had the necessary permission from the Reserve Bank of India to carry on with its banking activities at the suit premises as well.		 [Para 23,28,29]

The shifting of the activities from office purpose to godown purpose is a change of use of premises. It is not shifting of the business from one trade to another trade.   [Para 30]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Question as to whether agreement between parties creates lease or license - Defendant literate person entered into several agreements of leave and licence with plaintiff - Defendant not taking plea that agreement entered into by way of camouflage - Oral and documentary evidence clearly establish relationship between the parties as licensor and licensee - Order of trial court for eviction restored.

Where defendant was a literate person with open eyes enters into several agreements of leave and licence and did not take a plea that the agreement was entered into by way of camouflage to get out of the provisions of the Rent Act and terms of agreement are clear and suggestive of creation of licence between the parties, the question of referring to surrounding circumstances to find out intention of the parties does not arise, and evidence oral and documentary led by the parties clearly established the intention of the parties in entering into an agreement was to create licence and not lease in favour of the defendant which means  that the relationship between the parties was that of licensor and licensee so order by trial court for eviction would be restored.

1999(2) ALL MR 576 (S.C.) Rel. on.

AIR 1989 SC 1816, 1992 Supp (2) SCC 29, 1995 Supp (4) SCC 158, 1999 5 SCC 721, 2004 (5) ALL MR (S.C.) 460, 2006(3) ALL MR 195, 2006(5) ALL MR 457, AIR 1996 SC 3288, (2001) 3 SCC 179, 2011 ALL SCR 1326 Ref. to. 			       [Para 35,37]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction proceedings
HeadNote.description: Eviction proceedings - Failure to deposit rent pendent lite - Tenant a widow filing affidavit that because of disputes with her son she lost track of proceeding and also due to financial constraints was unable to pay rent regularly - Held, yardstick laid down by the court in numerous judgments to be applied to conclude as to whether conduct of petitioner was contumacious or cantankerous and was such as to cause harassment to respondent landlord - Tribunal failed to consider the same - Matter relegated back for de novo consideration. (Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction order
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Eviction order - Challenge to - Proved facts are (i) construction of shed on open place appurtenant to leased premises without consent of landlord, (ii) construction of shed covering area where well and a septic tank existed - No arbitrariness or perversity noticed in impugned judgments - Writ petition against order of eviction dismissed with costs. 2005(1) SCC 8 - Ref. to. 		(Para 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Jurisdiction of civil court
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of civil court - Dispute regarding lease agreement between parties - Jurisdiction would follow only in cases where building is completed 15 years prior - Findings that building was completed in August 1981 only on basis of Occupancy Certificate held, not proper.
1993(1) Mah. L. R. 493 Rel.on. 	(Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Payment of rent
HeadNote.description:
Payment of rent - Appeal by tenant against order of eviction passed by Rent Controller - Application filed by landlord under S.32(4) for non-payment of rent by tenant during proceedings - Application by landlord is maintainable. 

All India Rent Control Journal 1988 (1) 520, 2003 (1) SCC 123 Ref. to. 	(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Non-payment of rent
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Non-payment of rent - Default in payment of rent prior to decision on application under S.32(4) - No sufficient cause shown by tenant - Landlord be put in possession of building.

The mandate must be read in Section 32(1) that the tenant cannot remain content without depositing the admitted amount of rent until the entire matter is disposed of under sub-section (3) of section 32. The Controller, in such circumstances, is required to make an order directing a tenant to deposit the rent admitted even during the pendency of the application under Section 32(3). Section 32(4) of the Act provides that if any tenant fails to pay or to deposit the rent as aforesaid, the Controller or the appellate or revisional authority, as the case may be, shall unless the tenant shows sufficient cause to the contrary, stop all further proceedings and make an order directing the tenant to put the landlord in possession of the building.      [Para 15,18]

Mere filing of the Revision Application along with application for condonation of delay cannot be a sufficient cause for not complying with the order for payment of rent. Non-compliance of the order of the Competent Authority, in the facts and circumstances above, show the cantankerous and contumacious nature of the tenant, in resisting/delaying payment of the rents due, only to harass the landlord. Insofar as the said admitted default in payment of rent ordered to be paid after the final order the question of prejudice being caused to the appellants by not permitting them to peruse the register of challans does not arise. Besides the above, in view of the said admitted default, by way of delay, the question of holding any inquiry, fulfledged by taking evidence or otherwise a summary inquiry, also does not arise. 			         [Para 19,20]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Repairs to tenanted building
HeadNote.description: Repairs to tenanted building - Alleged NOC from owner permitting only repairs to ceiling wall, flooring and roof - Appellants demolishing whole structure - They are not entitled to protection of S.33(3) - Moreover, consent of all the tenants was not obtained by the appellants and appellants also did not seek any order from Rent Tribunal - Held, acts of appellants would amount to totally changing nature of suit building without consent of all co-owners of property and as such they were entitled to challenge correctness of findings in the present appeal. 	(Paras 9, 11, 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of change of user etc.
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of change of user etc. - Tenant not depositing rent during pendency of proceedings - Landlord's application under S.32(4) served on tenant - Dues not deposited within 30 days after service of notice - Stopping of proceeding is valid.

Under S.32(1) no tenant against whom proceedings for eviction have been instituted by a landlord shall be entitled to contest the proceedings before the Controller or any appellate or revisional authority, or to prefer any appeal or revision under the Act unless he has paid to the landlord or deposits with the Controller or the appellate or revisional authority, as the case may be, all arrears of rent due in respect of the building upto the date of payment or deposit and continues to pay or deposit rent which may be subsequently due in respect of the building until the termination of proceedings before the Controller or appellate or revisional authority. In terms of Rule 7 of the Rules the tenant is to deposit within 30 days from date on which the notice is served.  [Para 6]

Some of the factors which are relevant for exercising power under Section 32(4) of the Act, are whether the default is for a short period or long period, whether the default is wilful or intentional, whether the default is consistent or persistent, whether the payment was made at the earliest opportunity or after cantankerous contest and whether it was bona fide or to harass the landlord. In the instant case the default is for a period of more than four years. The default is consistent and persistent even inspite of clear provisions of law that the tenant is required to pay the rent during the pendency of the proceedings. The tenant did deposit the rent, but after cantankerous contest and just prior to the passing of the Order by the Additional Rent Controller and that the failure to deposit the rent can, by no stretch of imagination, be said to be bona fide. In these circumstances, it can be said that the authorities have exercised discretion in accordance with law and there is absolutely no reason for the High Court to interfere with the discretion exercised by the authorities.  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Notice of landlord's application served on tenant - Arrears of rent not deposited within 30 days of service of notice - Tenant present in court on one or two occassions within 30 days period - Order of stoppage of proceeding and delivery of possession passed against tenant under S. 32(4) as no sufficient reason cause was shown - Administrative Tribunal in appeal setting aside order of Rent Controller - No finding by Tribunal whether tenant was persistent defaulter or cantankerous contestant - Order is liable to be set aside - Matter remanded. (Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - On ground of bonafide requirement - Rejection by Courts below - Invocation of jurisdiction u/Art.227 - Suit shop situated at Mapusa - Applicant-landlord having his jewellery shop at Mapusa but residing at Bastora with his three sons - Rent Controller based on material on record and on suo motu inspection of house at Bastora came to conclusion that said house was adequate for applicant and better than suit house at Mapusa - Rent Controller however failed to consider indifferent health of applicant or that he had no other house in Mapusa and that better medical facilities were available at Mapusa than at Bastora - Though original applicant died pending appeal, no finding recorded to the effect that need of suit house of original applicant was not bonafide - Courts below failed to exercise jurisdiction resulting in grave injustice to petitioner - Impugned order quashed in exercise of jurisdiction u/Art.227. 			(Paras 40, 41, 42, 43, 44)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Sub-letting
Followed.	 [Para 2,3]
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Sub-letting - For getting decree of eviction on ground of sub-letting, the landlord has to establish that there was a transfer of exclusive possession of premises to sub-tenant and that the transfer of possession was for consideration.

1999(7) SCC 263 and AIR 1987 SC 2055 - Followed.	 [Para 2,3]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Application for rejection of plaint - Father of applicant and later mother of applicant was statutory tenant of commercial shop of respondent - Upon her demise, applicant continued in shop - Respondent sought for eviction and mesne profit alleging that applicant was in illegal possession - Trial Court rejected application under O.7 R.11(d) on ground that in case applicant had produced any document establishing that he was tenant, suit would have been barred by S.56 of Rent Control Act - Not proper - As held, commercial tenancy is heritable and in view of S.56, Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain suit for eviction - Application is allowed. 1985 ALLMR ONLINE 247 (S.C.), 1998(4) ALL MR 458 Rel. on. 			(Paras 15, 16, 17, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Petition against
Pendency
No interference
HeadNote.description: Repairs/reconstruction of tenanted premises - Proceedings u/S.33 initiated by tenants - Interim relief permitting repairs/reconstruction of northern and southern walls of premises granted to tenants by Revisional Authority - Petition against - Pendency - Certain interim arrangements were consented to by landlord - Tenants already carried out certain limited repairs - Findings recorded by revisional authority on basis of material on record not suffering from any perversity - View taken by Revisional Authority found not improper - No interference - Proceedings instituted by tenant u/S.33 and proceedings initiated by landlord u/S.30 for permission of reconstruction, ordered to be expeditiously disposed of.			(Paras 16, 17, 20, 24, 25)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction proceedings
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Eviction proceedings - Application for payment of rent during pendency of proceedings - Disposal of application by holding that quantum of rent has to be first determined - Challenge - No dispute that there is written document in terms of which rent payable was Rs.15,000/- p.m. - Tenant stated that he used to give cheque of Rs. 15,000/- every month but landlord used to return Rs.5,000/- in cash - Tenant stated that correct rent amount was of Rs.10,000/- - Tenant admitted that rent for suit premises was at least Rs.10,000/- - Tenant claimed that he has not paid rent as water supply to his toilet was disconnected - However, disconnection of water supply can hardly exempt tenant from paying or depositing admitted rent amount - Moreover, when it was no case of tenant that landlord caused disconnection of water supply - Tenant cannot on one hand insist upon not handing over possession of suit premises and at same time not paying or depositing amount or holding on suit premises, even though claiming that he is not using suit premises - Order of Trial Court modified by directing tenant to deposit amount of Rs.10,000/- p.m. in respect of suit premises. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Definition of "tenant
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Definition of "tenant - Scope - Statutory tenancy is heritable - Heirs residing with tenant at time of his death acquire status of statutory tenant - Tenancy was heritable even before the amendment - Suit for eviction against heirs can be entertained only by Rent Court.

AIR 1985 SC 796 Rel. on. (Paras 7 to 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Revisional jurisdiction
Exercise of
HeadNote.description: Revisional jurisdiction - Exercise of - Tribunal can exercise revisional jurisdiction under S.46 only if exceptional circumstances exists. 	(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Sub-lease
HeadNote.description: Sub-lease - Can be created provided there is consent from landlord prior to sub-letting and not otherwise. (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of Tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of Tenant - Landlord erst while employee of Burmah Shell Co. becoming Central Govt. employee after taking over of that company by Central Govt. - He is qualified to seek eviction of tenant for purpose of bonofide occupation of tenanted premises. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Landlord being Central Govt. employee claiming benefit of provision - No summary or immediate possession ordered - Procedure under S. 23A (3) (a) not followed - Question which speaks of leave to defend does not arise - No prejudice also caused to tenant. (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Court has to see whether part of building is available for occupation of landlord and if he requires additional accommodation - Hardship of parties has to be taken into consideration - Rent Controller finding that equity was in favour of tenant - Administrative Tribunal was not justified in reversing their order. (Para 12)
