heading: Eviction of tenant
Ground of sub-letting
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Ground of sub-letting - Sub-letting contemplates actual parting of possession by tenant in favour of third party, for consideration - Element of parting of physical or actual possession is lacking - Except admission of wife of tenant there is no other evidence to establish sub-letting - Eviction of tenant, improper. (Para 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Pleadings
HeadNote.description: Default in payment of rent - Pleadings - Essential ingredients not stated in the application - In absence of proper pleadings no amount of evidence can come to the help of applicant. (Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant - Non-user of premises that must be proved. 

In so far as non-user of the premises for the requisite period is concerned, what has been pleaded is that the first respondent/petitioner ceased to occupy the premises for a period more than a year from the date of the application for eviction and kept the premises closed. As far as this aspect is concerned, the landlord can seek eviction of the tenant from the premises under Section 22(1)(f) which clearly states that tenant must have ceased to occupy the building for a continuous period of four months without reasonable cause. Obviously this means that the premises have remained unoccupied prior to the date of application for eviction. The application for eviction did not set out that it had been kept closed or that prior to the filing of the application, the tenant had ceased to occupy the building for a continuous period of four months without reasonable cause. In such circumstances even on that count eviction could not have been ordered, much less ex-parte.  [Para 13]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction sought on ground of change of user, alternations and nuisance to other occupants
HeadNote.description:
Eviction sought on ground of change of user, alternations and nuisance to other occupants - Property sold by owner - Cause of eviction survives to purchaser - Cause does not survive in favour of purchaser if eviction is sought for personal use of premises.

In case when eviction is sought on the ground of need for personal occupation of the landlord, the need ceases to exist moment the property is sold by the landlord to a stranger. In case of eviction on the ground of change of user or damage to the premises or nuisance by the tenant to the other occupants of the building, the cause of action does not cease to exist on transfer of ownership by the landlord in favour of a stranger, but does survive in favour of the purchaser.  [Para 5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction sought under S.22 for change of user, alterations and nuisance
HeadNote.description: Eviction sought under S.22 for change of user, alterations and nuisance - Eviction not sought on ground of personal requirement under S.23 - Bar prescribed for eviction proceedings on account of acquisition of right by virtue of deed inter vivos is not applicable and need not be considered. (Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction on ground of non-occupation of premises
HeadNote.description:
Eviction on ground of non-occupation of premises - Word 'occupy' means physical occupation - No evidence to show that tenant was occupying - Landlord is entitled to evict tenant.

Words and Phrases - 'Occupation'

The word 'occupy' in the context in which it is used in S.22(2)(f) of the Act must mean physical occupation of the suit premises. In fact, a tenant who ceases to occupy a building for a continuous period of four months for valid reasons, can place the same before the Court which can be considered under Section 22(2)(f) of the Act and this will take care of tenants who are temporarily transferred from the place where the suit premises is situated. For the application of section 22(2)(f), the tenant has to cease to occupy the building for a continuous period of four months without reasonable cause which means that if reasonable cause is there for not occupying the suit premises for a continuous period of four months, it would not furnish ground for eviction. When the tenant's case is that he was physically occupying the same, mere animus poscedendi without actual occupation would not be sufficient. Even if it be assumed that the luggage of the tenant continued in the suit premises, that fact, by itself, would not be sufficient to hold that the tenant had continued to occupy the suit premises.  [Para 7]

The tenant in the case had categorically affirmed that he was in occupation of the suit premises. But the relevant evidence in the nature of production of ration card, evidence of persons who visited him during the relevant period, receipt of correspondence during the said period at the address of suit premises, electricity and water bills and such other evidence was never placed by the tenant before the Court. His name was also not found in the electoral roll. Electricity connection was cut and it was difficult for tenant to occupy the premises without electricity since the premises was in the basement. Thus there was no evidence to show any occupation and the landlord  was entitled to evict the tenant.  [Para 7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant on grounds of arrears of rent
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on grounds of arrears of rent - Tenant not depositing costs along with arrears - He is liable to be evicted.

In case the tenant wants to avoid eviction on the ground of arrears of rent, he is required to deposit the arrears within thirty days along with the costs of the application in terms of Section 22(3) of the said Act. The fact that a composite application is filed where eviction is sought on other grounds, as well, does not make any difference whatsoever so far as the ground relating to non-payment of arrears of rent is concerned. Even if the proceedings are finally rejected by the Rent Controller in which no costs are awarded, that would not in any manner absolve the tenant in so far as the initial stage under S. 22(3) was concerned.  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Interim relief
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Interim relief - Grant of - Rent Tribunal has no jurisdiction under S.33 - Plea neither raised before Rent Tribunal and Administrative Tribunal nor in writ petition - Allowed to urge at stage of hearing as it goes to the root of the matter.

Constitution of India, Art.226. (Para 3)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Interim relief
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Application by tenant for repairs - Interim relief - Grant of - Rent Tribunal has power in exceptional cases, though not specifically provided in S.33 - Power is to be used sparingly.

The object and the obligation which has been cast on the landlord under Section 33 is that every landlord shall be bound to keep the building in good and tenantable repair.  The whole purpose behind this obligation on the landlord is that the tenant is able to enjoy the premises without inconvenience to him.  There may be cases where the tenanted premises cannot be used at all unless immediate repairs are carried out and a few instances of the same can be total or partial collapse of the roof, house-breaking by a thief either breaking of the wall or the door and window and instances of such nature.  If the repairs are not immediately attended to, the tenanted premises cannot be used properly which may result in terrible inconvenience to the tenant.  For such exceptional cases the Rent Tribunal will certainly have jurisdiction to grant interim relief even though there may not be any specific provision to that effect under Section 33 of the said Act.  Courts and Tribunals have inherent power to take action of preserving the subject-matter of the litigation before them.  Therefore, in certain cases if no immediate relief is granted, the remaining tenanted premises may be in danger of total collapse.  It would be too much to expect in such type of cases that the tenant should wait for the final order which normally takes quite some time with usual tactics adopted by the parties.  Of course, this power to grant interim relief shall be exercised by the Rent Tribunal only in such cases where there is complete justification for granting such interim relief.  It is not to be granted as a matter of routine, but only upon the party making a strong case.  This power has to be used sparingly in exceptional cases only.  [Para 4]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Repairs and reconstruction
Distinction between
HeadNote.description:
Repairs and reconstruction - Distinction between - Tenanted house damaged by fire - Permission granted by way of interim measure by Rent Tribunal to replace roof - Did not amount to reconstruction - No interference under Art.226.

Constitution of India, Art.226.

Repair is restoration by renewal or replacement of some parts of a whole.  'Renewal', as distinguished from 'repair', is reconstruction of the entirety; meaning by 'entirety' not necessarily the whole, but substantially the whole subject-matter under reconstruction.

The permission granted in instant case for replacement of roof of the house with Mangalore tiles, wooden rafters, battens, would not amount to reconstruction, especially when it is found that the same was necessary to preserve the remaining part of the building.  Held that no exceptional case has been made out for interference in the writ jurisdiction, since, prima facie, the orders do not suffer from any error of jurisdiction or breach of principles of natural justice, or otherwise, vitiated by manifest or apparent error of law.  [Para 9,10]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Provisions of
Are not mandatory
HeadNote.description: Provisions of - Are not mandatory - It is not that the moment there is any default in payment or deposit of rent that the order to stop the proceedings has necessarily to follow - Tenant must be afforded an opportunity to put forth his defence in reply - If he files an affidavit to corroborate his reply it cannot be rejected on technical ground and that too at appellate stage. (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction proceedings
HeadNote.description: Eviction proceedings - Analysis of materials placed on record is not merely to find out whether there was sufficient cause for not depositing or non-payment of rent, but it is essentially to find out whether the tenant has been able to show sufficient cause for not stopping the proceedings - Justification for delay may be one of the reasons for not stopping the proceedings, but is not the sole reason which is to be considered under S. 32(4). (Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant for default
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant for default - Tenant not disputing payment of arrears - Tenant was given opportunities to pay arrears - He can avoid eviction after complying with provisions of Act.

An analysis of the provisions of section 22(1), (2)(a), (3) and (4) shows that the default in payment of rent for 3 months by the tenant does not ipso facto conclude the matter enabling the rent Controller to pass an eviction order. The legislature has thought it proper to provide for two more opportunities to the defaulting tenant who does not dispute the fact of his being in arrears of rent for three months or more. The tenant gets protection against the action by the landlord to evict him on the ground of non-payment of rent if he avails of all the opportunities contemplated by Sub-sections (3) and (4) and complies with the same. In such event, the landlord has to be content only with the realization of all the arrears of rent.  [Para 9]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of default
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of default - Tenant admitting liability to pay arrears - Tenant's application to deposit upto date arrears - It is one under S. 22(4) and cannot be treated as one under S. 32(4) - Tenant cannot be given opportunity to explain cause of delay.

An application filed by the tenant seeking permission to deposit the upto date arrears of rent purports to be an application under Section 22(4) and not under Section 32(4) for the simple reason that the provisions of Section 32 come into picture when the tenant chooses to contest the proceedings including one on the ground of non-payment of rent. In the instant case there was no question of tenant contesting the proceedings, since the fact that the non-payment of rent by him was admitted by him. Therefore, the tenant's application for permission to deposit the upto date arrears of rent falls under Section 22(4) of the Act.  [Para 10,13,14]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Tenant set ex parte - No steps taken to set aside ex parte within limitation - His application for depositing upto date arrears could not be considered as one under S.22(4).

The tenant's application under Section 22(4) for depositing the arrears of rent could have been entertained by the Additional Rent Controller only after the tenant had succeeded in getting the exparte order set aside by showing that due to some unavoidable circumstance he was prevented from appearing before the Court on relevant date. Since he failed to make out a case for his absence, there was no question of considering his application under Section 22(4) and giving him an opportunity to show that his default was not without reasonable cause'.  [Para 13]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Demand notice
Address of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant on ground of arrears of rent - Demand notice - Address of tenant - It is not necessary to send notice to tenant's address of demised premises - Notice sent to tenant's address and received by his father - It can be held that tenant was duly served.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Appeal under
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Appeal under - Maintainability - For exercising jurisdiction U/S.32(1) petition or appeal must be properly constituted - Petition filed after limitation period - No jurisdiction to pass eviction order U/S.32(4) - Such jurisdiction would arise only when delay in filing appeal was condoned - Where no application for condonation of delay made - Order U/S.32(4) is illegal.	(Paras 8,9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - On ground of default in paying rent - Protection to tenant if arrears that are legally recoverable are paid within 30 days of issuance of notice by landlord - Payment contemplated by S.22(2) of Goa Rent Act is of full arrears as are legally recoverable - Tenant by paying part of arrears due, cannot ward off eviction proceedings - Paying part of arrears due neither discharges landlord's notice nor eviction proceedings become incompetent - To prevent any such interpretation legislature has consciously used the expression "such arrears as are legally recoverable". 	(Paras 16, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Act is beneficial legislation for benefit of tenants
HeadNote.description: Act is beneficial legislation for benefit of tenants - Undoubtedly it is to be interpreted liberally - However, benefits are given to tenants on certain conditions - And compliance with conditions is to be strictly viewed. 	(Para 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Are materially different
HeadNote.description: Eviction on ground of default in paying rent - Protection from eviction u/S.22(3) Goa Rent Act, on tenant paying arrears within 30 days of receipt of landlords notice - And protection u/S.22(4) when default is for reasonable cause - Are materially different - Tenant getting benefit of protection u/S.22(3) can also get benefit of S.22(4). 	(Para 23)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - On ground of default in paying rent - Protection on ground that default was for reasonable cause - Tenant running restaurant in demised premises - Plea that because of daughter's sickness, tenant was unable to look after his business and was in financial crisis - Record however showing that during that period tenant was earning substantial profit and was regularly paying substantial sum towards bills and salaries - Plea of reasonable cause for default cannot stand. 		(Para 29)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - On ground of default in paying rent - Failure of landlord to enter witness box - Immaterial, when tenant admits default but raises plea that default is for reasonable cause - In such case burden is not on landlord to prove default but is on tenant to prove his plea. 2004(5) ALL MR 396 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Para 35)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
Plea of equity
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - On ground of default in paying rent - Plea of equity - Proceedings protracting for 40 yrs. - Equity claimed on ground that during pendency of proceedings tenant regularly paid rent - Payment made was under pain of striking of defence - Can hardly be a ground to invoke equity jurisdiction. 			(Para 37)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of default in paying rent
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of default in paying rent - Show cause notice by Rent Controller - Compliance of preconditions for seeking eviction must be apparent in landlord's application - Eviction order in absence of satisfaction to that effect cannot be sustained.

Under S.22(2)(a) the Controller can invoke his jurisdiction to summon the tenant to show cause against his eviction on the ground of non-payment of rent only when the landlord discloses all the ingredients of the ground for eviction mentioned in sub-section (2)(a) of section 22 in the application for eviction by the landlord and not otherwise. An application which does not disclose the necessary particulars and facts regarding the period of default in payment of rent, issuance of necessary notice, failure on the part of the tenant to comply with the registered notice within thirty days from the receipt of such notice or refusal of such notice by the tenant, will not entitle the Controller to invoke the jurisdiction for issuance of show cause notice to the tenant in terms of sub-section (2)(a) of section 22.  [Para 5,6,7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Word "utility" in S.22(c)
HeadNote.description: Word "utility" in S.22(c) - Would mean the condition of being useful and profitable.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Defendant the tenant altering the external structure of the suit house by its shape, design and complexion without written consent of plaintiff the lessor - Held, plaintiff is certainly entitled for a decree of eviction against the defendants.

In the present case, the defendants had committed acts of damage which were likely to impair materially the value or utility of the building to the plaintiff.  On this aspect the evidence of the plaintiff has gone absolutely unchallenged.  The plaintiff had stated that his house was an ancestral house.  He had further stated that by reconstruction it had greatly affected the exterior look of the house.  He had also stated that by virtue of the said reconstruction it had also affected separately the value of the house.  Although the defendant might have incurred some expenditure for the said reconstruction and additions of rooms, looking at it from plaintiffs angle that expenditure instead of enhancing the value of the house, has diminished the same.  It is to be noted that there are many owners of houses who like to maintain their ancestral houses externally as they are, either because of family pride or sentimental value or aesthetic beauty or antiquity which in this case the defendants have impaired materially by the said reconstruction.

From whatever angle one looks at the case of the plaintiff, in the first suit, the plaintiff was certainly entitled for a decree of eviction against the defendants, under Section 22(2)(c) of the Act.  [Para 35,36]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Inventory proceedings
HeadNote.description: Portuguese Civil Code, Decree No.43525 - Inventory proceedings - Right of succession in "lease premises" - Available to married daughters - Portuguese Civil Code or Inventory Proceeding Act makes no distinction as to gender, order of birth or marital status - S.68 of Inventory Proceeding Act specifically provides for right of succession without distinction of sex or age - Whereas S.399 provides for inclusion of lease property in list of assets - Rejection of claim of married daughter by Courts below on basis of S.2(o) of Goa Rent Act, not sustainable - Rent Act not relevant, when dispute is not between landlord and tenant. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Bona fide personal requirement
HeadNote.description: Bona fide personal requirement - Landlord and his wife were having health problems and were required to live at Panaji and not at Ponda - Landlord not having any accommodation nearabout Panaji - Concurrent findings to this effect cannot be interfered with.	(Paras 6, 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Bona fide requirement for self and family members
HeadNote.description: Bona fide requirement for self and family members - After eviction order was passed landlord dying during pendency of appeal - Plea by tenant that need had ceased with the death of landlord and question of need will have to be re-examined - Not sustainable.	(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction on ground of bona fide requirement
HeadNote.description: Eviction on ground of bona fide requirement - Landlord a government servant - Had retired on 31-05-1983 - S.23-A(3) came in force from 27-02-1988 and was applicable to pending proceedings - Landlords need was proved by concurrent findings - High Court even without considering whether S.23-A(3) was prospective or retrospective in nature setting aside concurrent findings in favour of landlord - Held order could not be sustained.	(Paras 7, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Ground of sub-letting
Ingredients
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Ground of sub-letting - Ingredients - Parting with possession of tenancy in favour of third party with exclusive right of possession and such parting must be without consent of landlord and in lieu of compensation or rent.		 (Para 28)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Ground of sub-letting
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Ground of sub-letting - Inducting partner/partners in business or profession by tenant - When would amount to sub-letting.

Inducting a partner or partners in the business or profession by a tenant by itself does not amount to subletting. However, if the purpose of such partnership is ostensible and a deed of partnership is drawn to conceal the real transaction of sub-letting, the court may tear the veil of partnership to find out the real nature of transaction entered into by the tenant.

The existence of deed of partnership between tenant and alleged sub-tenant or ostensible transaction in any other form would not preclude the landlord from bringing on record material and circumstances, by adducing evidence or by means of cross-examination, making out a case of sub-letting or parting with possession in tenancy premises by the tenant in favour of a third person.

If tenant is actively associated with the partnership business and retains the control over the tenancy premises with him, may be along with partners, the tenant may not be said to have parted with possession.							 [Para 28]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Ground of sub-letting
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Ground of sub-letting - Presumption as to and burden to prove nature of occupation by third party - When shifts to tenant.

Initial burden of proving subletting is on landlord but once he is able to establish that a third party is in exclusive possession of the premises and that tenant has no legal possession of the tenanted premises, the onus shifts to tenant to prove the nature of occupation of such third party and that he (tenant) continues to hold legal possession in tenancy premises.

In other words, initial burden lying on landlord would stand discharged by adducing prima facie proof of the fact that a party other than tenant was in exclusive possession of the premises. A presumption of sub-letting may then be raised and would amount to proof unless rebutted.  [Para 28]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Ground of sub-letting
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Ground of sub-letting - Pleadings ought not to be construed too technically.

It has to be kept in mind that a transaction such as sub-letting by tenant which is not permissible under lease may be outwardly a deceptive arrangement and landlord may not come to know of true facts. The pleadings in such matters ought not to be construed too technically. The true test, as has been repeatedly said, is to see whether the other side has been taken by surprise or prejudiced.

If the purpose of constituting partnership by the tenant is ostensible and a deed of partnership is drawn to conceal the real transaction of subletting in a given case, the court may be required to tear the veil of partnership to find out the real nature of transaction entered into by the tenant and in such circumstances the evidence let in by the landlord cannot be ignored on the ground that there is some variance between pleading and proof. In a case such as the present one, the rule of secundum allegata et probata is not strictly applicable as the tenant cannot be said to have been put to any prejudice.						 [Para 29,30]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Ground of bonafide requirement - Respondent land lady acquired suit house through a Gift deed from her sister - She owns no other residential house - Adjoining house wherein landlady resides owned by her sister - Claim of land lady that she has been asked to leave that house, is plausible - Sister of land lady would naturally expect landlady to occupy the house so gifted and not house of such sister - Claim of tenant that landlady should live in that adjacent house to take care of her father and as her sister lives in some other city - Not acceptable - Landlord is the best judge of residential requirements - A tenant cannot dictate terms to the landlady - Eviction proper. (Paras 13, 14, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Scope
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Concurrent finding as to bonafide requirement of land lord - Interference in writ petition - Scope - Jurisdiction of HC is limited only to test whether findings arrived by authorities below are in accordance with law - Court cannot appreciate or re-appreciate evidence merely because it is inclined to take a different view on question of facts. (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Eviction proceedings - Amendment of 2013 providing for entitlement of widows to seek possession of premises in summary manner, brought in force during pendency of eviction proceedings - Landlady entitled to benefit of such amendment.
2008(2) ALL MR 345 (S.C.), (2002) 1 SCC 329 Ref.to.(Paras 18, 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Bona fide requirement
HeadNote.description:
Bona fide requirement - Landlord is the best judge of his residential requirement. 

The landlord is the best judge of his residential requirement and as such, it is for him or her to decide how and in what manner she should live. If the landlord desires the beneficial enjoyment of her own premises when the other premises are occupied, she cannot be subjected to an inconvenience as she has no other premises at her exclusive disposal. It is not the duty of the Court to dictate to her to continue to occupy such other premises which cause her inconvenience. In the present case, the records reveal that it is the contention of the respondent that grave inconvenience is caused to her as she has to travel from Margao from where she is presently coming to Panaji to pursue her legal profession. This will have to be accepted as the petitioner has not adduced any evidence to show that the respondents have other vacant residential premises.

2010(5) ALL MR 483 (S.C.), 2010(5) ALL MR 483 (S.C.) Rel. on.      [Para 15]

The Rent Control Legislation generally leanes in favour of the tenants but only in cases in which the eviction is sought of the tenant on account of bonafide requirement of the landlord for its own occupation when it treats the landlord with some sympathy.

2001 (8) SCC 561 Rel.on.      [Para 18]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Application for eviction
HeadNote.description: Application for eviction - Rent Controller can grant amendment of pleadings.		 	(Paras 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Ground of trespass
HeadNote.description: Suit for injunction and eviction - Ground of trespass - Plaintiffs averred in plaint that defendants were engaged by them temporarily in 1983 to run the business of a bar & restaurant in their absence - However said averments were not proved - In fact depositions of plaintiffs revealed that the business of restaurant was handed over to defendants in 1977 that too with their consent - Plaintiffs tried to mislead the Court and approached with unclean hands - Case of trespass as put by plaintiffs, became very weak - Suit dismissed.  (Paras 12 to 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Ground of unauthorized sub-letting - Suit premises handed over to third party on 7-10-1977 - Landlord consented to said transaction by his letter dated 4-11-1977 - Held consent U/S.22 need not necessarily be prior to transaction - Subsequent consent would also work in favour of defendants. 
AIR 1976 P & H 27 Rel. on.(Para 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Amendment in S.3(1)(c)
HeadNote.description:
Amendment in S.3(1)(c) - Substitution of word "fifteen" in place of "four" - Effect of amendment would be that a newly constructed building would mean a building in respect of which 15 years have not expired from date of construction - Contention that the word "newly" refers to date of amendment i.e. 5/5/1994, not tenable.

Section 3(1) (c) of the Rent Control Act, as is presently existing, provides that nothing in this Act shall apply to any newly constructed building for a period of "fifteen" years from the date of its completion. The word "fifteen" came to be substituted in place of the word "four" by virtue of amendment, which came into force as from 5.5.1994, in terms of Goa Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control (Amendment) Act 1993 published in the Official Gazette Series I, No. 5 dated 5/5/1994. Except for the change of the period from four years to fifteen years, there is no other change in the said provision. There is no dispute that the expression "newly constructed building" was there in that provision even prior to the amendment of the said clause (c). The amendment does not add the words "as from the date of coming into force of this amendment" after the expression "newly constructed building". The expression "newly constructed building" cannot be read literally to mean a recently constructed building. The entire clause (c) should be read. Newly constructed building means a building in respect of which a period of fifteen years has not expired from the date of completion of its construction. Prior to coming into force of the amendment, newly constructed building meant a building which had not completed four years from the date of completion of its construction. The meaning of newly constructed building, for the purposes of the Rent Control Act, has changed after the said amendment. Therefore, the submission of learned Counsel for the defendant that the word 'newly' means from the date of amendment i.e. from 5/5/1994 is without merit. 			     [Para 23]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Amendment in S.3(1)(c)
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Amendment in S.3(1)(c) - Substitution of word "fifteen" in place of "four" w.e.f. 5/5/1994 - Applicability - Construction of suit premises completed in Dec.1984 - Defendant inducted in it in 1985 - Therefore, defendant contended that as per old S.3 (1)(c), on expiry of four years period he become a protected tenant - Defendant further contended that subsequent amendment of 1994 would not apply to his case merely because the suit was filed against him in 1996 - Contention held to be not tenable - S.3 does not confer any substantive statutory right on defendant - It merely deals with non-applicability of Rent Act to certain buildings - After the provision is changed, defendant cannot claim old statutory protection - Fifteen years having not completed, Rent Act not applicable to suit premises.

The contention of learned counsel for the defendant that since the construction of the building consisting of suit premises was completed in December 1984 and defendant was inducted in the suit premises in the year 1985 and further since the period of four years from the date of completion of construction of the building, as contained in clause (c) of Section 3(1) of the Rent Control Act, prior to its amendment of 5/5/1994, had expired in December 1989, the defendant had already become a protected tenant since the Rent Control Act had become applicable to it, has no legal sanctity and cannot hold ground. Section 3 of the Rent control Act does not speak about accrual of any substantive right as a statutory tenant, under the Act but it deals with the non-applicability of the Act to certain buildings. The defendant had a right to take advantage and enjoy the said statutory protection as long as the provision remained in force and was applicable to it. As soon as the said provision changed, the defendant cannot claim to continue to have the old statutory protection. It was another thing if the plaintiff had filed the suit when the provision of Section 3(1)(c) of the Rent Control Act had the word "four" instead of "fifteen". In that case, the defendant could have taken advantage of the said provision to resist the eviction by the plaintiff.

Section 3 of the Rent Control Act, does not create any substantive rights in the tenant but it only provides for some protection or benefit, in certain eventualities mentioned therein. It imposes certain conditions for application of the Rent Control Act. The said protection or benefit can be utilized as long as it exists but a party cannot claim a vested right in the same and as soon as the said protection or benefit is taken away, the party cannot claim the same on the ground that it was previously existing. The plaintiff had not filed the suit prior to 5/5/1994, but had filed it on 19/3/1996. The beneficial provision as was existing on 19/3/1996, would apply.

Mere protection/benefit given by the provision does not give arise to any vested right. Therefore, merely because prior to 5/5/1994, the Rent Control Act did not apply to any newly constructed building for a period of four years from the date of completion and because the building consisting of suit premises had already completed the said period of four years, in or about 1989, it cannot be said that on account of the said protection of non-application of the Rent Control Act, a vested right, as protected tenant, accrued in favour of the plaintiff. If any proceedings for eviction were filed against the defendant prior to 5/5/1994, the defendant could have taken benefit of the said protection. However, as from 5/5/1994, the said provision of Clause (c) of Section 3(1) of the Rent Control Act changed and as per the amended provision, nothing in the Rent Control Act applies to any newly constructed building for a period of 15 years from the date of its completion. Admittedly, the building consisting of the suit premises was completed in December 1984. The suit was filed on 19/3/1996. The period of 15 years from the date of completion of the building had not expired as on the date of filing of the suit. Therefore, the Rent Control Act cannot apply to the suit premises.

AIR 1960 SC 936, (1984) 1 SCC 206, AIR 1984 Bom.144, (2003) 2 SCC 577 Disting.

AIR 1995 SC 1781 Rel. on. 					 	    [Para 23,24,30]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Amendment of S.3 (1)(cc) - Insertion of date "20/4/1994" in the provision - Applicability - Suit filed by landlord in 1996 - Subsequently in 1997, S.3(1)(cc) was amended by way of insertion of a date i.e. 20/4/1994 - Since on date of filing of suit "20/4/1994" was not existing in S.3(1)(cc), held, its subsequent insertion would not affect case of landlord filed earlier. 			(Para 32)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Stopping of proceedings u/S.32(4) - Legality - Tenants were in arrears of rent - Rents that were due for period from October, 1994 to March, 2012 were deposited only in 2012, rents for June, 2012 upto May, 2013 were deposited in 2013 and rents for period from June 2013 to July, 2014 were deposited in August, 2014 - From time to time tenants were allowed to deposit such arrears of rent in Court - Such defaults were not occasional but were persistent, which disentitled tenants for benefits of S.32 - No illegality in stopping proceedings u/S.32(4) with direction to put landlords in possession of suit premises. (2003)1 SCC 123 Ref. to. (Paras 16, 15, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - On ground of bonafide requirement - Contention that "bonafide" requirement of landlord for his personal occupation or for occupation of any member of his family, is not the requirement u/S.23(1)(a)(i) unlike S.23(1)(a)(ii) of Goa Act - Held, S.23(1)(a)(i) and 23(1)(a)(ii), both are concerned with ground of landlord requiring tenanted premises for his occupation (which includes occupation of his family members) - Only distinction is u/S.23(1)(a)(ii) that landlord has more than one building in the city, town or village where tenanted premises is situated - In such a case, S.23(1)(a)(ii) speaks about landlord establishing that such a building is bonafidely required for his own occupation - However, that cannot exclude such requirement u/S.23(1)(a)(i) of the Act - Therefore, said contention held not acceptable.	(Para 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Term "bonafide"
HeadNote.description: Term "bonafide" - Means it is genuine and real requirement and not a mere desire or wish or ipse dixit of landlord.	(Para 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - On ground of bonafide occupation - Son of deceased landlord does not have its own house which he could occupy and therefore require suit premises for his bonafide occupation - Evidence on record proves said fact - Tenant did not lead evidence to disprove this fact - Requirement set up by landlord not fanciful or unreasonable - Eviction of tenant, proper.		(Paras 22, 25)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - On ground of change of user - Suit house allotted to tenant for residential purpose - Plea that wife of deceased tenant is running a transport business and used to park and repair trucks in suit house and adjoining open space in same compound - Tenant had admitted in evidence that earlier gate which was there in suit premises was changed to an iron gate for allowing entry of truck in open adjoining space of suit house - This was done without consent of landlord - Change of user of premises proved by landlord - Eviction of tenant, proper.	(Para 33)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Illegal
HeadNote.description: Non-registration of lease deed - Consequent dismissal of eviction proceedings - Illegal - S.34 of Goa Act (1968) providing for registration, is not mandatory - Only two consequences of non-registration provided u/S.55, viz. (i) presumption as to terms and conditions of license as stated by licensee (ii) punishment of imprisonment - Right of landlord to get the tenant evicted, not taken away on account of non-registration. 2005(4) Bom.C.R. 383 Ref. to. 			(Paras 15, 21, 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction proceedings
HeadNote.description: Eviction proceedings - Grounds of non-payment of arrears of rent and subletting of premises - Tenant sought dismissal of proceedings on ground that even after commencement of Goa Act (1968), agreement of lease not reduced to writing and not registered - However, in earlier proceedings initiated for eviction of tenant, he had filed application u/S.32 whereby he was permitted to deposit arrears of rent with costs and proceedings against him were dropped - Filing of such application by tenant clearly indicates that he was admitting his tenancy - Otherwise he would not have taken recourse to said provision of Act - Prayer for dismissal not tenable. 			(Paras 16, 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Change of user
Shop and godown
Meaning of
Referred.	 [Para 12]
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Change of user - Shop and godown - Meaning of - If the premises is being used for the purpose of sale then it can be called as a shop and if it is used only for storing of goods then it can be called as a godown.

A shop is a place where the transaction of selling of the articles takes place and godown, i.e. ware house is a place where the articles which are merchandised are being stored which may be used for the purpose of sale as and when those are required. So, if the premises is being used for the purpose of sale, then it can be called as a shop and if it is used only for storing of goods then it can be called a godown.

1997 RCJ 783 - Referred.	 [Para 12]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Lease agreement
HeadNote.description:
Eviction on ground of change of user - Lease agreement - Has to be treated as the basis to decide the intention of the parties.

When a new lease agreement has come into existence, may be in the background of what it transpired between the parties, the lease agreement will have to be treated as the basis to decide the intention of the parties.

In the instant case the lease deed dated 21st January, 1972 is produced on record from page No.61 to 67.  After giving the background regarding how this lease deed came to be executed, the terms of lease are narrated in the lease deed and while giving the background of this lease deed, it must be noted that sometimes the suit premises is described as 'shop' and sometimes as 'room'.  While laying down the specific conditions of agreement with respect to lease, the term used is 'leased premises'.  These conditions are from Page No.66 to 68.  So, it appears that the premises is described not only as a shop, but even as room.  Therefore, it cannot be said that the parties intended to treat that premises only as shop premises.  When the wider term 'room' is used time and again for the description of the premises, then, the meaning cannot be restricted by describing the premises only as a shop.  If the parties had intended to treat that premises only as shop, then throughout this document the premises would have been described as shop and shop only.  But sometimes the premises is described as room and specially in condition (ix), neither the term 'shop' nor the 'room is used but the term is 'lease premises'. [Para 15,16,18]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Not mandatory
HeadNote.description: Requirement of execution of written lease deed - Not mandatory - Absence of written lease deed does not disentitle landlord to claim eviction of tenant.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction petition
HeadNote.description: Eviction petition - Act prescribes no period of limitation - And Rule-making power does not permit stipulation of limitation for filing eviction petition. (1999) 3 BCR 663 Foll.	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Old premises
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Causing damage as are likely to impair materially the value or utility of tenanted premises - Old premises - Tenant increasing height of floor by covering old floor by cement and kadappa stones - Act though reduces some cubic space of premises and also reduction in size of doors and windows of premises - Only constitutes alteration and not damage as is likely to impair materially the value or utility of the tenanted premises - Eviction order liable to be set aside. (1996) 2 SCC 626, (1999) 1 SCC 133, (2003)1 SCC 59, (2005)7 SCC 517, (1988)4 SCC 545, (1987)1 SCC 458, (1988)1 SCC 454, (1996) 2 SCC 626, 1999 1 SCC 133 Foll. (2005)1 SCC 8 Disting. 			(Paras 31, 35, 38)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
Ground
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Ground - Tenant causing damage as are likely to impair materially the value or utility of the tenanted premises - Real issue in cases under S.22(2)(c) is the inference to be drawn from proved facts - As such even though there is concurrent finding on fact of damage caused by tenant if inference drawn is wrong, Court under Art.227 can interfere with order passed.			(Paras 35, 38)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description: Eviction - On ground of transfer of rights under lease/ sub-letting - Premises let out for doing hospitality business - Landlord alleging that partnership formed by wives of tenants was exclusively using portion of tenanted premises for business of selling sweets - Even income from sale of sweets was also shown in IT returns of Firm - Evidence however showing that tenants themselves were running this business and partnership deed was only a measure of tax planning - Tenants cannot be said to have transferred rights or sublet premises - Landlord not entitled to eviction decree. (2005(1) SCC 481, (2004)4 SCC 794 Rel.on.	(Para 41)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description: Eviction - On ground, of change of user - Premises let for running of "Hospedaria" - Use of premises to manufacture and sell sweets - Not change of user. (1992)2 BCR 698 Foll. (2004)6 SCC 166, (2004)6 SCC 166, (2005)7 SCC 643 Ref.to.			(Paras 47, 50, 54)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Ground of non-payment or deposit of rent during pendency of eviction proceedings - Suit premises given on lease to tenant on monthly rent of Rs.300/- - Whatever payments of rent made were matters of record - Conduct of enquiry u/S.32(3) was not necessary - Further, despite opportunity to make payment/deposit during pendency of proceedings, tenant failed to comply - Earlier also on two occasions tenant defaulted in making payment of rent - It shows that he was habitual defaulter and default was not casual or stray default - Eviction of tenant, proper.	(Paras 15, 16, 21, 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Stopping of proceedings u/S.32(4) - Sufficient cause - When tenant demonstrated that there were some reasons which prevented him from making payment of rents and those defaults were only occasional and not persistent, Court may be justified in holding that sufficient cause is shown. 2000(3) ALL MR 626, 2013(2) GLT 630 (Bom) (PB), 1995(1) GLT 117 Ref. to. 	(Para 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969)
heading: Tenant
Definition of
HeadNote.description: Tenant - Definition of - Sons who had not been living with tenant as member of his family upto date of his death - Would not be included in definition of “tenant” - Not necessary to bring them on record after death of tenant - Landlord, would be entitled to order of eviction straight away against LRs. of deceased, statutory tenant. (Paras 14, 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969)
heading: Powers of Appellate Board
HeadNote.description: Powers of Appellate Board - District Judge acting and exercising powers as Appellate Board - Does not act as "Personal Designata" - R.9(3) of Goa Rules 1969 providing that Appellate Board shall follow procedure under CPC - It would include power under O.47 CPC for review of its own judgment and order - Plea on basis of second proviso to S.47 of Act that finality having been attached to orders passed in, appeal or revision, the power of review stands excluded by necessary implication - Not tenable. AIR 1973 Ker. 214 Disting. (Paras 27, 30)

headline:
Goa, Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968), Ss.41, 32(4) – Goa, Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969), R.9(3) – Powers of Appellate Board – District Judge acting and exercising powers as Appellate Board – Does not act as "Personal Designata"
R.9(3) of Goa Rules 1969 providing that Appellate Board shall follow procedure under CPC – It would include power under O.47 CPC for review of its own judgment and order - Finality of orders and exclusion of power of review, on basis of second proviso to S.47 of Act, held not tenable

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of change of user etc.
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of change of user etc. - Tenant not depositing rent during pendency of proceedings - Landlord's application under S.32(4) served on tenant - Dues not deposited within 30 days after service of notice - Stopping of proceeding is valid.

Under S.32(1) no tenant against whom proceedings for eviction have been instituted by a landlord shall be entitled to contest the proceedings before the Controller or any appellate or revisional authority, or to prefer any appeal or revision under the Act unless he has paid to the landlord or deposits with the Controller or the appellate or revisional authority, as the case may be, all arrears of rent due in respect of the building upto the date of payment or deposit and continues to pay or deposit rent which may be subsequently due in respect of the building until the termination of proceedings before the Controller or appellate or revisional authority. In terms of Rule 7 of the Rules the tenant is to deposit within 30 days from date on which the notice is served.  [Para 6]

Some of the factors which are relevant for exercising power under Section 32(4) of the Act, are whether the default is for a short period or long period, whether the default is wilful or intentional, whether the default is consistent or persistent, whether the payment was made at the earliest opportunity or after cantankerous contest and whether it was bona fide or to harass the landlord. In the instant case the default is for a period of more than four years. The default is consistent and persistent even inspite of clear provisions of law that the tenant is required to pay the rent during the pendency of the proceedings. The tenant did deposit the rent, but after cantankerous contest and just prior to the passing of the Order by the Additional Rent Controller and that the failure to deposit the rent can, by no stretch of imagination, be said to be bona fide. In these circumstances, it can be said that the authorities have exercised discretion in accordance with law and there is absolutely no reason for the High Court to interfere with the discretion exercised by the authorities.  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Tenant set ex parte - No steps taken to set aside ex parte within limitation - His application for depositing upto date arrears could not be considered as one under S.22(4).

The tenant's application under Section 22(4) for depositing the arrears of rent could have been entertained by the Additional Rent Controller only after the tenant had succeeded in getting the exparte order set aside by showing that due to some unavoidable circumstance he was prevented from appearing before the Court on relevant date. Since he failed to make out a case for his absence, there was no question of considering his application under Section 22(4) and giving him an opportunity to show that his default was not without reasonable cause'.  [Para 13]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969)
heading: Eviction of tenant on ground of default in paying rent
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of tenant on ground of default in paying rent - Show cause notice by Rent Controller - Compliance of preconditions for seeking eviction must be apparent in landlord's application - Eviction order in absence of satisfaction to that effect cannot be sustained.

Under S.22(2)(a) the Controller can invoke his jurisdiction to summon the tenant to show cause against his eviction on the ground of non-payment of rent only when the landlord discloses all the ingredients of the ground for eviction mentioned in sub-section (2)(a) of section 22 in the application for eviction by the landlord and not otherwise. An application which does not disclose the necessary particulars and facts regarding the period of default in payment of rent, issuance of necessary notice, failure on the part of the tenant to comply with the registered notice within thirty days from the receipt of such notice or refusal of such notice by the tenant, will not entitle the Controller to invoke the jurisdiction for issuance of show cause notice to the tenant in terms of sub-section (2)(a) of section 22.  [Para 5,6,7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Rules (1969)
heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Stopping of proceedings u/S.32(4) - Legality - Tenants were in arrears of rent - Rents that were due for period from October, 1994 to March, 2012 were deposited only in 2012, rents for June, 2012 upto May, 2013 were deposited in 2013 and rents for period from June 2013 to July, 2014 were deposited in August, 2014 - From time to time tenants were allowed to deposit such arrears of rent in Court - Such defaults were not occasional but were persistent, which disentitled tenants for benefits of S.32 - No illegality in stopping proceedings u/S.32(4) with direction to put landlords in possession of suit premises. (2003)1 SCC 123 Ref. to. (Paras 16, 15, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Entertainment Tax Act (1964)
heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Cls.2 and 3 of Scheme explains precise purpose of formulation of 2004 Scheme - Clauses of scheme have to be construed in entirety and in harmony with one another - Over emphasis on Cl.4 alone would not be proper - Thus, scheme was formulated to assist existing cinema halls/theaters which were in bad shape and which required Govt. support by way of "incentives and concessions" in order to upgrade themselves upto required standard - Said scheme was not formulated to extend any assistance to brand new multiplexes - Benefit under scheme cannot also be extended to multiplex theatre constructed on Govt. land by agency, instrumentality of State Govt.	(Paras 26, 28, 37, 38, 39, 42, 43)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Excise Duty Act (1964)
heading: Condonation of delay in filing appeal
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay in filing appeal - S.5 of Limitation Act is applicable - Held, sufficient cause for condonation of delay existed and appeal was required to be heard on merits. (Paras 17, 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Government Assistant Conservator of Forests (Sub-Divisional Forest Officer) Gazetted Posts Recruitment Rules (1982)
heading: Subsequent training period
HeadNote.description:
Recruitment under old Rules - Portion of training period spent after coming into force of new Rules - Conditions of service to be governed by Rules from time to time - Held, training period spent after coming into force of new Rules was to be counted for purpose of seniority.

AIR 1990 SC 405 and JT 1993(1) SC 360 Disting.

Recruitment under old Rules - Subsequent training period - Portion of training period overlapping to the period after coming into force of new Rules whereunder training period was to be treated as in-service - Question of inclusion of training period in-service. (Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Irrigation Act (1973)
heading: Public Interest Litigation
HeadNote.description: Public Interest Litigation - Challenging permission for relocation of pond - On ground that alterations and realignment of water bodies will severely affect hydro dynamics of area and it would affect eco sensitivity of area - Disputed pond located in private property and not in use by public - Also necessary permissions were obtained from authorities for relocation of pond - Nothing on record to show that such relocation would affect environment - Environment degradation, if any, is under consideration before National Green Tribunal and cannot be examined in present petition - Nothing wrong in granting permission for relocation of pond - Conditions imposed while granting permission directed to be strictly followed.   (Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Judicial Commissioner's Court Regulation (1963)
heading: Goa, Daman and Diu Judicial Commissioner's Court (Declaration as High Court) Act (1964), S.6
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Judicial Commissioner's Court (Declaration as High Court) Act (1964), S.6 - Judgment of Division Bench - Judgment not per incuriam - Held, it would, therefore, be inappropriate to sit in appeal over the earlier decision taken in the said case and to take a view contrary to the decision taken therein. 2008 ALL SCR 224 - Ref. to. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Kerosene Oil (Export and Price) Control Order (1975)
heading: Framing of charge
HeadNote.description:
Allegation of Commission of offence under provisions of order - Framing of charge - Materials should disclose factual ingredients constituting offence - Framing of charge in absence of materials - Order cannot be sustained.

At the stage of framing of charge, the Court has not to apply the standard of test, proof and Judgment which is to be normally applied at the final stage while deciding whether the accused is guilty of the offence or not.  However, at that stage the Magistrate has to find out from the materials before it whether such materials disclose factual ingredients constituting the offence alleged.  The conclusion regarding strong suspicion about the commission of offence can be arrived at only when the Court finds existence of such factual ingredients alleged against a person.  [Para 6]

Clause 4(i) of the order of 1975 requires that no person should sell or abet the sale of kerosene oil to any person at a price in excess of the price notified by the Government.  The materials, therefore, should disclose that the accused person has either attempted to sell or abet the sale of kerosene at the price in excess of the price notified.  [Para 7]

Considering the materials on record, there is no case made out for framing of charge for the alleged offence against the accused Petitioner and, therefore, the impugned Order cannot be sustained and is liable to be quashed and set aside.  The Petition, therefore, succeeds.  The impugned Order is quashed and set aside.  [Para 9]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Khadi and Village Industries Board Act (1965)
heading: Khadi Village Industries Board (K.V.I.B)
HeadNote.description:
Khadi Village Industries Board (K.V.I.B) - Subsidy amount kept in fixed deposit receipt - Revocation of such subsidy deposit - Revocation can be done only if the beneficiary does not utilize the funds to the satisfaction of the Board (K.V.I.B).

Condition no.23 of the Margin Money Scheme gives power to the Board to revoke the subsidy amount kept in fixed deposit receipt in case the beneficiary fails to utilize the funds to the satisfaction of K.V.I.B. Once the Board accepts the project profile and agrees to sanction subsidy, it has to forward the subsidy amount to the concerned bank to be kept in fixed deposit receipt in the name of the beneficiary for a minimum period of two years and thereafter to adjust the same along with interest accrued thereon towards the repayment of last installment of the loan. Revocation of such subsidy deposit can be done only if the beneficiary does not utilize the funds to the satisfaction of the Board, which is not the case in the present matter. Therefore, the defendant no. 1, in the present case, could not have denied its liability to pay the subsidy amount to the plaintiff.     [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Acquisition Rules (1972)
heading: Objection for acquisition
HeadNote.description: Objection for acquisition - Procedure under R.4 not followed - Land Acquisition Officer completely ignored specific objection that land in question is not suitable for developing playground viz. purpose for acquisition and there is alternative barren land - Enquiry by Land Acquisition Officer being farce, it impaired decision making process of State Government in issuing notification under S.6 - Report under S.5-A cannot be sustained - Notification under S.6 set aside. 	(Paras 12, 16, 17, 18, 20, 22, 23, 31, 33)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue (Partition of Holdings) Rules (1969)
heading: Partition
HeadNote.description: Partition - Application for, by purchaser of property - Co-holders of property raising dispute as to title of purchaser - In view of S.61(2) of Goa Land Revenue Code, Collector has to lay off his hands from partition proceedings till issue of title is decided by civil court - This limitation contained in S.61(2) cannot be taken away by Rules 2 and 7 of Partition of Holdings Rules, 1969. 		(Paras 12, 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue (Record of Rights and Register of Cultivators) Rules (1969)
heading: Survey of village promulgated
HeadNote.description:
Survey of village promulgated - Irregularity found by Govt. in Survey records - Inquiry in the matter is not barred under S.14(3).

Where survey in respect of a village is promulgated and the Govt. finds some irregularity in records, an inquiry under S.14(3) by the authority becomes necessary. There is no restriction on holding such inquiry. As Section 14(3), on the face of it, does not provide for any such restriction, on plain reading of Chapter VIII, with Rules 6 and 7 of the said Rules, does not, in any manner, suggest any such restriction on inquiry under Section 14(3). In fact, any such interpretation of Section 14(3) would amount to reading something in Section 14(3) which has not been provided for by the Legislature in its wisdom. The inquiry under Section 14(3), pursuant to the claim by the Government, can therefore, be held even after promulgation of record of rights in respect of any land.  [Para 5]

Section 96 in the said Chapter VIII, speaks about acquisition of rights only. It does not speak about existing right or obligation of any person to inform about such existing rights to the Talathi. It is only when a person acquires right by way of succession, survivorship, inheritance or partition, purchase, mortgage, gift, lease or otherwise, any right as holder, occupant, mortgagee, landlord, tenant or Government Lessee of any land that such person should inform about the acquisition of such right. Section 96 does provide that the person acquiring any right in the manner specified thereunder, as well as 'otherwise' to inform about the same to the Talathi. According to the Rule of 'ejusdem generis' the word 'otherwise' has to be understood.  [Para 7]

Rule 6 of the said Rules does not provide that Talathi before preparing the draft of the index in Form III has to collect information by making local inquiry, but such inquiry cannot be beyond the scope of Sections 96 and 97. In other words, the information that is required to be collected by the Talathi is in relation to the properties claimed by private persons or belonging to the private persons. The local inquiry by Talathi under Rule 6 does not include the claim of the Government or in relation to the Government land.  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue (Record of Rights and Register of Cultivators) Rules (1969)
heading: Land records
HeadNote.description: Land records - Presumption of occupancy and possession - Name of appellant shown to have been entered in index of land under form No.III - Form No.III is only a draft of index which is subject to correction and promulgation - There can be no presumption regarding correctness of entry in Form No.III - Same cannot confer any title upon appellant - Mere production of Form No.III cannot prove occupation or possession. (Para 21)

headline: Goa, Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968), S. 32 (As amended by Amendment Act, 2013) – Relevant date for fixing conversion charges for conversion of user of land will be date on which decision is taken to grant Sanad.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968) S. 32 (As amended by Amendment Act 2013)
heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Conversion of user of land - Levy of conversion charges - Challenge to - On ground that conversion charges should be fixed as per rates applicable on date of application - Relevant date for fixing conversion charges will be date on which decision is taken to grant Sanad - Landowner filed affidavit and undertook to pay demanded charges and not to sue for recovery of any excess conversion charges and accordingly deposited conversion charges - Landowner also obtained all necessary permission and thereafter challenge levy of conversion charges - Landowner not entitled to challenge levy of conversion charges in view of his own acts, deeds and conduct. (Paras 14, 22, 23)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Suit for ownership
Counter claim
HeadNote.description: Suit for ownership - Counter claim - Defendants-State claiming that name of plaintiffs be struck off from survey of suit property - Subject matter of suit is forest property and in records it is in name of plaintiffs as well as defendants - Evidence showing that name of plaintiffs was illegally recorded in record of rights of suit property - It also does not establish any claim of plaintiffs over suit property - Plaintiffs failed to justify continuance of their names in survey records - Additional evidence brought on record by State, support counter claim of defendants - Counter claim of defendants is to be allowed. 	(Paras 18, 19, 23, 26, 28, 30)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Preliminary decree for partition
HeadNote.description: Preliminary decree for partition - Permissibility, in absence of any inventory proceedings or a public deed of division - Objection by defendants that suit property was never assessed to land revenue - Not sustainable in view of O.20 R.18(2) of CPC - S.51 of Land Revenue Code also deems the assessment - Besides, suit property bears matriz no. which pertains to revenue record - S.61 of Revenue Code also provides for division and apportionment of holdings - No interference.(Paras 19, 20, 21, 26)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Non grant of NOC
HeadNote.description:
Non grant of NOC - Petitioner's application for conversion of land from agricultural to non agricultural purpose rejected - Communication sent that area is identified as forest area - Petitioners intending to build residential houses in area - Survey conducted by Forest Department - Report states that lands in petition do not form part of forest area - Communications issued by respondent no. 3 is liable to be set aside - Respondent to decide applications for conversion of properties considering that said area is not part of Private Forest.

1997 (2) SCC 267 Ref. to. 	 [Para 22,23]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Conversion of land
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Conversion of land - Challenge - On ground that said conversion results into demolition of public pond - Perusal of photographs of location and survey record, shows nothing to point out existence of such public pond - Mere accumulation of water which is stored for consumption of animal, cannot by itself be natural pond for benefit of villagers or public at large - It was also not admittedly maintained by local authority nor visited by any villager - Hence, conversion of land is proper.

Only when the ponds are natural ponds, which is a natural wealth, the Courts can take measures to protect such ponds. The material resources of the community like forests, tanks, ponds, hillocks, mountain, etc., are nature's bounty. They maintain delicate ecological balance. They need to be protected for a proper and healthy environment which enables people to enjoy a quality life which is essence of the guaranteed right under Article 21 of the Constitution. In case, there was a pond on the subject site, it would have been the duty of the Authorities to develop the same which would, on one hand, have prevented ecological disaster and on the other, provided a better environment for the benefit of the public at large.  [Para 8,9,10]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Imposition of penalty
HeadNote.description: Imposition of penalty - Directing petitioners to restore land and undo development undertaken on it - Penalty imposed on petitioners for use of orchard land for illegally developing plots, hill cutting, constructing road by rubble and laterite stones and cutting trees without permission - Site visit report and inspection report shows that property was developed by petitioners as alleged by Collector in notice - No rebuttal from petitioners that they demarcated plot and sold to different persons - Construction put up by petitioner was illegal, without obtaining conversion under provisions of Code therefore liable for demolition - Order directing to restore land by demolition of construction, proper. 			(Paras 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Filing of suit
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.7 R.11 - Filing of suit - Limitation - Order dismissing appeal u/S.14(3) of Goa Land Revenue Code passed on 12.5.2011 in open Court - Both parties or their representatives present when said order was passed - There was corrigendum to said order on 20.5.2011 for correction of typographical errors - Certified copy issued on 23.5.2011 - Suit against said order filed on 23-5-2012 - Held, barred by limitation being filed beyond one year as prescribed u/S.14(5) - Provision as to exclusion of time required for obtaining certified copy, not attracted - Rejection of plaint, being barred by limitation, was proper. (Paras 19, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Presumption u/S.105
HeadNote.description: Presumption u/S.105 - Is rebuttable. (Para 23)

heading: Injunction

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Correction of entries in survey records
HeadNote.description: Correction of entries in survey records - Jurisdiction of civil court - Revenue entries made in record of rights are required to be corrected by Mamlatdar/Talathi - Civil Court should leave issue of removing/deleting name of defendant from revenue records to Talathi - Order passed by Civil Court directing removal of name of defendants from survey records, liable to be set aside. 2005(1) Goa L.R. 47 Rel. on. heading: Survey record

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Not acceptable
HeadNote.description:
Civil suit against order under Art.14(3) - Limitation of one year - Impugned order passed on 24.10.2002 and civil suit filed on 24.10.2003 - Section 12(1) of Limitation Act will come into play i.e. date on which order was passed, would be excluded for computing limitation - Civil suit filed within limitation - Contention that Land Revenue Code is a complete Code in itself and provisions of Limitation Act shall not apply - Not acceptable - No provision in Land Revenue Code excludes applicability of Limitation Act. 
AIR 1961 SC 1500, (2009) 5 SCC 791, AIR 1989 SC 1477 Ref. to. 	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Presumption not rebutted
HeadNote.description: Application for re-survey with amalgamation of additional area - Title over additional area disputed - Sale deed produced by the applicant did not show area of land nor any plan was annexed - Sale deed also does not show source of title of seller - Considering absence of document to show source of title and description of property (near a river), presumption under Art.14(1) would arise that property belongs to Govt. - Presumption not rebutted - Claim of applicants unsustainable under Art.14(3). HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Partition of holdings
Jurisdiction of Collector
HeadNote.description: Partition of holdings - Jurisdiction of Collector - Is by implication of consent. 	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Partition
HeadNote.description: Partition - Application for, by purchaser of property - Co-holders of property raising dispute as to title of purchaser - In view of S.61(2) of Goa Land Revenue Code, Collector has to lay off his hands from partition proceedings till issue of title is decided by civil court - This limitation contained in S.61(2) cannot be taken away by Rules 2 and 7 of Partition of Holdings Rules, 1969.
