HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Partition
HeadNote.description: Partition - Application for, by purchaser of property - Objection raised by petitioner who is heir of one of co-holder - Disputed land is a large plot of about 28 lacs sq. mtr - There are 10 co-holders - Some of them sold about 10 lacs sq. mtr land to respondent - Respondent seeking partition and allotment of separate survey number to his portion - However, civil suit for declaration of title in respect of said property already filed by another co-holder - S.61(2) of Goa Land Revenue Code bars partition when title is disputed - Contention that title not disputed by petitioner, not tenable - Petitioner in any event was claiming inheritance through his grand-father - Further contention that property purchased by respondent is identifiable from sale deed, also of no assistance - Once title of land disputed, Collector has to lay off his hands from partition proceedings - Decision of Collector and Administrative Tribunal in allowing partition while taking "pragmatic view" of matter, was contrary to mandate of S.61(2) - Liable to be set aside.			(Paras 12, 27, 28)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Suit against Government
Bar to
HeadNote.description: Suit against Government - Bar to - Relief of deletion of name of father of defendant appearing in column of occupant in revenue record - Cannot be granted by the trial court in view of specific bar contained in S.106.			(Para 5, 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968)
heading: Discharge of accused
Rejection of application
Validity
HeadNote.description: Judges (Protection) Act (1985), Ss.2, 3 - Penal Code (1860), Ss.19, 77 - Discharge of accused - Rejection of application - Validity - Prosecution case that petitioner in capacity of Collector conspired and without following proper procedure, gave permission for non-agricultural (NA) use of land in favour of accused thereby causing wrongful gain to them - Grant of permission for N.A. is neither a formal nor a summary but it is an ordinary inquiry - Proceedings of ordinary inquiry are not deemed to be judicial proceedings - Hence, not covered u/S.180 of Land Revenue Code - By virtue of S.165(2), Revenue Court shall be treated as Civil Court - Collector does not enjoy immunity which is available u/S.3 of Judges Protection Act and u/S.77 of IPC - There is evidence to frame charge against petitioner - Hence, not a case for discharge. 2013 ALL MR (Cri) 933 Disting. (Paras 14, 16, 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mamlatdar's Court Act (1966)
heading: Injunction

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mamlatdar's Court Act (1966)
heading: Exclusion of time

(Paras 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) (Amendment) Act (1985)

heading: "Dwelling House"
Scope

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Execution of decree
HeadNote.description: Execution of decree - Directing petitioners/judgment debtors to remove illegal construction and restraining them from making illegal construction - Objected by petitioners on ground that they have applied for declaration as mundkars - Mundkarial rights claimed in respect of another property - Decision in mundkarial proceedings will not have any bearing on executability of decree - Also objection on basis of mundkarial rights was raised for first time - Dismissal of application objecting execution of decree, proper.			(Paras 10, 11, 13, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Execution
Order of demolition
HeadNote.description: Execution - Order of demolition - Issue of Mundkarship in respect of disputed property, pending before authority under Mundkar Act - Execution of demolition of structure on disputed land is to be stayed - Such stay however would not affect the removal of vegetation, fencing or any plantation etc. on the public road.  (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Application under S.8A
Dismissal by
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Application under S.8A - Dismissal by - Challenge to - Petitioner by filing an application under S.8-A against the respondents, claimed that he was their mundakar - Respondents encroached on government land and had built the house illegally - When the petitioner came to occupy it in the year 1974 or thereabout, the respondents were not the owners of land - From the year 1985, they have been granted occupancy rights, class II - Held, the petitioner's application could have been dismissed by the Mamlatdar in terms of R.14(5)(c)(i) of the said Rules - That exercise has now been done by the Administrative Tribunal - This is not a fit case for interference in exercise of supervisory jurisdiction. 2006(1) G.L.R. 585 - Ref. to.			(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Proceedings before Mamlatdar
Petition for stay
HeadNote.description: Proceedings before Mamlatdar - Petition for stay - Where evidence of parties is complete, held, there is no case for interdiction in writ jurisdiction.	(Para 2)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Eviction of defendant
Challenge to
Plea of Mundkarship
HeadNote.description: Eviction of defendant - Challenge to - Plea of Mundkarship - Once the issue of mundkarship was decided against the defendant, held, the plaintiff is entitled to the decree of eviction of the defendant. (1998)4 SCC 539 - Ref. to.	(Paras 10, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Jurisdiction of Administrative Tribunal in revision
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Administrative Tribunal in revision - Cannot reassess evidence and interfere with finding of Addl. Collector.

The Adm. Tribunal in its revisional jurisdiction cannot reassess evidence and interfere with finding of Addl. Collector.  This is not permissible in revisional jurisdiction which is restricted in terms of Section 115 of the Civil Procedure Code.  The Administrative Tribunal could not have interfered with the findings of the Addl. Collector rendered in appeal in exercise of revisional jurisdiction unless it was shown that the Addl. Collector had exercised jurisdiction not vested in law or has failed to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it or had acted in the exercise of its jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity.  The Administrative Tribunal, on assessment of evidence on record, had not come to the conclusion that the findings rendered by the Addl. Collector were perverse, but came to the conclusion that the Addl. Collector had not given any good reason to disturb the findings and he was wrong in declaring the petitioner to be a mundkar.  [Para 4]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Exemptions
HeadNote.description: Exemptions - Property belonging to Christian institution - Provisions of Act do not apply - Application filed by persons claiming mundkarship in respect of house belonging to institution - Institution is necessary party to proceedings - Rejection of application discloses non application of mind by authorities - Provision of Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act could not be referred to as the two Acts are not in pari materia. (Para 7,8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Scope
Commencement of Act
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Agreement permitting a person to construct hut at his cost - After 15 years Bhatkar to resume it - Commencement of Act - Person in possession of hut on appointed day - Entitled to be registered as mundkar - Cannot be evicted.

The essential ingredients for a person to claim mundkarial right within the definition under S.2(p) are that he should be lawfully residing with the consent of bhatkar with a fixed habitation in a dwelling house.  The appointed date on which the status of a person as mundkar has to be determined is 12-3-1976 and if a person on that day satisfies the requirements contained in Section 2(p), he is entitled to get registration as a mundkar in terms of Section 29(4) of the Act.  [Para 4,5]

In the instant case an agreement was entered into between the landholder and the applicant claiming to be registered as mundkar in the year 1969 whereby the applicant was permitted to construct a barrack of mud with the cover of Mangalore tiles, consisting of two compartments, in a small tract of land covering an area of 50 sq. metres and of the length of 30 feet and breadth of 15 feet on his own expenses of approximately Rs.6,000/- and in terms of the said agreement, he was to possess the said dwelling house as his own during the period of 15 years and, at the end of 15 years, the said barrack would belong to the landholder.  The agreement was entered into when Diploma No.1952 was in force and under the said Diploma, mundkar was required to render services like watch and ward duties for the purpose of agriculture and the said concept of mundkar as propounded in the said Diploma was retained in the temporary legislation, namely, The Goa, Daman and Diu (Protection of Mundkars, Agricultural Labourers and Village Artisans) Act, 1971, which was finally replaced by the Act of 1975.  On the appointed date the applicant did satisfy the said requirements and as such was certainly lawfully residing with the consent of the bhatkar with a fixed habitation in the dwelling house.  In view of the provisions of S.4 notwithstanding the conditions in the Agreement of 1969 permitting the applicant to reside in the barrack constructed by him for 15 years, only at the end of which the barrack would belong to the Bhatkar, the occupation of the said barrack by the applicant as on 12th March 1976 i.e. the appointed date and thereafter would be that of a mundkar and, therefore, he would be entitled to register himself as mundkar of the barrack under Section 29(4) of the Act.  [Para 5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Eviction of Mundkar
HeadNote.description:
Eviction of Mundkar - He cannot be forced to shift to another site at sweet will of landlord.

Under the Mundkar Act, a mundkar is entitled to remain where the dwelling house is and within the plinth area, he is entitled to construct or reconstruct the house.  He cannot be forced to shift from the existing mundkarial house to another site at sweet-will of the landlord.  [Para 5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Dispute by Mundkar alleging encroachment by another mundkar on dwelling house
HeadNote.description:
Dispute by Mundkar alleging encroachment by another mundkar on dwelling house - Area of dwelling house not demarcated or divided by Mamlatdar - Suit alleging violation of rights is not maintainable.

The definition of the dwelling house in Section 2(i) does not, by itself, create any right in the land around the house. The right assured under the said provision is to the extent that the mundkar can opt for the purchase of an area to the extent of 5 metres around or appurtenant to the house in villages and 2 metres around or appurtenant to the house in cities or 300 metres in total in village and 200 metres in total in cities.  Beyond the said option assured to the mundkar for the purpose of purchase of the house in occupation of the mundkar, the definition of the term "dwelling house" by itself does not create any right or interest in the land around or appurtenant to the house in favour of mundkar.  As to the exact extent and the location of this area around the dwelling house, the same has necessarily to be decided by the Mamlatdar.  Such a question will necessarily be an issue to be decided by the Mamlatdar under Section 8-A r/w. Secs. 15 & 2(i) of the Mundkar Act and the jurisdiction of the Civil Court to decide such issue would stand excluded in view of the specific provision to that effect in Section 31(2) of the Mundkar Act.  [Para 6]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction - Suit for declaration of ownership over a mundkarial house and eviction of defendant - Defendant claiming herself to be owner and denying the suit property to be mundkarial - Issues not covered by Mundkars Act - Civil Court would have jurisdiction to entertain the suit. 		(Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Denial of title of land-lord - Mere claiming of right as mundkar under Mundkar Act in respect of the house - Does not amount to denial of title of land-lord within the meaning of S.21 r/w. S.22(1)(g) of the Rent Act.

Merely because a person has claimed the right to reside in a mundkarilal house, it cannot be said that he has denied the title of the bhatkar.  In fact he accepts the title but claims protection of the Mundkar Act.  Precisely in this case petitioners only claimed the statutory protection under the Mundkar Act and it was an error to read as denial of title of the landlord.  In fact they accepted the title and claimed protection.  Section 15 of the Mundkar Act gives right to a mundkar to purchase the mundkarial house and to a limited extent land below the house.  This is on payment to the landlord.  Thus there is recognition of title by the mundkar of the landlord.  Position can be visulised under various statutes giving protection to weaker community persons.  The question involved in such proceedings is very limited as in the present case whether petitioners can get protection of Mundkar Act.  If it is held that they get protection then legal consequences follow.  But claiming of such protection cannot amount to denial of title.	  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkar is entitled to protection against eviction from his dwelling house
HeadNote.description:
Mundkar is entitled to protection against eviction from his dwelling house - Dwelling house includes cowshed also - Dispute arising under Act can be decided by authority under Act - Jurisdiction of civil court is barred under S. 31 - Decree of perpetual injunction granted by civil Court is illegal.

There is, no doubt that the plaintiff, who is a mundkar enjoys protection under the Mundkar Act against eviction from his dwelling house which includes his cowshed also. Since the plaintiff has sought the relief of perpetual injunction against the defendants, it is for him to show that his cowshed and fencing which were destroyed by the defendants, were within the permissible limits mentioned in sub-clause (i) (a) and (b) of clause (i) of Section 2. Once the plaintiff proves this fact, then he is entitled to be protected so far as his dwelling house including the cowshed are concerned. In that event, the defendants, even though they have acquired the land occupied by the plaintiff's cowshed under a Gift Deed, cannot demolish the same in order to carry out the construction of a road.  [Para 6]

The questions as to what is the extent of areas of the dwelling house of the plaintiff as a mundkar and whether the fencing and cowshed of the plaintiff are within or outside the said area are essentially the questions which are, under the Mundkar Act, required to be settled, decided or dealt with by the Mamlatdar or the Collector. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to decide the said questions is clearly barred by Section 31(2) of the Mundkar Act. Consequently the Civil Court cannot grant the relief of perpetual injunction to the plaintiff, assuming that the cowshed and the fencing are within the area of permissible limit stated in Section 2(i) (i) of the Mundkar Act. The order of Court which granted the decree of perpetual injunction in favour of the plaintiff results in failure of justice since there is material irregularity.  [Para 7,9]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Applicant claiming right as mundkar through usufructuary and not directly from bhatkar
HeadNote.description:
Applicant claiming right as mundkar through usufructuary and not directly from bhatkar - Not sustainable.

Portuguese Civil Code (1867), Art.2207.

"Mundkar" is a person who lawfully resides with a fixed habitation in a dwelling house with or without obligation to render any service to the bhatkar and such residence is with the consent of the bhatkar or person acting or purporting to act on behalf of the bhatkar.  [Para 6]

In instant case a person filed an application for registration of his name as mundkar.  He averred that he was mundkar of the landlady (since deceased).  The non-applicant objected on ground that he was the bhatkar and the lady was only usufractuary.  She had given part of the house on rent to the applicant.  The applicant had never claimed to be mundkar of the non-applicant or that he was inducted in the suit premises by the lady with the consent of the bhatkar or that she was acting or purported to act on behalf of the bhatkar.  The lady was enjoying the suit property as usufruct during her lifetime in pursuance of a will and on her death the suit property was to go to the bhatkar.  In view of the provisions of Art.2207 of the Portuguese Civil Code a person holding usufruct can only create rights in favour of third parties during his lifetime and not beyond that.  Any such rights which are created during the lifetime stand extinguished with the death of usufructor.  Therefore, permission granted by the lady would not create any right in favour of the applicant beyond her death.  For the application of S.4 it is first essential for a person to prove that he is a mundkar within the meaning of Section 2(p) of the Act.  The applicant had failed to establish that he was residing with the consent of bhatkar, or with the consent granted by any person acting or purporting to act on behalf of him.  Unless this basic requirement is established, the applicant could not qualify to be a mundkar of non-applicant.  Till the death of the lady the residence of the applicant was under permission granted by her in her right as usufructor of the suit property and, as such, the applicant could by no stretch of imagination be considered as trespasser within the meaning of Explanation to Section 2(p) of the Act.  [Para 6,7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Threatened wrongful possession
HeadNote.description:
Threatened wrongful possession - Grant of interim mandatory injunction - Only access for going to the well for fetching drinking water blocked by construction of a compound wall - It is a fit case for passing interim mandatory injunction - It is not necessary to wait till completion of enquiry in such cases.

It is clear from Section 6 of the Mundkar Act that the mundkar is having right to enjoy supply of electric power or water or any customary easement etc. and if there is any threat to it, then injunction can be granted preventing the disturbance thereof.  It can be granted by the Mamlatdar after making the enquiry as contemplated by Section 6(2).  The learned advocate for the petitioner submitted that it is only possible for the Mamlatdar to grant such a mandatory injunction after holding the necessary enquiry as contemplated by Section 6(2) of the Mundkar Act and she also invited Court's attention to Rules 14(7), 15 and 16 of the Goa, Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection From Eviction) Rules, 1977.  They prescribe the method of holding enquiry.  Further, Section 6(3) of the Mundkar Act speaks about granting of temporary injunction and this could be granted by the Mamlatdar on the basis of the affidavits or otherwise.  Thus he can also grant a temporary injunction so as to prevent a bhatkar from disturbing mundkar's right.  It is contended that Section 6(3) only speaks about prevention of contravention and not where already the contravention is committed.  It is not possible to accept this contention.  The disturbance of right is continuous and in the present case by putting a wall or blockade, the access of the respondent to the drinking water well is blocked and the said facility of having drinking water is cut off.  It is continuous.  Therefore, there is nothing wrong in granting such interim mandatory injunction.  It is not necessary to wait till completion of enquiry in such cases.			 [Para 4]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Purchase proceedings
Not maintainable
HeadNote.description: Purchase proceedings - Initiated merely on basis of registration as Mundkar u/S.29 of 1975 Act, in absence of declaration as Mundkar u/S.8A - Not maintainable - Because entries made u/S.29 are only presumptive in nature, while declaration u/S.8A concludes rights of parties finally. 	(Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Registration as mundkar
HeadNote.description: Registration as mundkar - As per electoral poll petitioner is occupying house in question since 1975 - Authorities failed to consider effect of such occupation in context of deemed consent as provided in Act - Further documents relied by authorities below were produced at appellate stage - Petitioner did not get opportunity to cross examine on said documents - It vitiates orders of authorities below - Matter remanded back to Mamlatdar for fresh consideration as per law. 	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Eviction
Suit against respondent
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Suit against respondent - Plea that respondent is mundkar in suit property - Provision states Civil Court has to refer issue to Mamlatdar - Respondent himself deleted plea of mundkarship from written statement - In execution proceedings of eviction decree respondent cannot delay proceedings by re-opening plea - Furthermore issue is finally adjudicated, against respondent by Mamlatdar - Execution proceedings cannot be kept in abeyance in view of some proceedings now initiated by respondent before Mamlatdar.
2011(4) ALL MR 904 (S.C.), 1995 (1) G L T 154, 1989 (1) GLT 175, 2001 (1) GLT 3, 1989 (2) GLT 167 Ref. to. 	(Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Revision
HeadNote.description: Revision - Order passed in appeal in terms of S.29(8) - Revision is not maintainable.	(Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Declaration under S.8-A
Demarcation of area
HeadNote.description: Declaration under S.8-A - Demarcation of area - Petitioners having not been declared as Mundkars pursuant to any proceedings under S.8-A of the Mundkar Act - Held, though the demarcation as ordered by the Administrative Tribunal is allowed to be carried out, the right eventually of the petitioners, would hinge upon the declaration, that would be issued in that favour under S.8A. 1995(1) Goa L.T. 154 - Ref. to. (Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Registration as Mundkar
Application by respondent
HeadNote.description: Registration as Mundkar - Application by respondent - Respondent paid house tax for 16 years - Also reconstructed house with construction license from Municipal Council - These actions of respondent were never opposed by petitioner bhatkar - It is implied acceptance by bhatkar that respondent is 'Mundkar' - Contention that in proceedings under S.8-A respondent has committed payment of rent - This cannot be used as conclusive proof of respondent being tenant in proceedings under S.29 - Concurrent findings by Appellate Authority and Administrative Tribunal that respondent is 'Mundkar' - Not liable to be interfered with in writ jurisdiction.	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Jurisdiction of civil court
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of civil court - Suit to decide issues which are required to be decided by Mamlatdar or Collector - Civil Court is obliged to stay such suit and refer matter to Mamlatdar or Collector for determination. 

The scheme of the Act, would show that it is enacted for the better protection to mundkars against eviction from their dwelling houses and for granting them the right to purchase the same at a reasonable price. The said Act is a piece of beneficial legislation, aimed at improving the service conditions, so to say, of the mundkars, particularly when the said Act aims at abolishing the system of free service rendered by mundkar and to turn it into a remunerated one. Thus, the scheme of the said Act would show that it creates special rights in favour of the mundkars and the corresponding liabilities on the Bhatkar. The said Act confers jurisdiction on the Mamlatdar, the Collector, the Administrative Tribunal and the Government for purposes of carrying out the object of the said Act. It is a complete Code in itself. This, if considered in juxtaposition with the bar created under Section 31(2) and Section 32 of the said Act, would make it explicit that the jurisdiction of the Civil Court in respect of the matters, which are required to be dealt with or determined by such authorities under the said Act, would stand excluded. 			     [Para 26]

When the said Act provides for an express bar and the scheme of the said Act also shows that it creates special rights and liabilities and provides for machinery for its redressal, with an hierarchy of appeals and revision and attaches finality to such orders, coupled with further bar on the Civil Court, not to entertain any such challenge, the legislative intent is clear that in such cases, the jurisdiction of the Civil Court would stand excluded. 			     [Para 28]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Declaration of 'Mundkarship'
Legality
HeadNote.description: Declaration of 'Mundkarship' - Legality - Petitioner was in occupation of wine shop belonging to predecessor of respondent who obtained decree of eviction in 1969 - Second suit was filed again in respect of suit hut which was illegally constructed when eviction suit was pending and which was decreed in 1973 and suit hut was demolished pursuant to execution proceedings - In 1980, Mamlatdar declared petitioner as Mundkar of suit hut and on that basis petitioner sought restoration and possession - Erroneous finding of Mamlatdar that there were two houses i.e. one shop and one hut in occupation of petitioner and he was evicted by Court order of shop and no proceedings initiated in respect of suit hut - Petitioner failed to establish that he was residing in suit hut with consent of bhatkar and in fixed habitation - Petitioner's case that there were two huts or that portion of suit hut alone was demolished pursuant to execution proceedings and another portion of hut was still in existence not raised in initial suit - No jurisdictional error committed by Addl. Collector in setting aside order of Mamlatdar declaring petitioner as Mundkar. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 17, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkars protection
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Mundkars protection - Application u/S.8A of Mundkars Protection Act - Principle of res judicata - Contention that once finding that applicant is not mundkar was rendered in proceedings u/S.29, applicant is barred from filing application u/S.8A - Not acceptable - Enquiries u/S.8A and S.29 operates differently - Inquiry u/S.29 is summary inquiry only for purpose of making entry - While proceedings u/S.8A are not summary proceeding - Adverse decision in summary enquiry may place higher burden on those who seek declaration u/S.8A, but right to make application u/S.8A is not lost - Therefore, application made u/S.8A is not barred by res judicata. 1995 (1) Goa L. T. 154 Ref. to. 			(Paras 15, 16, 19, 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Application by mundkar in proceeding before Mamlatdar for bringing on record legal representatives of deceased bhatkar filed after more than one month from death of deceased
HeadNote.description: Application by mundkar in proceeding before Mamlatdar for bringing on record legal representatives of deceased bhatkar filed after more than one month from death of deceased - Provisions of Civil P.C. and S.5 of Limitation Act apply. (Paras 3, 4, 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Issue of Mundkarship
HeadNote.description: Issue of Mundkarship - Practice and procedure of Tribunal - Special Judge remanded back application seeking declaration of Mundkarship to Tribunal with direction to consider it on basis of materials adduced by petitioner - Tribunal dismissed application on holding that no requisite pleadings made by petitioner and had not gone into other materials - Mundkar Act is a special statute, laying down certain procedure for trying issue of Mundkarship - Tribunal ought to have considered entire materials on record especially when such direction is issued on remanding application - Non-application of mind by Tribunal in giving obeisance to order of Special Judge - Impugned order cannot be sustained. (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Negative declaration
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Negative declaration - Challenge - Respondent-tenants obtained relief of injunction restraining petitioner from interfering with suit access pending disposal of application for permanent injunction - Petitioner moved application for negative declaration u/S.8(A) before Mundkar who had directed both parties to appear on 03.02.2015 - Respondents preferred to remain ex-parte and only thereafter matter came to be heard and negative declaration came to be granted to petitioners - Respondents cannot now allege that negative declaration was passed ex-parte - Once such order passed after due notice to respondents, plea of undue prejudice cannot be entertained at their instance - Challenge, not tenable. 			(Paras 6, 7, 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Application for declaration as Mundkar
HeadNote.description: Application for declaration as Mundkar - Petitioners who are not tenants need not be joined as parties - Joinder of such parties necessary if application is for purchase of property. (Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Grant of area to Mundkar
HeadNote.description:
Grant of area to Mundkar - Mamlatdar cannot grant more area than that permitted under law.

Constitution of India Art.226.

The statute itself has fixed the area to which a Mundkar is entitled to. What the Authority under the Mundkar Act has to do is to merely demarcate the area to which the Mundkar is entitled to under Law. The Authority cannot grant more area than what the Mundkar is legally entitled to as the Act also has fixed the price which is to be paid which is not the market value of the land and as such the Bhatkar cannot be compelled to sell more areas than what the Act provides. Any area beyond what the Mundkar intends to purchase or otherwise will be the subject matter of an agreement between the Mundkar and the owner. Insofar as the Mundkar Act is concerned, the jurisdiction of the Mamlatdar is restricted to deciding the area of the dwelling house in terms of the definition and provisions contained under the Act. Agreement with the parties to purchase more area than what in Law is provided can be an agreement between the parties to which at the highest the Mamlatdar can put his seal; in other words, it is something like a consent decree obtained by parties.  [Para 7]

If the  persons have obtained more area than they are entitled to and there is demarcation and they have constructed thereon it would be too late in the day to call on such persons who may be occupying more area than what in law they are entitled to under Art. 226. Interest of justice would suffice if the landlord is compensated.  [Para 7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkar can claim right as existed on 12-3-76 when Act came into force
HeadNote.description: Mundkar can claim right as existed on 12-3-76 when Act came into force - Division of property subsequent to that date - Dwelling house of Mundkar falling in land of more than one Bhatkar - Mundkar would be entitled to protection of both Bhatkars. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkar
Plea of mundkarship
HeadNote.description:
Mundkar - Plea of mundkarship - Mere reference to year 1975 by itself cannot disclose that claimant has been residing prior to 12.3.1975

In this case  there was no plea nor it is remotely disclosed in the original pleadings of the respondent that the occupation  of the respondent in the suit house is or was of the nature of 'fixed habitation'.  So also the respondent had not disclosed the exact date of the year 1975 since when he had been occupying the suit house .  The Explanation clause clearly specifies that the occupation has to be for a period of one year prior to the appointed date.  In other words, in order to  avail benefit under the Explanation clause, the person claiming to be mundkar should have been staying from the date prior to 12th March, 1975.  In the absence of disclosure of all the ingredients of the definition of the term 'mundkar' it cannot be said that the party has raised a plea of mundkarship.  Mere reference to the year 1975 by itself cannot disclose that the respondent had been regarding prior to 12th March,1975.  [Para 12]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: "Dwelling house"
Suit
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Civil Court - "Dwelling house" - Structure to form part of dwelling house must be situated within the area of 300 Sq. m. or 5 m around Mundkar's house in Panchayat area - In Municipal area such structure must be situated within 200 sq. m. or 2 mts. around Mundkar's house - Suit in Civil Court for permanent injunction - Suit - Shed situated 50 mts. from Defendant's house - Though issue of Mundkarship already raised by Defendant before Mamlatdar - No issue of Mundkarship can be raised in respect of suit-shed - Court order framing such issue and staying suit for lack of jurisdiction - Unsustainable and liable to be set aside.

All the structures referred in the said Section 2(i) of the said Act as forming part of the dwelling house of a mundkar have necessarily to be situated within the area of 300 sq.m. or 5 metres around the house of the mundkar in .case of Panchayat areas and within the area of 200 sq.m. or two metres around the house in case of Municipal areas.  Any structure situated beyond the said area cannot form part of the dwelling house,  in other words, a structure which is situated within the said area and claimed to be part of the dwelling house and such claim being disputed by the bhatkar of the land, then the issue can certainly be said to be arising for decision and is necessarily to be decided by the Mamlatdar under the said Act.  However, a structure which is situated beyond the said area cannot form part of the dwelling house within the meaning of the expression 'dwelling house' under the said Act. Therefore, there cannot arise any issue for the decision of the Mamlatdar under the said Act when the structure claimed to be a part of a dwelling house is situated at a distance beyond 5 metres from the house or beyond 300 sq. m. of area wherein exists the house.  In other words, once it is clear that a structure falls beyond the area defined as dwelling house under Section 2(i) of the said Act, it cannot form part of the dwelling house and therefore there cannot be an issue as such as to whether the structure falling beyond the said area to be forming part of the dwelling house requiring the Mamlatdar to adjudicate upon the same.  [Para 10,11,13]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Revision
Powers of court
HeadNote.description: Revision - Powers of court - Court cannot reappraise or reassess the facts or go into questions of facts - Constraints as under S.115 C.P.Code are applicable.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Term "Mundkar"
Scope
Care taker
Not a "Mundkar"
HeadNote.description: Term "Mundkar" - Scope - Care taker - Person included under definition but rendering service to Bhatkar or his family members - Not a "Mundkar" - Mere care taker is not a Mundkar. (Paras 45)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Decision of Mamalatdar
HeadNote.description:
Decision of Mamalatdar - Appeal against, maintainable before the Collector.

2000(2) Goa L.T. 318 - Rel.on.  [Para 1]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkarship or tenancy
HeadNote.description: Mundkarship or tenancy - When an issue of mundkarship or tenancy is raised in a suit, it is required to be decided by the Mamlatdar in terms of S.32(2) of the Act of 1975 and S.58 of the Act of 1964.	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Declaration of mundkars
Rejected by Mamlatdar
HeadNote.description: Declaration of mundkars - Application by petitioner under S.29 for registration as mundkar of suit dwelling house - Rejected by Mamlatdar - Subsequent application under S.8A is not barred by principle of res judicata.	(Paras 6, 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Registration as mundkar
HeadNote.description: Registration as mundkar - Order passed under S.29 has only presumptive value until contrary is proved or a new entry is lawfully substituted thereafter - Merely because application for registration as mundkar under S.29 is rejected by itself would not disentitle such a person from filing an application under S.8A. 			(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkar
HeadNote.description: Mundkar - Essential requirement for establishment of - Is to show that person was residing in such house with 'Fixed habitation'. 	(Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkar
Claim of
HeadNote.description: Mundkar - Claim of - Respondent claims to be mundkar in respect of dwelling house surveyed under chalta No.48 of P.T. sheet. No.109 - For claiming as mundkar person has to show that he was residing in house with fixed habitation - Respondent was already declared as mundkars in respect of other house situated in same city - A person cannot have fixed habitation at two different places in same city - Respondent cannot be declared as mundkar. (Paras 6, 7, 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Claim for damages
HeadNote.description: Claim for damages - Defendant mundkar filed proceedings against plaintiff before Joint Mamlatdar - Defendants prayed to restrain plaintiffs from constructing any structure - Plaintiffs did not state in their reply that proceedings are malicious - Ex parte order was not passed against plaintiff by Mamlatdar - Proceedings were withdrawn by defendant without objection from plaintiffs - Trial Court did not hold  that defendant had filed false proceedings - Basis for claiming damages by plaintiff was filing of false proceedings by defendant - As foundation of claim  for damages was not proved, question of proving quantum of damages does not arise - Second appeal on this ground is liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 16, 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction - Issue regarding easement i.e. right of access of a Mundkar - Definition of 'dwelling house' in Mundkars Act covers customary easement - Civil Court has no jurisdiction - Issue comes within ambit of Mamlatdar. (Paras 5, 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Mundkar
HeadNote.description: Mundkar - Person lawfully residing with fixed habitation in a dwelling house is mundkar - Persons who are in order of succession in terms of Portuguese Civil Code, Art 1969, are also included in the ambit of Mundkar if they are residing in the dwelling house. (Paras 10, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Object of Act
HeadNote.description: Object of Act - Is to protect the person residing in dwelling houses from being evicted.(Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Object
Mundkar
Definition of
HeadNote.description:
Object - Mundkar - Definition of - Is enumerative and not-exhaustive.

When the word "includes" is used in the definition as in the case under Section 2(p) of the said Act of 1975, the legislature does not intend to restrict the definition, it makes the definition enumerative and not exhaustive i.e. the term defined would retain its ordinary meaning but its scope would be extended to bring within the term certain other persons who in the ordinary meaning may or may not comprise of. The object of the Mundkar Act is not to allow strangers of the family of the Mundkar to come upon the dwelling house but that such right continues after his death to the member of his family and also the legal successor who is similarly placed. The object and purpose of Section 3 of the said Act of 1975, needs to confine the right of a Mundkar upon his death only to those successors in the order of succession who have been living with the Mundkar with a fixed habitation at the time of the opening of inheritance besides the members of the family as defined in the said Act of 1975.  [Para 17]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Right of Mundkar
Heritability
HeadNote.description:
Right of Mundkar - Heritability - Would extend to members of the family as well as to successions who are living with Mundkar at time of opening of inheritance.
2001(1) Mh.L.J. 694 Held not good law.(Para 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Property dispute
Issuance of notice
HeadNote.description:
Property dispute - Issuance of notice - Cannot be held to be mandatory, irrespective of fact situation.

	The issuance of notice under Section 29(7) of the Act cannot be held to be mandatory, irrespective of the fact situation. There is nothing in the Act which indicates that a person is precluded from waiving the requirement of notice. Waiver can be construed from the conduct of the party. If the party who had consciously chosen to remain absent and not to contest the matter further, with full knowledge, is allowed to reopen the proceedings after an inordinate delay on the ground that the order was not communicated to him, would be placing an artificial and hypertechnical construction on the section. 	 [Para 16]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Order of Deputy Collector - Appeal against - Delay of 11 years in filing - Deputy Collector by its order entering name of heir of mundkar as mundkar of property - Opposite party consciously choose not to remain present in proceeding and also aware that such order was going to be passed - In these circumstances, subsequent assignee cannot start litigation all over again after such huge delay - Rejection of application for condonation of delay by appellate and revisional authority - Found proper. 1975 (2) SCC 779, AIR 1961 SC 1500 Disting. 	(Paras 15, 16, 17, 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Claim of Mundkarship
HeadNote.description: Claim of Mundkarship - Oral submission of petitioners that they are residing in suit premises as Mundkars since 1973 - Contradictory to the documentary evidence on record - A relative of petitioners occupied the premises as Mundkar till 1986 - Undertaking given by petitioners in 1987 negates their own claim of Mundkarship since 1973 - Oral evidence cannot overwrite the documentary evidence on record - Nothing to show that contents of undertaking are not correct - In fact, these contents are corroborated by other documents i.e. house tax receipts and electoral rolls - Claim of Mundkarship liable to be rejected. (Paras 9, 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Appeal
Recording of findings
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Recording of findings - When appellate court agree with the views of trial court, it need not re-state the effects of evidence or reasons given by trial court - Expression of general agreement would suffice - However, this should not be a device for appellate court for shirking its duty. (Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: "Mundkar"
HeadNote.description: "Mundkar" - Deemed fiction of lawful residence of mundkar and consent of bhatkar - Pendency of eviction suit during period of one year prior to appointed date itself is not sufficient to attract Explanation to Section 2(p) - Such suit must be filed only on ground that person is trespasser. 	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Claim for mundkarship
Legality
HeadNote.description: Claim for mundkarship - Declined, on ground that possession was unlawful in view of Explanation to S.2(p) - Legality - Eviction suit filed against petitioners was pending during period of one year prior to the appointed date - However, said suit was not on ground that petitioners were trespassers - But, on ground that criminal complaint was filed by petitioners against respondents - Having not fulfilled conditions for presuming lawful residence and consent of bhatkar by deemed fiction of law, Explanation to S.2(p) would not come into play - Impugned order cannot be sustained. 1992 (2) Bom.C.R. 39 Ref. to.  (Paras 11, 12, 13, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Land belonging to communidade
HeadNote.description:
Land belonging to communidade - There can be mundkar on such land if requirements of law are satisfied.

If a person claims to be a Mundkar and claims rights under this Act, it is the Mundkar Act which will have over-riding effect. Ultimately, the Mundkar Act is a special Legislation by which the Legislature has conferred rights on persons who fall within the definition of Mundkar. The Legislature also thought it fit in these circumstances to exclude and or give over-riding effect to this Act over other Acts. The Code of Communidate merely provides for regularising the encroachment on the land of the Communidade. Therefore, there can be a Mundkar on the land of the Communidade if all the predicates of the definition of Mundkar and dwelling house are satisfied by the person claiming to be Mundkar as there is no exclusion as in the case of Government land.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Apportionment of compensation
Determination
Impugned order quashed
HeadNote.description: Apportionment of compensation - Determination - Appellant claiming to be owner of suit land by adverse possession on basis of decree of Civil Court passed in her favour against Communidade - Respondents had applied for declaration as mundkar of suit house structured on suit land, but application was dismissed - Appellant case that she had permitted respondents to occupy suit house on royalty - She had filed eviction suit, but same was dismissed and first appeal was also dismissed - Second appeal so filed was also withdrawn as suit house came to be demolished pursuant to acquisition - Admission of respondents that suit house was located in property belonging to appellant herein till suit house became subject matter of acquisition along with land - Mutation entry was done in appellant's favour consequent upon decree of Civil Court declaring her to be owner of suit land without reference of house structure - Respondents had not produced any such documents except few Panchayat receipts to substantiate her claim to suit house including their plea of having derived possession from Communidade - Reference Court failed to consider all these aspects properly and erroneously allotted entire compensation to respondents - Impugned order quashed - Appellant entitled to compensation awarded by LAO. 			(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 19, 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Act (1975)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Plea of bar of limitation - Plaintiff claiming that defendant unauthorisedly occupied suit hut by staking her claim to be mundkar - Period of limitation to file suit commenced from date when possession of defendant becomes adverse to plaintiff - Possession of defendant becomes adverse to plaintiff in 1996 when defendant took step to claim her right as mundkar in property of plaintiff - Defendant’s attempt to stake claim of mundkar failed before two revenue authorities and when it failed before Deputy Collector, plaintiff filed suit for eviction in 2006 - It is within period of limitation of 12 years prescribed under Limitation Act - Suit is not barred by limitation. 	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Mundkars (Protection from Eviction) Rules (1977)
heading: Application by mundkar in proceeding before Mamlatdar for bringing on record legal representatives of deceased bhatkar filed after more than one month from death of deceased
HeadNote.description: Application by mundkar in proceeding before Mamlatdar for bringing on record legal representatives of deceased bhatkar filed after more than one month from death of deceased - Provisions of Civil P.C. and S.5 of Limitation Act apply. (Paras 3, 4, 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Municipalities Act (1968)
heading: Respondents
HeadNote.description:
Promotion of clerks to post of Market Inspectors - Respondents - Clerks not possessing minimum qualifications to be promoted to such post - Order of reversion passed against them - Director not willing to relax rules - Order of reversion revoked by Minister - Order is without jurisdiction.

In the instant case, the respondents did not possess the basic qualification for the post of Market Inspector either in terms of the 1975 Rules or in terms of the 1986 Rules. As per the 1975 Rules, the educational qualification for promotees to the posts of Market/Municipal Inspector was Intermediate/Senior Cambridge or any other equivalent qualification. Senior Supervisor with five years standing in the grade was qualified to the promotional post. In terms of the 1986 Rules minimum educational qualification required for the posts of Market/Municipal Inspector is S.S.C. Thus, the respondents did not possess minimum educational qualification for promotion to the posts of Market Inspector. There was no power to relax the educational qualification and, as such, the promotion of respondents to the posts of Market Inspector in the year 1983 on ad-hoc basis was contrary to the Recruitment Rules. Taking this factor into consideration they were reverted to their original posts. There was no provision for relaxation of educational qualification either under the 1975 Rules or under the 1986 Rules, but the provision relating to relaxation of educational qualifications was introduced for the first time by the 1994 Amendment which came into force from 20th January 1994. The power under the said Amendment to relax the educational qualification vests in the Director of Municipal Administration. The Director of Municipal Administration had refused to relax the said provisions relating to educational qualification in respect of respondents. The matter having been closed it was again examined by the Minister and order of revocation of revision order was passed by the Minister.

Held, that the order revoking the reversion orders and directing regularisation of respondents was totally arbitrary, illegal in utter defiance of recruitment rules and abuse of power. His plea that the exercise was done bona fide could not be accepted.  [Para 16]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Municipalities Act (1968)
heading: No confidence motion
HeadNote.description: No confidence motion - Meeting for consideration of - Petitioners-Councillors seeking direction to Director of Municipal Administration to fix early date for considering motion of no confidence against Chairperson of Municipal Council - There cannot be undue delay in holding meeting to consider motion of no confidence - No time limit prescribed for holding said meeting, does not mean that such holding can be delayed unreasonably or without any valid reason - Fixing date after almost four weeks or six weeks from date of receipt of requisition, cannot be regarded as reasonable exercise - Reason for delay stated by director that there there are elections to 5 other municipal councils and officers will be busy, is certainly no good reason not to spare even single officer to preside over meeting in question - Removal of elected office bearer on loss of confidence, is an essential feature of democracy - Same cannot be defeated by Director by simply delaying holding of meeting to consider such motion - Direction issued to hold meeting on 16.04.21 instead of 30.04.21. 			(Paras 19, 20, 23, 24, 26)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Municipalities Act (1968)
heading: Scope of appeal
HeadNote.description:
Scope of appeal - Validity and legality of tax - Could not be challenged before Judicial Magistrate - Scope of appeal is restricted to valuation and assessment alone.

1982 Mah. L.J. 866 overruled.

S.115 of the Goa,Daman and Div Municipalities Act, 1968 provides for the objections which can be filed by the party aggrieved in relation to the assessment list. S.115(2) restricts the objections which can be raised by the aggrieved party to the calculation and amendment. It does not provide that levy of tax its validity or legality can be challenged thereunder. The aggrieved party is required to state the grounds on which the valuation or amendment is disputed. S.164 provides for appeals to Magistrates against any claim for taxes or other dues included in a bill presented to any persons u/s. 145 or any other provisions of the Act. The provisions of Ss. 164and 165 clearly restrict the scope of the appeal before the Judicial Magistrate and the scope is restricted to valuation and amendment alone. The filing of written objections, which are restricted to the valuation and assessment u/s. 115(2) is a condition precedent for entertaining an appeal u/s. 165 of the Act. In view of this, it is clear that in an appeal u/s. 164 of the Act, it is not open to the assessee to challenge the legality or validity of the tax itself AIR 1978 Bom 9 and (1955) 57 Bom. L.R. 547 foll. AIR 1977 SC 955 Disting 1982 Mah. L.J. 866 Overruled.  [Para 6,7,12]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Municipalities Act (1968)
heading: Procedure
HeadNote.description: Procedure - Filing of objections to assessment list - Objections dealt with not by authorised Valuation officer but by Chief Officer - Held, challenge to procedure regarding levy & tax amounted to challenge to assessment itself and hence matter had to be remanded back to follow proper procedure u/s. 116. (Paras 9,10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Municipalities Act (1968)
heading: Recovery of tax
Retrospectivity
HeadNote.description: Recovery of tax - Retrospectivity - Tax cannot be recovered retrospectively and recovery would be in relation to financial year during which assessment list is duly authenticated. (Paras 11,12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Municipalities Class III and Class IV (Ministerial and Non-Ministerial and Non-Gazetted) Posts Recruitment Rules (1975)
heading: Respondents
HeadNote.description:
Promotion of clerks to post of Market Inspectors - Respondents - Clerks not possessing minimum qualifications to be promoted to such post - Order of reversion passed against them - Director not willing to relax rules - Order of reversion revoked by Minister - Order is without jurisdiction.

In the instant case, the respondents did not possess the basic qualification for the post of Market Inspector either in terms of the 1975 Rules or in terms of the 1986 Rules. As per the 1975 Rules, the educational qualification for promotees to the posts of Market/Municipal Inspector was Intermediate/Senior Cambridge or any other equivalent qualification. Senior Supervisor with five years standing in the grade was qualified to the promotional post. In terms of the 1986 Rules minimum educational qualification required for the posts of Market/Municipal Inspector is S.S.C. Thus, the respondents did not possess minimum educational qualification for promotion to the posts of Market Inspector. There was no power to relax the educational qualification and, as such, the promotion of respondents to the posts of Market Inspector in the year 1983 on ad-hoc basis was contrary to the Recruitment Rules. Taking this factor into consideration they were reverted to their original posts. There was no provision for relaxation of educational qualification either under the 1975 Rules or under the 1986 Rules, but the provision relating to relaxation of educational qualifications was introduced for the first time by the 1994 Amendment which came into force from 20th January 1994. The power under the said Amendment to relax the educational qualification vests in the Director of Municipal Administration. The Director of Municipal Administration had refused to relax the said provisions relating to educational qualification in respect of respondents. The matter having been closed it was again examined by the Minister and order of revocation of revision order was passed by the Minister.

Held, that the order revoking the reversion orders and directing regularisation of respondents was totally arbitrary, illegal in utter defiance of recruitment rules and abuse of power. His plea that the exercise was done bona fide could not be accepted.  [Para 16]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
HeadNote.sub_clause: R.64, Sch.1, Entry 21, Item (4) (A-IV) (As amended in 1992) and R.54-A (inserted in 1994)
heading: Levy of fee for use of riverine land
HeadNote.description:
Levy of fee for use of riverine land - Not ultra vires provisions of Act.

Section 6 of the Act enables the Government to make rules in respect of the several matters enumerated therein. The scope and ambit of supervision and control of the Port Authorities under the Ports Act in regard to areas declared as ports, is very wide. As noticed above, section 6(jj) of the Act, in particular, enables the State Government to make rules for regulating the use of landing places, piers, jetties, wharves, quays, warehouses and sheds belonging to the Government and fixing the rates to be paid for the use of the same. [Para 17]

The 1992 amendment and the 1994 amendment to the Goa, Daman and Diu Ports Rules, 1983 which enable the Port Authorities to levy, charge and recover a fee or charge for using open Government riverine land from the person who is permitted to use such Government riverine land is within the rule-making power of the State, and cannot therefore be said to be ultra vires the rule-making power under the Act. In fact, even without specific rules, the Port Authorities in exercise of domain over riverine land and the river, could object to or prohibit the exclusive mooring by vessels which call at the workshop. The Port Authorities can also enter into an arrangement of lease/licence with the users of such riverine land/demarcated river surface alongside the workshop or establishment. But in the absence of specific rules and in the absence of stipulation of any special condition when granting permission, the persons permitted to have their establishment on private land on the banks of the river (falling within the port area), could well presume that the permission to have their establishment, included implied permission to use the riverine land/river alongside their establishments.   [Para 19,20]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
heading: Fee for occupation of riverine land
HeadNote.description:
Fee for occupation of riverine land - Can be levied only from 1994 - Before that Government had no such power.

When the Rules were brought into force on 5.4.1984, there was no provision for levy of any fee or charge for use of riverine land. The Rules only provided for a fee for the occupation of open plots. Only by the 1992 amendment, the words 'open riverine land' was added under Entry 21(4)(A-iv) of the First Schedule so as to subject the occupation of open riverine land to payment of fees. Prior to the 1992 amendment, the First Schedule to the Rules did not provide for levy of any fees for occupation of riverine land. However, it was only by the 1994 amendment, with effect from 3.3.1994, the Rules were amended by inserting clause (ff) in Rule 2 containing the definition of 'government riverine land' and by inserting Rule 54-A specifically providing that no government riverine land shall be used, without prior written permission of the Captain of Ports and without making advance payment of rental charges at the prescribed rate. Therefore, prior to the said amendment to the Rules in 1994, neither the Act nor the Rules authorized or enabled the Government to levy any fee/charge for use of government riverine land. The fact that the Port Authorities were demanding a fee for use of riverine land even prior to 1992/1994 or that some workshop owners were paying such amount, did not mean that the demand was lawfully made in pursuance of authority vested in them to make such demand, or that the persons on whom the demands were made, were bound to pay the same.   [Para 22]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
heading: Levy of wharfage
HeadNote.description:
Levy of wharfage - Wharfage can be collected for use of wharf even when there is no loading or unloading of goods or even when accommodation is not provided in wharf - Purpose of user is immaterial - Held, where barges touched wharf even for few minutes to obtain customs clearance from Customs Officer, levy was not unauthorised.

Ports Act (1908), S.6

Levy of wharfage - Wharf used only for few minutes for some purpose other than loading or unloading of goods or storing of cargo - Levy if valid. (Paras 7, 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
heading: Permission for
HeadNote.description: Construction in riverine land - Permission for - Is to be granted by Ministry of Environment and Forest for project of more than five crore rupees - Permission granted at State level by Captain of Ports and Goa Costal Zone Management Authority by assuming that invest involved in project was less than five crores - Permission issued by incompetent authority - Permission liable to be set aside.	(Paras 14, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
HeadNote.sub_clause: R.64, Sch.1, Entry 21, Item (4) (A-IV) (As amended in 1992) and Rule 54-A (As inserted in 1994)
heading:
Not retrospective in operation.

The amended Rules do not provide that they are retrospective in operation. Nor do the circumstances warrant such an inference. In fact, the contention of the respondents is not that power to levy fees/charges for use of riverine land was created/vested in the Port Authorities, by virtue of the amendment rules and that such power was given to levy fees/charges retrospectively. The contention has been that the power to levy fees/charges existed ever since the Rules came into force on 5.4.1984 and that position was merely clarified by the amendment rules in 1992 and 1994. The amendment rules of 1992 and 1994 are not clarificatory, but are provisions investing the Port Authorities with the power to levy and collect charges for occupation of government riverine land. Therefore, the demand for charges for use of government riverine land is valid only from 3.3.1994. Therefore the Port Authorities could not demand or recover any amount for the period prior to 3.3.1994. The Port Authorities are therefore liable to refund any amount recovered within three years prior to the date of the writ petition. Obviously, any amount paid during a period beyond three years from the date of the writ petition, is not recoverable as barred by delay and laches.   [Para 24]
