HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
heading: Term 'open plot'
HeadNote.description:
Term 'open plot' - Meaning of.

In the absence of a special or deeming definition, the term 'open plot' cannot be read as referring to the river bed which is covered by water for part of the day and exposed for remaining part of the day. 'Open plot' refers to a plot of land which is open to sky. A land which is covered by any construction or water, cannot obviously be termed as an open plot. [Para 21]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Ports Rules (1983)
heading: Port clearance
HeadNote.description: Port clearance - Order of Captain of Ports introducing a condition precedent to obtain NOC from Directorate of Mines and Geology - Cannot be said to be illegal as the Govt. has right to prevent illegal mining of minerals and its transportation evading payment of royalty - Further, issuing such condition is well within jurisdiction of Captain of Ports under Rr.38, 41, and R.43 of 1983 Rules. 	(Para 43)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Preservation of Trees Act (1984)
heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Forest (Conservation) Act (1980) - Permission to cut trees - Challenge to - Tree Officer granted permission for felling 21709 trees from entire area of forest for public project - Officer had stated that no objection has been conveyed for same - Impugned order lacked exercise of ascertaining exactly how many trees are required to cut, whether some can be saved or transplanted, what conditions can be imposed to ensure strict supervision and check any abuse by contractors - Appeal is also heard in most casual manner - Total failure on part of both Tree Officer and Appellate Authority to give reasons - More so when permission was granted to cut such large number of trees - Appeal is remanded back.	(Paras 10, 13, 14, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Preservation of Trees Act (1984)
heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Order to cut tree - Legality - Impugned order does not speak of dangerous condition of tree in question which is a savor tree - It only shows that tree has been left unattended and problem is caused by release of silk cotton from tree - Even in report of Range Forest Officer, it was nowhere stated that condition of tree is ruinous or such as to indicate that it is likely to fall down - Requirements of S.12-A, not fulfilled - Impugned order is not sustainable and therefore, liable to be set aside - Petitioner, on instructions, gives undertaking of harvesting pods of Savor tree regularly before they are allowed to burst. 	(Paras 3, 4)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Preservation of Trees Act (1984)
heading: Legality
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Order to cut tree - Legality - Perusal of impugned order shows that appellate authority has not come to conclusion that tree is not in ruinous condition and is likely to fall - If that be so, no order for cutting of tree could have been passed - Not only this, appellate authority also ordered that failure to comply with order would attract S.12(A)(3) of Goa Preservation of Trees Act to take all reasonable steps to cut/trim/maintain tree at cost and charges of petitioner - Not proper - Appeal remanded for fresh consideration. 	 (Para 3)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Public Gambling Act (1976)
heading: Sentence
Minimum prescribed
HeadNote.description: Sentence - Minimum prescribed - Cannot be reduced further - No discretion vests in court in this regard - Court has to impose minimum term of imprisonment and also fine. (Para 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Public Health Act (1985)
heading: Not sufficient
HeadNote.description: Establishment of dairy farm - Without obtaining prior permission from Director - Contention raised that respondent is not undertaking any commercial activity - Not sufficient - Director/Health Officer is directed to visit site to verify statement of respondent - If it is found to be not correct, steps shall be taken to stop such activity. (Paras 7, 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Public Health Act (1985)
heading: Public nuisance
Removal of
HeadNote.description: Public nuisance - Removal of - Parallel proceedings for abatement of public nuisance can be taken by Health Officer as well as the S.D.M. - There always could be more than one remedy for a single malady, given under different statutes.	(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Realisation of Land Revenue Rules (1969)
heading: Auction purchase
HeadNote.description: Auction purchase - Donor made Gift deed of his 1/3rd share in joint property - Donor had secured loan from Government which remained unpaid - Property gifted with encumbrance to repay loan - Property was sold by donee without repaying loan - Property was attached and auctioned by Mamlatdar for recovery of Government dues - Property auctioned with encumbrances - Donee and purchaser from donee did not seek remedy in Civil Court - Sale certificate was issued in name of plaintiff auction purchaser - Plaintiff auction purchaser is owner of 1/3rd interest in said property of donee. (Para 26)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Realisation of Land Revenue Rules (1969)
heading: Auction purchase
HeadNote.description: Auction purchase - Donor made Gift deed of his 1/3rd share in joint property - Property gifted with encumbrance to repay loan - Property was sold by donee without repaying loan - Property was attached and auctioned by Mamlatdar for recovery of Government dues - Purchaser from donee filed suit for injunction - Claim of purchaser from donee was admitted in consent terms filed by donee and other defendants in that suit - Plaintiff auction purchaser had cause of action to file suit for declaration that consent terms are illegal - Suit by plaintiff was dismissed - However plaintiff being auction purchaser was held as owner of 1/3rd share by Trial and First Appellate Court - Hence Gift deed, consent terms hold no validity pertaining to 1/3rd share of plaintiff. (Paras 27, 28)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Reorganisation Act (1987)
heading: Change in age of retirement from 60 to 58 yrs. after Reorganisation
HeadNote.description: Change in age of retirement from 60 to 58 yrs. after Reorganisation - S.60(6) requires previous approval of Central Govt. - Post facto approval is of no avail - Impugned change, illegal. 			(Paras 16, 17, 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Reorganisation Act (1987)
heading: Change in age of retirement
HeadNote.description: Change in age of retirement - Writ petition, whether barred by delay - Petitioners retired between years 2000 to 2004 - In 2008, they filed departmental representations which was rejected only in 2013 - Petitioners cannot be called as “fence sitters” - They have legitimate grievances of being discriminated against similarly situated persons to whom State Govt. has itself provided remedy - Petition filed in 2014, not barred. 			(Paras 27, 28, 31, 32, 33)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Reorganisation Act (1987)
heading: Relief to petitioners
HeadNote.description:
Illegal change in retirement age - Relief to petitioners - Cannot be denied on sole ground of delay - There is distinction between mere delay and laches - If circumstances justify conduct of petitioners, manifest illegality cannot be sustained for mere physical running of time - By court verdicts in other cases as also by order of State Govt. itself, other similarly situated employees were provided relief in terms of revised pension - State Govt. thus acknowledged illegality on its part - Petitioners also ready to accept same relief - It would not prejudice any third parties - Petitioners entitled to relief of revised pension - But not for arrears of backwages. 
1992 ALLMR ONLINE 669 (S.C.), 2008 ALL SCR 2457, (2010) 12 SCC 538, 2015 ALL SCR 3692 Rel. on. 
2007(3) ALL MR 374 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 37, 38, 44, 54, 57, 58, 64, 65)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Reorganisation Act (1987)
heading: Appellate Side Rules
Applicability of
HeadNote.description: Appellate Side Rules - Applicability of - S.20 establishes common High Court for State of Maharashtra and Goa - High Court of Bombay has been referred as common High Court - S.22 provides that law in force with practice and procedure in existing High Court, with necessary modification apply in relation to common High Court - Law in force with respect to procedure in existing High Court was in form of Appellate Side Rules - Hence Rules are applicable to common High Court - Contention that Appellate Side Rules are not applicable to State of Goa is liable to be rejected. (Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Salaries and Allowances of Ministers Act (1964)
heading: Travelling and Petrol allowance to Minister
HeadNote.description:
Travelling and Petrol allowance to Minister - Execution of private as well as official duties - Limit of 60 liters does not apply.

When a Minister travels on duty and the cost of petrol for the travel is met by the Government, the Minister is not entitled to draw travelling allowance. Therefore, besides the quota of 60 litres of petrol which is sanctioned to the Minister under Section 5 of the Act for his personal use, the Minister can also utilise the petrol at the expense of the Government for tours on official duty, but in such an eventuality the Minister is not entitled to draw T.A. though he is still entitled to draw D.A. Therefore, the PIL which is based upon misconception of law that the minister is entitled to use 60 litres of petrol for private as well as official duty is based upon misconception and liable to be quashed.  [Para 4,5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Sales Tax Act (1964)
heading: Successor in business
HeadNote.description:
Successor in business - Person having business premises initially running business through dealer and on his surrendering business to him giving it to another dealer to run it - Liability of second dealer for payment of Tax for period prior to starting his business.

Sales Tax - Liability of dealer who has taken over business from another dealer to pay tax for period prior to starting his business.

In the present case, the premises and the business which belonged to F was registered in his name. F initially went on running the business through D on royalty basis by agreement, D was a registered dealer under the Goa, Daman and Diu Sales Tax Act, 1964. Subsequently D terminated the said agreement and surrendered the business to F who in turn gave it by agreement to the appellant to run it again on royalty basis, the appellant commenced the business in his own name and style, got registered the establishment as an independent dealer under the Sales Tax Act and started paying sales tax on goods sold by him. He had no connection with the business of D. He was only a bonafide purchaser for price of the goods which belonged to D. By the agreement between the appellant and D, the former was not responsible for any liability of D prior to the date of the agreement either with the Government departments or other public parties.

Held that the business must be treated as continued to be of F, although the same was being run and managed by the appellant. The appellant did not become a successor in the business run by D. There was no attempt on the part of D to transfer the business to the appellant and being so the question of the appellant having taken over the business from the establishment of D did not arise at all. Therefore, any liability for payment of tax which was found to be owned by D cannot be saddled on the appellant. It was F, at the most who could have been made responsible jointly with D for payment of tax.  [Para 5,6]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Fee structure
HeadNote.description:
Fee structure - Unaided private recognized school - Fee structure revised to enable it to pay retrospectively from 1-1-2006 higher salary to teachers and staff consequent on recommendations of 6th Pay Commission - Revised fee structure for 2010-11 not including any capitation fee and was not exorbitant or arbitrary - Only parents of five students objecting to revised fee - Surplus, after all expenditure was less than 15% which could not be termed as excessive profit - Held petitioners have not made out a case of commercialization and exploitation by the school. 
2004(5) ALL MR 894 (S.C.) - Rel. on. (Paras 26, 27)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Interpretation of Statutes
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statutes - Use of the words "Shall" and "May" need not be treated as mandatory or directory - Possibility of Justice suffering from a too rigid application of  time limit should be taken into account - Time clause will not be considered to be mandatory unless its non-observance will result in the object of the provisions being frustrated - Section 11 (3) of the Act has a rider or limit on the second proviso to sub-section (3) - Convincing reasons for delaying the grant of approval by the Director cannot be said to be illegal.

Punishment imposed shockingly disproportionate to the offence proved - Administrative tribunal has jurisdiction to reduce the punishment - No interference in writ petition.

The use of the words "Shall" and "May" in the statute cannot itself be automatically taken to be construed as mandatory and direcctory respectively. The third proviso to section 11(3) has put a rider or limit on the second proviso to sub-section (3) of section 11. When there is convincing explanation for delaying the grant of approval of the Director, it cannot be said the approval given after stipulated time is illegal or should be treated as non-est in the eye of law pursuant to the proviso to sub-section (3) of Section 11.   [Para 7]

The administrative Tribunal has appreciated the evidence and found that the punishment imposed is shockingly disproportionate to the offence proved and therefore imposed minor penalty.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: School
HeadNote.description:
School - Starting of standard 8th class in existing middle stage school - Amounts to starting of new school and not merely starting a new class - Requirements of R. 31 ought to be followed.

The contention is that the appellant-society wanted only to have a new class in the existing school, therefore, the norms laid down under Rule 31 are not applicable and Rule 32 alone should have been looked into by the Director, Education. This contention is not tenable for various reasons. Admittedly, the appellant started the school as a middle school and the Vth standard was started in the year 1994-95. VIth standard was started in 1995-96 and the permission to open the VIIth standard was given during the year 1996-97. The present request is to start VIIIth standard in that school which would convert the school to a secondary school. Even though the request of the appellant is to have a new class in the existing school but the real demand of the appellant is to have a secondary school as the existing school is only up to VIIth standard and if the school is to become a secondary school, norms laid down under Rule 31 are to be necessarily followed. The contention of the learned counsel for the appellant that starting of a new class does not amount to a new school cannot be accepted for the reason that rigorous criteria prescribed under Rule 31 are to be followed for starting a new school. For opening a new class in the existing school, the appellant-society need only satisfy the authorities that there are certain physical facilities available with the school and that there are sufficient students for starting a class. Whereas under Rule 31, the authorities have to take into consideration various other aspects and find out whether the opening of a new school is necessary to meet the educational needs of that area.  [Para 8]

Under Rule 2(1)(f), middle stage of the school is specifically mentioned as the stage of school education from Class Vth to VIIth (both inclusive). As regards 'Secondary Stage', an inclusive definition is given so as to take in standards Vth to VIIth also, within the secondary stage and that would only indicate that even if a school is having a middle stage consisting of classes IVth to VIIth still it would be deemed as secondary stage if there are classes from Vth to Xth. As regards the appellant's school is concerned, there are classes only from Vth to VIIth, it does not fall within any other category and it has to be held as a middle school. If it is converted into a secondary school by addition of standard VIIIth, we are of the view that the guidelines under R. 31 of the 'Rules' are to be followed as it amounts starting of new school having Secondary stage.  [Para 9]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - Order refusing to grant penalty to employee, challenged by Management - Contention that appeal is not maintainable in terms of S.22 at instance of Management Tribunal, held, not sustainable. 	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Grant-in-aid to pre-primary or primary schools
HeadNote.description: Grant-in-aid to pre-primary or primary schools - Such schools are not entitled to receive grant in-aid - Grants would not be available to non-Govt. Aided Elementary primary school teachers - Such primary school teachers would be entitled to benefits in terms of directions of the High Court in an earlier writ petition but not under law. (Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Evidence Act (1872), S.115
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.115 - Appointment of computer teacher - Was subject to approval of Director of Education as per advertisement - Director of Education granted approval to her appointment on contract basis and petitioner accepted the same - She did not challenge order of approval on contract basis - In fact, on re-advertisement of post, without any protest, appeared before selection committee, participated in selection process without any force or duress - On her non selection, subsequently challenged her earlier termination of service - Moreover, Writ Petition filed six months after appointment of new teacher - Plea that she was legitimately expecting her selection on permanent post, not tenable - Since petitioner not holding requisite experience and accepted her appointment on contract basis, it comes to an end by efflux of time and issuance of separate order of termination, not necessary - Petitioner would be estopped from claiming that her initial appointment must be treated as regular one.			(Paras 15, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Retirement
Age of
HeadNote.description: School Education Rules, R.88 - Retirement - Age of - Petitioners reached age of superannuation on 12. 04. 2006 and on 16.04.2006 - As per R.88 petitioners were entitled to continue till 30.04.2008 - Amendment to S.11 discloses that age of retirement has been increased from 58 to 60 as per notification dated 19.04.2006 - Contention that as per R.88 petitioner was in employment on 19.04.2006 - Hence notification is applicable to petitioner - Continuation as per R.88 after attaining age of superannuation is by way of re-employment and not as matter of right - Therefore petitioner would not get benefit of amendment - Petition liable to be dismissed. 	(Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Retirement
HeadNote.description: School Education Rules, R.88 - Retirement - Amendment to S.11 discloses that age to retirement has been increased from 58 to 60 as per notification Dt.19.04.2006 - Bare perusal of notification discloses that respondent has not fixed any cutoff date - Notification has been published on 19.04.2006, deemed to come into force from said date and as such, question of fixing of cutoff date by respondent does not arise - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected. 	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Taking over management of recognised school
HeadNote.description:
Taking over management of recognised school - It is extreme step to be resorted to only in rare and exceptional cases.

The action of taking over the management of a recognised school is an extreme step to be resorted in rare and exceptional cases when no alternate remedy is to be found.  It is a step to be resorted in public interest and not to vindicate individual interests.  Before an action under S.20 can be justified not only one or the other of the seven grounds appearing in S.20(1) to be made good, but also it has to be found that the action of taking over the management is expedient in public interest or in the interest of the school education or in order to secure the proper management of the school.  It is only when both these ingredients are held to have been satisfied that an action of taking over management under S.20 can be justified.  [Para 6,7]

Held, on facts, that the action which was purported to have been taken under the provisions of S.20 of the Act was not only not bonafide, but was virtually undertaken as a matter of witch hunting.  The case did not fall under any of the clauses found in S.20(1) of the Act.  The impugned order of taking over the management therefore deserves to be quashed and set aside.  [Para 24]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Refusal to comply with directions given by Director of Education
HeadNote.description:
Refusal to comply with directions given by Director of Education - That by itself cannot attract S.20.

The consequence of non-compliance of directions issued by the Director of Education can only have the effect as provided in the R.56 of stoppage, reduction or suspension of grant-in-aid.  The same do not justify an action under S.20.  Before an action under S.20 can be undertaken the case has to fall in one of the seven clauses provided in S.20(1) and hence the mere refusal to comply with the directions given by the Director of Education cannot and will not attract the provisions of S.20.  [Para 14]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Confidential report
HeadNote.description: Confidential report - Promotion to post of Head of School - Most senior teacher bypassed by management on ground of adverse remarks in confidential report - No appeal against adverse remarks was filed by concerned teacher and thus adverse remarks stayed in the field - Held, action of management could not be faulted and Department was not justified in taking action under S.20. (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Right of appeal
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), S.9 - Dispute as to seniority - Right of appeal - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - During pendency of suit, Rules of 1986 amended, thereby providing a right of appeal before Tribunal - A change in procedural law covers the pending litigation unless otherwise provided - Nothing in R.87A that right of appeal before Tribunal is available only to subsequent causes of action and not to pending proceedings - On introduction of R.87A, Civil Court lacked jurisdiction to entertain a dispute as to seniority - Remedy of appeal lies before Administrative Tribunal.
AIR 1976 SC 237 Ref. to. (Para 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Retirement
Age of
HeadNote.description: School Education Rules, R.88 - Retirement - Age of - Petitioner reached age of superannuation on 12. 04. 2006 - As per R. 88 petitioner was entitled to continue till 30.04.2008 - Amendment to S. 11 discloses that age to retirement has been increased from 58 to 60 as per notification dated 19.04.2006 - Contention that as per R. 88 petitioner was in employment on 19.04.2006 hence notification is applicable to petitioner - Continuation as per R. 88 after attaining age of superannuation is by way of re-employment and not as matter of right - Therefore notification is not applicable to petitioner - Petition liable to be dismissed. HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Retirement
HeadNote.description: School Education Rules, R.88 - Retirement - Amendment to S. 11 discloses that age to retirement has been increased from 58 to 60 as per notification dated 19.04.2006 - Bare perusal of notification discloses that respondent has not fixed any cut off date - Notification has been published on 19.04.2006, deemed to come into force from said date and as such, question of fixing of cut off date by respondent does not arise - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected. HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984)
heading: Appointment
HeadNote.description: Posts of principal in minority institution - Appointment - Constitution of Committee of chairman, Educationalist and Govt. officer - All appointments made by it sent to Govt. and approvals were granted - Further, committee reached to its conclusion after evaluation of merits of each candidate based on chart having rational criteria under supervision of Govt. observer - Plea that criteria was different from selection to selection, not tenable since procedure adopted was fair and deviation if any between two committees, cannot ipso facto mean it was not fair procedure - It was not a case of completely random choice without application of mind with utter disregard to seniority of candidates - Procedure also not reflecting complete abuse of society of its minority status - Thus, decision of committees cannot be inferred with, since procedure adopted in appointments was not unfair, absurd or in breach of principle of natural justice. 			(Paras 36, 39, 41, 42, 45, 47)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Scope
Teacher
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Vacancy arising on retirement of teacher belonging to Arts (Graduate) Category - Petitioner-teacher satisfying requirements of R.86 - She is entitled to be promoted to that vacancy in preference to another teacher absorbed under S.34.

Education - Teacher - Promotion.

According to Rule 86, when the seniormost teacher who is qualified to hold the post is available, then that teacher is entitled to be promoted to that post.  That Rule specifically says that the promotion should be made on the basis of the seniority if the incumbent possesses the requisite qualifications required for that post.  It also provides that management shall select the best qualified and most competent person from among those available for selection/appointment to the post.  [Para 4]

Rule 34 is a Rule enacted to meet a particular contingency of a Teacher being thrown out and become jobless on a fine morning without any fault of that Teacher.  A protection by the Rules is given to such Teachers from saving that Teacher from being thrown out of employment.  However, it is not the intention of the rule-making authority that by operating this Rule a statutory right of promotion to another teacher is to be jeopardized.  Right of being considered for promotion is a fundamental right of a Government employee, but this right is being extended to a private school which is run by the Government funds.  Rule 86 gives a paramount right to a teacher for promotion.  This right cannot be subjected to any fetters.  [Para 5]

The petitioner in instant case is having B.Com., B.Ed., qualifications with the subjects of English and History.  She was appointed as an Assistant Teacher in the school as an Under-graduate Teacher.  Another teacher was a Science Trained (Graduate) Teacher.  She was appointed on part-time basis as Under-graduate Teacher.  Her subjects were Maths and Science.  When a regular vacancy of Science (Trained) Teacher arose.  She being qualified for that post, was appointed in that post.  However, because of fall in number of divisions in the school, she had to be retrenched.  Again when an Under-graduate (Arts) Category Teacher resigned, she was accommodated in that vacancy, though she is Science Graduate.

In the facts of the case held that when a vacancy arose on retirement of a teacher belonging to the Arts (Graduate) Category, the petitioner being fully qualified to hold the post was eligible to be promoted to that vacancy.  Another teacher who was absorbed under S.34 could not be promoted to that vacancy.  When a conflict arises between Rule 86 and Rule 34, certainly claim under Rule 86 should prevail.  [Para 5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
HeadNote.sub_clause: R.34(3)- Head clerk of School becoming surplus and reversed
index: R.34- Head clerk of School becoming surplus
heading:
His pay and allowances last drawn by him has to be protected.

Where the petitioner a Head Clerk in a school is reverted because he became surplus, he would be entitled to pay scale and pay protection of the post of Head Clerk to whichever post he is absorbed, subject to availability of vacancies in the other School, or in the same School and in case the petitioner is absorbed in a lower post in the same School or another School, he shall rank senior most in the said lower post. However, if he is absorbed as Head Clerk he shall rank as juniormost in the said category of Head Clerk in terms of the second proviso to Rule 34(1) of the said Rules. In case no post of U.D.C. is available in any other School, the petitioner will be entitled to be absorbed in the School in which he is working and in such eventuality also pay scale of Head Clerk and pay and allowances last drawn by him in the said scale are to be protected.  [Para 12]

Insofar as the absorption of a surplus employee who is Head Clerk, against another vacancy of Head Clerk in another School is concerned, in view of the second proviso to Rule 34(1) of the Rules, the absorbed employee shall have to be treated a s juniormost person in the said category of Head Clerk. However, the same Rule cannot be applied if a surplus Head Clerk is appointed to the post of U.D.C. or, for that matter, against the post of L.D.C. in case no vacancy of U.D.C. is available in any School. On re-deployment against the said post of U.D.C. and L.D.C. which are admittedly lower posts than the post held by the petitioner, his seniority against the said absorbed post cannot be brought down as lowest in the category of U.D.C. or L.D.C. Even in case of reversion of an employee from higher post to lower post, after reversion the employee would rank as seniormost in the category where he is reverted. Accordingly, after reversion of the petitioner to the post of U.D.C. in the same school, he would be on the top of the seniority list of U.D.Cs. There is no reason as to why this principle should not be followed in case of absorption of an employee to a post lower than the one which he was holding. Ofcourse, if the surplus employee who was working as Head Clerk is to be absorbed in any other school in the category of Head Clerk, such Head Clerk shall have to rank as juniormost in the said category of Head Clerks in the other school in the absence of any challenge to the second proviso to Rule 34(1) of the said Rules. The petitioner who was holding the post of Head Clerk would rank as seniormost if absorbed against the post of U.D.C. irrespective of whether he is absorbed in the same school or other school, and will have to be placed on top of the seniority list because otherwise it will result in grave injustice to the petitioner.  [Para 7]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - It provides for appointment on probation - Does not apply to employees appointed in temporary vacancy or for limited period - Employee appointed for limited period - Cannot be treated as probationer.

Rule 83 deals with two types of vacancies namely temporary vacancy or any vacancy for a limited period.  The latter part of Rule 83(3) would prima facie cover within its ambit the appointment made for a limited period against a vacancy.  The employee appointed for a limited period cannot be treated to be on probation, since the Director of Education had granted approval on temporary basis for limited period only.  [Para 4,5]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: School
HeadNote.description:
School - Starting of standard 8th class in existing middle stage school - Amounts to starting of new school and not merely starting a new class - Requirements of R. 31 ought to be followed.

The contention is that the appellant-society wanted only to have a new class in the existing school, therefore, the norms laid down under Rule 31 are not applicable and Rule 32 alone should have been looked into by the Director, Education. This contention is not tenable for various reasons. Admittedly, the appellant started the school as a middle school and the Vth standard was started in the year 1994-95. VIth standard was started in 1995-96 and the permission to open the VIIth standard was given during the year 1996-97. The present request is to start VIIIth standard in that school which would convert the school to a secondary school. Even though the request of the appellant is to have a new class in the existing school but the real demand of the appellant is to have a secondary school as the existing school is only up to VIIth standard and if the school is to become a secondary school, norms laid down under Rule 31 are to be necessarily followed. The contention of the learned counsel for the appellant that starting of a new class does not amount to a new school cannot be accepted for the reason that rigorous criteria prescribed under Rule 31 are to be followed for starting a new school. For opening a new class in the existing school, the appellant-society need only satisfy the authorities that there are certain physical facilities available with the school and that there are sufficient students for starting a class. Whereas under Rule 31, the authorities have to take into consideration various other aspects and find out whether the opening of a new school is necessary to meet the educational needs of that area.  [Para 8]

Under Rule 2(1)(f), middle stage of the school is specifically mentioned as the stage of school education from Class Vth to VIIth (both inclusive). As regards 'Secondary Stage', an inclusive definition is given so as to take in standards Vth to VIIth also, within the secondary stage and that would only indicate that even if a school is having a middle stage consisting of classes IVth to VIIth still it would be deemed as secondary stage if there are classes from Vth to Xth. As regards the appellant's school is concerned, there are classes only from Vth to VIIth, it does not fall within any other category and it has to be held as a middle school. If it is converted into a secondary school by addition of standard VIIIth, we are of the view that the guidelines under R. 31 of the 'Rules' are to be followed as it amounts starting of new school having Secondary stage.  [Para 9]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - Order refusing to grant penalty to employee, challenged by Management - Contention that appeal is not maintainable in terms of S.22 at instance of Management Tribunal, held, not sustainable. 	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Grant-in-aid to pre-primary or primary schools
HeadNote.description: Grant-in-aid to pre-primary or primary schools - Such schools are not entitled to receive grant in-aid - Grants would not be available to non-Govt. Aided Elementary primary school teachers - Such primary school teachers would be entitled to benefits in terms of directions of the High Court in an earlier writ petition but not under law. (Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Promotion
Departmental Promotion Committee
HeadNote.description:
Goa, Daman and Diu School Education Act (1984), - Promotion - Departmental Promotion Committee - Factors to be considered by Committee - Senior most eligible teacher - R.86 does not give equal importance to seniority and merit - Seniority a principal consideration - Can be by-passed only when there is something negative indicating  teachers' unsuitableness - Reasons which play negative role must be described in minutes of Committee - However such reasons must have relevance to purpose to be achieved.

A cumulative reading of all the norms under sub-rule (2) of Rule 86 goes to show that the Rule requires that normally senior qualified teacher will have to be selected. It is only when there are tangible reasons to by-pass the claim of such person, any person junior to him can be selected. The Rule does not give equal importance to seniority and merit.

When the seniority has been made the principal consideration by the Rules, it would only be permissible to by-pass the claim of the senior most person if there is something negative which would disentitle him from being what is due according to his seniority. This negative has to be something to do with the job for which he is being considered. Therefore, in no uncertain terms, the Rule prescribes that such a reason which plays negative role in denying just promotion to a senior most teacher will have to be recorded in the minutes of the Departmental Promotion Committee. This is to ensure that arbitrarily any claim of a senior most person is not by-passed. The use of the expression "tangible reasons" also indicates that the reasons must have some relevance with the purpose to be achieved.  [Para 4]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Evidence Act (1872), S.115
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.115 - Appointment of computer teacher - Was subject to approval of Director of Education as per advertisement - Director of Education granted approval to her appointment on contract basis and petitioner accepted the same - She did not challenge order of approval on contract basis - In fact, on re-advertisement of post, without any protest, appeared before selection committee, participated in selection process without any force or duress - On her non selection, subsequently challenged her earlier termination of service - Moreover, Writ Petition filed six months after appointment of new teacher - Plea that she was legitimately expecting her selection on permanent post, not tenable - Since petitioner not holding requisite experience and accepted her appointment on contract basis, it comes to an end by efflux of time and issuance of separate order of termination, not necessary - Petitioner would be estopped from claiming that her initial appointment must be treated as regular one.			(Paras 15, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Order approving appointment of petitioners passed by Assistant Director
HeadNote.description:
Order approving appointment of petitioners passed by Assistant Director - Department cannot deprive petitioners of benefits of order on ground that order had no approval of Director - Such contention could be sustained only if order has been passed by defrauding Department or with malafide intention.

Evidence Act (1872), S.115.

The beneficiaries of an Order purported to have been passed by a statutory authority cannot be denied that benefit merely because there is a defect in that Order.  Viewed in this perspective, assuming for a moment that the contention of the learned Government Advocate that the Order approving the appointment of petitioner passed by  the Assistant Director has no approval of the Director, the contention could be sustained only if the Department succeeds in proving that the Assistant Director has passed the Order by defrauding the Department or with malafide intention. Only in a case of fraud or other vitiating circumstances alone, could such a contention be sustainable. Of course certain irregularities have been pointed out as regards the petitioners' appointments. These irregularities are, not very fatal so as to vitiate the entire Order. It is not the case of the Department that unqualified teachers have been appointed against the sanctioned posts and though the Department was trying to make out a case in such a line, on facts it has been established that all the petitioners are qualified to hold the posts.

Robertson Vs. Minister of Pension, 1948(2) All Eng. Law Rep. 767, Falmouth Boat Construction Ltd. Vs. Howell, 1950 (1) All Eng. Law Rep. 538 and AIR 1988 SC 1247 Relied on.  [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Graduate Teachers' posts sanctioned by Department
HeadNote.description: Graduate Teachers' posts sanctioned by Department - Management filling up these posts by promotion from lower category and resorting to direct recruitment for lower category posts - There is no illegality in action of Management. (Para 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Procedure adopted by selection Committee
HeadNote.description: Procedure adopted by selection Committee - No objection raised by Departmental Representative in Selection Committee to the procedure - Department cannot complain about irregularity in procedure as a shield to cancel order of selection and approval. (Para 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Minimum qualification of teachers
HeadNote.description: Minimum qualification of teachers - Advertisement inviting applications for post of part time graduate teacher to teach Geography and French - Held, advertisement was not proper - Prescribed minimum qualification was not notified and in its absence availability of qualified teachers cannot be ascertained. (Paras 7,9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Power to relax qualifications
HeadNote.description:
Power to relax qualifications - Relaxation can be sought only in cases where trained and qualified teachers are not available - Unless such situation is established by management , even by management of minority school, it cannot apply for relaxation of qualification.

Appointment of teachers - Power to relax qualifications - When can be exercised. (Paras 7,8,9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Refusal to comply with directions given by Director of Education
HeadNote.description:
Refusal to comply with directions given by Director of Education - That by itself cannot attract S.20.

The consequence of non-compliance of directions issued by the Director of Education can only have the effect as provided in the R.56 of stoppage, reduction or suspension of grant-in-aid.  The same do not justify an action under S.20.  Before an action under S.20 can be undertaken the case has to fall in one of the seven clauses provided in S.20(1) and hence the mere refusal to comply with the directions given by the Director of Education cannot and will not attract the provisions of S.20.  [Para 14]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Appointment and promotion
HeadNote.description: Appointment and promotion - Matter falls within power of management of school - Department has no say in matter except when there is difference of opinion between selection committee and management. (Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Confidential report
HeadNote.description: Confidential report - Promotion to post of Head of School - Most senior teacher bypassed by management on ground of adverse remarks in confidential report - No appeal against adverse remarks was filed by concerned teacher and thus adverse remarks stayed in the field - Held, action of management could not be faulted and Department was not justified in taking action under S.20. (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Right of appeal
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), S.9 - Dispute as to seniority - Right of appeal - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - During pendency of suit, Rules of 1986 amended, thereby providing a right of appeal before Tribunal - A change in procedural law covers the pending litigation unless otherwise provided - Nothing in R.87A that right of appeal before Tribunal is available only to subsequent causes of action and not to pending proceedings - On introduction of R.87A, Civil Court lacked jurisdiction to entertain a dispute as to seniority - Remedy of appeal lies before Administrative Tribunal.
AIR 1976 SC 237 Ref. to. (Para 20)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Appointment
HeadNote.description: Posts of principal in minority institution - Appointment - Constitution of Committee of chairman, Educationalist and Govt. officer - All appointments made by it sent to Govt. and approvals were granted - Further, committee reached to its conclusion after evaluation of merits of each candidate based on chart having rational criteria under supervision of Govt. observer - Plea that criteria was different from selection to selection, not tenable since procedure adopted was fair and deviation if any between two committees, cannot ipso facto mean it was not fair procedure - It was not a case of completely random choice without application of mind with utter disregard to seniority of candidates - Procedure also not reflecting complete abuse of society of its minority status - Thus, decision of committees cannot be inferred with, since procedure adopted in appointments was not unfair, absurd or in breach of principle of natural justice. 			(Paras 36, 39, 41, 42, 45, 47)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Peon
HeadNote.description: Peon - Regular appointment made during 1989-90 - Education Deptt. can restrict approval till April 1990 - Even if found surplus, he was entitled to protection under R.34 in view of his de novo appointment in 1991 - Mere fact that appointment was informed to Deptt. after more than 7 days is immaterial. (Paras 13 to 16, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu School Education Rules (1986)
heading: Surplus/retrenched teacher
Primary school
Unsustainable
Rel.on.
HeadNote.description:
Surplus/retrenched teacher - Primary school - R.34 applicable to primary school teachers - School bound to consider such teacher for absorption in another school - Teacher cannot be retrenched - Plea that circular granting salary only had prospective effect - Unsustainable - Entitled for salary for period of her retrenchment.

-W.P.No. 86/95, dt: 28-6-1997 (Bom)(DB) - Rel.on.

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Refusal to register sale deed
HeadNote.description: Refusal to register sale deed - Relating to undivided share in land - For not obtaining NOC u/S.49(6) - NOC u/S.49(6) is necessary where document required to be registered u/S.29(1) of Registration Act, purports to transfer, assign, limit or extinguish right, title or interest in respect of plots which are not as per survey plan - Plot in question is as per survey plan - Further, Chief Town Planner also stated that in case of registration of undivided share of land which is as per survey plan, NOC u/S.49(6) is not necessary - Order refusing to register sale deed, improper. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11, 13, 15, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Deemed sanction to plan
HeadNote.description: Deemed sanction to plan - Claim for grant of - On ground that appeal against order refusing to approve plan was not disposed of within 3 months as specified by S.45 - Proviso to S.45 provides that on failure of Board to dispose of appeal within 3 months from date of filing, it shall be deemed that prayer of appellant is granted - However, proviso for deemed approval or deemed permission cannot be stretched to extent of permitting construction or securing approvals for plans which are not consistent to provisions of law - Directions issued to authority to verify whether revised plans and request to furnish completion certificate is in accord with provisions of law and then only issue necessary approval/completion certificate. 			(Paras 8, 9, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Appeal
Dismissal
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Dismissal - Challenge - Appeal dismissed by Board with one line reasoning that construction of plot does not conform to the prevailing Regulation - Absolutely no discussion at all as regards rival contention - Absolutely no reasons given in support of decision - Reply just states that Board will hence forth pass speaking order - Action Board not only in violation of natural justice but against public interest - Matter remanded back to the Board. 	(Paras 5, 8, 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Revocation of development permission
HeadNote.description:
Revocation of development permission - Necessity of personal hearing - Revocation made for unauthorized construction over a drain and non-submission of certain documents - Respondent authority kept quiet for long time and allowed construction to be continued - Explanation sought when work almost completed - None of the explanations of petitioner was considered - Grounds mentioned in show cause notice were different from grounds mentioned in revocation order - No opportunity for personal or oral hearing given to petitioner - Principles of natural justice violated - Revocation order cannot be justified on fresh grounds - Liable to be set aside - Matter remanded to respondent authority for fresh decision after giving personal hearing to petitioner. 
2011 ALL SCR 260, 2010 ALL SCR 326, (1978) 1 SCC 405 Ref. to. 		(Paras 20, 21, 22, 25, 26, 27)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Industrial use of residential plot - Challenge - Respondents setting up a paper cutting industry for facial and toilet papers - Industry of respondents analogous to printing press - Printing press not using more than 15 H.P. electrical motors, are not prohibited in residential zone as per Reg.26 of Developlment Plan Regulations, 1989 - Not a case that respondents use more than 15 H.P. of electrical motor - Paper cutting industry is permitted also under Regional Plan for Goa, 2001 - Challenge by petitioner, not sustainable - As regards complaint of nuisance, petitioner can seek remedy under law of tort - No relief in writ petition. 			(Paras 7, 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Legality of construction
HeadNote.description: Legality of construction - Complaint as to excess of FAR/FSI - Held, it is for Village Panchayat to determine as to whether construction is wholly illegal or regularisable for alleged excess - Site inspection carried by Town and Country Planning Authority pointed out various irregularities in structures of respondents - However, inspection report not sent to Village Panchayat - Only a letter mentioning irregularities was sent - Respondents directed to apply for regularisation so that Village Panchayat and Planning Authority may take appropriate decision. 	(Paras 4, 5, 6, 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Expression "development"
HeadNote.description: Expression "development" - Construction activity of a building cannot be started without prior permission - Permissions applied after coming into force of CRZ notification of 1991 - As such restrictions under CRZ Notification, would be applicable to the project undertaken - Fact that lease agreement for project was approved prior to CRZ Notification would be of no help to the respondent. (Paras 13, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Immunity from legal proceedings
HeadNote.description: Immunity from legal proceedings - Is question of fact in the context of plaint allegations that entire action was fraudulent - Suit cannot be dismissed at threshold merely relying on the bar u/S.121. 	(Paras 21, 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Validity of
HeadNote.description: Illegal construction in costal regulation zone - Validity of - Construction made in 100 meters of No Development Zone - Construction made by breaching rule of law blatantly - Such construction and sanction to it are illegal and liable to be demolished. (Paras 58, 62, 63)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)
heading: Investigation u/S.156(3)
Rejection of application
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Investigation u/S.156(3) - Rejection of application - Challenge - Petitioner alleged illegal cutting of hill and excavation of earth by respondent - Respondent got permission u/S.17-A of Town and Country Planning Act on conditions of not cutting hill beyond permissible limit - Nothing on record to show that such hill cutting was beyond permissible limit - As such, commission of alleged offence, not established - Hence, rejection of application u/S.156(3), just and proper.  (Paras 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Village Panchayat Regulations (1962)
heading: Goa Panchayat Raj Act (1994)
HeadNote.description: Goa Panchayat Raj Act (1994) - Expression "any order" occurring in Sub-section (2) - Expression suggests every order is revisable by Dy. Director of Panchayats - It does not place any restriction as regards the nature of the order or the party applying for revision - Village Panchayat capable of applying for revision. 2002(1) ALL MR 912 (S.C.) - Followed. 	(Paras 5 & 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Village Panchayat Regulations (1962)
heading: Appeal filed on various grounds against order of demolition of construction
HeadNote.description:
Appeal filed on various grounds against order of demolition of construction - Challenge restricted only to two points relating to previous notice by Panchayat - There was no challenge to suit on ground of failure to serve notice under S.56 - No issue framed by trial court and no opportunity given to lead evidence - Such new point cannot be raised in first appeal.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.96. (Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Village Panchayat Regulations (1962)
heading: Order to demolish illegal construction
HeadNote.description:
Order to demolish illegal construction - Order passed by Block Development Officer - No evidence that Sarpanch was issued notice to perform his duties and there was failure on his part - Order of Development Officer was illegal and party could restrain its implementation.

If, at any time, it appears to the Collector that the Panchayat has made wilful and persistent default in the performance of any duty imposed on it by the said Regulation, the Collector may by Order in writing, fix a period for the performance of that duty and if the duty is not performed within such a period then the Collector may appoint any person to perform it and direct the expenses of the performance of the duty to be recovered from the Panchayat within such period as he may think fit.  Therefore, unless the directions issued by the Collector are received by the Sarpanch, question of appointment of a person to perform the duties of the Sarpanch cannot arise.

Therefore, the order passed by the Block Development Officer to demolish the construction could not be given effect to by the Govt. and the implementation of the order could be restrained by the party.  [Para 9]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Village Panchayat Regulations (1962)
heading: Order to demolish illegal construction
HeadNote.description:
Order to demolish illegal construction - Prior show cause notice to person accused of such illegal construction is necessary.

Constitution of India, Art.14.

Under S.83 whenever any illegal construction is noticed within the area of Village Panchayat, the action for demolition of such construction can be taken by the Village Panchayat subject to prior show cause notice to the person who is accused of having done the illegal construction.  In the absence of such notice being issued, it cannot be held that there was compliance of the provisions contained in Section 83 by the concerned Panchayat and, therefore, there was no occasion for the authorities to proceed to take any action under Section 49 of the said Regulation against person concerned.  [Para 10,11]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman and Diu Village Panchayats (Regulation of Buildings) Rules (1971)
heading: Construction licence
Revocation of
HeadNote.description: Construction licence - Revocation of - Licence issued can be revoked whenever there has been any false statement or any misrepresentation by applicant.	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman Diu Rent Control Act (1968)
heading: Decree no.43525
Scope
Notice terminating tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Decree no.43525 - Scope - Notice terminating tenancy - Served upon one of heirs of original tenant, since deceased - Noticee in his reply claiming to be tenant - Not suggesting that there were other heirs as joint tenants - Such plea taken in written statement for first time - Held, notice to him was valid - Transfer of Property Act (1882), Ss.106, 111.

In case of joint tenants, notice to one of the joint tenants is sufficient notice as against the other joint tenants and it is not necessary to give any separate notice to each tenant in case of joint tenancy.  [Para 20]

The landlord gave notice to one of the heirs of the deceased tenant terminating tenancy on ground of arrears of rent and bona fide requirement.  The premises were initially given on rent to the deceased father of the noticee.  In his reply to the notice he admitted the same and also claimed that on his father's death, he became the tenant of the premises.  He did not suggest in his reply that the other heirs of the deceased father were also tenants of the suit premises.  Accordingly, the landlord filed this suit against the tenant alone and it is only in the Written Statement that the tenant took the plea of non-joinder of other legal heirs who were also the tenants of the suit premises.  In fact, he would be estopped from taking such plea in view of the stand taken by him in reply to the notice wherein he contended that he was the tenant of the suit premises and the plea in the Written Statement has been taken to defeat the suit.  In the meantime, Rent Act was made applicable to the area in which the suit premises are existing and, therefore, the landlord joined the other legal heirs.  From the notice and reply it appears that the tenant alone was conducting business in the suit premises.  The notice on him will have to be treated as notice to all the other legal heirs as well.  Moreover, it is the case of the landlord that the rent of the suit premises was being paid by the tenant.  In reply to notice also the tenant contended that he was the tenant.  From all these circumstances, it appears that he was acting on behalf of all the other legal heirs, who were joint tenants.  The notice for eviction which was issued by the appellant was in respect of eviction of the entire suit premises and not a part of it.  In the circumstances the notice served upon him was sufficient compliance of law.  [Para 21,22]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Daman Diu Rent Control Act (1968)
heading: Decree no.43525
Eviction of tenant
Joint tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Decree no.43525 - Eviction of tenant - Joint tenancy - Suit filed against only one - Other impleaded after commencement of Rent Act - Civil Court's jurisdiction saved by S.59(2) of Rent Act.
Civil P.C. (1908), O.1 R.10. 
Limitation Act (1963), S.21.

A suit for eviction of tenant was filed prior to application of Rent Act to the locality wherein suit premises were situated.  Notice terminating tenancy was given to only one heir of the original deceased tenant.  No notice was required to be given before institution of the suit under Decree No.43525 on ground of non-payment of rent, though, under the Rent Act, such notice is required.  It was only after the heir raised plea in his written statement that he along with other heirs were joint tenants, that they were impleaded in the suit.  In view of S.59(2) of the Rent Act no rights can be acquired by the other heirs during the pendency of the suit which was saved from the applicability of the Rent Act vis-a-vis the subject-matter of the suit.  Therefore, the eviction proceedings which had been instituted for termination of tenancy of the suit premises as a whole would be saved under Section 59 of the Rent Act, not only vis-a-vis the heir against whom the suit was instituted initially, but also against the other heirs who were joined as necessary parties to the suit at a later stage.  The Civil Court had taken cognizance of the subject-matter as a whole and non-joinder of necessary parties was a mere irregularity, which was subsequently cured by bringing the legal heirs on record.  Accordingly, the jurisdiction of the Civil Court to deal with the matter against the other heirs shall not be affected in view of Section 56 of Rent Act.  In the circumstances of the case, the effect of Order 1, Rule 10(5) C.P.C. and Section 21 of the Limitation Act would be only for the purpose of determination of the question as to whether the proceedings as on the date when the new plaintiff or defendant is added, are barred by limitation and if such proceedings are barred by limitation as on the said date, the proceedings are bound to fail.  There is no limitation period prescribed either under Decree No.43525 or under the Rent Act to file a suit for eviction.  Therefore, the joinder of the other heirs at a later stage does not, in any manner, affect the proceedings.  The proceedings as against the other heirs are not bad on account of lack of jurisdiction in view of Section 56 of the Rent Act.  [Para 23,24]

heading: Constitutional validity
HeadNote.description:
Constitutional validity - State Act imposing duty on consumption of electricity - Even if electricity is generated outside State or is a subject of inter-State sale, in view of fact that consumption takes place within State, State Legislature competent to enact impugned Act - Said Act falls within Entry 53 of List II of Sch.VII of Constitution.
	In the present case, upon analysis of the provisions and scheme of the said Act, it is quite clear that the duty or the tax which the said Act levies, is upon the consumer of the electricity and neither upon the generator or producer of electricity nor upon any sale, much less any inter-State sale of electricity. Accordingly, upon plain reading of the provisions of the said Act and upon applying the principles adverted to above, we are satisfied that the said Act is relatable to Entry 53 of List II (State List) and consequently, the State Legislature was quite competent to enact the same.	(Para 25)
	The observations in NTPCL (2002) 5 SCC 203, upon which the petitioners seek to rely were clearly made in the context of a challenge to a State enactment which had levied duty upon the inter-State sales of electricity. The enactments sought to levy duty, not on consumers but upon the seller selling electricity in pursuance of inter-State contracts of sale. These observations therefore, cannot be torn out of context or applied to the challenges to the said Act, which, as pointed out earlier, impose no duty either upon the seller or upon sales, much less, inter-State sales of electricity.	(Para 34)
	We are satisfied that the case of the petitioners cannot be said to be covered by the decision of the Constitution Bench in NTPCL (2002) 5 SCC 203. Rather, we are satisfied that the provisions of the said Act, make it quite clear that the levy is not either upon the production or generation of electricity or upon the seller of electricity or upon any sales, much less inter-state sales of electricity. The said Act levies a duty only upon consumption of electricity by the consumers in the State of Goa and consequently, such a legislation, is entirely relatable to Entry 53 of List II of the VIIth Schedule to the Constitution of India and consequently intra vires legislative competence of the State Legislatures. 
(2002) 5 SCC 203 Disting.
2017 (1) Karnataka Law Journal 7, 2011 (5) Karnataka Law Journal 296 Ref.to.				(Para 37)

Validity

heading: Death by electrocution
Quashing of

(1973), S.482 - Death by electrocution - Complaint u/S.92 alleging breach R.132(1) of Goa Factories Rules - Quashing of - No negligence alleged on part of petitioner in so far as accident is concerned - Allegation is only as regards late communication of the incident - Petitioner tried to establish a contact with Chief Inspector of Factories and Boilers within four hours of death and subsequently faxed intimation to office of Chief Inspector of Factories and Boilers - Considering, overall circumstances and fact, possibility of conviction is remote and bleak - Prosecution would be in nature of abuse of process of Court - Hence, complaint quashed. 2010 ALL MR (Cri) 3942 (S.C.) HeadNote.description: Notification of accidents and dangerous occurrences - Liberal or reasonable construction - Held, R.132(1) of Goa Factories Rules allows four hours, which would mean that intimation has to be sent with reasonable dispatch and without delay. 2006(1) CHN 594 Foll. (Para 10)

Rejection of application
Appeal against

heading: Inventory proceedings
Dismissal
Review against
HeadNote.description: Inventory proceedings - Dismissal - Review against - Applicant was gifted share in landed property by her parents which she contributed in partnership business of family - Later on, she voluntarily retired from partnership on accepting Rs.35 lacs surrendering all her rights in properties of firm - However, after death of parents, she filed inventory proceedings claiming share in properties left by deceased - Contention raised that amount of Rs.35 lacs was accepted from partnership firm and not from inheritance - Brother of applicant appointed as Cabeca de Casal stated on oath in terms of Article 1370 that no movable and immovable assets were left behind by deceased - This statement was not objected by applicant - Another brother of applicant stated that after sale of certain properties by deceased, whatever has remained, belongs to partnership firm - There is also a Will of deceased which states that claim of applicant is restricted to Rs.35 lacs as already accepted - No fault can be found with order of dismissal - Under guise of review, applicant is seeking to reopen entire case - Not permissible.
