HeadNote.act_name: Goa Goa Daman and Diu Buildings (Lease Rent and Eviction) Control Act (1968)
heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Amendment of written statement - Amendment of pleadings is a rule and refusal is an exception - Amendment of written statement is always granted more liberally than the amendment of plaint.

There can be no dispute that amendment of pleadings is a rule and refusal is an exception and as far as the amendment of a written statement, it is always granted more liberally than the amendment of plaint.  Admittedly, the tenant by his first application dated 7-7-93 sought an amendment to the written statement, on the ground that it would be in the interest of justice to allow the tenant to take the plea of permanent tenancy.  However the tenant in subsequent application dated 14-6-04 did not assign any reason as to why the tenant was withdrawing the plea of permanent tenancy taken by him earlier.

The tenant by taking up the plea of permanent tenancy gave a new or additional ground to the landlords for the eviction of the tenant, in case the said plea of permanent tenancy was proved not to be bonafide.  Both the parties have been agitating over the said plea for over ten years.  It would hardly matter if the said period of ten years lapsed on account of the fault of either of the parties or for that matter on account of the fault of the learned Rent Controller in adjourning the proceedings for one reason or the other.  An amendment which would displace the landlords from the said new ground of eviction made available to him by virtue of earlier amendment application ought not to have been allowed and has rightly not been allowed to be carried out by the Controller as well as the Administrative Tribunal.  AIR 1971 M.P. 127 and AIR 1977 SC 680 - Referred to.   [Para 10]

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Promotion to post of Deputy Director of Health Services - Challenge to - Respondent was promoted to post of Deputy Director of Health Services, being senior to petitioners - Rules provide that person who is appointed as a result of earlier selection process would be senior to those who have been appointed as a result of subsequent selection - Document on record shows that respondent was appointed in earlier selection than petitioner - Also petitioner challenges promotion after delay of seven years - Promotion of respondent was not illegal. (Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Right to life
Shelter and housing
HeadNote.description: Right to life - Shelter and housing - Held, shelter and housing is part and parcel of right to life guaranteed by Art.21 of the Constitution of India - While fulfilling this constitutional mandate, the Board has to abide by Article 14 as well - All actions have to be fair, transparent, non-arbitrary and non-discriminatory, so also reasonable. 1990(1) Goa Law Times 291 and (2004)3 SCC 553 - Ref. to.	(Para 29)

heading: Right to life
HeadNote.description: Right to life - Goa Housing Board an instrumentality or agency of State - Board must fulfill its obligation under the Constitution and make the right to life meaningful, purposeful and complete - All actions of the Board have to be in conformity with the mandate of Art.14 of the Constitution of India - Writ petition against the Board, held, maintainable.			(Paras 52, 53, 54)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Suit barred by law - Non-service of notice u/S.52A of GID Act - Dispute between parties is about illegally blocking suit road providing access to suit property - Question whether acts complained of in suit are within scope and ambit of provisions of GID Act or beyond that is a disputed question, which cannot be resolved by mere reference to pleadings in plaint - Applicability of S.52A GID Act itself is in question - Plaint cannot be rejected under O.7 R.11(d) for the alleged non-compliance. 	(Para 19)

heading: Allotment of land
HeadNote.description:
Allotment of land - Lands acquired under Land Acquisition Act for industrial development - Lands placed at the disposal of GIDC are public properties - GIDC cannot arbitrarily allot lands - Allotment can be made only in a fair and transparent manner and also in public interest.

The power under Clause (a) of Section 14 of the transfer of lands vesting in GIDC can be exercised only with a view to ensure establishment, growth and development of industries. Therefore, the exercise of power under Section 14 for grant of land for setting up SEZs will depend on the factual situation such as the purpose for which it is going to be used by the SEZ. If the land is to be allotted or transferred to SEZ predominantly for promoting or establishing or developing industries, then the power to allot can be lawfully exercised.  In this case, the allotment of lands to the companies has been made in undue haste without proper scrutiny of their applications. The allotment of lands has been made arbitrarily. Procedure adopted in the allotment is not fair and transparent. The allotments made by the GIDC do not stand the test of reasonableness. 					 [Para 84,101]

It is true that the allotment of public property need not be made by holding a public auction as a matter of rule. However, the State or public authorities cannot act like private persons while disposing of the public properties. A public authority can allot lands only to deserving and eligible persons after satisfying itself about the credibility and capacity of the person. The procedure adopted while allotting public properties must be fair and transparent and the action has to be in the public interest. Before the concerned authority comes to the conclusion and records subjective satisfaction that the proposed allotment is in public interest, at least some kind of scrutiny of the credentials of the applicants is mandatory. In these cases allotment of large lands having area of more than 30,00,000 square meters was made to few companies within a span of few days or a few weeks. Moreover, the action of allotment shows lack of application of mind. Such huge lands which are public properties were allotted for the asking to the said companies in a manner not known to Law. The action of allotment of lands is illegal being arbitrary and unreasonable.						  [Para 91]

Even assuming that on the date when applications were made by the said companies, there were no applications made by any third parties for the allotment of the said lands, there was no reason to make allotments in a great deal of haste and without any scrutiny of the applications. Even assuming that the GIDC could have done it without inviting offers from competitors, surely the GIDC without satisfying itself that the allotment was being made to deserving companies having good experience in the field with a view to promote orderly establishment, growth and development of industries in the State of Goa, could not have allotted such vast lands. For recording such satisfaction, a scrutiny of financial status and capacity of the companies was mandatory especially when two of the companies were under formation. In the circumstances, a finding will have to be recorded that the allotment of lands to the said Companies was not legal.						 [Para 92]

heading: Notice u/S.52A of GID Act
HeadNote.description:
Notice u/S.52A of GID Act - Waiver, whether permissible as in case of notice u/s.80 CPC - Held, no provision under S.52A of GID Act is similar to S.80(2) of CPC, conferring power upon Court to grant leave to file a suit without serving of any notice - If S.80 of Code and S.52A of GID Act bear no similarity with each other, principle of deemed waiver of notice cannot be applied on S.52A of GID Act.

Provisions of Section 52A of Goa Industrial Development Act (GID) Act and Section 80 of CPC are neither comparable nor analogous to each other. The notice under Section 80 is required when the suit is filed in respect of any act purporting to be done by the public officer in his official capacity. The expression "act purporting to be done" is important and it would take within its fold even those acts which may not be actually part of the powers or duties of the public Officer, but are so intimately connected with the duties of the public officer as cannot be separated from them. This is not so, in case of Section 52A of the GID Act. There is no use of the expression "purporting to be done" therein and what is used is expression "in pursuance or execution or intending execution of this Act", which expression appears to be narrower in connotation from the former expression used in Section 80. In the latter expression, the act complained of must be such as is performed in execution of the powers, functions and duties under the GID Act or in accordance with the provisions of the GID Act or should be in respect of alleged neglect or default in putting into effect the execution of the Act. Thus, the act complained of should have direct nexus with the powers, functions and duties under the Act. This may not be so in case of the act contemplated under Section 80 CPC and it would be enough if the act, though not strictly within the four corners of the officials capacity, has been done in the course of discharge of official functions. That apart, there is no provision under Section 52 A similar to sub-section (2) of Section 80, conferring power upon the Court to grant leave to file a suit without serving of any notice as required under sub-section (1) of Section 80. Once we find that Section 80 CPC and Section 52A GID Act bear no similarity with each other, there can be no question of applying the principle of deemed waiver of the notice required under Section 52 A of the GID Act. It would be incorrect to say that once the authority contests the suit on merits, it could not complain later on of non-service of notice. Authority cannot be deemed to have waived notice under Section 52 A. Requirement of Section 52 A, one need not say are mandatory, which is clear from its language. The Section places an embargo upon institution of the suit until the expiration of the period of two months next after notice in writing has been given to the corporation. The Section begins with the words "No suit shall lie against the corporation or against committee......." and use of the word "shall" is sufficiently indicative of imperative nature of this Section. The Section also admits of no exceptional situation as it does not contain provision, unlike the one under sub-section (2) of Section 80 C.P.C., for dispensing with the notice.     [Para 13,14,15]

heading: Pension
HeadNote.description: Central Civil Services (Pension) Rules (1972) - Pension - Benefits of additional service as per R.22 of Rules of 2005 - Petitioner was appointed as President of Administrative Tribunal on 16.10.2003 and retired on 30.9.2012 - Pensionary benefit declined to him as he has completed only 8 years, 11 months and 15 days of his service - Before appointment as President of Administrative Tribunal, he was practicing as advocate and therefore, claimed benefits of additional service of 7 years under said R.22 - On count that post of President of Administrative Tribunal is equivalent to that of District Judge - However, these two posts were equivalent to extent of pay and allowances - Word "pension" does not appear in proviso S.2 of GJS Act - In absence of express provision and also because petitioner is not from Goa Judicial Service, R.22 cannot be applied - No illegality in declining benefits of R.22 to petitioner. (2010) 11 SCC 1 Disting.  (Paras 17, 19, 21, 23)

heading: Order of
HeadNote.description: Demolition of religious structure - Order of - Opponents are 194 residents of PDA colony carried out construction on Government acquired property - Representation was made by opponents that already temple was in existence and only repair work was carried on - Mamlatdar passed order of demolition without giving opportunity of hearing  to opponents - Order liable to be set aside.  			(Para 11)

heading: Clearing public lane
HeadNote.description: Clearing public lane - Order to clear rubble stones and material dumped by petitioner in public lane - Mamlatdar to perform function as authority under Act as per Gazette notification dated 22.09.1995 - Order passed by Mamlatdar is within jurisdiction and liable to be upheld.  (Para 7)

heading: Clearing public lane
HeadNote.description: Clearing public lane - Order by Mamlatdar to clear material dumped by petitioner in public lane - Notice was served, petitioner was heard, inspection was also carried out on petitioner's request - Principles of natural justice were followed - Order liable to be upheld. (Para 8)

heading: Removal of trees
HeadNote.description: Removal of trees - Order by Mamlatdar to clear material dumped by petitioner in public lane - Mamlatdar has no power to direct removal of trees under provisions of Act - Order of removal of trees liable to be set aside.  (Para 9)

heading: Demolition of house
HeadNote.description: Demolition of house - Order by Mamlatdar to clear material dumped by petitioner in public lane - Plan produced shows disputed portion does not cover house area of petitioner - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected.  (Para 9)

heading: Suit for declaration and injunction in respect of some land covered by notification under S.20 and some land not so covered
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and injunction in respect of some land covered by notification under S.20 and some land not so covered - Suit dismissed in its entirety - Contention by Government that suit was rightly dismissed in its entirety based on S.114 of the Revenue Code - Held in absence of such a plea in written statement and in absence of issue and decision thereon it would be premature for High Court to decide the issue in appeal - Matter remanded for deciding suit afresh after framing proper issues bearing in mind provisions of order 14 of Civil P.C. (Para 11, 12)

heading: Dismissal
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Portuguese Civil Code, Art.953 - Suit for declaration of title - Dismissal - Challenge - Suit was filed against Govt. - Name of ancestors of plaintiffs appearing in land registration record as well as survey records - Presumption under Art.953 of Code available in favour of plaintiffs that property belonged to them - Though there is endorsement in survey record that Govt. land is usurped, its translation does not appear to be correct - Nothing in original document suggests usurpation - Further, no steps were taken by Govt. for eviction of plaintiffs - That apart, witness of Govt. himself admitted that Govt. was never in possession of suit property - Presumption in favour of Govt. u/s.105 of Land Revenue Code, stood rebutted - Dismissal of plaintiff's suit was improper - Matter remanded back for fresh decision in accordance with law.	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Evidence Act (1872), S.35
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.35 - Suit for permanent injunction - Restraining defendants from interfering with possession of plaintiff over suit property - Plaintiffs claiming to be owner of suit property on basis of sale deed - Defendants have not challenged said sale deed - In revenue records also name of plaintiffs was recorded - Defendants objected to said revenue entries as those entries were made by deleting name of defendants - Appeal against substitution of said revenue entries is pending - However, pendency of appeal would not amount to rebutting of presumption of correctness of entries recorded by competent officer - Presumption u/S. 105 lies in favour of plaintiffs - Defendants have not rebutted presumption u/S.105 - Grant of decree of permanent injunction, proper.	(Paras 10, 12, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Cause of action
Accrual of
HeadNote.description: Cause of action - Accrual of - Suit for correction of revenue entries - When promulgation of survey, as provided u/s.75 of LR Code takes place, it becomes necessary for party to approach civil court.	(Para 34)

heading: Land
Nature of
HeadNote.description:
Land - Nature of - Agricultural land or non-agricultural land - Not depends on location of the land - Land located within municipal limits - Not necessarily a non-agricultural land - No presumption exists that all lands are agricultural lands unless converted into non-agricultural lands.

Neither the Land Revenue code nor any other law presupposes that all lands are agricultural lands. So also no law supports the presumption that the moment the land is found located in the Municipal limits of a city, the same has necessarily to be a non-agricultural land. Whether a particular land is an agricultural land or not or whether it is non-agricultural land or not would depend on the factual situation in loco in each case. It will depend on the evidence regarding nature of land to be placed before the authority competent to decide the said issue.  [Para 3,4]

heading: Conversion of agricultural Land for non agricultural purpose
HeadNote.description:
Conversion of agricultural Land for non agricultural purpose - Demolition of alleged construction by way of penalty - Actual user of land prior to conversion has to be found out.

There is no presumption that all the land in Goa is non-agricultural land and, therefore, before arriving at any finding that the Petitioner had converted the land for the purpose of non-agricultural use, it is absolutely necessary for he concerned authority to find out as to what was the actual use that the land was originally put to particularly prior to the alleged conversion of the land by the Petitioner. In the absence of any material in that regard, there is no occasion for the authority to hold that the Petitioner had converted the land in question for non-agricultural purposes. The entire proceedings having been proceeded on the presumption that there has been change in user of the land without there being any material in support thereto, it is apparent that the authorities have acted arbitrarily and in improper exercise of their jurisdiction while imposing the penalty of demolition of structure constructed by the Petitioner in the said area.  The orders cannot be sustained.  [Para 2]

heading: Presumption under
HeadNote.description:
Presumption under - Once an entry is made in Record of Rights by following provisions of Land Revenue Code, a presumption as contemplated by Section 105 has to follow it.

Once an entry is made in the Record of Rights by following the provisions of the Land Revenue Code, 1968 a presumption as contemplated by Section 105 has to follow it.  However, as far as this case is concerned, the dispute raised by the plaintiffs regarding the entry of the name of the defendant was not decided finally and on its merits by the survey authorities and as admitted by the defendant at the time of promulgation of the survey record the said dispute was pending.  In case the dispute was pending the name of the defendant could not have been transferred from the Register of Disputed cases to the Register of record of rights, and, in such a situation any promulgation done due to mistake would not give rise to a presumption available under Section 105 of the said Code.  The benefit of presumption was certainly not available to the defendant, as held by the first appellate court.  [Para 18]

heading: Survey record
Correction of
HeadNote.description:
Evidence Act (1872), S.110 - Portuguese Civil Code (1939), Art.953 - Survey record - Correction of - Findings that property described in land registration document and inscribed in matriz records does not correspond to property surveyed under no.43/1 - For payment of revenue property is recorded as paddy field does not mean it can remain so even after long lapse of time - It is law that identity of property cannot be ascertained on basis of documentary evidence - Appointment of Commissioner was not made to identify property as claimed by appellants on basis of documents - Further there is no discussion regarding possession of property - Decree in favour of respondents correcting survey record is liable to be set aside. 
2009(4) ALL MR 761, 2008 DGLS (soft) 2122, 2008 (8) SCC 671, 2004 (2) Mh.L.J. 594 Ref. to. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10)

heading: "Due inquiry"
HeadNote.description: "Due inquiry" - "Due" is always a relative term, and must be applied to each case in the exercise of the discretion of the Court - A notice to residents of locality before conversion application is granted may be desirable, but S.32 does not require that any such notice or public notice is to be give.			(Para 12)

heading: Conversion fees
Validity of
HeadNote.description: Conversion fees - Direction to pay as per Amendment Act 2013 - Validity of - Application for conversion was submitted on 8.3.2013 - Receipt of acknowledgment has to be issued within seven days - Receipt was issued on 29.4.2013 without any explanation for such inordinate delay - All requisite formalities for granting conversion were duly complied with much before coming into force of amendment - Respondent decided application of the Petitioner based on form prevailing in March 2013 and not form as prescribed by the Amendment Act 2013 - Also language used in amendment does not in any way provide that such revised rates would also be applicable to pending application - Crucial date to charge conversion fees is date of receipt of application - Direction to pay conversion fees as per Amendment Act, 2013, not proper. (2005) 10 SCC 203, (1991) 1 SCC 63, 74 (1998) DLT 152, 2012 SCC Online Calcutta 10759 Rel.on.	(Para 9)

heading: Record of Rights
HeadNote.description:
Record of Rights - Entry record of rights in register of mutation - Are presumed to be true unless contrary is proved - Presumption is rebuttable Evidence Act (1872), S.114.

There is a presumption under Section 105 of the Land Revenue Code as to correctness of Record of Rights entries which provides that an entry in the Record of Rights and a certified entry in the register of mutation shall be presumed to be true until contrary is proved or a new entry is lawfully substituted therefor. This means that the presumption which arises under Section 105 of the Land Revenue Code is not an urrebuttable presumption but is capable of being rebutted by producing evidence to the contrary.  [Para 10]

heading: Mutation entry
HeadNote.description: Mutation entry - Application under S.96 on basis of allotment which took place in year 1955 - Survey record of disputed property in occupants column discloses some other name - Petitioners have not derived their title from said person - After coming into force of Revenue Code succession deed was executed which shows petitioners have inherited property from their father - Succession cannot conclusively establish right on property unless property stood in name of deceased - Question of seeking any mutation entry on basis of deed of succession does not arise. 	(Para 6)

heading: Mutation entry
HeadNote.description: Mutation entry - In mutation proceedings authorities are not entitled to decide title of parties - Claim of petitioners for mutation is on basis of allotment which took place in year 1955 when survey number was not disclosed - Hence it was not open to petitioners to file application for mutation in terms of S.96 - Rejection to mutation entry sustained. 	(Para 7)

heading: Competency of Tribunal
HeadNote.description:
Competency of Tribunal - Order rejecting objections on application for mutation entry by petitioners - Assumption that impugned order was passed by Dy. Collector in exercise of powers of Collector in accordance with S.6 - Therefore respondent preferred second appeal before Tribunal - Appeal was filed before authority higher than Collector - No objection on this count was raised by petitioners - Order not liable to be interfered with.
1993 Bom. Civil J. 431 Ref. to. 	(Para 9)

heading: Land records
HeadNote.description: Land records - Presumption of occupancy and possession - Name of appellant shown to have been entered in index of land under form No.III - Form No.III is only a draft of index which is subject to correction and promulgation - There can be no presumption regarding correctness of entry in Form No.III - Same cannot confer any title upon appellant - Mere production of Form No.III cannot prove occupation or possession. (Para 21)

heading: Permission to transfer
Scope
HeadNote.description: Permission to transfer - Scope - Permission to transfer can be granted only when land is to be used for agricultural purposes - Such permission can be granted only to ascertained transferee - Mamlatdar must satisfy himself that parties are bonafide and capable of carrying on agricultural operations - Moreover transfer can only be to categories of persons set out in S.18J. (Para 8)

heading: Powers of authority
HeadNote.description: Goa Land Use (Regulation) Act (1991),S.2 - Powers of authority - Conversion of user of land in violation of S.2 - Conversion can be revoked by authorities u/s.33. (Para 10)

heading: Auction proceedings
Notice of auction

heading: Rebuttal of
HeadNote.description: Presumption of truth attached to revenue record - Rebuttal of - It can be rebutted only on basis of evidence of impeccable integrity and reliability - Oral evidence can be adduced contrary to revenue record but such oral testimony will not be sufficient to hold that statutory presumption stands rebutted - Presumption can be rebutted if such entry was made fraudulently or surreptitiously or where such entry has not been made by following prescribed procedure. HeadNote.description: Presumption of truth attached to revenue record - Rebuttal of - Mere pendency of appeal would not amount to rebutting of presumption of correctness of entries recorded by an officer competent to make those entries - Particularly when there is no order granting stay to directions mutating name of person in Record of Rights. HeadNote.description: Presumption of truth attached to revenue record - Entry in Record of Rights and in Register of Mutation, shall be presumed to be true until said presumption is rebutted or new entry is lawfully substituted therefor - This presumption would continue to hold good in respect of disputed entry and when finding is rendered by competent revenue authority in such dispute, and change is effected in Record of Rights, until entry is substituted by new entry. heading: Reference
Burden of proof
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964), S.58(2) - Reference - Burden of proof - Compensation - Appellants being claimants in reference under S.18 of Land Acquisition Act, in the position of a plaintiff - Therefore, held, burden was on them to prove that compensation offered under the award under S.11 of the Act of 1894 was adequate. 	(Para 9)

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - S.2 has been given overriding effect over the provisions of not only the Land Revenue Code but also for the provisions of Town Planning Act - Once the land vests in a tenant under the Tenancy Act, held, no person can use the said land for any purpose other than the agricultural use - Court cannot permit the parties to defeat provisions of law. 2007 ALL SCR 1363 and (1997)1 SCC 734 - Ref. to.			(Para 32)

heading: Effect of
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964) - Goa, Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974) - Non-obstante clause in S.2 - Effect of - Provision of Tenancy Act and Country Planning Act not replaced in their entirety but only to extent the conversion of land is prohibited u/s.2. (Para 10)

heading: Meaning
HeadNote.description:
Condition to use land for agriculture purpose - Exemption in case of acquisition - Meaning - S.3 does not enable landholder to claim that after acquisition, land should be valued as one with non-agricultural potential - Rather, it removes the bar of agricultural use when the land is acquired for public purpose.

The object of the Land Use Act is that no tenant in whom a land had vested under the provisions of the Tenancy Act shall use the land for any purpose other than agriculture. To see that he does not easily defeat the said bar by transferring the property, a prohibition was attached to the land itself by providing that no land which vested in a tenant under the Tenancy Act shall be used or allowed to be used for any purpose other than agriculture. But for the exemption contained in section 3, when such a property is acquired under the Land Acquisition Act for public purpose, the prohibition under section 2 in regard to use of the land for any purpose other than agriculture would have continued to apply. Therefore it was necessary to make an exemption in regard to the lands acquired for public purpose. That is, even though a land which vested in a tenant under the Tenancy Act was subject to a covenant that it could not be used for any agricultural purpose in future, once it was acquired under the Land Acquisition Act for a public purpose and vested in the government, the prohibition contained under section 2 would cease to operate, and the state government or the beneficiary of acquisition could use it for any purpose. Section 3 is therefore a provision which entitles the State Government or beneficiary of acquisition to use it for any purpose other than agriculture. The said section will not enable the landowner to get the market value of the land as one with nonagricultural potential. In so far as the landowner is concerned, the compensation to which he is entitled would be what he would have got if he had sold it in open market to a willing purchaser who could have used it only for agricultural purpose. 		   [Para 22]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Town and Country Planning Act (1974)Ss.13, 15, 17 - Goa, Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968) Ss.30, 32 - Condition to use land for agriculture purpose - Applicability - Notification issued in 1988 with proposal to convert agricultural land into industrial land - Plan thereof also approved in 1990 - Contention raised that even prior to commencement of Land Use Act, land had become industrial hence condition u/s.2 of Land Use Act would not apply - Held, notification & approval do not convert the land - Since conversion of land u/Ss. 30 & 32 of Land Revenue Code has not taken place, condition u/s.2 of Land Use Act would validly apply. 	(Paras 23 to 25)

Bar under S.2

heading: Comparison method
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Comparison method - When comparison method is adopted to determine the market value of the acquired land, the test is what a willing genuine and bonafide buyer will offer as price for the acquired land on the date of publication of a notification under S.4 of the Act.	(Para 12)

heading: Comparison method
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Comparison method - For the purposes of determination of market value of the acquired land, a sale instance of a developed land or a sale instance of a land having potential for non-agricultural use will not be relevant.	(Para 12)

heading: Market Value
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Determination , with reference to potential of land - Notification u/s.4 issued on 1.2.1990 - Land use Act restricting the use of land for agriculture only, came into force on 2.11.1990 - Relevant date for compensation is date of notification - Since on that date Land use Act was not in force, restriction imposed thereby will not be taken into account - Land in question can be valued as having potential for non-agricultural use.  (Para 7)

heading: Market Value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Determination - Land in question vested in tenant on condition that same will be used only for agriculture purpose - Land will be valued as agricultural land without any development potential - Value thereof will not be at par with adjoining land which is freehold and not subject to any condition on its use. 			(Paras 16 to 19)

heading: Art.30(4)(f)
Comparison method
HeadNote.description:
Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964) - Code of Communidate (Legislative Diploma No.2070) - Art.30(4)(f) - Determination of market value - Comparison method - Land held by Communidade - In case of a land held by a Communidade, the restriction on transfer will be one of the negative factors, which will have to be considered while fixing the market value - Taking into consideration the said negative factor, some deduction will have to be made depending upon the facts of a particular case while fixing the market value on the basis of a comparable sale instance of a free-hold land.

When a land is described as a free-hold land, it has reference to the tenure of the land. The characteristic of a freehold tenure is that there is inheritability and transferability as a matter of right. In case of a land held by a Communidade, there is no defect in the title or ownership of the Communidade, but the restriction is on transferring the land held by the Communidade by way of sale, lease or exchange. Restriction is that such a transfer by way of sale cannot be made without prior sanction. There is no complete prohibition against effecting such transfer. In case of an insolvency of Communidade, there is a power to sell land of Communidade. However, there is a general power vesting in a Communidade by virtue of Article 30 of the Code to transfer its land by sale, lease or exchange with the sanction.

While assessing the market value for the purpose of Section 23 of the said Act of 1894 by comparison method, the test adopted is what a prudent and genuine buyer will offer as a price of the acquired land. In case of a land, which is not freehold in the sense that a transfer thereof cannot be effected without sanction of the authorities, a willing bona fide buyer may not offer the same price, which he may offer in respect of a comparable freehold land as the buyer will be conscious of the fact that there are restrictions on transferability or that the authority empowered to sanction sale may impose some conditions. Therefore, he may offer to some extent a lesser price to the land having such restrictions. However, it cannot be said that the sale instance of a freehold land which is otherwise comparable to the acquired land cannot afford a basis to determine the market value of a land, which is having restrictions on transfer.

In case of a land held by a Communidade, the restriction on transfer will be one of the negative factors, which will have to be considered while fixing the market value. Taking into consideration the said negative factor, some deduction will have to be made depending upon the facts of a particular case while fixing the market value on the basis of a comparable sale instance of a free-hold land.  AIR 1979 SC 869 and 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 449 - Ref. to. 		 [Para 13,15]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Legislature Secretariat (Recruitment and Conditions of Services) Rules (1988)
heading: Promissory estoppel
HeadNote.description:
Fixation of pay scales - Promissory estoppel - There cannot be promissory estoppel against Law or Rules having the force of law.

In the case at hand, the scale payable to the translators of the Legislature Secretariat was revised by the Special Board who had no authoirty to revise the same in terms of Rule 6 in view of the fact that there were corresponding posts of translators in the State Secretariat and only in the event that there were not corresponding posts that the Special Board in terms of Rule 6(1) of the Rules could have determined the pay scales of the Translators of the Legislatuer Secretariat.  Not only that, the Order dated 7-7-1989 issued by the Under Secretary, Legislature did not even have the imprimatur of the State Government as required under the Rules and one fails to understand as to how without a formal approval of the Government and without changing the relevant recruitment which provided for a different scale Rules which a new pay scale from Rs.1400-2300 to Rs.1640-2900 came to be sanctioned in the case of the translators of the Legislature Secretariat.  In these petitions there is no question of attacking the Order of the Special Board by the Secretary (Legislature).  In fact, the Secretary (Legislature) who has filed the affidavit opposing the petition was duty bound to place the correct legal position, not only before the State Government but also before the Court as he has rightly done, namely that the translators of the Legislature Secretariat could not have been granted the said scale of Rs.1640-2900 when their counterparts in the State Secretariat were drawing a scale of Rs.1400-2300.  As far as the petitioner Yuvraj Naik is concerned, it is a clear case of he having been granted a revised scale of Rs.1640-2900 when he was not entitled to the same and having been so granted after 1-1-1986 the same had to be ignored in terms of Government Order dated 27-10-1997.  As far as the petitioner Smt. Blandina D'Sa is concerned, she could not have been appointed on a scale which is wrongly revised.  She is not entitled to the same on the principle of promissory estoppel since there cannot be promissory estoppel against Law or Rules having the force of law.  1972 S.L.R. 44 - Referred to.	 [Para 16]

heading: Goa Land Revenue Code (1968), Ss.14, 36
HeadNote.description:
Goa Land Revenue Code (1968), Ss.14, 36 - Quarrying lease in respect of minor minerals - Extinguishment of right of owner to grant such lease - Validity of 2002 Amendment - Provisions under Ss.14(2) and 36 of Land Revenue Code r/w. Art.2 of Portuguese Colonial Mining Law (20.09.1906) makes it clear that rights in minor minerals vest solely in State Govt. - Said legal position is even fortified by S.24-A of Mines and Minerals Act, 1957 - Right of land owner is limited to have compensation - Challenge to the 2002 Amendment is without any substance - Liable to be dismissed. 

Sub-section (2) of Section 14 of Land Revenue Code clearly provides that unless it is otherwise expressly provided in any law for the time being in force or in terms of a grant made by the Government, the right to mines, minerals and mineral products shall vest in the Government and it shall have all the powers necessary for the proper enjoyment of such rights.

Section 36 of the Land Revenue Code makes it clear that unless it is otherwise expressly provided by the terms of the grant made by the Government, the right to all minerals at whatever place found, whether on the surface or underground, including all derelict or working mines and quarries, old dumps, pits, fields, bandhas, nallas, creeks, river-beds and such other places, is and is hereby declared to be expressly reserved and shall vest in the Government which shall have all powers necessary for the proper enjoyment of such right.      [Para 12,13]

In view of sub-section (2) of Section 14 and Section 36 of the Land Revenue Code, right to minerals at wherever place found, has been expressly reserved and shall vest in the Government which shall have all powers necessary for the purpose of enjoyment of such right. It can thus be seen that in view of specific statutory provision which has reserved right in mines and minerals at all places in the State and also providing that the said mines and minerals shall vest in the State, the petitioner cannot claim to have right over the mines and minerals. The rights would be restricted only to surface soil.  [Para 27]

It would also be relevant to refer to Article 2 of Decree dated 20.09.1906 which was a Portuguese Colonial Mining Law in force during the erstwhile regime A perusal of Article 2 of the aforesaid decree would reveal that all metals and metal-liferous minerals belong to the State and such beds cannot be prospected or worked without licence and concession by the Government.  [Para 14]

In view of the provisions of sub-section (2) of Section 14 and Section 36 of the Land Revenue Code, read with the provisions of Article 2 of Decree dated 20.09.1906 which was a Portuguese Colonial Mining Law, the right in the minor minerals vests solely in the State Government and the State Government has all powers necessary for the purpose of enjoyment of such rights. This position is fortified by the provisions of Section 24A of the Mines and Minerals Act, which is applicable to all minerals, including minor minerals.

In view of the provisions of Section 24A of the said Act, a holder of a prospecting licence etc., is empowered to enter the lands over which such permit, etc. has been granted, at all times during its currency and carry out all such operations. The limited right in view of sub-section (2) of Section 24A of the said Act and sub-section (4) of Section 36 of the Land Revenue Code, is that the land owner will have right of compensation for such infringement.

In that view of the matter, the petition is without any substance and deserves to be dismissed.  [Para 31,32,34]

heading: Money Lender
Who is
HeadNote.description: Money Lender - Who is - A solitary instance of giving a loan does not make a person a money lender. 2004(4) Crimes 295 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)

Proof of
HeadNote.description: Money lending transaction - Proof of - Complainant advanced money to accused for business purpose - Accused failed to repay amount - Complainant requested accused to return principal amount he owed, by issuing cheque - Cheque issued by accused was dishonoured - Returning principal amount which was advanced by complainant to accused in terms of memorandum of understanding cannot be termed as money lending transaction - It would not be hit by S.2(I) of Act. heading: Validity
HeadNote.description:
Validity - Fees utilised for maintenance of Claims Tribunals - Satisfy principle of quid-pro-quo - Not illegal merely because maximum limit is not prescribed - Being a matter of fiscal policy - Plea of hardship to litigant not available - Rule not arbitrary discriminatory or ultra vires.

Motor Vehicles Act (1988), S.140, 166. Constitution of India, Art.14.

Salary and expenses for maintenance of the Motor Accident Claims Tribunal is comparatively larger than the collections made towards the fees by the Claims Tribunal. The difference in the collection and the expediture is very vast and the Government will have to meet it either by the imposition of independent Court fee for other civil proceedings or by defraying from their own exchequer. The fees collected by way of court fees cannot be utilised by the State for a purpose unconnected with the administration of justice. It is enough if there is a broad correlation between the fees collected and the service rendered to satisfy the principles of quid pro quo.

The fee prescribed under the Rules satisfies the principle of quid-pro-quo and need not give advantages proportionately to payer of fee.  [Para 5,6]

It cannot be said that the fee is illegal, since the Rules do not prescribe an upper limit.  [Para 7]

The plea of hardship to litigant is also not available, levy of fee being a matter of fiscal policy. Thus R.278 is not ultra vires.  [Para 8]

Legality

Locus standi
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.32 Rr.1 to 15 - Claim petition - Locus standi - Injured claimant filing claim petition through his wife - Claimant suffering permanent disability to the extent of 91.5% - He is bedridden, semi conscious and unable to respond - Held, injured claimant can be taken to be a person with mental disability - His wife can represent him as his next friend. heading: Application for declaration
Rel.on.	 [Para 6]
HeadNote.description:
Application for declaration - Mere fact that a person has been registered as mundkar, cannot be taken as conclusive until that person is declared as mundkar in respect of the dwelling house - The scope of an application under S.8-A and u/s.29 of the Act is entirely different - The entries made under S.29 of the Act are only presumptive in nature, while declaration u/S.8-A concludes the rights of the parties finally.

The scope of an application under Section 8-A and under Section 29 of the Act is entirely different. The entries made under S.29 of the Act are only presumptive in nature, while declaration under S.8-A concludes the rights of the parties finally. In view of this it is clear that the mere fact that a person has been registered as mundkar, cannot be taken as conclusive until that person is declared as mundkar in respect of the dwelling house.  It is pertinent to note that the application which was before the Mamlatdar was one for declaration under S.8-A of the Act. Therefore the Mamlatdar was obliged to hold an inquiry in terms of Rule 14, sub-rules (7), (8) and (9) of the Mundkars Rules. The question whether the applicants could be declared as mundkars of the respondents ought to have been decided only after holding an inquiry as provided under the Act and the Rules. 1995(1) Goa L.T.154 - Rel.on.	 [Para 6]

heading: Death of mundkar
HeadNote.description:
Suit challenging certain extensions made by mundkar to suit house - Death of mundkar - Her married daughter applying for being impleaded as defendant - Held even assuming that married daughter is not a member of family as defined in S.2(n) and she is not entitled to claim possession in respect of suit house, fact remains that as legal representative of deceased she has some interest in the suit house of which deceased was admittedly a mundkar.

At the stage of deciding an application under Order 1, Rule 10, C.P.C. the Court has to consider prima facie, whether the party who seeks impleadment in the suit has some direct interest in the suit property.  At that stage the Court has not to adjudicate as to what are the rights which ultimately the party is going to get in the suit.  If the party who seeks impleadment, prima facie, establishes that he has some direct interest in the suit property, the application of such a party for impleadment under Order 1, Rule 10, C.P.C. cannot be rejected.  It is difficult to accept the submission that Section 3 is not at all attracted in the present case.  Even upon harmonious reading of Sections 3 and 2(n) and (p) of the Act, it cannot be said that section 3 is not attracted in the present case.

The concept of dominus litus is not an absolute concept and if the court comes to the conclusion that a party is either a necessary or proper party, an application made by such a party for impleadment ought to be allowed by the Court.  Having regard to the nature of the controversy involved in the suit, it is clear that the presence of the petitioner is necessary in order to enable the court effectually and completely to adjudicate upon and settle all questions involved in the suit.	 [Para 5]

heading: Constitutional validity of S.184D
HeadNote.description:
Constitutional validity of S.184D - S.184D provides for a remedy of an appeal to Govt. against an order of appellate tribunal passed u/s. 184B - Held, appeal u/S.184B is dealt with by a judicial authority which has trappings of a Court - There cannot be any further appeal to an administrative authority and such an administrative authority cannot be considered competent to hold administrative review of a decision taken by the judicial authority - Providing for such a mechanism could be against the scheme of the Constitution - Thus, provision of S.184D declared as unconstitutional - Proceeding to be forwarded to appellate authority which would be created by State Govt. in this regard - Till then status quo ordered to be maintained.

Meaning of

AIR 1984 SC 385 Rel. on. 	(Paras 20, 30)

heading: Demolition of structures
Legality
HeadNote.description: Code of Communidade, Art.372A (Amended) - Demolition of structures - Legality - Petitioners erected suit structures without license of Municipal Council in land, which, according to them, belongs to Communidade and for which they are seeking regularization - Whereas respondent claimed to be owner of said land - Submission made that structures are assessed for tax and Municipal Council collecting same, has effect of regularization of structures - Not acceptable, as it was neither raised before Municipal Council nor before Tribunal but raised first time before Court - Once structures are found to be without permission, Municipal Council has right to initiate action for removal of unauthorised construction - Order of demolition is proper. 2007(2) ALL MR 317, 2002(1) ALL MR 131 Ref. to. heading: Exercise of powers of Chief Officer
HeadNote.description: Exercise of powers of Chief Officer - Allegations that Chief Officer refuses to follow mandate of S.74 of Goa Municipalities Act in matter of implementation of resolutions of Council - In matters of financial and executive administration of Council, Chief Officer is subject to control, direction, and supervision of Chairperson - Chief Officer must, under no circumstances act like some rival power centre in council - Chief Officer to assert his independence and act accordingly and not expected to take any sides or act under dictation while discharging his role - Chief Officer, in his affidavit, made bold but bald assertions about his compliance with provisions of Act and circulars - But orders by him and his unjustified refusal to implement even resolutions of Council that were admittedly not stayed belies such assertions and suggest otherwise - Secretary (Urban Development) must take serious note of conduct of Chief Officer and affidavit and reply filed by him - Statement/undertaking by Chief Officer that he will implement resolutions adopted by Council in its meeting, accepted and Chief Officer, directed to take steps accordingly. 			(Paras 41, 42, 43, 47, 49)

heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Expression "for any other reason" - Meaning of - Principle of noscitur a sociis would apply.

When the application is received by the Chief Officer in respect of the building permission, the Chief Officer has power to either refuse or grant the permission. The grounds on which the Chief Officer and council can refuse permission are listed in Section 185(1) of the Goa Municipalities Act 1968. The contingencies in which the permission can be refused are: if the Council has passed resolution acquiring the land; if the proposed construction would contravene the provisions of the Act or any other law or scheme or other orders passed; if the relevant documents and information required are not furnished; if no plans have been prepared for laying out streets; if there is no provision for access to the building; if the proposed construction is an encroachment on Government land; and for any other reasons recorded in writing.       [Para 8]

As regard the last ground "for any other reason", it will have to be read noscitur a sociis with the earlier grounds. This ground cannot be an independent ominous ground to include any reason whatsoever. The earlier categories deal with legal and technical grounds pertaining to the construction. They have direct reference to the proposed construction. The residuary power therefore will have to be in respect of legal and technical grounds, with direct reference to the proposed construction. This clause obviously will not cover adjudication of rights of a third party qua the proposed construction.       [Para 9]

heading: Order u/S.184A(1)
Remedy
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Order u/S.184A(1) - Remedy - Order of Municipal Council as to sealing of premises which was allegedly constructed without permission of landlord or Municipal Council - Challenged in appeal u/S.184(13) in which Appellate Tribunal directed Municipal Council to remove seal - Not proper - Only order passed u/S.184(8) regarding stopping, altering or demolishing disputed premises would be challengeable u/S.184(13) - Impugned order was order of sealing premises passed u/S.184A(1), against which no appeal is provided under statute - Once appeal filed before Appellate tribunal was not maintainable, order passed in such appeal would also not be sustainable - In such case, appropriate remedy would be revision application u/S.303 of Act. 2007 ALL SCR 207, 1992(2) Mh.L.J. 1573, 1988(3) SCC 26, 1974(2) SCC 393 Ref. to. 		(Paras 9, 10, 11, 13, 14)

heading: Order of eviction
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Order of eviction - Setting aside of, by Revisional Court - Challenge - Order of eviction passed by Chief Officer of Municipal Council on basis of evidence showing that petitioner is licensee to suit kiosk and respondent was permitted to use it only for a particular time period on account of illness of petitioner's father - Revisional authority set aside order of Municipal Council on ground of lack of jurisdiction and directed petitioner to approach Civil Court - Fact that issue before Municipal Council was as to who was licensee of suit kiosk, materially lost by Revisional authority - No basis for Revisional Court to hold that it was a family dispute or to relegate matter to civil court - Order of Revisional Court set aside. 	(Para 21)

heading: Order of eviction
HeadNote.description: Order of eviction - Jurisdiction of Chief Officer of Municipal Council - Source of power of Chief Officer to pass such order of expelment, is S.257(4)(i) of Goa Municipalities Act - Therefore, contention questioning power of Chief Officer held without any basis. 			(Para 20)

heading: Objection based on want of statutory notice
HeadNote.description: Objection based on want of statutory notice - Can be raised by any of the defendants and not necessarily by Municipal Council i.e. by a statutory body - Non-raising objection by Municipal Council cannot tantamount to waiver as there is statutory bar in entertaining suit in absence of notice. 		(Para 18)

heading: Powers of
HeadNote.description:
Chief Officer of Municipal Council - Powers of - No judicial power to decide right of access or easementary rights - Aspects of access can be looked into only when such right has already been established in public documents or pronounced by court of law.
1945 Law suit (ALL) 102, 1987 Law Suit (AP) 571, 1987 Law Suit (Bom) 16 Ref. to. (Paras 15, 17)

heading: Writ petition against
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Order of sealing of shops - Writ petition against - Maintainability - Alternate remedy of appeal available u/S.184(13) of Goa Municipalities Act - However, challenge to order is based on violation of principles of natural justice - Therefore, writ petition is maintainable without relegating parties to resort to alternate remedy. 	(Para 10)

heading: Order of sealing of shops
HeadNote.description: Order of sealing of shops - Challenge, on ground of breach of principle of natural justice - Petitioners are allegedly renovating suit shop illegally - Show-cause notice issued to them which has not been disposed of - In mean time, despite stop work order, petitioners continued such illegal work and therefore, impugned order of sealing shops passed - Since show cause notice is yet to be disposed of and matter is placed for affording personal hearing of petitioners, impugned order is set aside. 		(Para 11)

heading: Committee
HeadNote.description: Committee - For management of waste - Rules require every local authority to constitute such committee - Affidavit filed by respondent discloses that no such committee is formed - Directions given to respondent to constitute Waste Management Committee - Petition allowed. 	(Paras 5, 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Panchayat (Constitution Powers and Functions of Ward Development Committees and Preparation of Annual Development Plan) Rules (2008)
heading: Development committees
HeadNote.description: Development committees - Rule mandates Gramsabha to constitute two or more developmental committees in every Panchayat for different sectors of development - Affidavit filed by respondent which discloses that no steps are taken to comply with R.6 - Respondent directed to constitute Ward Development Committees - Petition allowed. 	(Paras 4, 6)

heading: No confidence motion
Majority
HeadNote.description: No confidence motion - Majority - Resolution expressing want of confidence has to be passed by a majority of the total number of members of the panchayat, and not the members present at the specially convened meeting for that purpose.	(Para 8)

heading: Resolution
HeadNote.description: Resolution - Difference between 'defeat' and 'non-passing by requisite majority' of a Resolution - Non-passing of a resolution with the requisite majority is different from a resolution which is defeated - In 'defeat' voting against Resolution should be by majority. 1995(1) Goa L.T. 302 and AIR 1966 Bom. 149 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)
