heading: Claim for
HeadNote.description: Postponement of Zilla Panchayat election - Claim for - Ground of threat of COVID-19 virus - If election was conducted half of population of State will gather and there will be movement of more than 10,000 Govt. employees, which will constitute mass gathering - As per directions issued by Central Govt., State Govt. and WHO mass gatherings is to be avoided - Further, provisions of sanitization, mopping, hand wash would not be sufficient to prevent spread of Corona virus in case of such mass gathering - Holding of election in such time would cause potential threat to health of citizen as well as Govt. officials - Elections postponed. (Paras 4, 5, 7, 8)

heading: Prohibition under
HeadNote.description: Prohibition under - Respondent No.1/member of Panchayat having pecuniary interest in matter under discussion - Respondent No.1, held, disqualified from voting on or taking part in discussion of any question in the meeting of Panchayat if he has any pecuniary interest in such question. Constitution of India, Art.243-O(b). AIR 1977 SC 237 & AIR 1966 SC 1339 - Rel. on.		(Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Meaning
Meeting therefor
HeadNote.description: Vacating seat by member of panchayat - Expression "pecuniary interest" in S.55(4) of Goa Panchayat Raj Act - Meaning - Regularisation of illegal construction in ancestral house recorded in name of father in law of respondent - Meeting therefor - Respondent member of panchayat attended meeting and voted in favour of resolution - Respondent proved to have lived in that house soon after marriage - Merely stating that respondent now lives in adjacent house, or some other house - Does not mean that respondent had no "pecuniary interest" in said house and in resolution to regularise illegal constructions therein - Record even showing that application was made by her own brother in law - Thus, respondent can be said to have voted in contravention of S.55(4) - Therefore, respondent would be deemed to have vacated her seat as member of panchayat.		(Paras 29, 30, 31, 32, 33)

heading: Disqualification of member of village Panchayat
HeadNote.description: Disqualification of member of village Panchayat - Respondent member participated in meeting in which permission was granted for repair of house construction - In application preferred for repair of house, he himself disclosed that he was owner of subject construction - Fact that repairs of house would enhance value and utilization of structure and consequently, creates pecuniary interest to respondent - Respondent would stand disqualified u/S.12(1)(d) r/w S.55(5) and consequently, cease to be member of Panchayat.			(Para 9)

heading: Demolition order
Issuance of
HeadNote.description: Demolition order - Issuance of - On ground that store room was constructed without permission of Panchayat - Store room was in existence since long and was earlier used as cattle shed cum storeroom and it was only repaired in view of fast approaching monsoon - Same proved by survey plan which shows that cattle shed was in dilapidated condition - Further, question of permission u/S.66 Goa Panchayat Raj Act arose only in case of erection, addition, alteration or reconstruction - Permission not required in case of work of repairs like repair of existing cowshed - Demolition order liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 6, 10, 11)

heading: Writ petition
Maintainability of
HeadNote.description: Writ petition - Maintainability of - Complaint for joining petitioner as against party to blockage of access/pathway filed by respondent - Application filed by petitioner in proceedings before Lower Appellate Authority - Application not allowed by Appellate Authority - Order expected to be passed in appeal by Lower Appellate Authority in no way adverse to the interest of the petitioners nor in relation to the alleged blockage of access/pathway in question as such - Appeal related to the fact that concerned Panchayat Authority had failed to take even cognizance of the complaint regarding the blockage of access/pathway which is stated to have been illegal - In this view of the matter, held, no illegality committed either by lower Authority nor there is any fraud as such played by the respondents upon the Court in non-joining the petitioners as party to the said proceedings - Petition dismissed.			(Paras 3 to 5)

heading: Disqualification of panchayat member
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification of panchayat member - Words 'Pecuniary' and 'Interest' - Complaint against member/respondent of doing illegal construction - Respondent participated in discussion of said complaint in panchayat meeting and proposed to reject complaint - As per provision and definition of words 'pecuniary' and 'interest', issue discussed was of 'pecuniary interest' of respondent - Respondent is liable to be disqualified as member.

In panchayat meeting issue of illegal construction by respondent was discussed.  Issue was of pecuniary interest of respondent/member.  Respondent participated in meeting and also proposed rejection of complaint when resolution was passed.  Thereafter in another meeting resolution was adopted and stated that proposal to reject complaint was made by another member and it was wrongly recorded that proposal was made by respondent no.1.  Secretary in his reply on affidavit and on endorsement made by him while recording minutes of resolution no.20 stated that minutes of resolution no.10 recorded by him are factually correct and no member was ready to listen to him while passing resolution no.20.  Furthermore though the house number of respondent No.1 stated in complaint is incorrect, subject structure is located at same place mentioned in complaint and respondent no.1 was served with notice on address with incorrect house number.  Hence resolution no.20 or incorrect house number do not save respondent no.1 from clutches of provisions of S.55(4).  Respondent no.1 is liable to be disqualified as member.  [Para 20,22,23,27]

heading: Scope of S.201A and its explanation
HeadNote.description: Scope of S.201A and its explanation - It covers a situation of failure or non-conveying of a reply or inaction - Petitioner made representation before Panchayat alleging misuse of construction in question - Said representation met with no response - Aggrieved thereby he preferred appeal before B.D.O. - Finding by authority that appeal is incompetent - Revision against filed before Dy. Director wherein order of B.D.O. was upheld - Both authorities failed to exercise power vested in them - Petition allowed.	(Paras 7, 8, 9, 10)

heading: Appeal or Writ Petition
HeadNote.description:
Appeal or Writ Petition - Can be filed only by an aggrieved person when it is otherwise not filed in public interest. 

Section 66 of the Goa Panchayat Raj Act provides for grant of permission by the Village Panchayat and to take action against constructions or reconstructions done without its permission. It is the primary duty of the Village Panchayat as an elected body to grant permissions and to take actions for demolitions in cases of buildings which are erected, added or reconstructed without such permissions. In case the Panchayat fails to grant permission when applied for, then the applicant is entitled to approach the Deputy Director in an appeal and obtain such a permission. It may be that the Village Panchayat is an elected body while the Deputy Director or the Director are government servants, but the fact remains that the Act provides a hierarchy of authorities for the grant of permission for the construction of buildings and/or demolition of illegal constructions carried out without permission or contrary to the rules. Again, it may be noted that the Panchayat may be elected body, but when it fails to decide an application for permission or take action for demolition in terms of Sub-sections (3) and (4), its powers are exercised or can be taken over by the Deputy Director who is entitled to take such steps as may be necessary for grant of licence or the demolition of the buildings. That one authority is elected and the others are not is of no consequence. That a Village Panchayat is heard by the Deputy Director or the Director before passing orders in appeals is only for the purpose of defending its action and for compliance of principles of natural justice but such a procedural formality cannot be construed as conferring a right of appeal on the Village Panchayat to challenge the orders of the Deputy Director or of the Director. There cannot be an appeal unless it is specifically provided for by the statute. In other words, Section 66 of the Act operates and regulates a mechanism of granting permission/s for the construction of building/s and demolition thereof, in case they are constructed without permission or contrary to the rules or conditions imposed by the permissions which are granted.

These Writ Petitions certainly are not filed in public interest against the orders of the Additional Director of Panchayats. They could be filed only if some rights of the petitioners are affected. Petitioners cannot be said to be aggrieved by the decisions of the Additional Director of Panchayats who in the scheme of Section 66 of the Act has been conferred an authority to hear appeals from the decisions of the Village Panchayat. An appeal or a Writ Petition can be filed only by an aggrieved person when it is otherwise not filed in public interest. The expression "Aggrieved" has been defined by Black's Law Dictionary as having suffered loss or injury; damnified; injured. An "Aggrieved party" has been defined in the same dictionary as one whose legal right is invaded by an act complained of, or whose pecuniary interest is directly and adversely affected by a decree or judgment. One whose right of property may be established or divested. The word "aggrieved" refers to a substantial grievance, a denial of some personal, pecuniary or property right, or the imposition upon a party of a burden or obligation.

1995 (1) SCC 203; 2002 (1) SCC 33 - Ref . to.  [Para 18,19]

heading: Meeting for no confidence motion
HeadNote.description: Meeting for no confidence motion - Meeting convened for removal of Sarpanch and Dy. Sarpanch - Only two members were present out of eight members - Meeting convened was also stayed by Addl. Director of Panchayats - BDO refused to call fresh meeting by stating that no confidence motion was passed by meeting attended by two members - Held BDO was not justified in taking such a view because quorum required was of five members out of eight and as such meeting attended by only two members could not have passed resolution and further meeting was also stayed by Addl. Director of Panchayats.  (Para 10)

heading: Locus to file writ petition
HeadNote.description:
Locus to file writ petition - Notice issued under S.64 challenging illegally constructed wall blocking access to water well, chapel and existing drains - Complaint also filed by local residents - Appeal by company allowed by Block Development Officer by  interim order under S.66 - Held High Court could not have summarily dismissed writ petition holding that it was not maintainable at the instance of Village Panchayat.

While the Village Panchayat and the Sarpanch had exercised their respective powers in public interest, Block Development Officer nullified that exercise because he felt that the resolution/action was contrary to law and was unjustified. While exercising the power under the Act, the Panchayat was not acting as a subordinate to Block Development Officer but as a body representing the will of the people and also a body corporate in terms of Section 8 of the Act. Therefore, it had the locus to challenge the orders passed by Block Development Officer and the High Court was clearly in error in holding that the writ petition was not maintainable.  [Para 21,26]

heading: Prohibition under
HeadNote.description: Prohibition under - Should not receive unduly narrow or restricted consideration - Expression "in any contract" - Appellant's husband awarded contract by Village Panchayat - His wife in law becomes entitled to share in the profits of the contract and as such she incurs disqualification as a Panch member of the Village Panchayat. (Para 23)

heading: Panchayat resolution
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Panchayat resolution - Decision taken to withhold petitioners application for building construction - Challenge - Whether, maintainable u/S.178 or u/S.66 - Held, there can be either acceptance or rejection of application - Withholding an application is unknown to Panchayat Act - Such withholding as to be taken as rejection - Challenge to it will be maintainable u/S.66 - No question of rescission of resolution u/S.178. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification - Restriction against taking part in meetings for private interest - Wife of respondent sought NOC to open a restaurant - Evidence on record showed that respondent had attended meeting wherein NOC was granted - Respondent at one stage stated that he had left meeting hall when issue of NOC was being considered - At other, he stated that he had attended meeting but did not take part in discussion on NOC - Held, respondent cannot be allowed to change his stand frequently - Distinction between "taking part in proceeding" & "taking part in discussion" also not tenable - In view of direct pecuniary interest involved, respondent stands disqualified.

Evidence on record unmistakably shows that the Respondent no.1 took part in the discussion, on the question in respect of which resolution no.5(3) was passed. It is clear that the Respondent was present during the entire meeting and he participated in the proceedings. It was respondent case that he left the meeting hall when the question of grant of NOC to his wife was being discussed. Thus, his stand is that he did not take any part in the discussion. Accepting such an argument would be ignoring the overwhelming evidence on record and allowing Respondent to change his stand frequently. The cross-examination of the Secretary of the Village Panchayat by Respondent no.1 reveals that in answer to a specific question on this point, the Secretary replied that all the members present participated in the said discussion. Thus, it is too late in the day to argue now that the Respondent does not incur any disqualification.

The version of the Respondent in his affidavit in evidence is that he had not participated in the discussion in the meeting held on 28.12.2007

It is argued that a provision for disqualification should be strictly construed as it is penal in nature, but the Hon'ble Supreme Court held that even such a provision can be interpreted consistent with the object and purpose for which the same is enacted.

Undue emphasis on the distinction as may frustrate and defeat the object sought to be achieved.

Once there is evidence to indicate that there is participation in the discussion when the question was taken up, then, to what extent and what degree the participation is, cannot be of much relevance. If all the conditions stipulated by the subject sub-section are satisfied, namely, about pecuniary interest of the member, then, he must incur the disqualification. AIR 1955 SC 459, AIR 1966 SC 1339 - Rel. on. AIR 2005 SC 688 Referred.  [Para 22,24,25,26,29]

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification - Respondent no. 3 is member of Village Panchayat - He participated in meeting in which NOC for milk booth for his son granted - Minutes of said meeting were confirmed in other meeting in which respondent no. 3 was present - Son of respondent no. 3 was minor - Contract entered into with Panchayat  could have done only through guardian i.e. father respondent no.3 - Contention that respondent no.3 had no pecuniary interest cannot be accepted - Respondent no. 3 stands disqualified as a member of Village Panchayat under S.12(1)(d) r/w S.55(4).  
2011(6) ALL MR 746, 2010(4) ALL MR 97, 2011(4) ALL MR 559, AIR 1966 SC 1339, 2012(2) ALL MR 48 (S.C.), 2010 (2) Goa L. R. 109 Ref. to. 	(Para 13, 14, 15)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Whether on date of election member was citizen of India - Amendment of petition sought to incorporate provisions of foreign laws applicable to case - Amendment is governed by Civil P.C. O.6 R.17 and can be allowed at any stage - Application cannot be said to be time barred by limitation. (Paras 9, 14)

heading: Writ of quo-warranto
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification of member of Village Panchayat - Writ of quo-warranto - Respondent member alleged to have participated in a meeting of Panchayat wherein she had pecuniary interest - Said meeting related to renewal of construction licence of her husband - Minutes of said meeting reveal presence of respondent wherein decision was taken to renew the licence - Respondent contended that she did not discuss the subject and walked out of meeting - But, same was not recorded in minutes - Presumption that respondent discussed the proceeding, stands unrebutted - Respondent had share in property of her husband as per law of communion of assets - Having pecuniary interest, she attended meeting in contravention of S.55(4) - Disqualified. 
2011(4) ALL MR 559 Ref. to. (Paras 11, 12, 15, 16, 17, 18, 22)

heading: Disqualification of member of Village Panchayat
HeadNote.description: Disqualification of member of Village Panchayat - On ground of having pecuniary interest in property of his father - Respondent-member of Village Panchayat was present when resolution passed to grant occupancy certificate and house tax was assessed in respect of workshop of his father - No evidence on record showing that respondent-member was carrying out business in workshop of his father - Merely sentimental or friendly interest cannot be termed as pecuniary interest to disqualify member of village panchayat - Respondent cannot be disqualified as member of Village Panchayat.	(Paras 6, 8)

heading: Demolition order
HeadNote.description: Demolition order - By Village Panchayat on ground that petitioner has carried out illegal construction to her house and shop without permission of Panchayat - Record showing that structures were in existence since 1987 and there was NOC of Village Panchayat to carry out commercial activities therein - Civil Court also in suit filed by respondent seeking assertion of her right in suit property gave finding that petitioner had not carried out illegal construction in suit property and they cannot be restrained from carrying out commercial activities in their shop - Village Panchayat ignored all these materials while passing demolition order - Demolition order liable to be set aside. 		(Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Disqualification of member of village panchayat - On ground of participation in meeting, where member had pecuniary interest - Legality - Member incurred expenses for removing bull/cow fallen in well - Incurring expenses in that regard are generally for benefit of public - Member cannot have personal interest in removing such animal - In performance of such duty, any amount spent has to be reimbursed to the concerned member - Receiving such reimbursement cannot give any pecuniary gain to member - Merely because member participated in meeting where reimbursement of an amount made, admittedly spent by member for benefit of public, cannot result in pecuniary interest for incurring disqualification - Also there is some ambiguity in minutes of meeting, which without being subject to cross examination cannot be relied - Failure to prove any pecuniary interest on part of member - Member cannot be disqualified. 	(Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - To contest election of Gram Panchayat - On ground that contract of petitioner-candidate with Govt. was subsisting on date of filing of nomination - Petitioner contended that work under contract was completed before filing of nomination - However, on date of filing nomination, it was his responsibility to make good if any defect is found in work - As long as liability to make good loss or damage in work is in existence on date of nomination, contract cannot be said to be concluded - Disqualification of petitioner to contest election, proper. 	(Paras 17, 19, 20)

heading: Disqualification
Pecuniary Interest
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - Pecuniary Interest - Mere Pecuniary Interest of a member of a Panchayat would disqualify him if he votes or takes part in the discussion of any question which comes up for consideration. 2009(5) ALL MR 702, 2010(6) ALL MR 352 - Ref.to. 	(Para 22)

heading: Revision application u/S.201B
HeadNote.description: Revision application u/S.201B - Whether, S.5 of Limitation Act would apply - For condoning delay of 29 days in filing revision - No provision in entire Act of 1994 for condonation of delay - Scheme of Act of 1994 as whole and S.201-B do not show that provisions of Limitation Act are either expressly or implicitly excluded - Use of word "shall" in S.201-B is not sufficient to hold that it excludes provisions as to condonation of delay - Reading of provisions for condonation of delay in filing revision u/S.201-B would not defeat object of deciding revision application expeditiously as is required u/S.201-B(4) - On taking recourse to S.29(2) of Limitation Act, provisions of S.5 of Limitation Act will be applicable to revision application. 2002(4) ALL MR 605 (S.C.), 2007(5) ALL MR 436 (S.C.), (2004) 4 SCC 252, (1997) 1 SCC 373 Disting. (Paras 9, 10, 19, 22, 24, 25)

heading: Revision application u/S.201-B
HeadNote.description: Revision application u/S.201-B - Whether, S.239-B would apply, as much as it refers to appeal or petition and not to revision - Although S.201-B provides for "revision to be filed", it has to be in nature of application or petition to District Court - For this reason, Legislature might not have thought it fit to correspondingly amend S.239-B to specifically mention about revision therein - It is trite that various statutory provisions in Act have to be read harmoniously to avoid any conflict and to ensure that none of them is rendered otiose. (Para 14)

heading: Disqualification for membership
Non
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification for membership - Absence of Rules under new Act - Non - Payment of dues to Panchayat - Letter issued to delinquent by Panchayat for payment of dues - Two years there after, portion of amount paid - Held, letter issued was a demand legally made and hence disqualification was incurred for non-payment of dues within three months from receipt of letter.

Goa, Daman and Diu Village Panchayats (Recovery of Dues) Rules (1966), R.3

Disqualification for membership of Panchayat-Non-Payment of dues to Panchayat-Letter issued by Panchayat to delinquent for payment of dues-whether can be treated as demand. (Paras 6,8,9)

heading: Jurisdiction of Election Commission
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Election Commission - It gets jurisdiction only on reference of question made to it - S.11 does not give any party other than Panchayat, any right to approach Election Commission for final decision

Village Panchayat - Jurisdiction of Election Commission. (Para 10)

heading: No confidence motion
Majority
HeadNote.description: No confidence motion - Majority - Resolution expressing want of confidence has to be passed by a majority of the total number of members of the panchayat, and not the members present at the specially convened meeting for that purpose.	(Para 8)

heading: Resolution
HeadNote.description: Resolution - Difference between 'defeat' and 'non-passing by requisite majority' of a Resolution - Non-passing of a resolution with the requisite majority is different from a resolution which is defeated - In 'defeat' voting against Resolution should be by majority. 1995(1) Goa L.T. 302 and AIR 1966 Bom. 149 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)

heading: Pecuniary interest
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of - Pecuniary interest - To attract the provisions of Ss.12 and 55, it is not necessary that pecuniary interest is discussed by Village Panchayat or disbursed by the very resolution - Nor is it necessary for these provisions to apply that the question discussed pertains to or involves the disbursement or accrual of the pecuniary interest.

To attract the provisions of Sections 12 and 55, it is not necessary that the pecuniary interest is discussed by the Village Panchayat or disbursed by the very resolution. Nor is it necessary for these provisions to apply that the question discussed pertains to or involves the disbursement or accrual of the pecuniary interest. It is sufficient if the subject matter of the question discussed or the resolution passed leads to or results or assists in the accrual of or has the effect of leading to, resulting in or assisting or has the potential to result or assist in enabling the member realizing the pecuniary interest.

The connection between the question discussed or the resolution passed on the one hand and the pecuniary interest on the other, must be proximate and real, not fanciful or too remote. It would depend upon the facts of each case. One test would be to examine whether the member would be able to or capable of realizing the pecuniary interest if an adverse decision on the question is rendered by the Village Panchayat.  [Para 11]

The accrual or furtherance of a pecuniary interest may be dependent on several factors. That would make no difference to the applicability of Sections 12 and 55. The applicability of these provisions is not so restricted by the Legislature. These sections would also operate even if the pecuniary benefit accrues or is dependent on account of other factors, so long as the discussion upon the subject matter of such a question or a resolution thereon falls within their ambit.  [Para 14]

heading: Scope and object of
HeadNote.description: Scope and object of - The purpose of Ss.12(d) and 55(4) of the Act is to ensure the purity and fairness in the proceedings, working and dealing of the Village Panchayat, inter alia, by ensuring that there is no misuse of the fiduciary capacity occupied by its members - The provisions are based on public policy.			(Para 17)

heading: Construction licence
Revocation of
HeadNote.description: Construction licence - Revocation of - Licence issued can be revoked whenever there has been any false statement or any misrepresentation by applicant.	(Para 8)

heading: Appeal
Construction licence
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Construction licence - Grant or revocation of - Matters stipulated by S.6 or S.66, held, are not subjected to provisions of S.201-A of the Act.

Matters stipulated by Section 6 or by Section 66 are not subjected to provisions of Section 201-A. Section 201-A permits appeal in miscellaneous matters within period of 30 days from the date of refusal of any request by said authority. The explanation defines refusal as rejection of any request in writing or non-conveying of any reply to the application within a period of 15 days from the receipt of application in its office by Panchayat. Section 66 of sub-Section (2) permits filing of appeal within 30 days after the date of expiry of period of 30 days of filing application for grant of permission if no decision is taken thereon by the Village Panchayat with said period. Thus, provisions of Section 66(2) prescribe different period for accrual of 'cause' and rule out applicability of explanation of Section 201-A. It is therefore obvious that Section 201-A read with explanation is not available in the matter regulated by Section 66. In view of this finding, it is apparent that reliance upon it by Panchayat to point out the alternate remedy to the petitioners is misconceived. Words in Section 201-A like "dealt with" or "request in writing" or new obligation to decide within 15 days contemplated therein, all show that said Section envisages that Panchayat is acting within four corners of Panchayat Raj Act and Rules. It is not attracted when Panchayat undertakes some activity without any authority of law and jurisdiction. In any case, such alternate remedy need not bar petitioners from directly approaching High Court. In the circumstances, the impugned action of Village Panchayat of issuing a show cause notice and of revoking construction licence of petitioner is found to be without jurisdiction. Hence, the order dated 2.1.2009 impugned in the present petition is accordingly quashed and set aside.  [Para 9,10,11]

heading: Director of Panchayats
HeadNote.description:
Director of Panchayats - Power to suspend a resolution passed by Village Panchayat - Director of Panchayats has power to suspend a resolution passed by the Village Panchayat in case it is unjust, unlawful or improper or is causing or is likely to cause injury or annoyance to public or to lead to breach of peace - The Director, however, shall submit his decision of suspension to the Government for its orders.

The Director of Panchayats can suspend a resolution passed by the Village Panchayat in case it is unjust, unlawful or improper or is causing or is likely to cause injury or annoyance to the public or to lead to the breach of peace, and, when he makes an order of such suspension in terms of sub-section (1) of Section 178, he is required to forthwith forward to the Government and the Panchayat, affected thereby, a copy of the order with the statement of the reasons for making it and thereafter the Government i.e the Secretary, on whom powers are conferred by the Government, may confirm or rescind the order or direct that it shall continue to be in force with or without modification permanently or for such period it thinks fit.

The Section itself shows that it consists in two parts. Sub-section (1) which gives power to the Director to suspend the resolution, for reasons stated therein and sub-section(2) which requires him to submit his decision of suspension to the Government for its orders.

When the Director makes an order under sub-section (1) and this order can only be of suspension, that he is required to forward to the Government a copy of the Order and then the Government may either confirm or rescind the order or direct it to continue to remain in force with or without modification permanently or temporarily. In case, an order or resolution of the panchayat is not suspended, there is no question of the Government taking any further action even if the Government is informed of the dismissal of the application.  1995(1) GLT 302 - Ref. to. 	 [Para 23,24,26]

heading: Suspension of resolution passed by village Panchayat under S.178(1)
HeadNote.description: Suspension of resolution passed by village Panchayat under S.178(1) - Power of Government under S.178(2) - Jurisdiction of Government under S.178(2) of the Act can be termed to be supervisory or revisional nature and can be exercised only in cases where the Director suspends a resolution or order but not otherwise.	(Para 27)

heading: Election petition
Not maintainable
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Filed before Election Commission u/S.10 of Goa Panchayat Raj Act - Not maintainable - Remedy of filing election petition lies before Administrative Tribunal u/S.16 - Same cannot be circumvented on a ground that limitation for filing election petition had expired. 	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Citizenship Act (1955)
Election petition
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Citizenship Act (1955) - Election petition - Dismissal, on ground of absence of jurisdiction - Legality - Petitioners challenged election of respondent as a member of village panchayat on ground that he has ceased to be an Indian Citizen and has acquired foreign citizenship - Determination of question of citizenship has to be done by Authority appointed under Citizenship Act - Dismissal of petition, proper.

AIR 1986 SC 1534, 1995 3 SCC 100 Rel. on. 	(Para 13)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Renewal of construction license - Grant of permission for - Challenge - Permission granted by village panchayat only in compliance with directions issued by Deputy Director and confirmed in appeal by the Additional Director - Essentially, the challenge by village panchayat is to these orders rather than permission granted - Objection to maintainability of writ petition by the village panchayat, cannot be sustained. 			(Para 14)

heading: Renewal of construction license
HeadNote.description: Renewal of construction license - Grant of permission for - Obligation of the authority concerned - Grant of either express or deemed permission, comes within obligation to abide by provisions of the Act or Rules, as may be applicable. 		(Para 14)

heading: Permission by Secretary
HeadNote.description: Renewal of construction license - Permission by Secretary - When the Secretary is executing the order passed by any authority in appeal, the provisions of S.47 cannot come in its way - S.47-B overrides S.47 thereof. 	(Para 19)

heading: Construction permission
Adherence of rules
HeadNote.description: Construction permission - Adherence of rules - Primarily it is for the Town and Country Planning Department to ensure adherence with the terms and conditions and all the rules and regulations in the matter of construction and development of the site. 	(Para 22)

heading: Construction license
HeadNote.description: Construction license - Once the Town and Country Planning Department grants technical clearance, order by Deputy Director directing village Panchayat to issue construction license, require no interference. 	(Para 23)

heading: Interpretation of Statute
Scope of S.10(d)
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of Statute - Scope of S.10(d) - Disqualification "for being chosen" - Clause (d) suggests that the candidate "is in arrears" - Held, when law disqualifies a person to be chosen to be a candidate saying "is in arrears", said present tense cannot be construed to include past tense. (Para 28)

heading: Disqualification "for being chosen"
HeadNote.description: Disqualification "for being chosen" - Disqualification cannot be read as a disqualification in perpetuity - Whether the candidate is in arrears on the date of scrutiny will have to be seen. (Para 26)

heading: Judicial legislation
HeadNote.description: Judicial legislation - If legislature wants a particular mischief to be remedied, it has to come from legislature as a piece of legislation, and cannot be enforced by judicial legislation or interpretation.	(Para 29)

heading: Disqualification "for being chosen"
HeadNote.description: Disqualification "for being chosen" - Question or dispute as to disqualification on account of failure to pay the arrears is essentially a question of fact.	(Para 15)

heading: Constitutional validity
HeadNote.description:
Constitutional validity - Delimitation of constituencies or reservations of seats thereat - Not included in domain of either preparation of electoral rolls or conduct of elections - Provisions regarding, not unconstitutional on ground that they usurp jurisdiction essentially vested in State Election Commission and confer the same on Govt. - Ss.7(4), 118, 119 of Goa Panchayat Raj Act held, not unconstitutional.

	It cannot be said that the constitutional scheme in Article 243K envisages that even the power of delimitation of constituencies or reservation of seats thereat has to be necessarily vested in the State Election Commission, SEC and not the Government. The SEC, no doubt, has plenary and consequently, even the residual powers when it comes to preparation of electoral rolls for or conduct of all elections to the Panchayats or Zilla Panchayats. However, since the subjects of delimitation of constituencies or providing reservations thereat, cannot be said to be included in the domain of either preparation of the electoral rolls, or conduct of elections, we cannot say that the impugned provisions are unconstitutional on the ground that they usurp the jurisdiction essentially vested in the SEC and confer the same on the Government.

	It is true that the Central Government in the Model Panchayat and Gram Swaraj Act which it has formulated and circulated for implementation of 73rd Amendment to the Constitution in letter and spirit also vests powers of providing reservations in the State Election Commission, instead of the State Government. However, based upon this, High Court declined to strike down the impugned provisions.	(Paras 44, 45, 47, 108)

 	The absence of rotation policy, or guidelines at the present stage, is not a ground to strike down the impugned provisions, particularly because this is not a matter where the legislature has provided for no guidelines or no norms whatsoever. The real difficulty is in the matter of implementation of these norms or guidelines in their letter and spirit. Therefore, merely because on some occasions, the administrative action in pursuance of the statutory provisions may be arbitrary, that by itself is not a ground to strike down the statutory provisions itself, particularly because the statutory provisions contain sufficient guidelines or norms, which, if adhered to, will rule out arbitrariness to a great extent. The High Court accepted the statement of Advocate General that the Government will, within a period of three months, formulate and publish the norms or guidelines for effective implementation of the rotation policy, envisaged in Article 243 D of the Constitution and Section 7 of the said Act.			(Paras 70, 71)

heading: Disqualification of Sarpanch and Deputy Sarpanch
HeadNote.description: Disqualification of Sarpanch and Deputy Sarpanch - Remiss in discharge of duties/misconduct/misuse/abuse of powers - Panchayat resolved to collect garbage and parking fees from tourists coming to wildlife sanctuary - Sought permission from District Officer - Without waiting for approval, Sarpanch and Dy. Sarpanch allegedly got printed or forged receipt books in name of local panchayat and also forged seal of panchayat - Started collection of said fees for a week - Held, panchayat had power to impose taxes or fees it proposed but its elected representatives acted prematurely - Panchayat or Sarpanch and Dy. Sarpanch, did not commit misconduct itself nor abused power for ulterior purpose - Order disqualifying and brandishing of Sarpanch and Dy. Sarpanch - Was disproportionate even if it accepted that panchayat “exercised powers not expressly vested” - Further, no mala fides in officeholders' conduct nor they attempted to misappropriate, embezzle or pilfer public fund - Moreso, when Panchayat Secretary stated on record that money could not be deposited in Panchayat account, as no appropriate head was created by then.		(Paras 81, 89, 90, 91, 97, 98)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification - Misconduct, misuse or abuse - Need not be persistent.

	Being remiss is a species of inaction, dereliction; it can last over a stretch of time. Thus, if every time an authority is expected to act but fails to act, that repeated failure reflects the authority’s remissness. It is recurring and persists until that authority acts. So an authority can be persistently remiss. On the other hand, misconduct, misuse, and abuse are instances of misfeasance. Every instance of misconduct, misuse, or abuse is one complete act. In other words, as to remissness, its length determines its gravity to be an actionable wrong, but other instances of active misfeasance do not depend on duration. So, misconduct, misuse, or abuse need not be persistent. It is on the contrary. It is illogical to think the Legislation insisted on repeated wrongdoing to apply the disqualification. Suppose a public representative indulgence in corrupt practice, it is preposterous to expect the Legislature to punish only his repeated acts of corruption- not a singular instance. So, applying the qualifier “persistently” to all instances of misfeasance, to not proper.	(Para 54)

heading: Revision application
Petitioner a Panchayat
HeadNote.description: Revision application - Delay of 10 days - Petitioner a Panchayat - In matters of condonation of delay a highly pedantic and technical approach should be avoided and an approach which furthers the course of substantial justice should be adopted - Delay of 10 days, held, is required to be condoned in the interest of justice. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing revision u/S.201B of Goa Panchayat Raj Act - Refusal to condone on ground of negligence, lack of due diligence and bona fide on part of petitioner - Revision filed against order passed in appeal - Order was passed in appeal 11 months after it was closed for order - When any matter is closed for order, there remains nothing for parties to do and keep on contacting Advocate - Petitioner's contacting his advocate twice at intervals of 6 to 10 months cannot be seen as sheer indolence of petitioner - Nor failure to give explanation for not contacting Advocate for period of 6 months shows lack of diligence and bona fide on part of petitioner - Further, one and half months period taken by petitioner in filing revision after getting knowledge of order in appeal is reasonable, considering controversy involved in matter - Refusal to condone delay, improper. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Parole
Refusal
Validity
HeadNote.description: Parole - Refusal - Validity - Application for parole filed by petitioner to attend brother's wedding - Rejected on basis of report sent by Superintendent of Police - Report not disclosing any serious allegations against petitioner for refusal of parole to him - R.324 gives right to petitioner to seek parole in cases in which there is wedding in a family - On facts and circumstances, petitioner granted parole for thirty days subject to terms and conditions as contemplated by law. (Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Furlough
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Furlough - Imposition of condition to execute personal bond of Rs.1,00,000/- while releasing petitioner on furlough - Challenge - Family of petitioner has negligible income - No adverse report against petitioner to avail of such furlough - Hence, personal bond to be executed by petitioner modified from Rs.1,00,000/- to Rs.10,000/-. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Parole
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Parole - Grant of - Petitioner, mother of prisoner suffering from an ailment - On earlier occasions, prisoner has not breached any of conditions imposed on him - Taking note of fact that petitioner is ailing and requires assistance of prisoner - Prisoner deserves to be released on parole subject to conditions. 	(Para 6)

heading: Parole
Essentials
HeadNote.description: Parole - Fixation of bond amount - Essentials - Competent authority should consider nature of offence committed, financial status of convict and other relevant factors - In the instant case considering financial status of petitioner bond amount reduced to Rs. 25000/- from Rs. 1,00,000/-.	(Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Application for parole
Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Application for parole - Rejection of - Validity - Prison authorities found two packets of biddi and ear phones in cell where petitioner was kept along with some other convicts - Mere finding of prohibited articles which are not very serious by themselves - Not sufficient to deny parole to petitioner for attending his mother who has to undergo an operation. 	(Para 6)

heading: Grant of Furlough
HeadNote.description: Goa Children's Act (2003) S.8(2) - Penal Code (1860), S.376 - Grant of Furlough - Execution of personal bond - Considering that the petitioner who was a labourer and was earning Rs.2000/- Per month prior to his arrest, the bond amount reduced from Rupees one lakh to Rs.10,000/- only.	(Para 6)

heading: Application for furlough
Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Application for furlough - Rejection of - Validity - Conduct of petitioner in jail is not satisfactory since petitioner was given punishment of 'formal warning' for possessing/hiding prohibited articles in cell - Mere discovery of prohibited articles which are not serious by themselves in cell occupied by several prisoners - Would not be sufficient to deny furlough to petitioner. 	(Para 5)

heading: Parole
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Parole - Ground of sickness of mother - Rejection on ground that sickness does not fall under serious illness - Challenge - Certificate produced showing that mother of convict apart from being highly diabetic, is also suffering from accelerated hypertension with cervical spondylosis - Somebody is expected to lookafter her - Convict was released on similar ground on earlier four occasions - However, he did not commit breach of conditions at any time and returned to jail in time - Parole granted on furnishing bail bond. 	(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Furlough
Rejection
HeadNote.description: Furlough - Rejection - Ground of possibility of prisoner taking advantage that he may not surrender before jail authority - Convict undergoing life imprisonment for offence punishable u/S.302 IPC, had completed 18 years 4 months and 23 days of imprisonment - His conduct in jail was satisfactory - No breach of any of terms and conditions by convict during his release on parole or furlough - Rejection, improper. 2018 ALL SCR (Cri) 227 Foll. 			(Paras 4, 5, 8, 10)

heading: Grant of parole
HeadNote.description: Grant of parole - Illness of nearest relatives - Under Rule 324, it is only in case of serious illness of nearest relatives that the prisoner can be granted parole - It does not lay down any proposition that for the same illness parole is to be granted continuously every year - That could not be the intent behind the Rule.	(Para 7)

heading: Furlough
Rejection
Challenge
Not proper
HeadNote.description:
Furlough - Rejection - Challenge - Petitioner convicted for committing grave sexual assault on his own daughter - He applied for release on furlough as he intends to spend furlough period with an organization "CARITAS" which attends prisoners who do not have any relative to support them - Application declined on count that said organization is not relative, petitioner cannot be released on furlough in view of R.316(3) - Not proper - Even close friend or head of organization, can be regarded as relative of prisoner, who has no relative or is unwilling to be received by any relative for variety of reasons - Considering object behind release of prisoner on furlough, such construction will have to be put on Prisons Rules - Petitioner released on furlough on at least nine occasions in past and every time stayed with said organization who entered into surety bond in amount fixed by Sanctioning Authority - Impugned order quashed with direction to release petitioner on furlough subject to usual conditions by treating head of organization as relative for purpose of R.315. 
2018 ALL SCR (Cri) 227, 1984 CrLJ 936 Ref. to. 	(Paras 18, 19, 20, 24, 25, 26)

heading: Parole
Refusal to grant
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Parole - Refusal to grant - Challenge - Petitioner sought parole on grounds of his mother's ailment - His mother was suffering from high blood pressure and diabetes - There was none to look after her - Medical record of mother indicates that she was under treatment in October, 2016, no subsequent medical record to consider request of petitioner for parole - No emergent situation to release him on parole - Order proper.	(Para 7)

heading: Furlough
HeadNote.description: Furlough - Rejection, on ground that convict u/S.392 IPC is not entitled to be released on furlough u/R.313(2) - As petitioner has served sentence of five years u/S.392 - Disqualification u/R.313(2) would not apply - However, petitioner has been convicted for other offences also - Had he been convicted for offence u/S.392 only he would have released on furlough - Direction issued to consider matter on merits. 1993(2) Mh. L. J. 1423 Rel.on.  (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Furlough
HeadNote.description: Furlough - Failure to provide escort - Held, once direction issued to release convict on condition of providing escort to enable him to reach his native place, the same need to be provided. (Para 6)

heading: Furlough
HeadNote.description: Furlough - Failure to provide escort - Held, once direction issued to release convict on condition of providing escort to enable him to reach his native place, the same need to be provided.	(Para 6)

heading: Premature release
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Premature release - Petition for - Convict has completed 19 years 1 months of imprisonment (including remission) - He attempted to escape from lawful custody while in confinement - Family members are not ready to accept him, if released prematurely - Sentence Review Board decided to consider his case after two years - David Jerald Francis Delaney, has expressed willingness to accept convict for purposes of rehabilitation from incarceration - As two years’ time is about to expire in April, 2020, direction issued to Board to consider case of convict for premature release. 	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Barbaric acts in jail
HeadNote.description:
Barbaric acts in jail - Complaint received that inmates were brutally beaten by jail authority - They were subjected to inhuman treatment and were denied basic amenity of medical facility for appropriate treatment - To avoid such untoward incident in jail, certain directions issued.

i]	Board of Visitors manned by District & Sessions Judges in both districts shall visit jails preferably every month to hear grievances of prisoners along with Members of Board and resolve issues relating to under-trial prisoners.

ii] 	CCTV cameras be installed at vantage points to monitor conduct inside Jail to serve as a system of checks and balances on conduct of Jail Officials and inmates and backup be maintained for necessary course of action.

iii] 	A Resident Medical Officer be appointed at Jail to provide due medical attention to inmates and in emergent cases to refer inmates to Government Hospitals for further evaluation and management;

iv] 	Proper training be imparted to Jail Officials for handling inmates particularly when they get violent or do not observe prison discipline but without resorting to any sort of violence to bring them under control.

v] 	Visits of NGOs to Jails for interacting with inmates to hear about their grievances, if any, and to ventilate their grievances generally.

vi] 	Installation of Complaint Box and regular processing of contents thereof by Principal District and Sessions Judge, and

vii] 	Sensitization of Jail Administration Officials that subjecting inmates to inhuman treatment would entail action in terms of Central Civil Service and CCS (CCA) Rules.   [Para 10]

heading: Parole
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Parole - Grant of - On ground of personal marriage - Refusal, for reason that marriage of prisoner was not emergent situation but was his own creation - However, after amendment, expression "for sufficient cause" used in S.324 would also take within its sweep marriage of prisoner - Therefore, direction issued to release prisoner on parole. (2014) 3 Crimes (HC) 590 Ref. to. (Para 10)

heading: Application for furlough
HeadNote.description: Application for furlough - Refusal on ground of non-completion of period of imprisonment by petitioner as required by R.310(1)(c) of Goa Prison Rules - Impugned order not showing what is exact period of actual imprisonment need to be undergone by petitioner as per said Rule - In terms of R.310(1)(c) amended in 2008 in respect of release on furlough for first time, period of three years will have to be counted from date of admission in prison as convict - Neither affidavit nor memorandum filed in this regard - Matter remitted back for reconsideration. 			(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Parole
Rejection
Report not considered
HeadNote.description: Parole - Rejection - Ground that no emergent situation exists - Petitioner sister of the convict has undergone major surgery of her leg and she is advised to take complete bed rest - She requires an attendant to take care of her - Mother of petitioner being of old age, not in a position to provide assistance - Superintendent of Police has reported to respondent authorities that convict person was of great help to take care of petitioner - Report not considered - No earlier occasion of convict having violated condition of furlough or parole - Hence, parole is granted on furnishing bail bond. 	(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Parole
HeadNote.description: Parole - Sufficient cause for grant of - It can be granted for any sufficient cause and even for marriage - Emergent situation of serious illness is not that which is likely to result in to death - Further, no rule that once furlough is granted, no parole can be granted within 30 days from date of return from furlough - One cannot know as to when emergent situation would arise. 			(Para 7)

heading: Parole
Delay in release
HeadNote.description: Parole - Delay in release - In cases of pressing emergency where prisoner is required to be released forthwith, Superintendent of Jail is competent authority to sanction release of prisoner on parole upto 14 days - In suitable cases, he can find out genuineness of grounds - State Govt. is required to work out a uniform procedure. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Premature release of life convict
HeadNote.description:
Premature release of life convict - Procedure stated.

	A life convict has no indefeasible right to premature release, but he is entitled upon completion of 14 years of imprisonment, to have his case considered by the Sentence Review Board in accordance with the Prison Rules and for an appropriate recommendation in that regard to the State Government.

	The State Sentence Review Board may consider the case of a life convict for premature release upon completion of 14 years imprisonment, and the role of the Sentence Review Board is only recommendatory and the decision on the premature release and the power to grant such release vests with the appropriate Government. The case of such a prisoner for premature release may be considered by Government, either upon a recommendation made by the State Sentence Review Board in accordance with the Prison Rules or on an application made to it by the Prisoner himself under S. 432 of the Cr. P.C.

	The State Government before it takes a decision on the recommendation of the Sentence Review Board, or on an application by the prisoner seeking release, has to seek the opinion of the Presiding Judge of the convicting or confirming Court under S. 432(2) of the Cr. P.C.

	The Presiding Judge of the convicting or confirming Court has to state his/her opinion on the case of the concerned prisoner with reasons for such opinion and to forward with the opinion a certified copy of the record of trial or of such record thereof as exists to the Government.

	The Government upon receipt of the opinion from the Presiding Judge of the convicting or confirming Court alongwith the records of the case and on considering the opinion of the Court and the relevant material submitted by the Superintendent of the Jail under R. 404(1) of the Prison Rules has to take a decision in accordance with S. 432(1) of the Cr. P.C. read with R. 404(2) of the Goa Prison Rules, 2006.	 [Para 18]

heading: Stock and sale of prohibited food articles
HeadNote.description: Stock and sale of prohibited food articles - Respondents alleged to have stocked for sale Gutkha containing tobacco which is prohibited in State of Goa - Omission of act of storing from notification, in operation at relevant time - Would only mean that storing of such food articles did not invite penal action - Consequently mere storing is not an offence - Acquittal of respondents therefore, is proper. 	(Para 6)

heading: Release of water connection
HeadNote.description: Release of water connection - Despite order passed u/S.94(A)(1)(a) for release of water to residential premises of petitioners, no action was taken in compliance of same - Petitioners suggested proposed manner in which water can be released whereas authority pointed out alternate route for such release of water - Modality of working to release water through specific route is matter which authority would have to consider on its own merits - Direction issued to authority to implement same as expeditiously as possible. 	(Paras 6, 7)

HeadNote.sub_clause: Ss.2(10), 30A, Chap.IXA, Ss.87A, 87L (amended by Act of 2005)
heading: Injurious food
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Sch.VII, List I, Entry 52, List III, Entry 33(a), List II, Entry Nos.8, 26, 27, Art.254(2) - Injurious food - Declaration in terms of Entry 52 of Union List - Neither Tobacco Act occupies field covered by Amendment Act, nor provisions in latter statute are in conflict with any of the former - Two statutes are not repugnant to each other in any manner - The field covered by Tobacco Act and declaration therein in terms of Entry 52 of Union List is not same as covered by Amendment Act - Notifications prohibiting consumption, manufacture, sale and distribution of any article of food containing tobacco in State of Goa and declaring any article of food containing tobacco to be injurious food - Notifications are in consonance with provisions of Amendment Act. 1995(1) SCC 574 and 2002(8) SCC 228 - Ref. to.			(Paras 40, 44)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Public Men's Corruption (Investigation and Inquiries) Act (1988)
heading: Public man
Who is
Municipal Engineer
HeadNote.description:
Public man - Who is - Chief Officer of Municipal Council - Chief Officer though a Government servant, is not considered to be a public man under the Act, therefore, action could not be initiated against him under the Act - Municipal Engineer - Also not a public man under the definition contained in the Act.

The post of Chief Officer of a Municipal Council has not been included in the definition of 'public man'. The Chief Officer though a Government Servant, is not considered to be a public man under the Act and, therefore, action could not be initiated against him under the Act, nor could the Commission or the Competent Authority make any reference to his conduct under the provisions of the Act. The petitioner in the other petition is a Municipal Engineer, who is also not a 'public man' under the definition contained in the Act. Therefore, the action initiated and the observations made by the Commission and the Competent Authority under the Act, in respect of the petitioners in both the petitions have to be set aside.							       [Para 6]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Public Men's Corruption (Investigation and Inquiries) Act (1988)
heading: Petitioner alleged to have misappropriated panchayat funds
HeadNote.description: Petitioner alleged to have misappropriated panchayat funds - Proceedings initiated before commission consisting of three members - Final report submitted by commission - Notice directing refund of misappropriated amount not issued by commission - Issue of notice containing such direction by Directorate of Panchayat is without jurisdiction and is liable to be set aside. (Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorized Occupants) Act (1988)
heading: Notice
Unauthorised occupation
HeadNote.description: Notice - Unauthorised occupation - Notice sent to respondent calling upon him to handover vacant possession of the said premises and to pay arrears of rent - Show-cause notice clearly specifying that one of the grounds of eviction was non-payment of license fees - Held, in addition to show cause notice issued under S.4, a separate show cause notice under S.10(3) was not necessary. 1991(2) GLT 55 - Rel. on.	(Paras 7 to 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Public Service Commission (Rules of Procedure) (1988)
heading: Selection process
HeadNote.description:
Selection process - Difference between shortlisting and prescribing minimum qualifications.

The difference between prescribing minimum qualifications and shortlisting candidates is this. Shortlisting candidates is from among candidates who are qualified. In other words, for the purpose of administrative convenience in certain circumstances such as where there are a large number of qualified candidates, only some are chosen on the basis of the stipulated parameters. Shortlisting is, therefore, from amongst qualified candidates. That is an entirely different exercise from prescribing a qualification.

(2003) 11 SCC 559 Rel. on.

(1999) 7 SCC 120 Disting.	    [Para 47]

heading: Eviction proceedings
HeadNote.description: Eviction proceedings - Application for temporary injunction - Deceased husband was carrying on business in the premises - Son of the petitioner was brought on record - Eviction decree passed against son of the petitioner - Petitioner wife of deceased brought a suit for declaration that eviction decree was fraudulently obtained and she was not joined as party to the suit - Petitioner, however, unable to prove her claim over suit premises - Held, courts below rightly denied her temporary injunction. 	(Para 9)

heading: Appointment of trained graduate teacher
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of trained graduate teacher - Requirements of promotee candidate - Held, petitioner having no sufficient experience in recognised school and not staked his claim within time was not entitled to said post on promotion.

School education - Appointment to the post of trained graduate teacher - Requirements of promotee candidate.

In the present case, the petitioner was initially appointed as Assistant Teacher in respondent school on probation for two years with effect from 6th June 1992.  The respondent was given necessary permission to start the school by the Education Department on 12th May 1993.  The petitioner himself had applied afresh on 4th June 1993 and the post in question was approved on 8th July 1993.  Thereafter the petitioner was given fresh appointment order with effect from 14th September 1993.

Held that the petitioner cannot be said to have fulfilled the requirements which were necessary or a promotee candidate for the post of trained graduate teacher.  The services rendered by him from 6th June 1992 till 13th September 1993 cannot be recognised as experience for the purpose of promotion since the said services were rendered by him in a school for which no permission was granted by the Director of Education Moreover, he had not put forward his claim for the post before the Management within time.  Claim for consideration was required to be staked by the candidate who fulfilled the requirements and it was not for the Department to consider all eligible candidates even without their staking claim otherwise, the words "the claim" in the proviso to R.86(1) would be rendered superfluous.  [Para 3,4,5]

heading: Promotion to post of lower Division Clerk cum Librarian
HeadNote.description: Promotion to post of lower Division Clerk cum Librarian - Petitioner was appointed as peon in 1988 - Vacancy arose for the post of LDC in 2007 - Requisite qualification was S.S.C and typing speed of more than 30 w.p.m. - Speed of petitioner was hardly less than 10 w.p.m. - He had committed 14 mistakes in 17 lines - Work expected from him was to type examination papers and minutes of interviews - Held, it would not be appropriate to exercise discretion in favour of petitioner as he was not suitable for the post. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Challenge
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Goa School Education Act (1984) - Promotion to post of Principal - Challenge - Petitioner-senior most Grade I teacher declined promotion and respondent-junior to him, promoted - Serious lapses alleged in tenure of petitioner - However, said allegation did not lead to any disciplinary proceedings nor any Memorandum of Charge against him - No adverse remarks in confidential report noted by DPC to hold petitioner ineligible - Also, same came into existence only after post of principal fell vacant - Merely because petitioner had moved under Right to Information Act against management, would not affect his suitability to hold post of Principal - Court in earlier petition filed by petitioner had directed to conduct fresh DPC and to withdraw approval granted for promotion of respondent - Respondent however allowed to hold post and function as such - Not proper - Direction issued to call for a review DPC. 	 (Paras 10, 11, 12, 14, 16, 17)

heading: Laboratory Assistants
HeadNote.description: Expression "other teaching staff" - Laboratory Assistants - Post of Laboratory Assistant, in the light of duties to be discharged by them, certainly fits within the expression "other teaching staff" of the amended proviso and therefore is entitled to work till he/she attains the age of 60 years. Goa State Civil Services (Third Amendment) Rules (2006).	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa State Commission for Backward Classes Act (1993)
heading: Caste claim
HeadNote.description: Government Notification dt. 1.3.2013 - Caste claim - Notification dt. 1.3.2013 is prospective and not retrospective - OBC class certificate issued in favour of party would be valid from date of notification and not from date prior to date of passing said notification. 			(Paras 17, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Succession Special Notaries and Inventory Proceeding Act (2012)
heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - From final order made in inventory proceeding - Is deemed to be an appeal u/S.96 CPC - It shall lie to competent Court depending on value of assets - While an appeal from order akin to that u/S.104 CPC, shall lie to competent Court depending on value given to assets at the time order is made.

In terms of Section 451 of the new Act, an appeal from the final order made in the inventory proceeding shall lie to the competent Court depending upon the value of the assets and such appeal shall be deemed to be appeal under Section 96 of the Code of Civil Procedure,1908. However, in terms of sub-section 2, an appeal from an order shall lie from every order, other than a merely administrative order, made in the inventory proceedings to the competent Court depending upon the value given to the assets at the time the order is made and appeal shall be deemed to be an appeal under Section 104 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. In other words an appeal from a final order which is deemed to be an appeal under Section 96 i.e. an appeal from an original decree shall lie to the Court depending on the value of the assets while an appeal from order which is akin to that under Section 104 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 shall lie to the competent Court depending on the value given to the assets at the time order is made. A reading of Section 451 of the new Act clearly makes a distinction between an appeal to the competent Court from a final order in terms of sub-section 1 and an appeal in terms of sub-section 2 being an appeal from order to the competent court based on the value at the time of the order. 

1991 (2) Goa L.T 11 Disting. 	 [Para 16]

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Succession Special Notaries and Inventory Proceeding Act (2012)
heading: Inventory proceedings
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Inventory proceedings - Maintainability - Brother and sister inherit mother’s estate - Over 30 years, sister remained quiet - Later, she claimed partition - Brother invoked Portuguese Civil Code and asserted that sister’s claim is barred by prescription - In view of Art.2015 of Code, co-owner holds property not only for himself but also for other co-owners - So, possession of mother’s estate by brother must be deemed joint and sister too, in constructive possession - Co-owner in possession must have communicated to other co-owner his intention in unmistakable terms that other co-owner has been excluded from possession and enjoyment - Not done by brother - So long as partition has not taken place, co-owner's right shall be indivisible in respect of both possession and ownership - Inventory proceedings maintainable. (Paras 42, 43, 47, 48, 50)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Succession Special Notaries and Inventory Proceeding Act (2012)
heading: Inventory proceeding
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Inventory proceeding - Some of the heirs had raised certain objections to listing of properties - Inventory Court to at least hold summary inquiry in first instance before deciding whether assets or liabilities should be listed or not - No such inquiry was ever held - Plea that even after holding an inquiry the result might not be different - Not tenable - Matter remanded to Inventory Court, to hold summary inquiry as contemplated by S.400(5) of Goa Succession Act, 2012.(Paras 10, 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Succession Special Notaries and Inventory Proceeding Act (2012)
heading: Inventory proceedings
HeadNote.description: Portuguese Civil Code, Decree No.43525 - Inventory proceedings - Right of succession in "lease premises" - Available to married daughters - Portuguese Civil Code or Inventory Proceeding Act makes no distinction as to gender, order of birth or marital status - S.68 of Inventory Proceeding Act specifically provides for right of succession without distinction of sex or age - Whereas S.399 provides for inclusion of lease property in list of assets - Rejection of claim of married daughter by Courts below on basis of S.2(o) of Goa Rent Act, not sustainable - Rent Act not relevant, when dispute is not between landlord and tenant. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Succession Special Notaries and Inventory Proceeding Act (2012)
heading: Inventory proceedings
HeadNote.description: Inventory proceedings - Challenge against non-inclusion of "lease premises" in list of assets - Pronouncement of final order by Inventory Court pending said challenge - Merely because appellant signed final chart prepared by Inventory Court without including lease premises, her challenge would not become infructuous - Her right to challenge list of assets would continue - And if non-inclusion of lease premises is ultimately held illegal, then final order would be liable to be modified in terms of S.446 of Inventory Proceeding Act. 			(Paras 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Succession Special Notaries and Inventory Proceeding Act (2012)
heading: Right of inheritance
HeadNote.description: Right of inheritance - Plea that right has to be determined only in inventory proceedings - Plea was based on presumption that right devolve upon legal heirs only after shares are determined - Transmission of right of inheritance takes place immediately upon death of deceased estate leaver - Inventory proceedings are not necessary for accrual of right of inheritance - Further, as estate leaver died intestate his inheritance will devolve equally among his two legal heirs - Right to claim amount deposited by estate leaver in Bank would accrue to both legal heirs equally - Inventory proceedings not necessary for determination of shares.  2015(5) ALL MR 160 Rel.on.	 (Paras 10, 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Goa Town and Country Planning Act (1975)
heading: Development plan
HeadNote.description:
Development plan - Withdrawal of area from operation of the Act - Subsequent application of the Act to the area - Would not revive the old development plan.

Section 19(1) of the Goa Town Planning Act enables the Government to withdraw from the operation of the Act the whole or part of any planning area. The notification dated 23rd June, 1993 issued in the public interest withdraws from the operation of the Goa Town Planning Act, the whole of the planning areas declared under the various Notifications, including the area in which the said land is situated. As the very application of the Goa Town Planning Act has been withdrawn, the development plan prepared under that Act, in respect of the area in which the said land is situated, no longer survives.  Therefore, the grievance of the petitioner that the buildings which are being constructed in the said land after 23rd June, 1993 contrary to the development plan, does not survive. The petition is, therefore, liable to be dismissed on this short ground alone. The petitioner submitted that after the withdrawal of the area in which the said land is situated from the operation of the Goa Town Planning Act, the Government of Goa has subsequently issued another notification again making the Goa Town Planning Act applicable to the said area. The petitioner made an oral request for permission to amend the petition to bring on record the subsequent notification, court has declined the oral request, because, subsequent application of the Act to the area would not revive the old development plan. The initial development plan which was made applicable by the Notification dated 11th January, 1990 lapsed by issuance of notification under sub-Section (1) of Section 19 of the Goa Town Planning Act withdrawing the said area from the operation of the Act on 23rd June, 1993. On issuance of a fresh notification making the Goa Town Planning Act applicable, the planning authority would be required to prepare a fresh plan in accordance with the Act. The development plan which lapsed on 23-6-1993 would not ipso facto revive on the Act being made applicable again by a fresh notification.			 [Para 3,4]

headline: Goa Town and Country Planning Act (1975), S. 20(2), 50, 52 – Show cause notice – Regarding violation of approved plan for development of property – Disposal of by Chairman of North Goa Planning and Development Authority (NGPDA) – Validity – Show cause notice was issued by NGPDA – It was required to be disposed of by NGPDA as body corporate – There is no provision which empowers only Chairman to discharge function which otherwise required to be discharged by NGPDA as body corporate – Order disposing show cause notice by Chairman being without jurisdiction liable to be set aside.

heading: Show cause notice
Validity

Meaning of

HeadNote.description: Suit against police station - Submission that breach of provisions of S.17A of Goa, Town and Country Planning Act, is a cognizable offence - Held, for this reason alone police station may not be retained as a party defendant in suit - Further, fact that no relief claimed against police station, will not preclude appellant from taking recourse to appropriate remedy in criminal law.
