heading: Refusal
Challenge
Discriminatory in nature
HeadNote.description: Grant of rank certificate - Refusal - Challenge - Petitioner was student of Bachelor of Engineering Course - She passed all semesters by obtaining more than 60% marks except in III semester she obtained more than 60% by availing grace marks - Respondents refused to grant rank certificate to petitioner in view of amendment of OA13 in year 2015, prescribing eligibility criteria that candidate has to passed all examinations without grace marks - However, said amendment was not in existence when petitioner had answered III semester examinations in 2013 - Goa University Act does not confer any power to University to make any ordinance retrospective - In 2016 similarly placed candidates who passed graduation by availing grace marks before 2015 were issued rank certificates - Discriminatory in nature - Therefore, respondents are not justified to refuse grant of rank certificate to petitioner if she is otherwise entitled in terms of statute - Impugned decision, quashed. 1991(1) Bom.C.R. 212, (2007) 5 SCC 77 Ref. to.  (Paras 8, 10, 11, 13, 15)

heading: Statute validly framed by University
HeadNote.description: Statute validly framed by University - Approval of State Government not necessary - Contention that it is the Government which funds the colleges and any Statute which involves financial liability to be incurred by the Government, requires the consent of Government is not tenable - University is an autonomous body and therefore, the State Government will not be entitled to interfere with the internal administration of the University notwithstanding the fact that the State Government is the funding body unless and until the University Statutes provide for the same or there is any Act of legislation conferring that power on the State Government. 2003(10) SCC 253 - Followed.		(Para 16)

heading: Retirement age of employees
HeadNote.description:
Retirement age of employees - It is a matter of policy of employer i.e. whether it is a Government or University as to till what age, their employees should work - Courts cannot venture in their path.

Retirement age of Government employees and the like, always differs from State to State and has always been a gamble, if we may use that expression, but that is a matter of policy of the employer i.e. whether it is a Government or an University as to till what age, their employees should work and Courts cannot venture in their path. That the Legislature has again extended it to 60 years in 2006 is entirely a different matter and the Petitioners who retired after the first amendment, cannot derive any benefit of the same. (2007)11 SCC 58 & AIR 1991 SC 276 - Ref. to.  [Para 19]

heading: Invalidation of nomination form
HeadNote.description: Invalidation of nomination form - For post of University Class Representatives - On ground of late submission of form - Time for submission of form was 3.00 p.m. on given date - Petitioners were present before 3.00 p.m. and ready to submit form - As insistence made by Election Officer to submit expenditures details which were not statutorily required, they were 5 minutes late in submitting form - No opportunity of hearing given to petitioners before Grievance Redressal Committee which held their nomination as invalid - Thereon, college reversed result of election by declaring candidates who lost election as elected - Not permissible by Statute - Impugned order cannot be sustained. 	(Paras 7, 8, 10, 11)

heading: Petitioner already superannuated
HeadNote.description: Statute of Goa University, SA-19 (xxv) - Revision of pay scale of university teacher with retrospective effect - Petitioner already superannuated - Under Statute SA-19 (xxv) pay scale cannot be revised if it is adverse to the interests of teacher - Teacher would be put to hardship if excess payments made was recovered by giving retrospective effect - Order revising pay scale cannot be given effect to - Equity would pilt in favour of petitioner and judicial discretion is required to be exercised in favour of petitioner in this case. 	(Paras 38, 39, 40, 42)

heading: Empanelment of Selection Committee
HeadNote.description: Empanelment of Selection Committee - If members preferred by Executive Council are not available, Selection Committee of members empanelled by Academic Council and recommended by Executive Council is permissible.	(Para 30)

heading: Post of professor
HeadNote.description: Post of professor - Qualification of teaching and research can be clubbed together to compute teaching experience. (Para 28)

heading: Eligibility criteria for appointment
HeadNote.description: Eligibility criteria for appointment - Candidate applying for post and appearing at interview without protest - Cannot question eligibility criteria as wrongly framed.	(Para 22)

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Appointment for fixed period - Termination of service as per contractual terms - Challenge to - Challenge made on ground that the respondents had no authority in issuing such an order - Held, petitioner cannot be permitted to question the action of respondents in discontinuing the services of the petitioner on expiry of the term for which he was appointed and which he had accepted - Petitioner blowing hot and cold at the same time cannot be permitted to approbate and reprobate.

The appointment order categorically stipulates the term of the office to be of 5 years, renewable for the same period upto age of 60 years. Knowing fully well that the term is of 5 years stipulated in the appointment order itself, the petitioner has chosen to accept the appointment and only at the fag-end of the term has, in the first place, requested for a renewal and thereafter filed the present petition, calling in question the vires of Section 23(2) of the University Act. The Counsel for the respondent University is justified in contending that the petitioner is blowing hot and cold at the same time and cannot be permitted to approbate and reprobate. The petitioner has taken advantage of the benefit provided by the appointment order and after availing of the benefit in full, he is questioning the authority of the respondents in issuing the said order. The principle of approbation and reprobation is based on the doctrine of election, which postulates that no party can accept and reject the same instrument and that "a person cannot say at one time that a transaction is valid and thereby obtain some advantage, to which he could only be entitled on the footing that it is valid, and then turn round and say it is void for the purpose of securing some other advantage". The petitioner cannot be permitted to question the so called termination which is consequent upon the expiry of the term for which the petitioner was appointed. In this regard, the Counsel for the petitioner has submitted that there cannot be an estoppel against the statute. Though the proposition of law is correct, its application to the fact situation is wholly misplaced. In the facts of the present case, the petitioner cannot be permitted to question the action of the respondents in discontinuing the services of the petitioner on expiry of the term for which he was appointed and which he had accepted. (1992)4 SCC 683 - Rel. on.  [Para 10]

heading: Delegated legislation
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Delegated legislation - Challenge to - Once policy principles or standards for guidance are provided in the Act, then conferring of power on a subordinate authority to make subordinate or ancillary legislation would be valid.

(a)	Delegated legislation has become a present day necessity and it has come to stay  it is both inevitable and indispensable. The legislature has now to make so many laws that it has no time to devote to all the details and sometimes the subject on which it has to legislate is of such a technical nature that all it can do is to state the broad principles and leave the details to be worked out by those who are more familiar with the subject.

(b)	It is enough if legislature declares its policy laying down the principles and it is enough if an intelligent guidance is given to the subordinate authority. The Court can only interfere if no policy is discernible at all or the delegation is of such an indefinite character as to amount to abdication, but as the discretion vests with the legislature in determining whether there is necessity for delegation or not, the exercise of such discretion is not to be disturbed by the Court, except in clear cases of abuse.

(c)	The legislature, as a part of its legislative functions, can confer power to make rules and regulations for carrying the enactment into operation and effect, after the legislature lays down the policy and the principles. Thus, it can delegate the authority to frame subordinate legislations. When the legislative policy and guidance are contained in the Act, the delegating provision would save it from vice of excessive delegation. Essentially legislative functions are those which cannot be delegated. However, other ancillary and incidental matters could be left to the subordinate authority to fill in details with a view to carry out the policy. If guidance is provided by the legislature to the delegated authority, the delegation is valid. Once policy principles or standards for guidance are provided in the Act, then, conferring of power on a subordinate authority to make subordinate or ancillary legislation would be valid. 1989 Supp (1) SCC 430 - Ref. to.  [Para 7]

heading: Retirement age
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Retirement age - For teaching staff, retirement age is 62 yrs. as per S.15A of Act - Contention of respondents that said provision is applicable only to a teacher appointed on regular basis, not on ad-hoc basis - Not acceptable - Petitioner’s retirement at age of 60 yrs. was improper - Petitioner directed to be paid differential salary etc.  (Paras 24, 25, 26)

HeadNote.description: Victim compensation - Victim, a 15 years old girl - Accused molested her and caused her death - Mother of victim, held, entitled to apply for compensation from Govt. under 2012 scheme. 	(Para 182)

HeadNote.description: Promotion on basis of academic or technical qualification - Classification provided under Recruitment Rules - Challenge to - Though persons appointed directly and by promotion were integrated into common class of Assistant Engineers, they could be classified on basis of educational qualification for the purpose of further promotion to the cadre of Executive Engineers - Classification provided under Recruitment Rules between degree holders and diploma holders for the purpose of promotion - Classification neither arbitrary nor discriminatory in any manner - Recruitment Rules, held, not voilative of Arts.14, 16 of the Constitution of India. heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.313 - Confiscation of smuggled gold - Appeal against acquittal - Accused in possession of contraband articles - Oral and documentary evidence produced - Accused in constant possession of gold not proved by prosecution - Sweetmeat box containing gold was with the customs officer and no signature of panch obtained on the same box - Commission of offence not established - Findings reached by Trial Court cannot be said to be erroneous - Order of acquittal would be proper. (Para 12)

heading: Assignment of land
Renewal
HeadNote.description: Letters patent (Cal.) Cl.15 - Assignment of land - Renewal - Second renewal not permissible in view of decision in 1997(10) SCC 61 - Single Judge nonetheless granting relief to applicant - Division Bench taking a view that 1997(10) SCC 61 was not applicable without indicating distinguishing features of that case - Not proper.	(Para 2)

heading: Lease of land by Government
HeadNote.description: Lease of land by Government - Lease deed stipulating that Government can terminate lease by giving two months notice if land is required by Government for any public purpose - Plot was situated just in front of the gate of the High Court and was required by government for extension of High Court building and extension of office of Advocate General - Government undertaking to pay rupees ten lakhs for the existing building of lessee on the land - Held government was entitled to take possession of land by terminating lease as per provisions in the lease deed without taking resort to acquisition of land under Land Acquisition Act. (Para 20)

heading: Nazul Rules, Rr.13, 14, 15, 16
HeadNote.description:
Nazul Rules, Rr.13, 14, 15, 16 - Form 3 of Nazul Manual - Mortgage of leasehold rights - Lessee mortgaging its leasehold interest with prior sanction of Govt. to a nationalized bank - Mortgage decree passed without issuing notice to Govt. - After expiry of leasehold rights of lessor, bank auctioning property - High Court directing Govt. to convert leasehold interest into freehold interest in favour of bank by applying doctrine of legitimate expectation - Held, as mortgage was itself bad in law, High Court committed grave error in applying doctrine of legitimate expectation in favour of the bank.

The doctrine of legitimate expectation ordinarily would not have any application when the legislature has enacted a statute. The legitimate expectation should be legitimate, reasonable and valid. For the application of doctrine of legitimate expectation, any representation or promise should be made by an authority. A person unconnected with the authority, who had no previous dealing and who has not entered into any transaction or negotiations with the authority cannot invoke the doctrine of legitimate expectation. A person, who bases his claim on the doctrine of legitimate expectation has to satisfy that he has relied on the said representation and the denial of that expectation has worked to his detriment.

2008 ALL SCR 2649 Rel. on. [Para 42]

In the instant case, admittedly, the State never recognized the appellant Bank as a mortgagee. Further the State was not aware about the alleged mortgage said to have been created by the lessee by deposit of Lease document. Moreover, the State never represented or promised either to the lessee or to the Bank to give any benefit under the lease. In such circumstances, we are of the definite opinion that the High Court has committed grave error in applying the doctrine of legitimate expectation in favour of the bank.

The appellant Bank has no right, title or interest in the property so as to claim a right of conversion of the property into a freehold property.

The impugned notice issued by the State of U.P. directing resumption of the property is legal and valid and cannot be quashed at the instance of the Bank. [Para 44,45]

heading: Government grants
HeadNote.description:
Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority (Disposal of Land) Regulations (1977), Regns.4 to 9 - Government grants - Land granted by Govt. to Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority - MMRDA leased out land to petitioner - Terms of lease agreement provided that use of additional basement would be permitted subject to payment of 5% of lease premium by petitioner - However, relevant statutory provision required for payment of 20% of lease premium - Contradiction in lease agreement and statutory provision - Held, MMRDA being a body corporate holds and transfers the land in its own capacity - Therefore, agreement of lease between MMRDA and petitioner is not a 'grant by or on behalf of Govt.' u/s.2 of Act of 1895 - Being so, contradictory terms of lease agreement would not be protected by Ss.2 and 3 - Statutory requirement will prevail.

In the present case, the land was granted by Govt. in favour of respondent-MMRDA in 1985 within the meaning of Government Grants Act and respondent was a grantee for the valuable consideration.  In view of S.3(2) of MMRDA Act, 1974 the respondent MMRDA, being a body corporate having perpetual succession and common seal has a power to acquire, hold and dispose of property, movable as well as immovable and also to enter into contracts.  In view of provisions of Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority (Disposal of Land) Regulations, even the Government cannot take back the land from respondent-MMRDA without following the procedure laid down in said Regulations.  Even the Government has to make payments if it wants to take back some land from the MMRDA.  In view of this the respondent-MMRDA does not hold the land for and on behalf of Government of Maharashtra.  Even though respondent-MMRDA being a local authority, may be a "State" u/Art.12 of the Constitution of India, it cannot be equated with Government of Maharashtra either under the Constitution or within the meaning of Government Grants Act, 1985.  It entered into a contract with petitioners as owner of the land as a body corporate, independent of Government of Maharashtra.  Therefore, when the respondent-MMRDA entered into an agreement with petitioner to lease out the land, it did not grant the land to petitioner far or on behalf of Government.  Therefore, it must be held that under the said agreement for lease, the land was not granted to petitioner by or on behalf of Government within the meaning of S.2 of Government Grants Act.  That being so the terms of said agreement cannot be immune from the applicability of statutory provisions contrary to the terms of contract.  [Para 9,10]

heading: Government Grants Act being a special statute would prevail over general statute i.e. Transfer of Property Act.	(Para 17)
HeadNote.description: Government Grants Act being a special statute would prevail over general statute i.e. Transfer of Property Act.	(Para 17)

heading: Reclamation leaves
Termination
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.14 - Reclamation leaves - Termination - Ground that subject land not reclaimed within period prescribed - Show cause notice dt.15.4.1981 - Reply filed on 14.12.1981 - No order passed pursuant to second show cause notice dt.10.9.2001 - Impugned order dt.20.11.2002, passed by Collector on presumptive finding that land was not fully reclaimed - Time gap of 21 years from date of issuance of show cause notice dt.15.4.1981 - Impugned order proceeding to decide even show cause notice dt.15.4.1981, is illegal and void to that extent - Moreover, Collector relied upon other two show cause notices and inspection report by Tahsildar, without supplying the same to noticee - Would render impugned order as illegal being contrary to principles of natural justice. (Paras 48, 52, 59, 73)

Assignment

heading: Recommendations of Ombudsman
HeadNote.description: Recommendations of Ombudsman - Recommendations ordinarily bind the Government - However, when the recommendations are not accepted by Hon'ble Chief Minister on the advice tendered by the Council of Ministers, the reasons are required to be given in order not to accept the recommendations of the ombudsman.	(Para 6)

heading: Age of retirement
Claiming extension of
HeadNote.description: U.P. Fundamental Rules, R.56 - Uttar Pradesh State Medical Colleges Teachers Service Rules (1990), R.26 - Age of retirement - Claiming extension of - On basis of notification issued by State Govt. which enhanced age of retirement from 60 years to 65 years - Appellant attained age of superannuation prior to date of notification - He was just continuing until end of session after retirement when notification was issued - He is not entitled to enhanced age of retirement. 	(Paras 19, 24)

heading: Deficiency in service
HeadNote.description: Post Office Savings Bank General Rules (1981) Rr.16, 17 - Deficiency in service - Notification No G & S R 118(E), 119(E), 120(E) - Notification prohibiting acceptance of Time Deposit from institutions with effect from 1.4.1995 - Temple depositing Rs.1,40,64,300/- For a period of five years - Post Master through ignorance of notification accepting deposits from temple and it was deprived of any interest there on - Held in view of notification and R.17 respondent cannot be fastened for deficiency in service in terms of S.2(1)(g). 		(Para 9)

heading: Nomination of shares
Effect of
HeadNote.description:
Banking Regulation Act (1949), S.45ZA - Depositories Act (1996), Bye-law 9.11 - Nomination of shares - Effect of - Held, nomination does not override the law in relation to testamentary or intestate succession - Nomination is not a testamentary disposition - Object of S.109A is to ensure that deceased shareholder is represented by someone as the value of shares is subject to market forces - And not to either provide a mode of succession or to deal with succession.

	Provisions of Section 109A and in particular Sub-section(3) thereof are not materially different from the provisions of Sub-section(1) of Section 6 of the Government Savings Certificates Act, 1959. Sub-section(2) of Section 45ZA of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 is also similar to Sub-section (2) of Section 109B. The same is the case with Byelaw 9.11 of the Depositories Act,1996. Even assuming that the format of the nomination requires attestation as required by a will under the Indian Succession Act,1925, the nomination does not become a testamentary disposition. 

	The provisions relating to nominations under the various Enactments have been consistently interpreted by the Apex Court by holding that the nominee does not get absolute title to the property subject matter of the nomination. The reason is by its very nature, when a share holder or a deposit holder or an insurance policy holder or a member of a Cooperative Society makes a nomination during his life time, he does not transfer his interest in favour of the nominee. It is always held that the nomination does not override the law in relation to testamentary or intestate succession. The provisions regarding nomination are made with a view to ensure that the estate or the rights of the deceased subject matter of the nomination are protected till the legal representatives of the deceased take appropriate steps. None of the provisions of the aforesaid Statutes providing for nominations deal with the succession, testamentary or nontestamentary.

	The object of the provisions of the Companies Act is not to either provide a mode of succession or to deal with succession. The object of the Section 109A is to ensure that the deceased shareholder is represented by some one as the value of the shares is subject to market forces. Various advantages keep on accruing to shareholders. For example, allotment of Bonus shares. There are general meetings held of the Companies in which a shareholder is required to be represented. The provision is enacted to ensure that the commerce does not suffer due to delay on the part of the legal heirs in establishing their rights of succession and claiming the shares of a Company.

	Considering the consistent view taken by the Apex Court while interpreting the provisions relating to nominations under various Statutes (including the view in the recent decision in the case of Indrani Wahi), there is no reason to make a departure from the consistent view. The provisions of the Companies Act including Sections 109A and 109B, in the light of the object of the said Enactment, do not warrant any such departure. The so called vesting under Section 109A does not create a third mode of succession. It is not intended to create a third mode of succession. 

2010(4) ALL MR 51 Held not good law.				 [Para 32,34,35]

heading: National Saving Certificate
Nominee
HeadNote.description:
National Saving Certificate - Nominee - On death of holder nominee does not become entitled to sum due, to exclusion of all other legal heirs.

The Act only makes the provisions regarding avoiding delay and expense in making the payment of the amount of the national savings certificates, to the nominee of holder, which has been considered to be beneficial both for the holder as also for the post office. Any amount paid to the nominee after valid deductions becomes the estate of the deceased. Such an estate devolves upon all persons who are entitled to succession under law, custom or testament of the deceased-holder. In other words, the law laid down by this Court in Sarbati Devi 's case, AIR 1984 SC346, holds field and is equally applicable to the nominee becoming entitled to the payment of the amount on account of national savings certificates received by him under Section 6 read with Section 7 of the Act who in turn is liable to return the amount to those, in whose favour law creates beneficial interest, subject to the provisions of sub-section (2) of Section 8 of the Act.  [Para 13]

heading: Non-obstante clause
HeadNote.description:
Non-obstante clause - Interpretation of.
Interpretation of Statutes - Non-obstante clause.

There is no doubt that by non obstante clause the Legislature devises means which are usually applied to give overriding effect to certain provisions over some contrary provisions that may be found either in the same enactment or some other statute. In other words such a clause is used to avoid the operation and effect of all contrary provisions. The phrase is equivalent to showing that the Act shall be no impediment to measure intended. To attract the applicability of the phrase, the whole of the section, the scheme of the Act and the objects and reasons for which such an enactment is made has to be kept in mind.  [Para 11]

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), S.2(2)

HeadNote.description: Election petition - Appellant candidate alleged of being less than 21 years of age - Statement of appellant that she was 10 years old on date of admission in Upper Primary School - Inference is drawn that if 10 years are deducted from date of admission particular date is her date of birth - Inconsistency in evidence of appellant regarding her age on date of admission in Upper Primary School and in High School - Statement about her age on date of admission in Upper Primary School not liable to be treated as admission of her date of birth - Judgement in favour of respondent is liable to be set aside. (Para 18)

HeadNote.description: Gratuity (Maharashtra) Rules (1972), R.7(5) - Expression "wages" - Fixed personal allowance or pay and special compensatory allowance - Cannot be included within the meaning of "wages" for the purpose of computing gratuity payable to the employee. AIR 1977 SC 941 and 2007(III) CLR 959 - Rel. on.	(Para 18)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Cannot be obtained for mere asking - There has to be sufficient cause to condone the delay though the expression "sufficient cause" is liberally construed and is elastic enough to enable the Court to apply the law in a meaningful manner - While condoning the delay what matters is not the length of the period but the acceptability of the explanation offered to condone the delay.

Condonation of delay cannot be obtained for mere asking. There has to be sufficient cause to condone the delay though the expression "sufficient cause" is liberally construed and is elastic enough to enable the Court to apply the law in a meaningful manner. There can be no dispute that while condoning the delay what matters is not the length of the period but the acceptability of the explanation offered to condone the delay. The Courts should not lose sight of the fact that by not taking steps within the time prescribed a valuable right accrues to the other party which cannot be lightly defeated by condoning the delay in a routine manner. Sufficient cause has to be considered with pragmatism and with justice oriented approach but any cause whatsoever cannot be construed as a sufficient cause and it is necessary for the Courts or the authorities to apply their mind to the cause shown and to satisfy themselves and to find out whether the cause shown is sufficient or not. Although the expression "sufficient cause" is liberally construed it does not mean that the Courts should readily accept whatever the party has stated to explain his default. If the Courts or authority accept anything and everything stated by a party, then such a party will have the last laugh at the cost of his adversary Courts and authorities are required to scrutinize the cause shown and would be justified in considering the merits of the evidence led to establish the same. Elasticity of the expression "sufficient cause" does not mean that it can be stretched to a breaking point. 2002(2) ALL MR 588 (S.C.) - Rel. on.							 [Para 12]

HeadNote.act_name: Grocery Markets or Shops Unprotected Workers (Regulation of Employment and Welfare) Scheme (1970)

HeadNote.description: Expression "products including fertilizers" - As used in Table given u/S.1(4) of Mathadi Act - Is wider expression than "chemical products including fertilizers" as used under Cl.2(1)(f) of 1970 Scheme - Said Cl.2(1)(f) is therefore intra vires the S.1(4) of Mathadi Act. heading: Custody of minor children
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor children - After Family Courts Act is enforced jurisdiction is vested in family court - Application under S.25 of Guardians and Wards Act is not maintainable.

After the Family Courts Act came into force, the proceedings in relation to the guardianship of a person or custody of, or access to, of a minor are required to be instituted in the Family Court in view of Section 7 of the said Act since it has a jurisdiction to decide these proceedings and also can exercise jurisdiction exercisable by the District Court and therefore, by necessary implication the application filed by the non-applicant under Section 25 of the Guardians & Wards Act, 1890, for custody of minor, is not maintainable.	 [Para 6]

heading: Application for appointment of guardian of person of minor
HeadNote.description:
Application for appointment of guardian of person of minor - Application would lie before the family court, irrespective of whether there is a matrimonial dispute pending before that court.

The High Court must be considered as a District Court for the purposes of the Family Courts Act and since the Family Courts have been established in the city of Mumbai, a Guardianship Petition for the custody or access to any minor would lie in the Family Court. The Guardians and Wards Act was enacted in 1890 and the High Court exercising its ordinary original civil jurisdiction is considered a District Court under that Act. The High Court's jurisdiction has been ousted in the light of the provisions of the Family Courts Act in case of guardianship proceedings instituted by a relative of a minor for guardianship of the minor's person. Such a proceeding clearly falls within the purview of section 7 of the Family Courts Act. Therefore, only the Family Court would have jurisdiction in view of the provisions of section 20. By virtue of section 20, the Family Courts Act has an overriding effect over any other law.  However, the High Court will continue to exercise its ordinary original civil jurisdiction in respect of petitions relating to the guardianship of the property of a minor. Therefore, a Guardianship Petition seeking guardianship of the person of a minor filed by either the parents or any relative of a minor would lie before the Family Court, irrespective of whether there is a matrimonial dispute pending before that Court. The Petition in the instant case, therefore, is not maintainable before High Court exercising its Ordinary Original Civil Jurisdiction and is accordingly, returned to the Petitioner for presenting the same before the appropriate Court. AIR 1991 Kant. 10 and AIR 1990 Mad. 100 - Referred to.	 [Para 11,12]

heading: Succession Act (1925)
Testamentary proceedings
Miscellaneous petition
HeadNote.description: Succession Act (1925) - Testamentary proceedings - Miscellaneous petition - Bequeath to minor on her attaining age of 21 yrs. - Money given to minor's mother to purchase property for benefit of minor - Mother purchasing property in joint names of herself and minor and leasing property for 99 yrs. for a paltry sum of money - Such conduct of mother in consonance with prophecy expressed by testator in Will - Mother not entitled to dispose off the property. (Para 14)

heading: Succession Act (1925)
Maintainability
Locus
HeadNote.description: Succession Act (1925) - Testamentary proceedings- Miscellaneous petition - Maintainability - Locus - Bequeath to minor on her attaining age of 21 yrs. - Property purchased by minor's mother from money given under will to purchase it for benefit of minor - Custody of minor jointly with minor's father and mother - Also decisions with regard to minor to be taken jointly by them - Petition by father to protect minor's interest in property - Contention that as Will was already probated, petition not maintainable - Prima facie, contention not sustainable. (Para 14)

heading: Guardianship petition
HeadNote.description: Guardianship petition - Rejection of u/O.7 R.11 - On ground that parties are nationals of U.S.A. and U.S. courts have intimate contact with matter - Principle of comity of courts or principle of forum convenience alone cannot determine threshold bar of jurisdiction - Paramount consideration is best interest of child - Same cannot be subject matter of final determination in proceedings u/O.7, R.11 CPC - Order rejecting guardianship petition, set aside. 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 1686 Foll. 	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Foreign decree
Enforceability in India
HeadNote.description:
Foreign decree - As to custody of child - Enforceability in India - Welfare of minor will be paramount consideration for courts while deciding validity or enforceability of such foreign decrees dealing with custody of minor - Even a consent order relating to custody of child, cannot bind the child - It can be varied, custody of child may be changed, if the welfare of minor so demands.

	The duty of a Court exercising its parens patriae jurisdiction as in cases involving custody of minor children is all the more onerous. Welfare of the minor in such cases being the paramount consideration, the Court has to approach the issue regarding the validity and enforcement of a foreign decree or order carefully. Simply because a foreign Court has taken a particular view on any aspect concerning the welfare of the minor is not enough for the Courts in India to shut out an independent consideration of the matter. Objectivity is the only consideration in such type of cases. It does not mean that the order passed by a foreign Court is not even a factor to be kept in mind while deciding the welfare of the child. The orders relating to custody of children are by their very nature not final, but are interlocutory in nature and subject to modification at any future time upon proof of change of circumstances, requiring change of custody but such change in custody must be proved to be in the paramount interests of the child.

	In nutshell, welfare of the child has to be appreciated in all possible manner. Any undertaking given in the divorce case between the couples is not binding upon the minor. All orders relating to custody of the minor must be considered to be temporary orders made in the existing circumstances. With the passage of time and with changed conditions and circumstances, the Court is entitled to vary such orders in the interest and welfare of the minor.

	The consideration on the basis of Section 13 CPC would give rise to a situation that if the foreign judgment is found to be not in consonance with the welfare of the child, then the Court in India which is not a reciprocating territory can interfere in the custody issue. All these things are dependent upon quality of evidence to be led by parties during trial. Since minor cannot be party to the lis between the parents, any order passed on consent of the parents is not binding upon the minor. Sub Clauses (c), (d) and (f) of Section 13 CPC may give rise to certain questions which are required to be answered by the competent Court after receiving evidence from the parties. The foreign judgment can be one of the considerations before the Court while considering the issue on merits. It cannot be a solitary point for decision of the custody issue before the Court under Section 7 read with Section 9 of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890.

2010 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 66, 2010 ALL SCR 794 Ref. to. 	 [Para 20,24]

heading: Special Leave petition
HeadNote.description: Special Leave petition - Against order of High Court directing wife to return to U.S. along with her daughter and son - Order passed in habeas corpus petition filed by husband for production of children who were illegally taken away from his custody by wife from U.S. - Both husband and wife are U.S. citizens and permanently residing there - Minor daughter also possessed American passport - Son was born in India when wife came to attend wedding in India - But he also became U.S. citizen by birth as both parties are U.S. citizens - Considering these facts High Court directed wife to return to U.S. along with her both children - During proceedings before Apex Court wife agreed to return to U.S. with minor children - Special leave petition dismissed with certain directions to husband. 	(Paras 2, 5, 7)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Child 15 years of age is a matured girl - Her intellectual characteristics are adequately developed - She is determined to live with her father - Inspite of giving ample chances to mother by giving her temporary custody of child - Mother has not been able to win over confidence of child - Welfare of child lies in continued company of her father which appears to be in her best interest. 	(Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Custody of minors
HeadNote.description: Custody of minors - Minor children lost their mother - Father stood trial under Ss.498-A/304-B, IPC and was acquitted - Application by him for custody of children - Court interviewing the boy (aged about 16 years) and girl (about 10 years) - They preferred custody with maternal parents - Both of them were studying in prestigious school at Dehradun - Father did not appear in Court on any date and was represented by his counsel - Held it would be just and proper to continue with maternal parents by appointing them as natural guardian. 2008 ALL SCR 2016 - Followed.			(Paras 6, 7, 8)

headline: Guardians and Wards Act (1890), S. 7 – Custody of minor daughter – Grant of, to father – Validity – Girl over 12 years of age expressed her definite desire to reside with her father – She stated that she received love and affection from her father, who was taking care of her food, education and would assist her in her school projects and activities – Grant of custody rights to father, proper.

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor daughter - Grant of, to father - Validity - Girl who is over 12 years of age is certainly capable of forming an intelligent preference regarding her custody - Girl expressed her definite desire to reside with her father - She stated that she received love and affection from her father, who was taking care of her food, education and would assist her in her school projects and activities - Counselors also in their report stated that girl is comfortable with her father - Grant of custody rights to father and visitation rights to mother, proper. (Para 24)

heading: Maintainability
Upheld
HeadNote.description: Application for appointment as guardian of minor - Maintainability - Minor living with his mother since birth - His present age was 17 and was likely to be a major in another year - Order that applicant grandfather was not entitled to custody of minor and his property - Upheld - Mere fact that mother of minor had entered into second marriage would not disentitle her from custody of her minor son.	(Para 3)

heading: Guardianship of minor girl
HeadNote.description: Guardianship of minor girl - Girl was brought up by both parents till the age of 7 - Girl was surreptiously removed by her mother from the custody of her father when she left the matrimonial home - Her custody was obtained under Court's order by the father and minor girl chose to stay with the father when she was interviewed by the Court - Father was lawyer by profession and was financially stable and not disqualified in any way from being guardian of minor child - Child was also well looked after by elder sister of respondent father - Held interest of the minor will be best served if she remains with the father but with sufficient access to the appellant to visit her at frequent intervals without disturbing her studies and other activities.	(Paras 25, 26)

heading: Appointment of guardian
HeadNote.description: Appointment of guardian - Predominant factor to be considered is welfare of minor, while exercising court's power to appoint a guardian. AIR 1987 SC 3 - Followed.			(Para 12)

heading:
Rel.on.

(2001)8 SCC 552
Distinguished. [Para 7,8,10]
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor child - Court obliged to keep in mind the paramount interest and welfare of the minor - Even if a natural guardian is alive and stakes his/her claim, but the Court can still proceed to appoint some other fit person as the guardian under the provisions of the Act.

The court is obliged to keep in mind the paramount interest and welfare of the minor.  Even if a natural guardian is alive and stakes his/her claim, but the court can still proceed to appoint some other fit person as the guardian under the provisions of the Act.  That needs to be done having regard to the welfare of the  minor.

In the present case, the Petitioner is the real  maternal grand mother of the minor.  Besides, the minor Aniruddha who was born on 29.1.1995, has throughout stayed with the Petitioner and her family.  The Petitioner and her family were looking after Alka as well as minor Aniruddha.  The mother (Alka) died on 9.2.2000 but, even thereafter, the Petitioner has continued to nurture the minor Aniruddha.  There is nothing on record to indicate that the interest of minor Aniruddha is not properly looked after by the Petitioner.

In the fact situation of the present case, it is seen that the minor has throughout remained in the custody of the Petitioner who is the real maternal grand mother, since his birth and, is being properly looked after by the Petitioner till  now.   The fact that the Respondent is the father of the minor or for that matter has been given access to the minor and visiting rights does not mean that the Petitioner is ineligible for maintaining the application under the provisions of Guardianship and Wards Act.  The Petitioner is compent to maintain this application.  AIR 1979 Bom 156 and AIR 1992 Kerala 277 - Rel.on.

(2001)8 SCC 552 - Distinguished. [Para 7,8,10]

heading: Declaration of guardianship
HeadNote.description: Declaration of guardianship - Minor child is living with his paternal relatives - Mother has remarried after death of father of minor child - Existence of biological mother was made known to child through counselor of court - Child is well settled in family - Present husband of child's mother not anxious to care for child in his home - It is not just, fair to alter present family situation of child - Petitioners are appointed as guardian of child - Access to child is granted to mother, biological brother of child. (Paras 20, 21, 22, 23, 24)

heading: Declaration of guardian
Validity of
HeadNote.description: Declaration of guardian - Validity of - Application filed by real grand-mother of child - During pendency of application, petition under Domestic Violence Act was filed by mother of child with prayer for custody of child - Said fact was suppressed from court - Also proceedings for declaration of guardian was proceeded ex-parte as summons issued to real mother of child by RPAD returned with remark "Refused" - Where family court is dealing with sensitive issue like guardianship of minor child, court must be cautious in passing order ex parte without there being authentic proof of service of summons - Declaration of guardian, not proper. (Paras 5, 6, 7, 8)

heading: Paramount consideration is welfare of minor
HeadNote.description:
Paramount consideration is welfare of minor - Held, mother of male child aged about five years was entitled to the custody of her son.

On a true construction of the provisions of S.17 & S.25, there can be no doubt that in appointing or declaring a guardian of a minor, the court must have regard to the welfare of a minor which is of paramount consideration. Taking in to account all the relevant facts as age, sex, religion, character and capacity of the proposed guardian, nearness of  kin to the minor, the paramount consideration is the welfare of a minor. It is for deciding this paramount consideration of the welfare of a minor that all other factors must be taken in to account.  [Para 13]

In the present case, the mother of the male child, aged about five years, made an application u/s 25 of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 for custody of her son.  She complained that the child was snatched away from her custody and was illegally detained by his father in his custody.  The father of the child was getting  salary of Rs.4,500/- p.m. and was required, from very nature of his job, to travel around.  He gave talak to the mother of the child and married a second wife.  The mother  was getting salary of Rs.3000/- p.m.

Held that the mother was entitled to the custody of her son.  That the father was drawing a higher salary than that of the mother was not relevant consideration.  For children of tender years, it is not money alone which matters.  It is the natural love and affection and particularly, the care which the mother can take that is more important and which has no substitute.  The welfare of the child was safer with the mother.  The father had a touring job.  Leaving his only son from his first wife to the case of his second wife, in preference to the natural mother, would not be in the best interest of the child.  He certainly needs love and affection of his natural mother who is anxious to bestow it upon her child.
AIR 1973 SC 2090, AIR 1977 SC 1359, 
AIR 1982 SC 1276, AIR 1989 SC 401
and (1993) 2 S.C.C. 6 7071.   [Para 8,10,14]

heading: Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act (2000), Ss.41(2), 41(3), 41(4) (Substituted from 22.8.2006)
HeadNote.description: Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act (2000), Ss.41(2), 41(3), 41(4) (Substituted from 22.8.2006) - Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Rules (2007), R.33 - By virtue of R.33(2) Guidelines of 2011 Notified under S.41(3) on 24.6.2011 will now govern all matters pertaining to inter country adoptions - Foreign adoptive parent suitable and willing and consent of child taken - Expert bodies advocating adoption process as it would be beneficial to both adoptive parents and child - Female child was 7 years old when NOC was issued and prospective parent was 54 years old - Held, as each and every norm of adoptive process was adhered to court must lean in favour of adoption. 			(Para 11)

heading: Guardianship petition
HeadNote.description: Guardianship petition - Hindu mother of minor girl child died unnatural death - Christian father is in police custody charged with murder - Paternal aunt claiming custody of child - Aunt has no experience of living with child - Aunt has filed petition on instructions of her brother without any personal desire - Child was not baptized till age of 3 years when her mother died - Mother also had not converted to Christianity during her lifetime - This has bearing on wishes of deceased parent - Contention that grandparents may not be able to initiate child into Christian precepts is not sustainable - Guardianship given to maternal grandparents, upheld. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Custody of minor children
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor children - Female child of 5 years and a boy of 9 years - Both having American citizenship - Their mother bringing them to India pending divorce proceedings in American court - Court granting decree of divorce as well as custody to husband - Husband filing habeas corpus petition in Delhi High Court which was admitted and custody was directed to be given to husband - Held, setting aside the order that it was in the interest of minor children to stay with their mother and the children also desired the same - Hence mother was entitled to custody.	(Para 6)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Interim arrangement for visitation made that children aged 8 years and 5 years shall visit to Kolkata from Noida by flight on fortnight basis to meet respondent mother - Same being extremely stressful for children, Supreme Court indicated viable arrangement that children shall travel once in a month to Kolkata while respondent shall meet in Delhi once in a month - Airfare and expenses for stay, for respondent and her mother directed to be paid by husband. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Interim custody of minor children
HeadNote.description:
Interim custody of minor children - Matter is to be approached and tackled carefully keeping welfare of minor in the forefront - Deceased mother left her minor children in custody of their paternal grand parents and father - Change of custody to maternal grand parents solely on ground that presence of children was necessary to perform obsequies of their mother cannot be considered as sufficient for granting interim custody till matter is finally decided by family Court.

Custody of minor children is a sensitive issue. It is also a matter involving sentimental attachment. Such a matter is to be approached and tackled carefully. A balance has to be struck between the attachment and sentiments of the parties towards the minor children and the welfare of the minors which is of paramount importance.		 [Para 9]

At the time of death of their mother the children were left in custody of their paternal grand parents with whom their father is staying and the attempt of the respondent No. 1 was to alter that position before the application filed by them is considered by the Family Court. For this purpose it was very relevant to consider whether leaving the minor children in custody of their father till the Family Court decides the matter would be so detrimental to the interest of the minors that their custody should be changed forthwith. The observations that the father is facing a criminal case, that he mostly resides in USA and that it is alleged that he is having an affair with another lady are, in our view; not sufficient to come to the conclusion that custody of the minors should be changed immediately. It is relevant to state here that the respondent No. 1 maternal grand-parents wanted immediate custody of the minor children for the purpose of performing certain obsequies in connection with the cremation ceremony of his deceased daughter and that purpose had been served by the order passed by the learned single Judge and such necessity for interim custody had ceased when the Division Bench passed the judgment/order under challenge.			 [Para 10]

The High Court appears to have overlooked the settled principle that custody orders by their nature can never be final; however, before a change is made it must be proved to be in the paramount interest of the children. In a sensitive matter like this no single factor can be taken to be decisive. Neither affluence nor capacity to provide comfortable living should cloud the consideration by the Court.					 [Para 11]

heading: Mohammadan Law
Application for
HeadNote.description: Mohammadan Law - Custody of minor children to father - Application for - Wife allegedly leading adulterous life having adverse impact on lives of children and neglecting to take proper care of children - Held, though Hanafi mother is entitled to custody of minor son until he completed 7 yrs. of age and minor daughter until she attained age of puberty - Yet, according to mulla if she neglects to take proper care of child she loses her right of custody - Evidence is reliable on point of immoral and adulterous character of wife - Moreover, in her cross-examination she admitted that she is totally illiterate, having no source of income - She could not state as to what level of education is available in the village she was residing in with her children - Primacy given to higher education of children and moral values of life over and above love and affection - Therefore, custody granted to father alongwith visitation rights to mother.	(Paras 13, 18, 24, 25, 26)

heading: Application for custody of minor child
HeadNote.description:
Application for custody of minor child - Fact that mother is employed and transferred away from home state - Cannot be a reason for drawing a presumption that she is not in a position to maintain the child or to look after the welfare of the child.

Parents of children all over the country are liable to be transferred away from their hometowns when the employment in which one or both the spouses is engaged is transferable. Undoubtedly, in matters of transfer a certain degree of hardship is likely to be caused to the family.  There is, however no reason for the court to draw a presumption that a mother who has been granted custody of her child will not be in a position to look after the welfare of the child if she is transferred outside the state.  The drawing of such presumptions is most inappropriate in the context of contemporary realities.  Women, including single women are able to combine in themselves multitudinous roles of being able members of the workplace and successful homemakers.  An interpretation which is anachronistic to the rapidly evolving position of women in society must be discarded.  There is no reason in facts of this case to hold that the petitioner would not take or has not taken necessary steps to ensure the welfare of the child.	 [Para 9]

heading: Adoption and relinquishment of child
HeadNote.description: Adoption and relinquishment of child - Procedure for eradication of mal-practices in adoption and relinquishment, indicated - Surrender document should be executed at the free will of biological parents/parent with no compulsion, payment or compensation of any kind on the part of adoption/placement agencies - Parents/parent should be informed by the agencies of his/her/their right to reclaim the child within 60 days from the date of surrender - He/she/they should be made aware that, after the period of 60 days, surrender document will become irrevocable and the child will be considered legally free for adoption and the recognized adoption placement agency will be free to place the child in adoption or guardianship, through In-country or Inter-country Adoption or any other suitable rehabilitation.			(Para 1)

heading: Guardianship certificate
HeadNote.description: Guardianship certificate - Petitioner, a natural guardian in all respects and for all purposes of minors - Petitioner's husband died and employer Municipal Corporation paid all dues to petitioner except gratuity and death-cum-service which was withheld for production of guardianship certificate - Petitioner being natural mother looked after day to day affairs and expenses of minors - Minors living with her - No direct adverse or conflicting interest - No other person claimed in respect of person or property of minors - No other heirs except petitioner - Held in view of substantial compliance of Ss.7, 10, 11 and welfare of minors, prayer for guardianship certificate in favour of petitioner has to be granted. AIR 1987 SC 3 Ref.	(Para 5)

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child - Application filed by father at Kalyan Court, and claiming that Kalyan was ordinary place of residence - Objection by mother that since she herself and child were residing at Thane, Kalyan Court had no jurisdiction to entertain application - Kalyan being within District of Thane, transfer of proceedings from Addl. District Judge, Kalyan to District Court at Thane directed, having regard to peculiar facts of the case to meet the ends of justice.		(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Appointment of guardian
Dist.	(Paras 12, 13)
HeadNote.description: Appointment of guardian - Entitlement to custody of minor - Held, in Every exceptional circumstance a person other than a natural guardian should be appointed guardian for the person of the minor. 2000(1) Mh.L.J. 136 and 2005(1) ALL MR 19 - Dist.	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Custody of minor
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor - Paramount consideration should be the welfare of child - Boy living with mother for last several years - Parents separated by divorce and wife remarrying soon after petition for custody of child was decided in her favour - High Court without giving opportunity to express willingness of child allowed appeal only on ground of remarriage of mother - In appeal by mother Apex Court interviewing child and the 11 years old boy expressed his willingness and desire to live only with mother and he felt that his mother will provide him good education - Held, in view of desire of the child to live with his mother the remarriage of mother cannot be taken as a ground for not granting custody of child to her.

The remarriage of the mother cannot be taken as a ground for not granting the custody of the child to the mother. The paramount consideration should be given to the welfare of the child.  At the interview, the boy has expressed his willingness and desire to live only with his mother and was admitted by him that the mother will provide him good education.  The mother is also drawing pension of Rs.6,000/- p.m. and also having land and properties in her name.  When the boy says he prefers to live with his mother, it will be beneficial for the boy and his education for a better future.  The High Court, erred in allowing the appeal on the ground of remarriage of the appellant without considering the other aspects of the matter.  It is a matter of custody of the child and the paramount consideration should be the welfare of the child.  It is not in dispute the boy is living with his mother for the last several years and the separation at this stage will affect the mental condition and the education of the child and considering that the child himself attaches importance to his education if the custody is to be given to the father  will now affect his academic brilliance and future. The High Court, ought to have seen that the re-marriage cannot be taken as a ground for giving custody of the child.  There is also no finding by the High Court that the remarriage has adversely affected the mental condition of the minor child. In cases like the present one, the mother may have shortcomings but that does not imply that she is not deserving of the solace and custody of her child.  If the Court forms the impression that the mother is a normal and independent young woman and shows no indication of imbalance of mind in her, then in the end the custody of the minor child should not be refused to her or else we would be really assenting to the proposition that a second marriage involving a mother per se will operate adversely  to a claim of a mother for the custody of her minor child.  AIR 1982 SC 1276, AIR 1950 Mad. 306 - Ref. 		 [Para 3]

heading: Appointment of Guardian
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Guardian - Guardian would be appointed only in respect of minor - Appointment of a guardian for a mentally ill person who is major - Remedy would be under Mental Health Act and not under Guardians and Wards Act.	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Adoption
Inter-country adoption
HeadNote.description:
Adoption - Inter-country adoption - Adoption of female child - Deed of relinquishment of child in favour of appellant society found to be fake and fabricated document - Prosecution launched against applicant - Some of its functionaries were already convicted - Held, every effort to see that child is adopted by Indian parents ought to be made before giving permission - Refusal of permission to give child in adoption abroad upheld.

While permitting any organization to keep a child or give him or her in adoption its credentials are to be minutely scrutinized. It should be ensured that behind the mask of social service or upliftment an evil design of child trafficking is not lurking. It is the duty of the State to ensure a safe roof over an abandoned child. Keeping in view the welfare of the child all possible efforts should be made by the State Governments to explore possibility of adoption under the supervision of the designated agency. Keeping in view the guidelines indicated in Lakshmi Kant Pandey case adoption by foreign parents may in appropriate cases be permitted. While making the requisite and prescribed exercise it has to be kept in mind that child is a precious gift and merely because he or she for various reasons is abandoned by the parents that cannot be a reason for further neglect by the society. (1984)2 SCC 244 Ref.  [Para 11,12]

heading: Guardian of minor
No evidence led
HeadNote.description: Guardian of minor - After death of mother - Custody of minor was with father of the demised mother - Application by father of minor under S.19(b) - No issue framed as to competency of father - No evidence led - Matter remitted to frame issue and to give opportunity to both parties to lead evidence and then to decide application of father under S.19(b).  (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child - Welfare of child is paramount consideration - Child born in Australia - After his birth his father taking divorce from his mother - Australian Court ordered joint custody and by settlement it was agreed that respondent father can take him to India to meet his parents - He, however, refused to send him to Australia in violation of order of Australian Court - He ought to have approached Australian Court for variation of consent order - Petitioner wife even before divorce from respondent was in relationship with other person and was pregnant with twins - Respondent also alleged that petitioner was unemployed and she and her father were declared bankrupt - Respondent who had applied for custody of child to the Family Court at Mumbai was living with his father who has retired, grand mother, mother and paternal aunt - Held minor child aged 3 1/2 years would be well looked after by respondent and his family members - Petitioner wife extended with visitation rights pending decision of proceedings pending in Family Court, Bandra, Mumbai.		(Paras 50, 52)

heading: Petition by father
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor sons - Petition by father - Elder son is about six years of age and is hale and hearty - Younger son is about 3 ½ years of age and one of his legs has been paralysed - Father was residing at city whereas mother was residing at remote place - Father was earning enough to provide food, shelter and clothing for his children - Several persons in his family to take care of his sons - However, it would not be in interest of justice to grant custody of both minor children to father as mother and father should equally have company of their children - Custody of elder son granted to father as elder son could be better educated in city - Custody of younger son granted to mother as she can look after him in better way. 	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Rel. on.	(Paras 18-21)
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child - Minor girl was born premature and had to be kept in incubator - Her mother died during delivery - Child was since then looked after by her grand-mother - On the contrary her father never visited her in hospital even once - He was also living separately from his parents and was heavily in debt - He subsequently got married for second time and has a child too - Grand mother even after death of her husband was financially sound and child was studying in well known public school and was leading a happy life - Held though natural guardian has right to custody of child, looking to welfare of the minor it was desirable to allow maternal grand-mother to retain custody of minor girl. AIR 1935 Mad 195, (2000)9 SCC 745, AIR 1987 SC 3 - Rel. on.	(Paras 18-21)

heading: Application by mother
HeadNote.description: Custody of two sons - Application by mother - Two sons 11 and 9 years respectively living with father for over seven years - Father had obtained decree of divorce after he suspected that his son from his first wife who died by falling into a well was killed by respondent wife - Her two sons deposed against her in criminal case under S.302, IPC - Trial, however, had ended in acquittal - Apex Court meeting two children and their father and mother individually - Both the children were happy with the father - Mother had no access to children or even a brief meeting with them - Apex Court after setting aside order of High Court granting custody to mother gave directions for access and visitation rights to her two children.			(Paras 7-9)

heading: Guardianship of minor
HeadNote.description: Guardianship of minor - Application for, filed at Dhule - Objection to jurisdiction of Court - Non-applicant-mother, claims to be residing with minor at Indore (M.P.) - Minor born at Shirpur (Dhule) - Taken education there till 2011 - His admission in school at Indore taken without transfer certificate from school at Shirpur - Non-applicant residing at Nashirabad, Ajmer (Rajasthan) with second husband - Minor left with her parents at Indore - Fact showing that minor taken away from parental family in questionable circumstances - Residence of Shirpur of minor will not change - Court at Dhule would have jurisdiction. AIR 1983 Madras 9 Ref. to. (Para 11)

heading: Custody of child
Access to children
Denial of
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Access to children - Denial of - On ground that daughters of petitioner father were 16 and 15 years of age and were reluctant to meet their father - Admittedly daughters demonstrated an extremely venomous attitude towards their father during counseling - Though father assured daughters that he will always love and care for them - In view of age and vehemence of daughter towards their father entire effort of counseling would be whittled down - Order of denial of access to the daughter by the father held proper. (Paras 16 to 19)

heading: Appointment of guardian
HeadNote.description:
Guardianship and custody of child - Appointment of guardian - Father of the child in jail for murdering mother of the child - Maternal grandfather applied for his appointment as guardian of his grand-daughter - Neither father nor aunt applied before him - Minor child secure and safe at her maternal grandfather's place - In a close knit healthy, happy family sex is no barrier to the appointment as guardian - Mother of child born as Hindu avoided the conversion and refused to convert to the Christian religion - Deceased wished her child to follow Hindu religion - Relations of child with grandfather better than her aunt - Grandfather demonstrated his capacity and intention by his action - Aunt filed petition only at the instance of the father, not fit for guardianship - Minor child reasonably well provided and cared emotionally by grandfather - Grandfather would be fit to be appointed as guardian.

2008 ALL SCR 2016, AIR 1992 Patna 76 Rel. on. 	 [Para 26,28]

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Dispute between husband and wife - Wife not remaining present in court - She did not file written statement - Court proceeding ex parte and husband was not cross-examined - Court accepted his evidence without interviewing child in camera to know his views - Paramount consideration in such matters is welfare of children - Proceeding remitted for fresh hearing. 	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction - Application for guardianship of minor - It is the District Court in whose jurisdiction minor resides has the jurisdiction to entertain and decide application - Economic condition or resourcefulness of parties to proceedings cannot be considered. 	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Custody of girl child
HeadNote.description: Custody of girl child - Child is born from appellant-wife - Child is girl coming of age - Child in her statement specifically showing unwillingness to go with her father - Appellant wife does not have independent source of income - Maintenance, education expenses of child can be asked for, from her father - Father has remarried, has a son - Child must remain with her natural mother rather than her step mother. (Para 7)

heading: Visitation right
HeadNote.description: Visitation right - Sought by mother, during pendency of litigation for custody - Children were deprived of company of mother due to parents' fighting - Considering welfare of children and feelings of love and affection of every mother for her children, visitation rights granted to mother to meet her children. 		(Paras 6, 9)

heading: Application for guardianship
HeadNote.description:
Application for guardianship - Words "ordinarily resides" would mean regular, normal settled home and not temporary or forced stay.

The child is said to ordinarily reside at a place where he is expected to be ordinarily found with his natural guardian but when against the wishes of one of the parents, the child has been sent to a person related, it will not tantamount to a presumption that the place where the child 'ordinarily resides' has been shifted. Generally, the matrimonial house or the house of the parents is considered the family residence of a minor unless and until there are extra ordinary reasons to arrive at a conclusion that the place of ordinary residence has been shifted. The circumstances under which a child has been compelled to reside at another place cannot be said to be a regular, normal or settled home. It cannot be laid down as a hard and fast rule that a minor child will be deemed to be permanently residing at a place where there is matrimonial home but depending on the circumstances, under which he has been removed from the matrimonial home will have to be considered to arrive at a conclusion whether the place where he has been shifted can be said to be a place where he ordinarily resides for the purpose of Section 9 of the Guardians and Wards Act.   [Para 13]

heading: Appointment as guardian
Application for
HeadNote.description: Appointment as guardian - Application for - Application filed by respondent real maternal aunt of minor child - During pendency of proceedings another daughter in law of appellants-natural grandparents of minor, had given birth to child - Appellants did not examine their son to show that he was fully equipped to take care of said minor - Appellants did not produce any documents showing that they were in sound financial position to take care of minor - Moreover, appellants were 80 yrs. and 74 years of age and suffering health problem - On contrary respondent and her husband are practicing doctors - She had spent lot of money on care and education of minor - Appellants also opposed proceedings filed by daughter-in-law for partition and maintenance during her lifetime - Such person cannot be allowed custody of minor - Application of respondent for appointment as guardian of minor allowed.	(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Custody of minor
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor - Child aged 16, studying in intermediate, right from 25 days of birth in care of maternal grandmother and showing consistently good performance in education - Mother divorced her husband and married again - Order of custody in favour of mother, when child desires to remain in custody of grandmother, unjustified - Minor, when old enough to form an intelligent preference, his intelligent preference deserves to be given due weight - In interest of his welfare, he should not be disturbed from his environment at home at this stage - Contempt case dismissed as grandmother never refused minor child from going to mother. United Nations Conventions on the Rights of the Child, Articles 12 and 13.

The material welfare of the child includes stability, security, living environment and understanding care and guidance with which the minor child is acquainted for the last 16 years. It is also on record that the child was showing consistently good performance in education which is evidenced by the fact that in S.S.C. Examination this year, he got 556 out of 600 marks; which is a very impressive academic record. The minor child is now said to be studying intermediate and the intermediate examination being crucial for shaping career of a student, ensuring that the minor child is not disturbed from his environment at home appears to be crucial circumstance with respect to his welfare.   [Para 22]

The other circumstance which we have to statutorily take into consideration is with regard to the wishes of a minor child. The preference of the minor child, if he is intelligent enough, is one of the factors which is required to be taken into consideration as per the mandate of Section 17(3) of the Act. The minor child is intelligent and old enough and on more than one occasion, he has expressed his desire to remain in the custody of grandmother rather than his mother.   [Para 23,24]

The U.N. Convention records in para 1.9 that there are a wide range of laws in India which guarantee to a substantial extent the rights and entitlement as provided in the Constitution and in the UN Convention. It also referred in para 1.12 that in 1974, the Government of India adopted a National Policy for Children wherein several welfare measures are provided including creation of a National Children Fund. It is in the backdrop of these legislations and steps taken by Government of India, it joined a comity of Nations and reaffirmed the commitment to advance the cause of children by endorsing and signing the world declaration. The aforesaid convention was ratified by Government of India on 12-11-1992 and has taken all measures for implementing convention. The U.N. Convention would not affect any provision of a domestic law which is more conducive of the realisation of the rights of the child. The reference to Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 is already found in para 1.9 referred to above and the reliance of the learned counsel on Articles 12 and 13 of the Convention that if the child is capable of forming and expressing his views, in all matters affecting child, his views are required to be given due weightage, already find place in Section 17(3) of the Guardians and Wards Act referred to above. In that view of the matter, Section 25 as well as Section 17 of the Guardians and Wards Act sufficiently take care of the welfare aspect together with intelligent preference and views of the child who is capable of making intelligent preference with respect to his or her custody.   [Para 27,30]

heading: Territorial jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Territorial jurisdiction - Petition seeking relief of guardianship, custody of minor etc. - To determine issue of territorial jurisdiction, Court is required to find out where minor ordinarily resides - Ascertainment of place of ordinary residence of minor would depend upon intention of parties - Minor-daughter was born residing and taking education at Nagpur till she was taken away by her mother to Rajamundry without consent of her father - Act of shifting of minor from Nagpur to Rajamundry was unilateral and hardly expressive of intention of parents - Rajamundry cannot be place where minor ordinarily resides - Ordinary place of residence of minor is Nagpur - Family Court at Nagpur has jurisdiction to try petition. 			(Paras 8, 10, 11, 12, 15)

heading: Mohammedan Law
Petition by father
HeadNote.description: Mohammedan Law - Custody of minor son - Petition by father - Son being less than 7 yrs. old, mother entitled to custody as per S.352 of Mulla's Principles on Mohammedan Law - Though remarriage of mother is a disqualification in terms of S.354, in instant case, mother has obtained divorce even from second husband - Even otherwise, such principles of Mohammedan Law are not so harsh to ignore welfare of child - Son is in custody of mother since his birth - His school progress card and other facts reflect that he is safe in present custody - Moreover, father has also remarried - He has two children from second wife and old aged parents to look after - He travels daily for employment - It would be hard for him to take out sufficient time to look after minor son - Further, due to absence of second wife it is also not known as to whether she is inclined to take care of child - Welfare of son is safer with natural mother - Father, not entitled to custody.	(Paras 10, 11, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Appointment of guardian
Validity
HeadNote.description: Appointment of guardian - Validity - Grant of custody of minor children to their aunt on ground that appellant/father of children had murdered his wife - Evidence yet to be adduced and offence yet to be proved against appellant - Order of grant of custody passed by Ad-hoc District Judge without jurisdiction since family Court is established in city - Appellant was not made party to the proceeding and no opportunity was given to him - Order of grant of custody liable to be set aside and matter was remanded. 	(Para 9)

heading: Temporary custody of minor female child
HeadNote.description: Temporary custody of minor female child - Child of six and half years is in custody of her father since her birth - Access given to mother for summer vacation - Allegations by father that child was physically hurt and traumatized by her mother on earlier two occasions - Two medico legal certificates on record showing that child suffered abuse - Further, child is not willing to join company of her mother for summer vacations - There is need to evaluate child psychologically for ascertaining reasons thereof - Considering welfare of minor female child access denied to mother till Child Psychologist gives evaluation report. 		(Paras 14, 16)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Child 15 years of age is a matured girl - Her intellectual characteristics are adequately developed - She is determined to live with her father - Inspite of giving ample chances to mother by giving her temporary custody of child - Mother has not been able to win over confidence of child - Welfare of child lies in continued company of her father which appears to be in her best interest. 	(Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Custody of child
Failure of settlement
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Failure of settlement - Consent order passed in year 2013 contemplated visitation rights of husband - However, same was not allowed by wife - Since all efforts to bring mediation between parties failed, children directed to be placed in boarding school - With every passing day, children pay heavy price of being deprived of parental love - Only other way is to expedite resolution of personal disputes through judicial process - Liberty given to parties to file independent proceedings for custody - However, there being no joint application, unilateral prayer of wife to withdraw from consent order not allowed. (Paras 33, 34, 36, 37, 39)

heading: Custody of child
Rejection of claim
