HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Claim by biological parents - Rejection of claim - Child was born out of illegitimate relationship between biological parents - Biological parents claiming that they were legally married but failed to produce any material showing that they were married before birth of child - Financial condition of biological parents is not sound - Biological parents living in house which appears to be temporary structure - At time of birth child was suffering from jaundice and his condition was critical - Adoptive parentsrespondents gave expert medical treatment to child, because of which he recovered - Since then, child was nurtured and brought up by adoptive parents - Child who is now of 6 years of age is emotionally attached to adoptive parents - Adoptive parents are in better financial position to give quality life and quality education to child and to take care of welfare of child - Considering welfare of child, rejection of claim of biological parents, proper. (Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 23, 24)

heading: Custody of child and guardianship
HeadNote.description: Custody of child and guardianship - Appellant-father, his wife and 13 years old child all British National - Mother of child suffering from depression and was under medical treatment in UK - Child in custody of 74 years old respondent i.e. maternal grandmother - Evidence showing that appellant has love and affection towards his wife and child also - Respondent has also love and affection towards child - Appellant not shown to have neglected child at any time - He is not shown to be unfit to be guardian and to have custody of his child - Appellant has rapport with child - Child has medical issues and undergone surgeries - Appellant being highly qualified doctor, can better understand condition of child and undertake corrective measures - Child a bright student never declined to be with appellant father - Appellant can better look after his future studies - Marriage Counselor's Report not against appellant - Thus, in view of facts, custody of child cannot be denied to appellant, a natural guardian, since welfare of child lies in his hands. 			(Paras 17, 22, 23, 24, 25, 28)

heading: Custody of minor
Validity
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor - Grant of, to mother - Validity - Husband claiming custody of minor child of three years - Girl child of three years would be more comfortable with her mother - Child is of such age that she is unable to converse properly - Allegations of husband that mother is living in adultery would be considered by trial court at relevant time - Grant of custody of child to mother, proper. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Welfare of children is paramount consideration - Marriage between Husband and wife dissolved - Both made allegations against each other, but allegations against husband are more serious - He is facing trial under POCSO Act on report of his own daughter - Therefore, custody of minor son cannot be given to father who is accused of molesting his own daughter - Though appellant-husband not convicted in said case, considering seriousness of allegations and pendency of a criminal case, custody of son cannot be given to appellant-husband - Moreover, record shows that wife is taking appropriate care of minor son whereas husband did not pay any attention to education of his daughter - Therefore, it cannot be said that welfare of son lies with father - Custody of minor son granted to father without considering welfare of minor, illegal and liable to be set aside - Claim of custody of daughter allowed to be withdrawn as she attained age of majority during pendency of appeal.		(Paras 14, 15, 17, 18)

heading: Custody of children
Interlocutory in nature
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Order passed u/S.12 of Guardians and Wards Act - Interlocutory in nature - Appeal against it barred by S.47 of said Act and S.19 of Family Courts Act - Principles in Khimji's case [1981 ALLMR ONLINE 409 (S.C.)], having been laid down before enactment of Family Courts Act, no more applicable. 2016(4) ALL MR 470 (S.C.), (1998) 1 SCC 112, 2010 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 66, 2010 ALL SCR 794, 2001(2) ALL MR 237 (S.C.), 1993 SCC Online Raj 216, 2008 (71) ALR 665 Ref.to. (2012) 192 DLT 714 (DB) Rel.on. 1981 ALLMR ONLINE 409 (S.C.) Not a Good Law.	(Paras 16, 25, 26)

heading: Custody of a minor
HeadNote.description: Custody of a minor - Cannot be decided solely by interpreting legal provisions - It is a humane problem and is required to be solved with humane touch - Paramount consideration shall be welfare and well-being of the child - But over and above physical comforts, moral and ethical values and wishes of the minor if he is old enough to form intelligent preference, should be considered.		(Paras 56, 64)

heading: Custody of minor
Considerations involved
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor - Considerations involved - It is not the "negative test" that father is not 'unfit' or disqualified to have custody of minor is relevant but "positive test" that such custody would be in the welfare of the minor which is material.			(Para 62)

heading: Custody of minor
Relevant considerations
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor - Relevant considerations - Controlling consideration governing the custody is the welfare of children and not the right of their parents.			(Para 59)

heading: Custody of minor
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor - Minor son six years old - His mother died in hospital after she was brutally assaulted by his father - Case under Ss.498-A and 304, IPC pending - Father's mother was absconding - Minor in a sick condition was handed over to his mother's parents - They maintained him with utmost love and affection - He was admitted in a well reputed school - Application for his custody by the father when he was released on bail - Trial Court not examining minor to ascertain his wishes simply because none of the parties asked for such examination by court - Apex Court examined the minor and he unequivocally refused to go and stay with the father - Held the trial court and the High Court failed to consider welfare of minor in right perspective, the fact of pending criminal case against the father and the wishes of the minor - Custody refused to the applicant father.	(Paras 68, 70-72, 74, 83-85)

heading: Custody of child
Application for
Consideration
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Application for - Consideration - Linkings and welfare of child, have the paramount aspect - Held, it is the child's desire to remain with either father or with mother - The age of the child will also play vital role whenever the child or the circumstances so compelled to make alternate arrangement about the custody - The matter naturally will not end by termination of such application either way. A.I.R. 1996 Rajasthan 162 and A.I.R. 1996 Madras 365 - Ref. to.	(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Guardian of minor child
HeadNote.description: Guardian of minor child - In selection of a guardian of a minor, the best interest of the child is the basic consideration, to which even the rights of parents must sometimes yield.	(Para 18)

heading: Guardian
HeadNote.description:
Guardian - His status and duties.

A Guardian stands in a fiduciary relation to his ward and he is not supposed to make any profit out of his office. On being appointed as Guardian of the property of minor, he is to act as a trustee and he cannot be permitted to gain any personal profit availing himself of his position and such action of the Guardian while dealing with the property against the interest of ward would be voidable in the eye of law. 			    [Para 13]

heading: Oral gift of property to guardian in lieu of his services as guardian
HeadNote.description: Oral gift of property to guardian in lieu of his services as guardian - Has no sanctity in eye of law.			(Para 14)

heading: Minor girl
Custody of
HeadNote.description:
Minor girl - Custody of - Application by her father - Not having sufficient income to maintain her and rear up - Already burdened with maintenance of big family - Girl receiving natural love and affection from her maternal grand parents - Father not entitled to her custody.

Where a minor girl aged 5 1/2 years was in custody of her maternal grand father since her mother had re-married, it was agreed in the community meeting that girl's father would pay Rs.60/- per month towards her maintenance, he had also re-married and was required to maintain a family of six members; had defaulted in making payments of maintenance allowance, his application for custody of his minor daughter could not be granted since he has not fulfilled the obligation, has no sufficient income to rear the child properly and look after her welfare. She was getting natural love and affection from maternal grand-parents. And will not be safe to give the minor in the custody of the natural guardian i.e. her father.  [Para 4]

heading: Application under by father for custody of her minor daughter
HeadNote.description: Application under by father for custody of her minor daughter - No pleadings therein that parties are subject to Mohamedan Law - Court not under duty to consider provisions of Mohamedan Law. (Para 5)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description: Scope - Minor girl in custody of her maternal grand parents - Her father agreeing to pay maintenance allowance for her - Cannot be said that the girl left his abode or was removed from custody of his person - S.25 not attracted. (Para 6)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description:
Custody of children - Orders relating to custody are never final but interlocutory in nature - Can be modified according to change in circumstances.

The orders relating to custody of children are by the very nature not final but are interlocutory in nature and subject to modification at any future time upon proof of change of circumstances requiring change of custody but such change in custody must be proved to be in the paramount interest of the child.  [Para 7]

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Claimed by both maternal and paternal grand father - Both parties quite well to do and not having any oblique motive - Both having utmost affection and love for the grandson - Paternal grandfather had changed his Will to bequeath his property to the grandchild - Evidence showing that child was required to stay all alone with servants in maternal grand fathers' house - Order granting custody to paternal grand father confirmed and made final for three years - Visiting rights of maternal grand father and mother secured by appropriate directions. (Para 9)

heading: Property of minor
Right of mother
HeadNote.description: Muslim Law, Arts.361, 364 - Property of minor - Right of mother - Mother has no right, whatsoever, to alienate the property of the minor - There is no representation of estate in such a case - Mother cannot represent the share of her minor son - She cannot bind him by acts of her alienation - There is no question of existence of legal necessity in such case of alienation likewise a concept available under the Hindu Law.	(Para 12)

heading: Discretionary jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Discretionary jurisdiction - Court must satisfy itself before granting relief prayed in a petition. (Para 25)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Court issuing direction at the instance of husband that if custody is resisted by wife, husband could take police help - Held, orders from Court in execution would be more appropriate - Police intervention where parties belong to educated respectable families should be avoided.	(Para 8)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description:
Custody of children - Husband's right to custody of children - Controlling consideration governing custody of children is welfare of children and not rights of parents - Custody of daughter age over 13 years and of elder and younger son - Custody of elder son allowed to continue with father but custody of daughter and youngest son given to the mother who was well placed to look after them.

The dominant consideration in making orders under S.25 is the welfare of the minor children and in considering this question due regard has of course to be paid to the right of the father to be the guardian and also to all other relevant factors having a bearing on the minor's welfare. There is a presumption that a minor's parents would do their very best to promote their children's welfare and, if necessary, would not grudge any sacrifice of their own personal interest and pleasure. This presumption arises because of the natural, selfless affection normally expected from the parents for their children. From this point of view, in case of conflict or dispute between the mother and the father about the custody of their children, the approach has to be somewhat different from that adopted by the Letters Patent Bench of the High Court in this case. There is no dichotomy between the fitness of the father to be entrusted with the custody of his minor children and considerations of their welfare. The father's fitness has to be considered, determined and weighed predominantly in terms of the welfare of his minor children in the context of all the relevant circumstances. If the custody of the father cannot promote their welfare equally or better than the custody of the mother, then, he cannot claim indefeasible right to their custody under S. 25 merely because there is no defect in his personal character and he has attachment for his children -which every normal parent has. No doubt, the father has been presumed by the statute generally to be better fitted to look after the children - being normally the earning member and head of the family but the Court has in each case to see primarily to the welfare of' the children in determining the question of their custody, in the background of all the relevant facts having bearing on their health, maintenance and education. The family is normal1y the heart of our society and for a balanced and healthy growth of children it is highly desirable that they get their due share of affection and care from both the parents in their normal parental home. Where, however family dissolution due to some unavoidable circumstances becomes necessary the Court has to come to a judicial decision on the question of the welfare of the children on a full consideration of all the relevant circumstances.	  [Para 14]

heading: Custody
Preference of Minor
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Custody - Preference of Minor - Scope - Minor suffering from AIDS - Both parents of Minor died of AIDS - Respondent in a better position to provide medical help to Minor - Admission of Minor that he behaves as directed by maternal grandparents - Willingness of Minor, therefore, cannot be significant factor in deciding issue of custody - Custody given to grandmother was held proper - No interference warranted.

In the instant case, the issue relates to custody of minor who is suffering from aids and both his parents had already died from aids; it was held that the paramount consideration for the present is as to who would be in a better position and fit person to provide proper medical facilities to the minor child.  For, the innocent life cannot be allowed to suffer due to tussle between relatives of his parents.  The considerations like his emotional attachment, better educational facility and upbringing are subsidiary as compared to the priority of making available proper medical facilities to him.  The willingness of the minor is one of the factor to be considered under Section 17(3) of the Guardian and Wards Act.  However, it is not the sole criteria.  The welfare of the minor is the only criteria while determining the question of custody.  The minors are gullible and are likely to express the thoughts and wishes of those who are in dominating position to tutor them.  The influence of tutoring process is likely to impair the testimony of the minor.  In the present case, minor Sudarshan candidly admits that he behaves as is directed by the maternal grandparents.  The willingness of the minor cannot, therefore, be the significant factor in such a situation.  Moreover the minor - Sudarshan is not a grown up child and is not yet capable to form an intelligent opinion as to the suitability of his guardian.  There appears nothing illegal in the impugned order only because wishes of the minor are not considered.  It is more probable that wishes of the appellants have been assiduously instilled into the minor.

In view of better treatment avenue available to minor with respondent, no interference in custody was warranted.						 [Para 9,15,16,20]

heading: 'Custody' & 'Guardianship'
HeadNote.description:
'Custody' & 'Guardianship' - Meaning and distinction between - Explained.

There is subtle distinction between expression "Custody" and "Guardianship".  The concept of custody is related to physical control over a person or property.  The concept of guardianship is akin to trusteeship.  A guardian is trustee in relation to the person of whom he is so appointed.  The position of guardian is more onerous than of mere custodian.  The custody may be for short duration and for specific purpose.  The custody of the minor, in the present case, may be handed over to the respondent with an object to ensure proper medical care and treatment.   [Para 19,20]

heading: Inter-country adoption
HeadNote.description: Inter-country adoption - Family Court failing to decide petition for a long time - Hence, writ petition filed for directions to expedite petition - Family Court rejecting petition on ground that recognition to NGO for granting inter-country adoption was suspended on 7-7-2006 though CARA had given its NOC for adoption on 13-7-2006 - Held, Family Court went wrong in rejecting petition because only consideration before it was welfare of child and not any extraneous consideration for which NGO may have come into disrepute.	(Para 8)

heading: Adoption petitions
HeadNote.description: Adoption petitions - Courts dealing with petitions should only consider financial and cultural background of the adoptive parents and the NOC of CARA when disposing off Petitions - Petitions should be taken up on the date of hearing itself and give adoptive child a home unless parents are found unfit for the role of being adoptive parents.			(Paras 7, 13)

heading: Principles of Mohammedan Law
HeadNote.description:
Principles of Mohammedan Law - Custody of minor child - Welfare of the child is the most significant criteria to be applied while considering the question of custody - Fitness of person seeking custody is also one of the important aspects - Personal law of the parties, and requirements of Guardians and Wards Act must be blended appropriately so as to ensure welfare of the minor while appointing a guardian.

There cannot be duality of opinion that welfare of the child is the most significant criteria to be applied while considering the question of custody.  The fitness of person seeking custody is also one of the important aspects.  In this case, the mother is partly fit in the sense that she has not remarried and has natural love and affection for the children.  So also, the father is partly fit in the sense that he too has not remarried and has financial capacity to provide better education to the children.  It appears from the affidavit of the father and photographs produced by him that Shahistabegum is residing in a hutment locality at small place i.e. Faizpur.  The appellant-Sayyad Sabdarali is gainfully self employed person.  He has shown readiness to provide better educational facility to the children.

In the present case it is true that Sayyad Sabdarali the father of the child resides in the house of his relative and his sister alongwith her children is also residing in the same house.  Still, however, this fact would not disentitle him from claiming custody of his son.  On the other hand, it can be said that Sayyad Danish would be in the company of other children and will not be isolated.

The Personal Law of the parties, and requirements of the Guardians and Wards Act must be blended appropriately so as to ensure welfare of the minor while appointing a guardian.  1989 Mh.L.J. 373 and 1996(1) Bom.C.R. 553 - Ref. to.   [Para 9,10,13]

heading: Custody of minor children
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor children - Welfare of minor child is the most important - Concept of welfare of the minor child cannot be pigeonholed to mere wish expressed by such a minor.

The concept of welfare of the minor cannot be pigeonholed to mere wish expressed by such a minor.  The Court is not supposed to act as executor of the wish expressed by the minor.  For, basically, the minor is incapable of taking his own decisions.  There is always probability that he/she would be tutored by the parents or relatives with whom the custody is at the time of interview.  The welfare of minor is multifaceted concept.  It cannot be cribbed in a straight jacket formula.   [Para 15]

heading: Appointment of a guardian
HeadNote.description: Appointment of a guardian - Welfare of child is paramount consideration - Word "welfare" is to be construed literally and taken in its widest sense - Guardianship cannot be decided on the basis of rights of the parties.			(Paras 10, 13, 14)

heading: Appointment of a guardian
HeadNote.description: Appointment of a guardian - After giving birth to a son mother died - Son living with maternal grand-father since then - Father remarrying and having a son through second marriage - He was residing in a village and was working as Operator with MSEB at a distance of 90 kms. away - Child living with maternal grand-father at a Taluka Centre and having good education - Respondent father had not attempted to meet child when he was in the custody of grand-father - In view of this Apex Court allowed custody of eight year old child with maternal grand-father till child attains age of 12 when matter will be reconsidered - Direction about visitation rights issued.			(Paras 5, 16)

heading: Transfer petition
HeadNote.description: Transfer petition - Suit filed under S.9 of Hindu marriage Act for restitution of conjugal right by husband against petitioner wife at Jaipur - Petitioner shifted to 'Delhi' to establish herself professionally and to maintain herself and her minor daughter - Transfer of cases to Delhi though will cause some inconvenience to husband, but it would be easier for husband to attend proceeding in Delhi than for wife - Hence, transfer petition allowed.  (Paras 14, 17)

heading: Place of Visitation
Shifting of
HeadNote.description: Place of Visitation - Shifting of - Respondent husband and petitioner wife with her minor daughter living separately - In view of transfer of cases to 'Delhi' where wife was residing - Respondent's plea that he should be allowed to meet petitioner and minor child at Jaipur, not tenable - Order of High Court rejecting prayer of petitioner to move place of visitation from Jaipur to Delhi - Liable to be set aside. (Paras 13, 16)

heading: Temporary custody
HeadNote.description: Temporary custody - Welfare of children is the sole and single yardstick for evaluating merits of parties contesting for custody - Question of guardianship is independent of and distinct from that of custody. (1973)3 SCR 918, AIR 1932 All 215 - Rel. on.	(Paras 32, 35)

heading: Temporary custody
HeadNote.description: Temporary custody - Stability and consistency in the affairs and routines of children - Is an important consideration to be kept in mind.		(Para 38)

heading: Interim custody
Balance of convenience
Guardianship application pending
HeadNote.description: Interim custody - Balance of convenience - Welfare of children is focal point - Guardianship application pending - Father of children had remarried after death of mother of two children - Children, daughter about 13 years and son aged about 5 years - Children staying with their maternal grandfather aged 72 years, maternal aunt and two uncles - Daughter had expressed her preference for living with maternal grandfather and the younger son instinctively approached his father in the Court premises - Held weight must be given to preference shown by daughter and both of them would continue to live with grandfather with visitation rights to appellant pending decision on guardianship application.	(Paras 45, 50)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Consideration of the welfare of the minor should be the paramount factor and cannot be subordinated to the personal law of the minor. AIR 1961 J & K 5 - Approved of.			(Para 46)

heading: Custody of child
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Petition for - Girl child living with her father since age of 21 months when her parents separated - She is now 8 yrs. old and wants to continue with her father - But view to the other side reveals that mother was forcefully thrown out of house without allowing her to take the child - She has been fighting since then for custody of child - At one stage of litigation, she was allowed custody, however, same could not be fructified due to a stay order - Since child had no opportunity to live with her mother, she is not in a position to evaluate whether her welfare lies with mother or father - Continuous company with mother, for some time, is absolutely essential - Custody for one year given to mother - Final decision to be made thereafter. 	(Paras 14, 17, 20, 21)

heading: Modification of order
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Interim custody of child - Modification of order - Exercise of parens patrias jurisdiction - Permissibility - Interim custody granted to petitioner grand father and respondent mother was allowed to take child during vacations - Petition against said order filed by petitioner, dismissed by High Court - Subsequently when child was given to respondent as per custody order, he was subjected to cruelty and inhuman behavior - Earlier in petition against custody order, Court chose not to interfere with custody order on basis of circumstance prevailing at that time - However, same cannot prevent court to exercise jurisdiction in the best interest of minor - Subsequent events warrant modification to the extent that during vacations also child shall remain with his grand father. 2012 ALL SCR 2917 Rel. on.			(Paras 3, 11, 23, 24, 26)

heading: Custody of Child
HeadNote.description: Custody of Child - Issue as to relevant considerations - Held, desire of the child coupled with ability of a conducive and appropriate environment for proper upbringing together with ability and means of concerned parent to take care of child - Are some relevant factors to be taken into account - In all, welfare of child and not the right of parents, will decide the matter of custody. AIR 1941 Bombay 103, (1973) 1 SCC 840, 2012(6) ALL MR 438 (S.C.) Rel. on.			(Paras 12, 25)

heading: Guardianship
HeadNote.description:
Guardianship - Application by mother to appoint her as sole guardian of her son - Court exercises paren patrae jurisdiction to secure welfare of hapless child of two adults.

A child, as has been ubiquitously articulated in different legal forums, is not a chattel or a ball to be shuttled or shunted from one parent to the other. The Court exercises paren patrae jurisdiction in custody or guardianship wrangles; it steps in to secure the welfare of the hapless child of two adults whose personal differences and animosity has taken precedence over the future of their child. As per Section 7 of the Act, the interest of the minor is the only relevant factor for appointing of a guardian, and the rights of the mother and father are subservient thereto. In this scenario, the interest of the child would be best served by immediately appointing the Appellant as the guardian. Furthermore, it is also pressed to the fore that her own fundamental right to privacy will be violated if she is compelled to disclose the name and particulars of father of her child.

 Avowedly, the mother is best suited to care for her offspring, so aptly and comprehensively conveyed in Hindi by the word 'mamta'. Furthermore, recognizing her maternity would obviate the necessity of determining paternity. In situations such this, where the father has not exhibited any concern for his offspring, giving him legal recognition would be an exercise in futility. In today's society, where women are increasingly choosing to raise their children alone, no purpose would be served in imposing an unwilling and unconcerned father on an otherwise viable family nucleus. A man who has chosen to forsake his duties and responsibilities is not a necessary constituent for the wellbeing of the child.    [Para 1,4,9]

heading: Guardianship order
HeadNote.description:
Guardianship order - Uninvolved parent can approach court to quash, vary or modify its orders if best interest of child so indicate.

Section 11 is purely procedural; no harm or mischief in relaxing its requirements to attain the intendment of the Act. Given that the term "parent" is not defined in the Act, we interpret it, in the case of illegitimate children whose sole caregiver is one of his/her parents, to principally mean that parent alone. Guardianship or custody orders never attain permanence or finality and can be questioned at any time, by any person genuinely concerned for the minor child, if the child's welfare is in peril. The uninvolved parent is therefore not precluded from approaching the Guardian Court to quash, vary or modify its orders if the best interests of the child so indicate. There is thus no mandatory and inflexible procedural requirement of notice to be served to the putative father in connection with a guardianship or custody petition preferred by the natural mother of the child of whom she is the sole caregiver.   [Para 16]

heading: Responsibility of guardian
HeadNote.description: Necessity of obtaining birth certificate for the child - Responsibility of guardian - It is also responsibility of the State to ensure registration of every birth of every citizen without failure. (Para 19)

heading: Interim maintenance
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Interim maintenance - Challenge - On ground that there is no jurisdiction conferred under Guardians and Wards Act to award interim maintenance - Although no express provision either under Act, welfare of minor being paramount consideration, interim maintenance implied in S.12.

Provisions of Section 12(1) of Guardians and Wards Act (1890), will have to be construed in a manner that would protect the person of the minor and if for such purpose grant of interim maintenance is warranted, the Court would be empowered in that regard. The welfare of the minor being the paramount consideration, the power to grant interim maintenance will have to be read in aforesaid provisions. Moreover, during pendency of proceedings when it is brought to the notice of the Court that the welfare of the minor requires to be taken care of by directing one party to pay an amount of interim maintenance, such power can surely be exercised in the facts of the case.  [Para 12]

Merely because by amending the said Act a provision for payment of maintenance is sought to be made, the same does not mean that the Courts had no power prior to such amendment to award interim maintenance. In fact, by the proposed amendment, the power to grant interim maintenance is sought to be specifically granted in place of such implied power that is available with the Court. Considering the object of the said Act and the settled position of law that welfare of the minor is the paramount consideration, the power to grant interim maintenance has to be read in the powers conferred by Section 12(1) of the said Act.  [Para 13]

Under Section 10(1) of the Family Courts Act, 1984, the Family Court is deemed to be a civil Court and provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 are applicable to the proceedings before it. Therefore, in an appropriate case before it, the Family Court in exercise of its inherent powers under Section 151 of the Code can even otherwise direct payment of interim maintenance to the minor child in proceedings under Section 7 of the Guardian and Wards Act.  AIR 1986 Allahabad 314, 2012(6) ALL MR 438 (S.C.) Ref. to.  [Para 14]

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Grant of interim maintenance - Challenge - On ground that interim maintenance had already been awarded in proceeding under DV Act - However, court found that impugned order was made after considering proceedings under DV Act - Considering standard of living of parties, amount of maintenance of Rs.5,000/- so granted is not in excess of requirements - As regards amount of Rs.33,00,000/- paid by petitioner voluntarily as alleged, same being in dispute, cannot be gone into at this stage - No interference. (Para 15)

heading: Visitation rights
HeadNote.description: Visitation rights - Grievance of father that visitation rights are granted on fortnightly basis and not on regular basis - Considering welfare of children, if fortnight access is found fit by court, discretionary order, cannot be interfered with at interlocutory stage. (Para 16)

heading: Consideration
HeadNote.description:
Interim custody of the child - Consideration - Is welfare of the child and not rights of parents. 

The controlling consideration governing interim custody of the child is the welfare of the child and not the rights of their parents. As such, the sole consideration to be weighed by the Court is what would be good for the paramount welfare of the child and nothing else. The Court will also have to examine what prejudice would occasion to such welfare by not changing the custody which is in existence at the time of the filing such application. To consider these aspects, the Court takes into consideration several factors such as the child's immediate environment and surrounding emotional security provided by those who have their custody and what would be conducive for the child to try and grow and become a good human being. Whenever there are conflicting demands of the parents the Court does not look into such claim on legalistic basis but takes the decision considering the welfare of such child. 

2010 ALL SCR 357, 2001(2) ALL MR 237 (S.C.) Rel.on.       [Para 8]

heading: Custody of child
Relevant considerations
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Relevant considerations - Relevant Statutes and legal rights of parents, have to be taken into account - However, issue not to be decided solely by interpreting legal provisions - Court is neither bound by statutes nor by strict rules of evidence or procedure nor by precedents - In selecting proper guardian, paramount consideration should be welfare and well-being of child - Wishes of child, also relevant. 	(Paras 22, 33)

heading: Interim custody
Challenge
Father remarried
HeadNote.description: Interim custody - Order directing father to hand over child to mother and providing police assistance to mother for securing child's custody - Challenge - Girl child aged more than 10 yrs. - Having resided in Canada with her mother for more than 7 yrs. after divorce of her parents - Father remarried - Child still wishes to live with her father in India and does not want to go back to Canada - Child being more than 10 yrs. of age, understands about her welfare - Order of court below disregarding her wishes, not justified - Allegations of parties against each other as to not taking proper care of child, tutoring child, documents and articles pertaining to child's mind and doctor's opinion etc. are all matters to be considered during trial - Not relevant at interim stage - Even as per Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, father is first natural guardian, mother comes after him - Impugned order liable to be set aside - Father entitled to interim custody - Mother can apply for visitation rights during pendency of matter. (2000) 9 SCC 745, 2009(1) ALL MR 925 (S.C.), 1982 ALLMR ONLINE 221 (S.C.), (2003) 10 SCC 760, 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 1686, 2018 ALL SCR (Cri) 1145, 2017 ALL SCR 588 Disting. 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 337, 2008 ALL SCR 2016, 2008(5) ALL MR 948 (S.C.), ILR 2003 KAR 1205, 2018 ALL SCR 2316 Ref.to.			(Paras 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 31, 32, 40, 44)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of child - Enforcement of foreign decree - Removal of minor child by mother from U.K. to India - Child whether to be returned to U.K. in compliance with order of English Court - For deciding said question, welfare of child would be of paramount consideration and not comity of courts.

India is not yet a signatory to the Hague Convention of 1980 on "Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction". As regards the non-convention countries, the law is that the Court in the country to which the child has been removed must consider the question on merits bearing the welfare of the child as of paramount importance and reckon the order of the foreign Court as only a factor to be taken into consideration, unless the Court thinks it fit to exercise summary jurisdiction in the interests of the child and its prompt return is for its welfare. In exercise of summary jurisdiction, the Court must be satisfied and of the opinion that the proceeding instituted before it was in close proximity and filed promptly after the child was removed from his/her native state and brought within its territorial jurisdiction, the child has not gained roots here and further that it will be in the child's welfare to return to his native state because of the difference in language spoken or social customs and contacts to which he/she has been accustomed or such other tangible reasons. In such a case the Court need not resort to an elaborate inquiry into the merits of the paramount welfare of the child but leave that inquiry to the foreign Court by directing return of the child. Be it noted that in exceptional cases the Court can still refuse to issue direction to return the child to the native state and more particularly inspite of a pre-existing order of the foreign Court in that behalf, if it is satisfied that the child's return may expose him to a grave risk of harm.

This means that the Courts in India, within whose jurisdiction the minor has been brought must "ordinarily" consider the question on merits, bearing in mind the welfare of the child as of paramount importance whilst reckoning the pre-existing order of the foreign Court if any as only one of the factors and not get fixated therewith. In either situation - be it a summary inquiry or an elaborate inquiry - the welfare of the child is of paramount consideration. Thus, while examining the issue the Courts in India are free to decline the relief of return of the child brought within its jurisdiction, if it is satisfied that the child is now settled in its new environment or if it would expose the child to physical or psychological harm or otherwise place the child in an intolerable position or if the child is quite mature and objects to its return.

The crucial question to be considered by the Court (in the country to which the child is removed) is to answer the issue according to the child's welfare. That has to be done bearing in mind the totality of facts and circumstances of each case independently. To put it differently, the principle of comity of courts cannot be given primacy or more weightage for deciding the matter of custody or for return of the child to the native state. (1998) 1 SCC 112, 2009 ALL MR (Cri) 3092 (S.C.) Rel. on.  Paras 24, 26)

heading: Appointment of guardian
Object of provision
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of guardian - Object of provision - Welfare of minor is only paramount consideration for deciding proceedings for custody of child and appointment of guardian.

	Section 17 of Guardians and wards Act lays down the salutary principle that the welfare of the minor is the only paramount consideration for deciding the proceedings for custody and appointment of guardian. On plain reading of the provisions of Section 17, it is apparent that the Court is under an obligation to decide the issue of custody and guardianship not on the basis of legal rights but on the basis of the paramount consideration of the welfare of the minor children. In a case where contesting parties to a Petition under the said Act or under any other Enactment place compromise on record dealing with custody and visitation rights in relation to minors, the Court cannot accept compromise mechanically. Before accepting the compromise and permitting parties to act upon compromise, the Court has to apply its mind to the well settled law. What is paramount is what is conducive to the welfare of the children. Therefore it is duty of the Court to consider whether the compromise is for the welfare of the children. 			 [Para 20,22]

heading: Custody of minor children
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor children - Cannot be decided on basis of consensus or consent of parties - Consent of parties and even personal law dealing with issue of custody of children - Cannot and must not supersede paramount considerations. 		(Paras 22, 24)

heading: Custody of child
Consideration
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Consideration - Issue has to be appreciated on universally accepted superiority of natural mother's care and affection - Mother is per se best suited to care for infant during tender age.	(Para 22)

heading: Suit for custody of child
HeadNote.description: Suit for custody of child - Defendant filing application for rejection of plaint - On ground that issue of custody already decided by foreign court wherein decree was passed with consent of both parties - Held, any order passed on consent of parents is not binding upon minor - Court in India will decide the matter keeping in view welfare of child - Consent decree of foreign court can even be changed by directing change in custody - Triable issues involved in instant case - Plaint cannot be rejected. 	(Paras 24, 25, 26)

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child - Factors to be considered - Welfare and interest of child is paramount consideration and not rights of parents under Statute - Court should give due weightage to child's wish also if child is sufficiently mature to express his or her intelligent preferences - Also, aspect of stability and security of child is essential ingredient for full development of child's talent and personality and therefore, need to be considered.	(Paras 12, 15)

heading: Custody of minor children
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor children - Dispute between father and maternal grand-father - Custody of minors are with grand-father since death of their mother - Both minors wish to remain with their grand-father, as within 15 days of death of their mother, father got re-married and also having one son from second marriage - Their feelings of hurt, sufficient to create some apprehension in their mind of not being treated properly by their father and his second wife - By presuming possibility of children being tutored as they were in custody of grand-father, Trial Court directed grand-father to hand over custody of children to father - At that time age of daughter was 12 to 13 years and son was younger to her - Now, daughter is 17 years and son is 15 years old - Both are matured enough to understand and decide whose custody would be in their best interest - Their preference needs to be given due weightage - Moreover, for more than 7 years they have been living with grand father, in whom they are having faith, confidence and also love and affection - Therefore, shifting them to house of father, definitely going to affect their stability, peace of mind and sense of security at this crucial age - Hence, custody of minors given to grand-father with visitation rights to father. 2008(5) ALL MR 948 (S.C.), 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 337 Rel. on. 			(Paras 12, 15, 16, 17, 18, 20, 22)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Paramount consideration is welfare of child and not inter se rights of rival parties - In the process of determining welfare, court shall, in totality of circumstances, consider the character and capacity of proposed guardian and also preferences of child itself. 2010 ALL SCR 357, 2008 ALL SCR 2016 Ref. to. 	(Para 15)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Mother of child expired - Maternal grand-parents on one hand and father of child on other hand contesting for custody - Appellant/grand-parents alleged that child was in their custody since death of their daughter, respondent/father is a drunkard and does not care for child - They also alleged that their daughter died due to cruel treatment by respondent against whom criminal case is also pending - However, none of these allegations proved by any cogent evidence - As per police report, criminal case was falsely lodged - On contrary, there is Social Investigation Report recommending custody of child to father, and an amicable decision (taken by Masjid Committee) giving custody of child to father and visitation rights to appellants - Appellants initially denied this settlement but later on admitted - It was appellants who did not act upon compromise and retained child on false pretext - Even though both parties admitted child to a school, school chosen by father is nearer - Father of child is a driver, he is having enough resources to maintain child - As against him, appellants are advanced in age - Welfare of child lies with her father - Custody granted to him. 			(Paras 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 30)

heading: Appointment of guardian
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Appointment of guardian - Welfare of minor child - Determination of - Application made with consent of biological parents - There cannot be any rigid formula for determining welfare of child to be given in adoption - Welfare to be determined keeping in mind totality of circumstances.	(Para 25)

heading: Appointment of guardians
HeadNote.description: Appointment of guardians - Application made with consent of biological parents - Considering facts it cannot be said that biological parents have without due consideration merely abdicated their duties as parents - Records indicating that they would not be able to take care of said child despite their best intention to do so - Application allowed. (2004)1 SCC 382 - Foll.		(Para 27)

heading: Custody of child
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Family Court gave custody and guardianship of girl child to her mother, till 11 years of age - Father allowed visitation rights - Family Court further directed that for academic session 2019-20, child shall be sent to boarding school of repute - Appeal against - High Court interacted with child on several occasions - Directed the child to be admitted in residential institution at Ooty from academic session 2018-19 - Appeal to Supreme Court - Intention of father was always that child should get best education at a neutral environment, which may help in developing her personality - However mother was right from beginning opposing sending of child in boarding school and finding fault with School at Ooty - Appeals before High Court still pending awaiting final decision - Therefore, Supreme Court declined to interfere - Requested High Court to decide appeals finally - High Court can consider subsequent material brought on record such as progress report of child from school at Ooty and medical issue regarding her health - It is for High Court to take decision with regard to interaction with child. 	(Paras 15, 22)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description: Custody of child - Interest of child depending on facts and circumstances of each case - Has to be decided on its own merits without adhering to any fixed formula or rule.	(Para 22)

heading: Jurisdiction of court
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of court - Must be decided on basis of averments made in pleadings of parties and requirement of S.9.	(Para 5)

heading: Jurisdiction of court
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of court - Solitary test for determining jurisdiction is "ordinary residence" of minor - Is at best a mixed question of law and fact.

It is evident from a bare reading of S.9 that the solitary test for determining the jurisdiction of the court under Section 9 of the Act is the 'ordinary residence' of the minor. The expression used is "Where the minor ordinarily resides". Now whether the minor is ordinarily residing at a given place is primarily a question of intention which in turn is a question of fact. It may at best be a mixed question of law and fact, but unless the jurisdictional facts are admitted it can never be a pure question of law, capable of being answered without an enquiry into the factual aspects of the controversy. The word 'resides' implies something more than a flying visit to, or casual stay at a particular place. The question whether one is ordinarily residing at a given place depends so much on the intention to make that place ones ordinary abode. [Para 14,18,20]

heading: Guardianship of minor
Jurisdiction of court
HeadNote.description: Guardianship of minor - Jurisdiction of court - There is a significant difference between jurisdictional facts relevant to exercise of powers by a writ court and a court under Guardian & Wards Act on the other.		(Para 40)

heading: Guardianship of minor
Jurisdiction of court
HeadNote.description: Guardianship of minor - Jurisdiction of court - Interest and welfare of minor being paramount, a competent court is duty bound to examine matter independently and cannot dismiss application by relying upon principle of comity of courts - Foreign judgment, if any, can be taken only as an input for final adjudication. 1998(1) SCC 112 - Rel.on.	(Para 42)

heading: Guardianship of minor
Father living abroad
HeadNote.description: Guardianship of minor - Order granting interim custody of minor to appellant mother - Order though interim should not insulate minor from parental touch and influence of father which is necessary for healthy growth of minor and development of his personality - Father living abroad - Trial court directed to issue necessary instructions about telephonic contract, video conferencing and visitation facilities on arrival of father in India.			(Paras 50, 51)

heading: Custody of minor child with mother and her parents
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor child with mother and her parents - Father living in USA - Constant hammering of negative feelings against father - It cannot serve his interests or his growth as a normal child.	(Para 50)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Children are ordinary citizens of U.S. - Application for custody filed in Court in India during a temporary visit - Applicant/mother concealed fact that she had already filed proceedings in US Court for divorce and custody - Court in India has no jurisdiction to decide matter in terms of S.9(1) of Guardians and Wards Act - Plaint liable to be rejected. 1984 ALLMR ONLINE 189 (S.C.), 1986 ALLMR ONLINE 515 (S.C.), 2009 ALL MR (Cri) 3092 (S.C.), 2017 ALL SCR (Cri) 1686, 2015 ALL SCR 1257 Ref.to. 	(Para 31)

heading: Appointment of Guardian
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Guardian - Welfare of child of 11 years - Petitionerfather, a superrich, influential foreign national - Child born in India but having dual citizenship of Kenya and U.K. - Child in various personal interactions by Family Court, High Court and Supreme Court, found to be bright, self-confident and articulated - Had great clarity about his preferences and aspirations - Nationality, relevant aspect to be given due consideration - Educational opportunities which would be available to child is an aspect of great significance - Objection by mother that petitioner was being racist, not established - Allegation of marital infidelity against petitioner, not established - Pending criminal proceedings against petitioner for alleged dam outburst in his family farms, not valid ground to refuse custody of child to him - In view of facts it would be in best interest of child to transfer custody of child to his father i.e. petitioner - However, mother cannot be kept out of further growth, progress and company of her son - Thus, she would be provided with temporary custody of child for 50% of his annual vacations once a year either in New Delhi or Kenya - Custody of child handed over to father subject to obtaining mirror order from Kenyan Court to reflect directions given by Supreme Court. (Majority view - Per Indu Malhotra, J. (for herself and on behalf of Uday Umesh Lalit, J.)

A reading of the plaint of the Guardianship petition shows that respondent father relies upon availability of his parents in Kenya to take care of the child and, on the other hand, stress on the physical condition of appellant’s mother to look after the child. I find that the entire basis to seek appointment as guardian of the child is the availability of his parents in Kenya and the physical condition of appellant’s mother. The entire basis is incorrect as in the presence of parents of the child, the grandparents are not the determining factor to appoint a guardian. The question of where does the welfare of the child lie thus narrows down to the mother who has stopped practicing law to nurture child as against the father who travels quite substantially every month. In the absence of the father, the child will be in the custody of nannies, maids and servants. The grandparents would not be able to take care of the growing needs of a young child. All things being equal, the presence of grandparents can tilt in balance but where a mother who is available 24/7 for guiding, caring and nurturing a growing child as against a father who needs to travel outside his normal place of stay frequently, I find that the mother is more suitable in whose hands the welfare of the child is secured. (Para 76)

The question required to be examined is whether this Court should permit the child to be out of its supervisory jurisdiction so as to be a mute spectator to the possibility of defiance of the order of this Court. I am of the opinion that welfare of the Child would be to stay in India with his mother who has brought up the child for last 11 years. The Child is intelligent but not mature enough to take decisions by himself. Even, the law recognizes that the child of less than 18 years is incapable of representing himself. Therefore, any opinion of the child is not determinative of the final custody of the child but this Court as parens patriae is duty bound to assess the entire situation to return a finding whether the welfare of the child will be with the mother with visitation rights to the father or custody with the father with visitation rights to the mother. If the child is moved to Kenya, there is no way that this Court can enforce the orders to get the child back to India, even if it so desires. (Para 124)

heading: Procedure
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), S.151, O.1 R.10, O.23 R.1A - Declaration of guardianship and grant of custody of child - Procedure - Family Court does not have plenary power to do away with mandatory procedural requirements - Application by appellant-father for guardianship and custody of minor child - He also filed applications for amendment of plaint - Application by his counsel seeking discharge in case, allowed without issuing notice to appellant - Assumption by Family Court about factum of abandonment of proceedings, not proper - Respondent-wife filed application for transposition as petitioner in said proceedings and declaring her as sole guardian and grant custody of child - Respondent in fact had not filed written statement in petition - Order passed by Family Court declaring mother as sole, exclusive and absolute guardian and granting custody of child to wife and issuing notice and serving applications filed by her on appellants - Amounts to substantial non-compliance of principles of natural justice - Liable to be set aside.

Both the enactments (Family Courts Act 1984 and the Guardian and Wards Act 1890), provide for procedure in the form of disclosures, declarations and assertions and its refutations by the other party opposing the claim, whereafter the matter proceeds for recording of evidence followed by the declaration or order passed by the Court. Intrinsic in all these steps is to guarantee fair opportunity to all concerned. (Para 31)

Family Court is expected to follow procedure known to law, which means insist for a formal pleading to be filed by both sides, then frame issues for determination, record evidence of the parties to prove the facts asserted by the concerned party and only thereafter, to enter upon determination and render decision thereon by recording reasons for such decision. For doing this, the Family Court is expected to give notice to the respective parties and provide them sufficient time and opportunity to present their claim in the form of pleadings and evidence before determination of the dispute. Family Court, in the present case, exceeded its jurisdiction by hastening the entire proceedings. Indubitably, the Family Court is obliged to inquire into the matter as per the procedure prescribed by law. It does not have plenary powers to do away with the mandatory procedural requirements in particular, which guarantee fairness and transparency in the process to be followed and for adjudication of claims of both sides. The nature of inquiry before the Family Court is, indeed, adjudicatory. It is obliged to resolve the rival claims of the parties and while doing so, it must adhere to the norms prescribed by the statue in that regard and also the foundational principle of fairness of procedure and natural justice. (Paras 27, 29)

In the instant Case the appellant, father had filed the petition by invoking provisions of Section 7 of the 1890 Act read with Section 7(g) of the 1984 Act. Admittedly, no written statement was ever filed by the respondent to oppose the said petition. On the other hand, the appellant took out two applications for amendment of the pleadings under O.6 R.17 CPC. No reply was filed by the respondent even to these applications, despite Court directing her to do so vide order dated 4.10.2018. There is nothing on record to indicate that the Family Court decided these two applications for amendment of pleadings taken out by the appellant. Although the main objection alongwith two applications for amendment filed by the appellant remained pending from February, 2018, the respondent never filed response to the main petition or the amendment applications and instead took out application under Section 151 of the CPC for being appointed the sole and absolute guardian and custodian of the minor child, on 13.9.2019. This application was posted for hearing on 13.9.2019, on which date the Court issued notice to the appellant and his counsel. As per that order, the matter was again notified on 16.9.2019 when the counsel appearing for the appellant requested the Court to discharge him from the case, which request was acceded to by the Court. As a matter of fact, before discharging the counsel, the Family Court should have ensured that notice was given to the appellant about the request made by his counsel including to make alternative arrangements, if he so desired. Admittedly, no such notice was issued by the Family Court. Father dasti notice sent to the appellant was still awaited. The Family Court instead set down the main matter on 19.9.2019 at 2.30 p.m. In terms of order dated 16.9.2019, the Family Court additionally cancelled the already scheduled returnable date of 30.10.2019, unilaterally. There is nothing on record to show that the respondent had made such a request. Further before 19.9.2019, the respondent took out another application under O.I R.10 read with O.23 R.1A of the CPC for being transposed as petitioner in the guardianship petition and to transpose appellant as respondent therein, for the reasons stated in the application dated 18.9.2019. Admittedly, even copy of this application was not served on the appellant nor a formal notice came to be issued by the Family Court on this application, when it was taken up for hearing on 19.9.2019. Despite this the Family Court proceeded on assumption that the appellant abandoned the proceedings, disposed of the transposition application and declared the mother, respondent as sole, exclusive and absolute guardian and granted custody of minor child.

Held, the orders passed by the Family Court without notice to the appellant and without waiting for service of notice already issued on the former application. amounts to substantial non-compliance of the prescribed mandatory procedure and infraction of principles of natural justice, not a technical irregularity to be overlooked. The impugned judgment and orders of the Family Court came to be passed by the Family Court in a tearing hurry, may be because of the insistence of the respondent and her counsel to do so in light of the observations made by the High Court in habeas corpus and contempt matters against the appellant. The impugned judgment does make reference to those orders. Therefore the ex parte impugned judgment and orders dated 21.9.2019 passed by the Family Court on transposition application, as well as, on the application for declaration that the respondent mother is the sole, exclusive and absolute guardian and custodian of the minor child, liable to be set aside being illegal. (Paras 37, 40)

heading: Custody of minor daughter
HeadNote.description: Custody of minor daughter - Petition by father, the natural guardian, would not be maintainable.	(Para 11)

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of child - Relevancy of criminal antecedent of proposed guardian - Unless there are reliable materials, mere registration of crime cannot be a ground to decline custody.

	Criminal complaint was lodged against respondent/father in respect of death of child's mother. The crime was registered under Sections 498A, 304B, 302, 201 and Section 149 of IPC. Said complaint of dowry death was lodged by appellant/parents of deceased, with a delay of 6 months. However, as per initial police report, registration of said case was false. Though at instance of appellants, re-investigation into said case is directed, that cannot be a ground to decline custody of child to her father whose claim for custody is otherwise legitimate and justified. Serious allegations of offences under POCSO Act also made after the commencement of custody disputes. No medical record produced on record showing that any sexual offence was committed by respondent on his own daughter. In said case also, no progress is made by police. Neither statement of child was recorded by police nor respondent was arrested, indicating that it was also a false case.

	The Family Court, before which such registration of crime is proved must necessarily apply its mind and endeavor to find out the true circumstances which activised the registration rather than being allured by the mere fact of registration. Unless a very cautious approach is adopted by the Family Court to ensure that information on which crime was registered is not frivolous and vexatious, many a innocent parent fighting for custody of his own ward would be victim of false implication of crimes under the POCSO Act. There is a growing tendency in the recent years to foist false crimes against the biological father alleging sexual abuse of own child misusing the provisions of the POCSO Act when serious fight for custody of ward is pending resolution before the Family Courts. The Family Courts to whose notice registration of crime under the POCSO Act is brought owe an onerous responsibility to ensure that the registration of crime against the parent is not a ruse for defeating his legitimate claim for custody of the ward. The Family Courts ought to examine the outcome of investigation of the crime placed before the court and also take into consideration all relevant facts and circumstances which would help the Judge form a prima facie opinion as to whether the allegation of sexual abuse of the ward is baseless or not. Each case requires to be approached and evaluated on its own facts. It does not mean to say that Family Courts should disregard the materials collected by the investigating agency in the crime and hold a total independent enquiry in order to get at the truth or veracity of the allegation. Unless there are reliable materials capable enough to convince the allegation of sexual abuse to be well founded, mere registration of crime shall not be reckoned as a ground for rejecting the claim of the parent for custody of the child. 2008 ALL SCR 2016, 2010(1) ALL MR (JOURNAL) 49 Disting. 	 [Para 24,28]

heading: Muslim Law, Art.364
HeadNote.description:
Muslim Law, Art.364 - Principles of Mohammedan Law - Mother, brother or uncle, etc. - Cannot act as legal guardian of a minor - Mother may be a de facto guardian but would never be regarded as a de jure guardian in respect of property of the minor.

The mother, brother or uncle, etc. cannot act as legal guardian of a minor. The mother may be a de facto guardian but would never be regarded as a de jure guardian in respect of property of the minor. The power of a guardian appointed by a Court to dispose of movable property is limited to the extent of movable properties. That too, it shall be so disposed of carefully as a prudent man deal with it if it were his own. This legal position is quite clear in view of section 27 of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890. Article 364 of the Mohammedan Law (by Mulla), (19th Edition by M. Hidayatullah and Arshad Hidayatullah) would make it manifest that a de facto guardian under Article 361 has no power to transfer any right or interest in the immovable property of the minor. Such a transfer would not be merely voidable, but would be void. A mother is only a de facto guardian and a bare custodian of property of minor son. She does not possess power to sell, mortgage, or otherwise deal with immovable property belonging to the minor. She has no larger powers to deal with her minor child's property than a stranger or non-relative who happens to have charge of the minor for time being.						 [Para 11]

heading: Letters Patent (Bombay) Cl.17
HeadNote.description:
Letters Patent (Bombay) Cl.17 - Juvenile Justice Act (1986) S.7(3), 15(2) - Application under Cl.17 in respect of neglected juvenile - Whether Court can reduce the term to which custody was given by the Board under Juvenile Justice Act.

Considering the power that has been conferred on High Court by clause 17 of the Letters Patent read with Section 3 of the Guardians and Wards Act also Section 7(3) of the Juvenile Act when such matter comes to High Court, High Court can exercise all the powers conferred on the Board or Juvenile Court. Such a power would include the power which the Board had to reduce the term by virtue of the second proviso to sub-section (2) of Section 15 of the Juvenile Act. In that light of the matter in respect of a neglected juvenile where an order has been passed by the Board, High Court apart from appointing a Guardian can pass orders under sub-section (2) of Section 26 of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890. In the light of the matter High Court has jurisdiction to entertain and dispose of these petitions in respect of a neglected juvenile in respect of whom temporary guardianship was granted under the Juvenile Justice Act.  [Para 6]

The effect of an order passed by the Board or the Court under the Juvenile Justice Act is for a particular term. Normally it is only thereafter that the Courts under the Guardians and Wards Act and/or this Court under clause 17 of the Letters patent exercise the power in respect of such neglected juvenile. In these circumstances a duty is cast on the Board or Courts, who pass orders in respect of neglected or delinquent juvenile to take all possible precautions as set out by various judgments of this Court and of the Apex Court to see that those directions are strictly complied with.  [Para 7]

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Welfare of child is a paramount consideration - Daughters aged 17 and 11 years respectively were living with their father and are in his custody - On detailed interaction, both of them were firm that they want to continue to live with their father and did not want to go with their mother - On facts and circumstances, custody with father need not be disturbed - However, ends of Justice would be met by providing visitation rights to mother. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Alienation of minor's property by guardian
HeadNote.description:
Alienation of minor's property by guardian - Previous permission of court - Restriction does not apply to undivided share of minor.

Hindu Law - Undivided Share of minor - Alienation.

Section 8 of the Act of 1956. Prevents natural guardian of Hindu minor to transfer by sale, gift, exchange or otherwise any part of immovable property of the minor without previous permission of the Court. This restriction on the natural guardian in relation to the property  of the minor applies only to the separate or absolute property of the minor. It does not include the minor's undivided share in the joint family property, as, under Section 6, there cannot be a natural guardian in respect of such property which is specifically excluded.  [Para 8]

Under  the Hindu Law, the manager or karta of the family of the minor can alienate minor's undivided interest in the joint family property without the permission of the Court, provided  alienation is for legal necessity or for the benefit of the minor and this right is left untouched by the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956.  [Para 11]

Consequently, rejection of application filed by the guardian under S.8, for permission is legal and  valid.  [Para 12]

heading: Visiting rights
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Visiting rights - Single Judge giving custody of child to father and visiting rights to mother - Appeal - Division Bench depriving mother of her visiting rights though respondent had not objected - Held such further adverse order was not justified, visiting right restored and order further modified to entitle her to custody on Saturdays, Christmas and summer vacation.(Para 3)

heading: Sale of land standing in the name of minor
HeadNote.description: Sale of land standing in the name of minor - Custody of minor with maternal uncle - Maternal uncle had applied for declaring him as natural guardian and the same was pending - Hence, his application for sale of land would be premature, moreover, land was also grossly undervalued - Order permitting sale of land set aside and matter restored to its original file. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Considerations involved
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor child - Considerations involved - Paramount consideration is "welfare of the child" and not the rights of parents.

The principles in relation to the custody of a minor child are well settled. In determining the question as to who should be given custody of a minor child, the paramount consideration is the 'welfare of the child' and not rights of the parents under a statute for the time being in force. Merely because there is no defect in fathers' personal care and his attachment for his children-which every normal parent has, he would not be granted custody. Simply because the father loves his children and is not shown to be otherwise undesirable does not necessarily lead to the conclusion that the welfare of the children would be better promoted by granting their custody to him. Children are not mere chattels nor are they toys for their parents. Absolute right of parents over the destinies and the lives of their children, in the modern changed social conditions must yield to the considerations of their welfare as human beings so that they may grow up in a normal balanced manner to be useful members of the society and the guardian court in case of a dispute between the mother and the father, is expected to strike a just and proper balance between the requirements of welfare of the minor children and the rights of their respective parents over them. When the court is confronted with conflicting demands made by the parents, each time it has to justify the demands. The Court has not only to look at the issue on legalistic basis, in such matters human angles are relevant for deciding those issues. The court then does not give emphasis on what the parties say, it has to exercise a jurisdiction which is aimed at the welfare of the minor.  					 [Para 35,40,42]

The word 'welfare' used in Section 13 of the Act has to be construed literally and must be taken in its widest sense. The moral and ethical welfare of the child must also weigh with the Court as well as its physical well being. Though the provisions of the special statutes which govern the rights of the parents or guardians may be taken into consideration, there is nothing which can stand in the way of the Court exercising its parens patriae jurisdiction arising in such cases. The trump card in appellants' argument is that the child is living since long with the father. The argument is attractive. But the same overlooks a very significant factor. By flouting various orders, leading even to initiation of contempt proceedings, the appellant has managed to keep custody of the child. He can not be a beneficiary of his own wrongs. It is true that taking the child out of the father's custody may cause some problems, but that is bound to be neutralized.   [Para 43,44,45]

heading: Custody of child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of child - Welfare of the child and not the rights of parents is deciding factor - Better financial resources or love for the child may be one of the relevant considerations but not the sole determining factor.

While determining the question as to which parent the care and control of a child should be committed, the first and the paramount consideration is the welfare and interest of the child and not the rights of the parents under a statute.  Indubitably the provisions of law pertaining to the custody of a child contained in either the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 (Section 17) or the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act, 1956 (Section 13) also hold out the welfare of the child as a predominant consideration.  In fact, no statute, on the subject, can ignore, eschew or obliterate the vital factor of the welfare of the minor.  The question of welfare of the minor child has again to be considered in the background of the relevant facts and circumstances.  Each case has to be decided on its own facts and other decided cases can hardly serve as binding precedents insofar as the factual aspects of the case are concerned.  It is, no doubt, true that father is presumed by the statutes to be better suited to look after the welfare of the child, being normally the working member and head of the family, yet in each case the Court has to see primarily to the welfare of the child in determining the question of his or her custody.  Better financial resources of either of the parents or their love for the child may be one of the relevant considerations but cannot be the sole determining factor for the custody of the child.  It is here that a heavy duty is cast on the Court to exercise its judicial discretion judiciously in the background of all the relevant facts and circumstances, bearing in mind the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration.						 [Para 14]

heading: Custody of male child
HeadNote.description: Custody of male child - Mother leaving matrimonial home when child was less than three years - Child since then living with father at Allahabad - Studying in good school and having a group of friends there - Mother working as a teacher at Panipat and living all alone - Child when interviewed by Court clearly showed his reluctance to go with the mother - Uprooting him from Allahabad likely to impede his schooling and may also cause emotional strain and depression in him - Held order of High Court giving exclusive custody to father with visitation rights to mother deserved to be maintained.	(Para 17)

heading: Custody of minor child
HeadNote.description:
Custody of minor child - Factors to be considered - Controlling consideration governing the custody of the minor is the welfare and well-being of the child concerned and not the right of their parents - Discretion vested in Court to be exercised judiciously - Father's fitness cannot override considerations of the welfare of the minor children - Court while dealing with the custody cases, is neither bound by statutes nor by strict rules of evidence or procedure nor by precedents - In selecting a guardian, the Court is expected to given due weight to the child's ordinary comfort, contentment, health, education, intellectual development and favourable surroundings.

(i)	The father in the case of a Hindu minor boy is the natural guardian of the person during his minority and it is permissible for the court to remove him from that position and to appoint either the mother and if the mother is also unfit somebody else as the guardian of the person of the minor boy if in the opinion of the court the father is unfit to be the guardian of the person of the minor. The controlling consideration governing the custody of the minor is the welfare and well-being of the child concerned and not the right of their parents.

(ii)	The discretion vested in the Court is, as is the case with all judicial discretions, to be exercised judiciously in the background of all relevant facts and circumstances. Each case has to be decided on its own facts and other cases can hardly serve as binding precedents.

(iii)	The father's fitness has to be considered, determined and weighed predominantly in terms of the welfare of his minor children in the context of all the relevant circumstances. If the custody of the father cannot promote their welfare equally or better than the custody of the mother, then he cannot claim indefeasible right to their custody merely because there is no defect in his personal character and he has attachment for his children - which every normal parent has. In short, the father's fitness cannot override considerations of the welfare of the minor children.

(iv)	Merely because the father loves his children and is not shown to be otherwise undesirable cannot necessarily lead to the conclusion that the welfare of the children would be better promoted by granting their custody to him as against the wife who may also equally be affectionate towards her children and otherwise equally free from blemish.

(v)	Section 6 of the Hindu Minority and Guardianship Act constitutes the father as the natural guardian of a minor. But that provision cannot supersede paramount consideration as to what is conducive to the welfare of the minor.

(vi)	The father's right to custody of the minor children is neither an absolute nor an indefeasible one. The welfare of the child should be the paramount consideration. The mother can also be given custody of the minors, if their welfare or interest should require it, even if the father is otherwise fit to act as guardian.

(vii)	Female child on the advent of puberty primarily requires mother's care and attention. Absence of female company in the house of the father is relevant factor.
